webTitle: Wouters joins Dutch legion at Ibrox

fields.headline: Wouters joins Dutch legion at Ibrox
fields.trailText: Former Ajax coach Jan Wouters has been appointed to the Rangers' management team in what is expected to be the first of many changes at the club.
fields.body:
The Dutch colony at Ibrox welcomed an additional member with the appointment yesterday of the former Ajax coach Jan Wouters to Rangers' management team.

Prior to the opening of a new training complex to the north of Glasgow and in the wake of a poor season by the club's own high standards, Wouters' appointment swells the number of Dutch staff at Rangers, with the manager Dick Advocaat and his assistant Bert van Lingen allied to the players Arthur Numan, Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Ronald de Boer, Michael Mols, Bert Konterman and Fernando Ricksen.

Rangers have not had a recognised first-team coach since the departure of Tommy Moller Nielsen two years ago.

The arrival of Wouters is expected to be the first of many changes at the club. Speaking to the club's website, the owner David Murray said: "There have to be changes and no one knows that more than me.

"It is fair to say that the last six months have been fairly disastrous, but the important thing is that we know how to put things right and the plans are in place."

Advocaat and Wouters have worked together before, when Advocaat managed the Dutch national side in which Wouters played. Wouters won 70 caps and was part of the team that won the 1988 European Championship. It was his flailing elbow which fractured Paul Gascoigne's cheekbone during a World Cup qualifier at Wembley in 1993.

As well as Ajax, Wouters also played for PSV and Bayern Munich. With Ajax, he won an European Cup Winners' Cup medal. He started his managerial career at Ajax, where an unhappy 15-month spell at the helm ended last March.

Wouter's arrival will fuel speculation that Advocaat has already decided whether to extend his contract beyond the end of next season. Either Wouters is being groomed as a possible successor or he is part of a strategy that extends beyond next season.

Rinus Michels, the former Holland manager, believes the former, drawing on the relationship he had with Advocaat, his assistant until it was time to hand over the reins of the national side in 1992.

"Jan should keep his eyes open and study what Dick Advocaat is doing because you can learn a lot from such a mature man," said Michels.

"If at any given moment [Advocaat] feels Jan has all the qualities to take over then I'm sure he will go down that road with Rangers.

"One of his most important qualities is that, tactically, he was a very mature player. He had a great insight into what the team needed on the pitch during the game."

webTitle: President accuses Ferguson of taking the PSV

fields.headline: President accuses Ferguson of taking the PSV
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson has been criticised by Harry van Raay, the president of PSV Eindhoven, over his handling of the Ruud van Nistelrooy transfer saga.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has been criticised by Harry van Raay, the president of PSV Eindhoven, over his handling of the Ruud van Nistelrooy transfer saga.

Despite banking a British-record £19m for the 24-year-old striker, Van Raay revealed that the club felt "aggrieved" by Manchester United's tactics in concluding the deal.

As well as visiting Van Nistelrooy's home, Ferguson has admitted calling him several times to check on his fitness and, without PSV's consent, inviting him to spend a month at Old Trafford.

"Ferguson played it well, but not fair," said Van Raay. "His proposal that Ruud should rehabilitate at United was scandalous. He also said that Ruud was better off training with them, but if that was the case he should have taken the financial risk. Instead he left it to us and Ruud has cost us £1.5m this season, his wages plus the rehabilitation costs.

"The only thing he has done is pick up the phone a few times. And then he gets praise for being so beneficial to Ruud. The only ones that were beneficial to Ruud were us."

United's fans in Thailand are up in arms over the meagre ticket allocation for a friendly between the national team and the English champions in July. Only 4,000 were made available to the public, the rest being taken up by sponsors at the new 60,000-seat Rajamangala stadium in Bangkok.

One United player not on view will be Ronny Johnsen, who will spend the summer training with his old Norwegian club, Eik Tonsberg, in hopes of being fully fit for the new season after a knee injury.

Birmingham City's leading scorer Dele Adebola will miss the play-offs and most of next season after rupturing ligaments and a tendon in his right knee in colliding with a goalpost in Saturday's 1-0 win over Grimsby. He needs surgery.

The West Ham defender Ian Pearce will not play again this season after suffering concussion and memory loss. He was kept in hospital overnight after clashing heads with Rigobert Song in Saturday's 1-0 defeat at Manchester City.

Ipswich 's Richard Wright will have a hernia operation next week, putting him out of contention for England selection this month.

Newcastle's Peruvian international Nolberto Solano was yesterday fined £1,000 and banned from driving for 18 months for drink-driving.

Walter Smith will begin another season of rebuilding at Everton by trying to sign the Bradford defender David Wetherall and the Wimbledon midfielder Neal Ardley.

fields.headline: Watchdog urges tougher PM code
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Tony Blair should rewrite the ministerial code in the wake of Peter Mandelson's resignation over the Hinduja passport affair, Sir Nigel Wicks, the new chairman of the committee on standards in public life, has recommended to the Cabinet Office.
fields.body:
Tony Blair should rewrite the ministerial code in the wake of Peter Mandelson's resignation over the Hinduja passport affair, Sir Nigel Wicks, the new chairman of the committee on standards in public life, has recommended to the Cabinet Office.

He wants all official meetings between the government, business and lobbyists to be properly recorded.

The move follows the Hammond inquiry findings into the affair which led to the former Northern Ireland secretary quitting his job over allegedly lobbying for passports for two of the Hinduja brothers after they gave £1m to the Millennium Dome.

Sir Anthony's report revealed a "muddle" at the centre of Whitehall with no proper records kept of all the meetings. Mr Mandelson was cleared of acting corruptly in recommending them for British passports.

The new chairman has asked Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, to recommend the incoming prime minister - almost certain to be Mr Blair - to insist on official records of all meetings as part of a series of stricter rules written into the code. This would make publication of details of meetings open to challenge under the government's new Freedom of Information Act from next year.

At present Mr Blair refuses to disclose the exact date of his meetings with companies - let alone the agenda - even to parliament. He recently refused to disclose when the American supermarket giant, Wal-Mart, which is seeking a huge expansion in Britain, met him in 1999.

Sir Nigel's initiative follows a meeting of the standards committee earlier this week. It suggests that he intends to be fiercely independent of government, despite his previous role as a discreet civil servant.

Sir Nigel also wants a strengthening of rules making it clear that ministers' behaviour and conduct must follow "firm guidance" rather than just advice from the prime minister.

This would make it much clearer when a minister ought to resign his job.

fields.headline: Houllier set to strengthen squad
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier is to meet the Liverpool board to seek finance for the "two or three" big-name players he hopes to sign this summer.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier is to meet the Liverpool board to seek finance for the "two or three" big-name players he hopes to sign this summer as the next step in his four-year blueprint to re-establish Liverpool as a major force both domestically and in Europe.

Even after Tuesday's 2-0 win at Bradford lifted his side into the Premiership's Champions League places, the Anfield manager recognised that Manchester United's £19m outlay on the Holland striker Ruud van Nistelrooy has upped the ante for any club aiming to challenge Old Trafford's reign.

"I need to meet with the board to see what financial backing we can get, but in an ideal world I would say we need two or three new players," the Frenchman said. "United will keep on spending because they will think that to do better in the Champions League they need more players."

Houllier has been linked with moves for the Bayern Munich defender Bixente Lizarazu, West Ham's midfielder Frank Lampard and Blackburn's winger Damien Duff, but stressed yesterday that he was not about to go off scouting.

 Alan Shearer will undergo knee surgery in Colorado today in an attempt to cure a tendinitis condition that has affected him for three seasons. The operation will keep the Newcastle striker out for four months if successful but could signal the end of his career.

webTitle: Friends flotation heads for top slot

fields.headline: Friends flotation heads for top slot
fields.standfirst: Insurance group's market value pencilled in at up to £4.2bn with 1.7m members sharing windfalls
fields.trailText: Mutual insurance group Friends Provident is likely to have a market value of between £3.7bn and £4.2bn when it floats on the stock market on July 9 - big enough to propel it into the FTSE 100 index, it said yesterday.
fields.body:
Mutual insurance group Friends Provident is likely to have a market value of between £3.7bn and £4.2bn when it floats on the stock market on July 9 - big enough to propel it into the FTSE 100 index, it said yesterday.

The demutualisation of the 169-year-old company will release windfalls to 1.7m members, several hundred thousand of whom will receive free shares worth well over £1,000.

Provided the flotation is approved next month, all of the 1.7m members will receive 200 free shares, which according to the company's estimate would be worth up to £540. Some 1.1m of these people will receive an additional allocation of shares based on the size of their policy and how long they have held it for.

Friends Provident refused to give an average windfall figure, saying this would be misleading, but examples it gave suggested that someone who had paid £50 a month into a with-profits pension or endowment policy for 15-20 years might expect to receive shares worth around £4,000-£6,500.

It was a year ago this week that Friends Provident, founded by Quakers in 1832, announced its intention to demutualise. The company, headed by chief executive Keith Satchell, is a leading player in personal pensions and ethical investment and has £38bn of assets under management.

Undeterred by the recent stock market volatility, it has decided to seek a London Stock Exchange listing on July 9. Merrill Lynch, the group's adviser, indicated that, had the shares been trading on April 25, they would have been worth between 225p and 270p.

Friends Provident intends to raise about £1.4bn of new capital through a share offer to institutional investors and others. Members and other customers will be able to buy extra shares on preferential terms.

David Newbigging, the group's chairman, said the planned flotation would provide the company with increased financial flexibility. "This will allow easier access to external capital and improve our financial strength," he said.

The company indicated it might go on the hunt for acquisitions. It said flotation would enable it to raise the additional finance required to "take advantage of future development opportunities, such as the growth in the pensions market and acquisitions".

The demutualisation will require the approval of 75% of those members who vote. Postal voting will be taking place in the coming weeks and members will also be able to vote in person at the extraordinary general meeting on June 6, at which the result will be announced.

Members of mutual insurer Scottish Provident are also in line for windfall payments of at least £500 if more than three quarters of them vote next month on a proposed takeover by Abbey National.

The Scottish Provident board has recommended the takeover after Abbey agreed last year to pay £1.8bn.

The insurer said yesterday it would be sending out voting details over the next few days to its 440,000 members ahead of an extraordinary general meeting set for June 14 in Edinburgh.

Managing director David Woods said the deal would be unaffected by the proposed takeover of Abbey by Lloyds TSB. He said with-profits policyholders would receive additional payments, expected at the end of the year, averaging about £3,400, although some payments could exceed £100,000.

fields.headline: HSBC suffers indigestion
fields.trailText: Commerzbank Securities yesterday sent HSBC spinning after advising clients to reduce their holdings.
fields.body:
Commerzbank Securities yesterday sent HSBC spinning after advising clients to reduce their holdings.

The German broker reckons the issues that caused the 20% slide in HSBC's share price after its February results announcement are still relevant.

Until recently, the market awarded HSBC a premium based on its portfolio of businesses. But what was once a virtue is becoming a liability, according to Commerzbank. It says the bank's apparent failure to integrate CCF, the French investment bank, and Safra Republic, the private client bank, and demonstrate synergies with its longer standing businesses is a concern.

"We do not yet see the operating leverage which the globally diverse Citigroup franchise has achieved, or the drive and focus of Standard Chartered's Asian expansion," it said. HSBC closed down 25p to 877p.

fields.headline: One-click finance check arrives
fields.standfirst:
More internet news
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: A new service enabling people to access all their online financial information in one place has gone live in Britain for the first time.
fields.body:
A new service enabling people to access all their online financial information in one place has gone live in Britain for the first time.

The "accountunity" service was introduced this week and is the result of a partnership between Silkmoth, a Manchester-based software company, and an Australian technology firm. It pulls together information about all the different accounts an individual runs online and presents it on a single web page.

This one-click access to a person's entire online account information has been dubbed "aggregation". More than a million people in the United States are believed to be using such services to view and monitor their current accounts, investments, mortgages or credit cards, plus see emails and any bills they pay over the internet.

Alex Grinberg, chief executive of the Australian account aggregation company eWise, said the free service gave users access to a growing list of more than 25 online accounts including those offered by banks, such as HSBC and Egg, stockbrokers, loyalty programmes such as Air Miles and phone companies such as BT.

Some of the US services have caused controversy because of the requirement that people disclose to the aggregator company their user names and passwords for all the accounts they wish to add to their personal page. But Mr Grinberg said that, with accountunity, customers' private details were stored in encrypted form on their own PCs, and no third party could see or gain access to this information.

To start taking advantage of the service, users download an application from the accountunity website www.accountunity.com This effectively enables the PC to enter the various account websites on an individual's behalf, call up the latest information and transmit it back to the page.

EWise is already running an aggregation service in Australia, claiming to provide "easy and secure access" to more than 80 online accounts including banks, credit cards, phone companies, email and share trading.

Accountunity is likely to face competition from banks such as Barclays and others thought to be planning British services.

fields.headline: CBSO/Oramo
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Five years have passed since the first performance of Anthony Payne's completion of the sketches for Elgar's Third Symphony, and it is still enormously impressive. It is also among the most successful new British works of the 1990s.

The received idea that Elgar's sketches for the Third Symphony are weak and repetitive has withered in the face of the evidence. The original material is never less than attractive; at best it is vintage Elgar. As for Payne's completion, its main strength is that it is obviously the work of a composer, not a scholarly restorer. Although Elgar's musical seeds have been transplanted to a different kind of soil, what they have grown into there is so noble and stirring that the question of who is responsible for what hardly seems to matter. The creaky structure of the finale may be the result of Payne being too faithful to Elgar's written instructions, but the slow movement could come to be seen as one of the great tragic statements of 20th-century English music. That was certainly the impression after the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's performance.

Conductor Sakari Oramo took a new approach to the final climax, with its grinding, repetitive march-rhythms, slowing down considerably before starting the long crescendo. It was gripping. Payne's ending (Elgar left no clues as to how he saw the end) made more sense than in any other account I've heard - the true emotional and logical conclusion of this wide-ranging work. Oramo's reading as a whole was strikingly purposeful, but there was affection too. Telling details were allowed time to expand, and the enigmatic second movement - called by Elgar "In place of Scherzo" - was enriched by the elegant dance-like character Oramo brought to so many of its leading themes.

In the first half of the concert, Oramo's account of Brahms's Third Symphony was full of good ideas, but it sounded as though it needed one more rehearsal for them all to become musical flesh. By Saturday's concert, when the programme is repeated, it may have come to full life.

 Further performance on Saturday. Box office: 0121-780 3333.

Telling details were allowed time to expand, and the enigmatic second movement - called by Elgar "In place of Scherzo" - was enriched by the elegant dance-like character Oramo brought to so many of its leading themes. In the first half of the concert, Oramo's account of Brahms's Third Symphony was full of good ideas, but it sounded as though it needed one more rehearsal for them all to become musical flesh. By Saturday's concert, when the programme is repeated, it may have come to full life.  Further performance on Saturday. Box office: 0121-780 3333.

webTitle: Banks on too rich a diet

fields.headline: Banks on too rich a diet
fields.trailText: Too many banks are chasing the wealth of some 4.5m British people who have at least £50,000 to invest, a survey concluded yesterday.
fields.body:
Too many banks are chasing the wealth of some 4.5m British people who have at least £50,000 to invest, a survey concluded yesterday.

The dash to attract the "mass affluent" is accelerating at a time when the economic backdrop is faltering, said Ian Woodhouse of PricewaterhouseCoopers, which conducted the survey.

Private or premier services, aimed at the more affluent customer, have become increasingly popular with banks as the wealthy customer base they are aimed at continues to grow. High street banks have also introduced "value added" accounts, which charge a monthly or annual fee to customers for extra services.

The PricewaterhouseCoopers survey showed that margins are increasingly coming under pressure in the private banking/wealth management industry, with most respondents saying they are planning to focus strategies on product innovation rather than cost leadership.

This means that products and services will be more personalised with the largest growth expected in complex products such as hedge funds, family office services and sophisticated life-cycle and wealth planning.

With competition in the sector intense and with a severe shortage of experienced staff, it is likely that more mergers and acquisitions will take place. Bruce Weatherill, partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers says this is expected because, for the first time in the survey's history, the private banking/wealth management sector may be too optimistic about its growth in the short-term.

fields.headline: Christopher Hampton's Hollywood horrors
fields.standfirst:
Donmar Warehouse, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Donmar Warehouse, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Christopher Hampton's eminently revivable play is a latterday Sunset Boulevard. But instead of a drifting hack meeting a marooned legend we see the Hungarian dramatist Odon von Horvath fictively and wittily projected into a post-1938 Hollywood packed with European emigres.

The real Horvath was killed in a freak accident on a Paris boulevard. But here he goes to Hollywood and becomes the archetypal Hampton hero: a detached, ironic observer encountering the ideological certainties of Bertolt Brecht and wanly contrasting the impoverished neglect of Heinrich Mann with the acclaim accorded his ponderously self-important brother, Thomas. The play both offers a vivid picture of wartime Hollywood where literary legends became studio hacks, and sharply counterpoints European experience with America's "tragic innocence".

The juiciest scenes in the play involve the collisions between Horvath and Brecht. The former believes a writer's primary duty is to interpret the world; the latter that it is his job to change it. Although Hampton's sympathies lie with Horvath, he endows Brecht with a bulldozing energy and wit that allow him to dominate every scene he is in. Brecht's detestation of Thomas Mann, contempt for America's "depraved cuteness" and conviction that he and Chaplin are the only first-rate directors are not only very funny but symbols of his iron certainty. And it's a sign of Hampton's maturity that he gives many of the best lines to the writer with whom he is least in sympathy.

What I noticed in John Crowley's production, more than in Gordon Davidson's in Los Angeles in 1982 or Peter Gill's at the National, is that the play is also about the melancholy of exile. Horvath himself happily adjusts to Hollywood's ebullient freakishness. But Hampton writes with real compassion about Heinrich Mann who, having written the original Blue Angel, is turned into a Burbank wage-slave, and about his wife, Nelly, who becomes an alcoholic wreck. Even the Olympian Thomas Mann is a prophet without a pulpit. For some Hollywood may have been a temporary paradise. But, in a brilliant Hampton phrase, it is an "Eden paid for out of other men's dreams".

Crowley's production, set in an empty swimming pool, also contains a number of fine performances. Ben Daniels's Horvath has exactly the right quality of amused detachment and there is first-rate support from Phil Davis as a chippy Brecht sockless in Santa Monica, Richard Johnson as a Heinrich Mann wreathed in melancholy dignity, Lizzy McInnerny as his blowsily boozy wife and Gawn Grainger as his self-satisfied brother. Hampton went on to script the musical of Sunset Boulevard; this exhilarating play is infinitely closer to the original's bittersweet spirit.

 Until June 23. Box office: 020-7369 1732. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Taxpayers face bill for new universal bank

fields.headline: Taxpayers face bill for new universal bank
fields.standfirst: Government to pay handling fees
fields.trailText: Taxpayers could face a rising bill from the proposed post office-based universal bank under terms to be unveiled today.
fields.body:
Taxpayers could face a rising bill from the proposed post office-based universal bank under terms to be unveiled today.

After protracted negotiations between the high-street banks and the government, Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is expected to announce that the major banks have decided to back the project.

Under the scheme, Mr Byers is expected to reveal that the banks have agreed to offer basic accounts which can be used in post offices. In addition, the Post Office is to offer its own-branded card account.

Early in the discussions, the banks had warned the government that the accounts might carry the "stigma of the poor".

The aim of the post office banking service is to create basic accounts for about four million claimants of social-security benefits who do not have one.

They will need an account when the benefits system is automated in 2003.

The Post Office, meanwhile, has been seeking a way to plug the £400m of revenue it will lose from handing out cash over post office counters.

Basil Larkins, managing director of network banking at the Post Office, admitted yesterday that the greater number of post office accounts opened, the "higher the cost to the taxpayer".

This is because the Post Office will charge a fee for handling the cash paid in and out of the accounts. This will be paid by the government for the Post Office's card account and by the individual banks for any transactions made through their own basic bank accounts.

Because of the terms attached to the banks' participation in the project, it is likely that many claimants without a bank account will choose to open one of the simple accounts operated by the Post Office rather than the more extensive ones to be offered by the high-street banks which might include direct-debit facilities.

The high-street banks have agreed to participate in the project provided the basic accounts are opened only in their own branches and not over the post-office counter. This may make the Post Office card account a more attractive option to benefits claimants as these accounts can be opened in post offices directly. This would place a financial burden on the taxpayer.

Mr Larkins said the Post Office had no opinion on which option would be more appealing to the claimants who needed accounts.

He described the Post Office card account as "looking like a benefit book" from the customers' point of view.

It could be used only over post office counters and to withdraw the amount of social security due.

The basic bank accounts being offered by the high-street banks, however, would enable customers to use cash machines, but are not intended to allow them to go overdrawn.

fields.headline: What Next?
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
There has been a car crash, though no one is hurt. As the six victims pull themselves together, they begin to reveal how they came to be involved in the accident, and what their relationships to each other may or may not be. That is the premise for Elliott Carter's first opera, What Next?, which he completed three years ago at the age of 90; its British premiere on Tuesday, a concert performance by the London Sinfonietta, was magisterially conducted by Oliver Knussen, following an introduction by its librettist, Paul Griffiths.

It's a fascinating though genuinely problematic work. Griffiths's libretto is full of intricate, punning word play, yet the characters he has created are as elusive as the text they sing, more archetypal than real. There's Rose, a young performer who is on her way to her wedding, possibly with her prospective bridegroom, who is unsure whether his own name is Harry or Larry. Stella is a female astronomer, and Zen a mystic left-over from the 1970s; Mama may or may not be the mother of Kid, a 12-year-old boy.

Everything is elliptical, and after 40 minutes nothing has been explained or resolved. The programme includes no text, and without a crib of some kind little of it can be clear, although that was not the fault of the singers (Valdine Anderson, Christopher Purves, Rosemary Hardy, Christopher Grier, Hilary Summers and Gwilym Bowen). Carter's word setting is an extension of his instrumental style rather than vocal writing for its own sake. In some ways, perhaps What Next? is best treated as an abstract piece of music theatre, a continuation of the line of instrumental scores that he has produced over the past half century, which have so often seemed to follow undisclosed dramatic scenarios.

From that viewpoint the work is rewarding. The orchestral writing is full of the fluent invention characteristic of Carter's late style - music that flows effortlessly from one image to the next with lightning changes of pace and mood. Lyrical lines burst into life from the translucent textures, to be quickly replaced by other equally vivid images; violent, dramatic gestures disrupt the flow and bring a change of tack. The car crash is depicted in a short overture of virtuoso percussion writing and a short interlude roughly halfway through introduces a sinuous cor anglais melody; otherwise the glistening instrumental web is always there, seamlessly buoying up the voices and carrying listeners along with it, even when they are not engaged with the drama.

webTitle: Pop: Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds

fields.headline: Is this a gig or a funeral?
fields.standfirst:
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds
Barrowlands, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds
Barrowlands, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.body:
You could spot Nick Cave fans on their way to his first UK gig with the Bad Seeds since 1999 long before they reached the venue. They may have read about this season's vogue for fashions in primary colours and pretty pink, but they are having no truck with it. Black and charcoal separates dominate, as does a certain intensity about the gaze. It is not the most rosy-cheeked gathering you'll ever see.

Cave steps up on stage dressed for a smart funeral in a black suit and tie, with white cuffs big enough to give designer Laurence Llewelyn Bowen sleepless nights. The stage is lit necromantically in black, white and red; it will later change later to purples, crimsons and other hues to suit Cave's songs of possession, damnation and the dark thing that love can be.

The 100-minute set is dominated by tracks from the lushly gorgeous recent album No More Shall We Part, and much of the show is as powerful melodically as it is lyrically - the Seeds are in fine, haunting musical form. There is still a brutal urgency about Cave's take on the world: in a track called Hallelujah you might expect redemptive celebration, but the song ends with talk of 20 buckets of tears and "20 deep holes to bury them in".

The set moves between tender, doom-laden love songs and thunderous renditions of faster numbers. The former include an affecting encore of Henry Lee, The Ship Song, and the Tom Waits-tinged Love Letter, during which someone lights a lighter - something you only do in Cave's company to light a big church candle. Meanwhile, Cave performs Fifteen Feet of Pure White Snow like a preacher from the underworld having a bad day.

During these faster numbers (Oh My Lord, Do You Love Me), Cave moves in a manner that seems to have been taken from the Fire and Brimstone Book of Dancing: he thrashes and tilts about, largely from the armpits up. When he does his one high kick of the night, in the midst of the visceral assault that is The Mercy Seat, a more benign inspiration reveals itself: you realise Cave dances in the way Basil Fawlty used to move across the hotel lobby.

Between and during songs he endlessly lights cigarettes for himself and others in the band. Still, at least he has given up the hard drugs. Cave recently became the father of twins and his lyrics are being published as literary works - but even in this new era of grown-up respectability he makes an unhealthy, bleak and cadaverous view of the world fabulously seductive.

 Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds are at Brixton Academy, London SW2 (020-7771 2000), from Saturday.

fields.headline: Michael Franti throws a party
fields.standfirst:
Michael Franti and Spearhead
Scala, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Michael Franti and Spearhead
Scala, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Dreadlocked and with the sleeves torn off his shirt, Michael Franti stands well over six feet tall and has the erect bearing of a natural leader, albeit one bound to the streets. Moreover, unlike many of his fellow Americans, Franti knows something about Britain, delivering a measured but coruscating rebuttal of attacks on Britain's multiculturalism, dismissing foot and mouth ("I'm more worried about head-up-ass disease"), and delivering a long speech advocating direct action in a "mindful" context, leavened with a lame wrestling gag.

Despite the covert and overt seriousness of his work, however, Franti is a big old ham: if he asks us "How y' feelin' out there?" once, he asks 50 times. He is the most Tigger-esque of performers, pogoing like Sid Vicious from beginning to end, and the master of the camp pirouette. Before the encore of Red Beans and Rice, he distributes pizza (vegetarian of course) to the front rows of the packed Scala: they are, indeed, eating out of his hand.

He even manages to preserve his dignity after diving into the crowd at the set's close, being foiled in his attempt to reach the dressing room by a locked door and having to return to the stage to exit by conventional means. In short, Franti is a star.

His muse, although diluted by Spearhead's unnecessary soloing, is strong too. The threat of the opening track Oh My God (which recalls Gil Scott-Heron) is soon dissipated by Franti's incessant exhortations to "party". People in tha Middle offers a thoughtful good time, Stay Human (All the Freaky People) almost takes a delightful turn into The Sound of Music, and Home is a swiftly dispensed but beautifully delivered lullaby. We Don't Mind is new to the audience, but by its climax Franti is conducting a mass singalong of its chorus.

During Sometimes, right at the death, Franti suggests everyone raise their hands and embrace "positive energy". It is hackneyed, but the response is as frenzied as Metallica's mosh pit and so loud it drowns out the band. Franti himself pogos ever more frantically, before bouncing off stage. "This," he notes breathlessly by way of a parting shot, "has been special." He has a point.

webTitle: Theatre: Rum and Vodka/ The Good Thief

fields.headline: Rum and Vodka/ The Good Thief
fields.standfirst:
Soho Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Soho Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Most writers' early works are faintly embarrassing, but this double bill of plays is a reminder of just how accomplished Irish playwright Conor McPherson's monologues were when he sprang fully fledged upon the world. If together the plays prove a little indigestible, that is probably only because the monologue is best enjoyed as a short rather than a full-scale bender. Back to back, this pairing is likely to induce a slight theatrical hangover.

It's a pity because both stories are very enjoyable. In the first, Rum and Vodka, a 24-year-old married clerk, regretting his lost youth and freedom and looking for "a cure for my life", goes on a drinking binge that gives him a glimpse of another Dublin, another world. As ever with McPherson, the beauty is in the detail: the Krazy Prices can of tuna with which his wife hits him when he tells her he has lost his job; the way that the idea of getting a Chinese takeaway follows from having to ask the taxi to stop so you can puke.

This is a straightforward and familiar story of a man trying to escape from his life only to discover that he is in thrall to the very thing that he is escaping from - love. McPherson undercuts the sentimentality by hinting that next weekend he'll do the same again.

The Good Thief is a more sophisticated tale rendered slightly less satisfying by the opaqueness of its anti-hero, a small-time thug whose boss has recently appropriated his girlfriend and who gets into trouble when he is sent to put the frighteners on another man. Again, McPherson shows enormous confidence as a writer when a summer afternoon picnic gives way to appalling darkness.

The monologues are brilliantly but unshowily performed by Alan Mooney as the young man in search of a saviour and Brendan Fleming as the thug. But even when performed as well as they are here, the question hovers - as it does over so much of McPherson's work - whether these stories might read as well off the stage.

 Until May 10. Details: 020-7478 0100.

fields.headline: Halifax and BoS locked in merger talks
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Halifax and Bank of Scotland remained locked in negotations last night to try to hammer out the terms of their £27bn merger ahead of a self-imposed weekend deadline.
fields.body:
Halifax and Bank of Scotland remained locked in negotations last night to try to hammer out the terms of their £27bn merger ahead of a self-imposed weekend deadline.

Issues surrounding the top managment roles, the name of the combined entity and the sensitive issue of the location of the head office were being ironed out. An announcement on the details of the "nil premium" merger is now slated for tomorrow at the earliest.

The two sides are determined to present their merger not as a cost-cutting deal but as one which could create revenues of as much as £500m a year. Job cuts, particularly in the Edinburgh and Halifax head offices, are expected to be kept to a minimum of 2,000 from a 57, 000 combined work force.

While Peter Burt, the BoS chief executive, is expected to be named in a similiar role in the combined entity, confusion last night surrounded the role of Lord Stevenson, the Labour peer and Halifax chairman.

One source close to the negotations said a better solution to the top management would have been for Mr Burt to be named as chairman, allowing James Crosby, the younger chief executive of Halifax, to become chief executive immediately. Instead, Lord Stevenson is expected to be named as chairman and Mr Crosby is thought to have agreed to the promise of the chief executive role in two years.

Suggestions that Lord Stevenson, who is also chairman of Pearson, should step aside to allow a clearer management structure were denied by some sources last night.

The banks were forced to accelerate their negotiations after their talks were leaked. They had hoped to make the announcement at this start of this week but that proved too ambitious.

Another source close to the negotiations insisted that an end was in sight. "Deals like this always have a beginning, a middle and an end. We're at the end," the source said.

Both sides are believed to be determined to reach an agreement on the structure of a combined bank to avoid a rerun of the protracted negotiations when BoS tried to merge with Abbey National, only to prompt a hostile offer for its partner from Lloyds TSB.

Speculation that the two sides were almost ready to announce their deal mounted after BoS took the unusual step of delaying the publication of its annual results, which were due yesterday.

webTitle: Classical: City of London Sinfonia/ Spivakov

fields.headline: City of London Sinfonia/ Spivakov
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
For a conductor to have a comet named after him could imply one of two things: that his career is starry and unstoppable, or that he is burning out fast and leaving a trail of debris in his wake. Vladimir Spivakov, well known in his native Russia as a violinist and director of the Moscow Soloists, inclines towards the former, but might more appropriately have lent his name to something a bit more solid and steady - a planet, say. His largely dispassionate conducting of the City of London Sinfonia only intermittently made sparks fly.

Schnittke's Concerto for Piano and Strings did benefit from his firm authority; the strings sounded confident in this infrequently performed work and effectively put across the differing inflections of blues, dance and church music. Clusters of notes were built up imperceptibly, making a distorting lens through which the piano's more lyrical phrases were heard. Julian Gallant played the solo part with heavy conviction, pushing at the louder edge of the piano's dynamic range.

However, Spivakov's detachment did not lend itself so well to Schoenberg's Verklärte Nacht; this is desperate music, one step away from the sound of Romanticism collapsing in on itself, and it demands a sense of abandon. Spivakov's cool approach kept the piece free of sentiment but often robbed it of fluidity, and musical turning points were overly hurried. Faced with this hugely difficult score, the orchestra seemed less assured and their range of expression narrowed; there was none of the barely audible, whispered playing we had heard in the Schnittke.

Conductor and orchestra alike were more at ease with Tchaikovsky's Serenade for Strings. Strong, vibrant playing announced the initial Andante, while in the waltz movement Spivakov finally seemed to loosen up, allowing the music to sparkle and bringing out the interplay between the instruments. An exhilarating Russian dance brought the finale careering to its close.

An arrangement of Bach's Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring was an odd choice of encore - it seemed to have an instrument missing, making it a chorale prelude without half of the chorale. After all that had gone before, to end on this serene yet hackneyed piece seemed a cop-out.

fields.headline: Postcodes affect premiums
fields.trailText: The cost of home insurance varies by as much as 326% for people in different areas of the country, according to a new survey.
fields.body:
The cost of home insurance varies by as much as 326% for people in different areas of the country, according to a new survey.

The research, conducted by AA Insurance services, found that the average cost of contents cover across the British Isles is £168. Not surprisingly the contents of a London home are the most expensive to cover at an average of £235, while the cheapest cover is on the Islands (Hebredes & Western Isles, Isle of Man and Jersey) at an average of £103.

The prices are based on a three bedroom semi-detached home (the most popular home) and show that eight out of the top 10 most expensive postcodes are in Greater London. Top of the list is Peckham, Rye at a daunting £709, while Liverpool and Manchester are close behind.

However, you dont have to move offshore to reduce your home contents premiums. According to the AA, a smoke detector, good locks on windows and doors, the installation of an insurer-approved burglar alarm, and being in the Neighbourhood Watch scheme can all help to cut costs by as much as 20%.

fields.headline: This battle for independence cannot be won
fields.standfirst:
Mutual fails size test twice over

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Friends Provident cheerily believes that its 169-year independence is not going to be compromised just because it is demutualising and heading on to the stock market.
fields.body:
Friends Provident cheerily believes that its 169-year independence is not going to be compromised just because it is demutualising and heading on to the stock market. Yesterday it confidently predicted that it will jump straight into the FTSE 100 index of Britain's biggest companies and, armed with £1.4bn in extra cash, go on the acquisition trail.

It is the same story retailed by the mortgage banks such as Northern Rock, Alliance & Leicester and Woolwich when they floated, and they soon got found out. The market started asking just what medium-sized free-floating financials are for. Not big enough to be attractive to an international buyer, not small enough to be a niche provider, their share prices head south.

Friends Provident is in the same trap. Its expected market cap of £4bn puts it at a quarter of the size of Prudential, a fifth of CGNU. Even Legal & General, permanently on the look-out for a takeover partner since its deal with NatWest fell apart, is twice the size of Friends.

When Scottish Amicable, a company similar in size to Friends Provident, tried to make a go of independence, its plans were scoffed at and it eventually opted for takeover by Prudential instead.

Friends Provident also comes to the market at the worst possible time for pension sellers. The new "stakeholder" world has slashed charges to 1% a year compared with the much higher levels enjoyed in the past. The mortgage banks saw their backbook margins ravaged by remortgaging and their frontbook by intense price competition. The insurers face a similar double hit from lower margins on existing business and loss-leading on stakeholder pensions. Privately, the big insurers admits that their stakeholder plans won't come into profit until after 13-14 years. Prudential might have the pockets - and the stomach - for it. Friends Provident does not.

If the 1.7m mutual members of Friends believe its management is "determined" to remain independent, they should sell their shares as soon as they receive them. The best they can hope is that a benign bank seeks them out, in the way that Barclays took over Woolwich. Unfortunately, there are a dwindling number of banks that have not already found their pensions partner, or, like Lloyds TSB, are wondering if they paid too much.

Safe bet

Life is rarely dull at British Biotech, which yesterday threw up the unusual scenario of a chief executive expressing "surprise" that one of his products was working.

The biotech company's boss, Elliot Goldstein, executed a screeching u-turn by backing marimastat, the firm's controversial cancer drug which has been in and out of favour more often than Stan Collymore.

His decision is a sensible one - the drug is, at last, showing useful signs in a trial on pancreatic cancer patients. An analysis of survivors from a two-year-old study on gastric cancer is equally promising.

Goldstein has had a tough job balancing calls from the City to axe the drug with his scientists' instinct that it is working. Critics suggested he should have ordered more trials following the initial semi-successful gastric cancer results in 1999. But that would have been a tough call to justify to investors.

British Biotech is now in the bizarre position of contemplating an immediate application for regulatory approval of a drug it wrote off in February. If marimastat ever reaches the market, it will be the safest medicine available, having been through a remarkably long-winded, if slightly shambolic, series of clinical studies.

Stop start

So, back to normality in the City. On with the suit, off with that daft stuff from the Austin Reed casual range. The May Day would-be rioters gave the Square Mile a wide berth this time round.

Yet a growing body of commentators view the anti-capitalist movement as becoming an increasingly mainstream force: big corporates are bad, full stop, and globalisation allows these profit-seeking beasts to pillage the entire earth, so let's protest.

"Increasingly fashionable" would be a better description. Many of the current combatants seem to believe they are on to something new. Some have even happened across the idea of disrupting companies' annual general meetings, as if company chairmen haven't spent 20 years learning how to deal with problem questions at AGMs.

Capital, meanwhile, has been global since it was invented - it is just that it moves faster nowadays. Even the Reclaim the Streets movement is showing its age, having roots in the Stop the City carnival of the early 1980s. Its greying founders have ended up doing things like editing the financial sections of national newspapers.

fields.headline: European Central Bank sticks to its anti-inflation guns
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The European Central Bank was last night sticking doggedly to its tough anti-inflation stance, shrugging off evidence that industry in the single-currency zone is being dragged into recession by the global slowdown.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank was last night sticking doggedly to its tough anti-inflation stance, shrugging off evidence that industry in the single-currency zone is being dragged into recession by the global slowdown.

As the International Monetary Fund reiterated its belief that the ECB has scope to cut interest rates, the bank's vice- president, Christian Noyer, said it would be a "mistake" to ignore the latent risks to euroland inflation.

Mr Noyer made his comments to a European parliamentary committee while explaining the bank's decision to keep its main interest rate unchanged at 4.75% since last October. "Since the last increase of ECB interest rates in October 2000, risks to price stability in the euro area have become more balanced. However, they have not entirely disappeared," he said.

Mr Noyer's remarks came as Belgium's finance minister, Didier Reynders, surfaced as the latest critic of the ECB's decision to leave interest rates unchanged at a time when inflation remains above its 2% ceiling.

"It is absolutely vital that the ECB looks at the entire economic situation and not just the inflation figures," Mr Reynders, chairman of the Eurogroup of eurozone finance ministers, told Belgium's weekly Knack magazine.

Meanwhile, the head of the IMF's EU department, Michael Deppler, said the risks to price stability did not present a barrier to cutting rates.

A survey released yesterday showed that manufacturing in the single-currency zone is starting to contract as a result of weaker global demand. The Reuters Eurozone Purchasing Managers' index fell below the 50 level in April, signalling that the region's industrial sector is shrinking for the first time in more than two years.

The PMI, based on a survey of more than 2,000 European manufacturing companies, tumbled to 49.3 from 51.2 in March as national PMIs for the eurozone's big three economies - France, Germany and Italy - all dipped below the 50-mark.

However, analysts said there was little prospect of the ECB changing course in the short-term, a view strengthened by comments by Wim Duisenberg, the ECB president, in the forward to the bank's annual report, which was released yesterday.

"Anchoring confidence in the euro, in particular for the general public, is a time consuming task," Mr Duisenberg said. "The best way in which to achieve it is to build a track record of low inflation," he said. His remarks were prepared in mid-March.

European commission president Romano Prodi said that the EU should raise its trend output growth rate to between 3% and 3.5% by 2008 from the present 2.5%.

fields.headline: Joint Security Area
fields.standfirst:
Metro Cinema, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Metro Cinema, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In its current, carved-up state, the Korean peninsular looks a curious construction; a cold war hangover bisected, with the north still under the sway of the communist east and the south overseen by the capitalist west. Fittingly, Park Chan Wook's Joint Security Area, which opened this year's Korean film festival, is itself split. The basic plotline of this pungent military drama (a stolid reworking of the A Few Good Men formula) comes tightly tailored in the Hollywood style. Its interior, by contrast, is airy, subtle and playful, and showcases the best elements of modern Asian cinema. At times it feels like two movies crushed into the same stretch of celluloid.

Writer-director Wook cut his teeth shooting cheap, zippy gangster flicks. This is more ambitious, a humane examination that plays out predominantly in the JSA, a demilitarised zone created by the UN as a wedge between North and South Korea. The hook is an investigation into a gun battle involving soldiers from either side conducted by Lee Young Ae's pensive UN lawyer. The set-up offers a rash of crude expository dialogue that fills us in on the historical background.

But Wook's picture comes into its own in its lyrical portrait of the friendship that develops between the rival soldiers (exchanging addresses, porn mags and photographs of girlfriends back home), and its satirical swipes at a single nation artificially split in two. When an American tourist on the southern side has her cap blown three feet across the border, it requires a North Korean soldier to pass it back to her. In this way Wook paints the division as bogus, ludicrous; like a line drawn down the middle of a bedroom by rivalrous siblings who can't recall what their original quarrel was about.

Refused permission to shoot in the actual JSA, Wook instead oversaw the construction of Korea's biggest, most expensive film set (US$800,000, 26,000 sq metres). The gamble paid off. The fascinating Joint Security Area opened to rave reviews and record-breaking receipts at the South Korean box office. Its divided tone is clearly one that native audiences can relate to.

 Screens tomorrow. Details: 020-7734 1506.

fields.headline: Tradition and Innovation
fields.standfirst:
City Art Gallery, York
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
City Art Gallery, York
Rating: **
fields.body:
This retrospective survey is the kind of show that enables us to pause, take stock, and contemplate where British painting has been going for the past 50 years. Straight into the corporate collections of major financial institutions, we find. The exhibition is a rare chance for work that normally serves as background ambience in the boardrooms and lobbies of the Royal Bank of Scotland (which recently swallowed up NatWest's art holdings as well) to take centre stage.

There is nothing new about art in the service of financial institutions, of course. Estelle Thompson's allusions to 15th-century frescoes and Gillian Ayres's jolly tondo, May Day Games, whose format refers to the spherical works of Botticelli and Raphael, remind you that the Medici were a family of bankers.

The selection takes us from one of Lowry's typically shadowless topographies to one of Dan Hays's typically hamsterless hamster cages. But between these two extremes, what kind of art do big banks consider bankable? The answer is invariably whatever's big at the time.

We're not talking about keeping abreast of trends here - just size. The majority of items are the wall-gobbling grotesques churned out in the 1960s and 1970s, hideous half-attempts at abstract expressionism by a nation instinctively mistrustful of self-expression. Basil Beattie's slurry-coloured crises of confidence the size of a kitchen, for example. In this company, even Patrick Heron's attempt to meet Matisse halfway looks like a loss of nerve.

Lines are a favourite too, from Terry Frost's abstract experiments with a plumbline to Sue Arrowsmith's inky pictures made with a ruler. You only have to glance at the titles - Criss Cross, Grid, Ins and Outs - to get the picture. Even the most recent acquisition, Lisa Milroy's Shoes, is arranged in grid formation. This is ledger-entry art: paintings that look reassuringly like columns of figures.

The best work in the show is a candy-coloured diptych of wire cages by Dan Hays. Another virtuoso display of intersecting lines. Like the poor rodent condemned to live in it, there's no escape.

 Until May 20. Details: 01904 551861.

Basil Beattie's slurry-coloured crises of confidence the size of a kitchen, for example. In this company, even Patrick Heron's attempt to meet Matisse halfway looks like a loss of nerve. Lines are a favourite too, from Terry Frost's abstract experiments with a plumbline to Sue Arrowsmith's inky pictures made with a ruler. You only have to glance at the titles - Criss Cross, Grid, Ins and Outs - to get the picture. Even the most recent acquisition, Lisa Milroy's Shoes, is arranged in grid formation. This is ledger-entry art: paintings that look reassuringly like columns of figures. The best work in the show is a candy-coloured diptych of wire cages by Dan Hays. Another virtuoso display of intersecting lines. Like the poor rodent condemned to live in it, there's no escape.  Until May 20. Details: 01904 551861.

fields.headline: Brian Friel's treat for the ears in Manchester
fields.standfirst:
Library Theatre, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Library Theatre, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Forcibly rehousing badgers is a very bad idea. Frank, a feckless Irish farmer, discovers this to his cost when he attempts to transplant a pair to a new set. Understandably furious, the bleary creatures make a bolt for their old hole.

The tragedy is that Frank badgers his wife in much the same way. Molly is a middle-aged woman who has her sight partially restored in a play that is only partially written. Molly Sweeney's resources are so meagre as to barely exist - three actors on three chairs intoning three monologues. Few contemporary playwrights could make a memorable event from a play about blindness and with nothing to watch. Brian Friel is the honourable exception.

For this theatrical poem from 1994, Friel revisited the monologue format of his earlier play, Faith Healer. Both pieces are embedded in stillness, requiring the audience to listen for the action in the language. But it is appropriate that Molly Sweeney should be a play for the ear as much as the eye, as it tells the story of a woman exiled from her world of darkness to a confusing region of half-shadow.

Stella Madden gives a brilliantly alert portrayal of a woman keenly alive to her own sensory sphere, whose edge is blunted by the influx of light. Madden persuades you that Molly does not have her sight restored so much as her blindness confiscated. Karl O'Neill is equally fine as the hapless Frank, whose butterfly enthusiasms suggest that his wife's eyesight is merely one among a number of unfinished projects involving Ethiopian bees and Iranian goats. And Ian Lindsay gives a grave and tender performance as the ageing eye specialist Rice, whose promising career has somehow faded into white hair and whisky but might be resuscitated by his miracle-cure of Molly.

Director Roger Haines hits the right note of understatement for this delicate work. The production is enhanced by the swirling, retinal tracery of Judith Croft's projected designs, which trickle like the capillary patterns of the mind's eye.

 Until May 19. Box office: 0161-236 7110.

webTitle: Will the real Barry please stand up?

fields.headline: Will the real Barry please stand up?
fields.trailText: Embarrassment for Scotland manager Craig Brown when he mistakenly called up Livingston striker Barry Wilson instead of Dunfermline midfielder Barry Nicholson.
fields.body:
The Livingston striker Barry Wilson may enter the record books as receiving the shortest international call-up on record after revealing yesterday that he was included in Craig Brown's Scotland squad against Poland - for 30 seconds.

Although Wilson has been a key part of Livingston's front line this season his ambitions were limited to helping secure promotion from the First Division. But all that changed when he received a phone call from Brown asking about his availability for the trip to Bydgoszcz.

Wilson is fast, direct and a great crosser of the ball but even he did not think his 16 league goals warranted international attention.

He was right. Brown had got the wrong Barry. It was the Dunfermline midfielder Barry Nicholson he was after.

Scotland's coach had been given the wrong number by Nicholson's Dunfermline team-mate Stevie Crawford, himself a hasty replacement for the injury-depleted squad.

"I knew Craig was struggling for players but I said to myself 'surely he's not struggling that badly?'" said Wilson. It was only when Brown began talking about Dunfermline that Wilson realised the mix-up.

"I was disappointed but I was realistic about the whole thing. Craig was brilliant. We had a laugh about it, although I think he was embarrassed."

webTitle: Rushden and Diamonds make the Football League

fields.headline: Diamonds to sparkle in league
fields.trailText: Rushden and Diamonds are set to enter the Football League for the first time in their short history after their Conference rivals Yeovil crashed 3-2 at home to Hereford.
fields.body:
Rushden and Diamonds will enter the Football League for the first time in their short history next season after their Conference rivals Yeovil crashed 3-2 at home to Hereford last night.

Yeovil needed at least a point to take the promotion issue seriously to the final games of the season on Saturday. Now they may win, Diamonds lose and, unless there is a 17-goal swing in goal difference, Diamonds will go up. Ian Rodgerson's 90th-minute strike for Hereford ended Yeovil hopes.

Diamonds, however, can cross Chesterfield off next season's fixture list after a league disciplinary panel yesterday upheld the nine-point penalty against them, leaving them just about secure in third place in the Third Division and thus promoted. "It's great news. It's brilliant," Chesterfield's captain David Reeves said. "It just shows we're innocent again."

The same three-man disciplinary panel recommended a nine-point deduction last month but was asked to reconsider by the league, which hinted that the punishment was not harsh enough.

The panel late yesterday evening decided to stand by its recommendation - including a £10,000 fine - and it is almost certain to be ratified by the league tomorrow.

Chesterfield's manager Nicky Law said: "I'm glad. To be fair to the panel they never wilted and they kept to their decision. The big question is will they ratify it or not."

A Football League spokesman said: "There are two options available. The panel's recommendations can now go back to the board for ratification or we can send it back to the panel."

As the panel appears unmovable on this issue, a rapid conclusion to the league's investigation can be expected.

But the Chesterfield scandal will rumble on. The fraud squad is investigating an accountant over alleged financial irregularities at the club and the former chairman Darren Brown is also likely to be questioned. It is believed that the new owners have inherited debts of over £1m and face a winding-up order next week.

The new owners will have to decide the future of the club's chief executive John Green. And more importantly they have to find the money to pay wages owed or face losing all their players on free transfers.

Chesterfield's 1-0 defeat at Brighton last night left them three points ahead of Hartlepool with one game to play. Hartlepool can still overtake them but they would have to beat Cardiff City on Saturday; Chesterfield would have to lose at home to Halifax and the combined margin of the defeats would have to be at least 10 goals.

fields.headline: Cullip late strike wraps up title for Brighton
fields.trailText: Brighton wrapped up the Third Division title and left Chesterfield waiting until Saturday to make absolutely certain of promotion. Plus, a full round-up of Third Division action.
fields.body:
Brighton made sure of the Third Division title last night with their 1-0 win over Chesterfield.

Danny Cullip's 78th-minute goal at Withdean Stadium wrapped up the championship and left Chesterfield waiting until Saturday to make absolutely certain of promotion.

Rochdale staged a second-half revival to sink Plymouth and move into the fourth and final play-off spot. They fell behind to Micky Evans but Stuart Elliott's own goal and Paul Connor's effort turned things round in the space of four second-half minutes.

Hull rubber-stamped their place in the play-offs with a 1-1 draw at Southend. Mike Edwards gave the visitors a fourth-minute lead but Tesfaye Bramble equalised just before the interval.

Marcus Richardson and Tom Cowan scored second-half goals eight minutes apart to give Cambridge United a 2-1 win over Colchester at the Abbey, but they are still not assured of staying in the Second Division. Swansea City's 6-0 win over Brentford came too late to save them from relegation to the Third.

Canvey Island came through the most exhausting end-of-season programme in senior football to win the big match between the top two in the Ryman League 2-1 at Farnborough last night, but that also came too late. Farnborough are already assured of the league title and promotion to the Conference.

Dundee have put Claudio Caniggia up for sale. The Scottish Premier League club said last night that they had taken the decision "reluctantly" because the 34-year-old Argentine international forward, who signed an extended contract only three months ago, saw his future elsewhere.

Caniggia has been the subject of intense speculation over the last month concerning a possible transfer to Rangers. He missed training twice last week while his agent discussed his future with the Dundee board.

Some reports say Dundee are looking for £1.5m for Caniggia, who joined on a short-term deal last October, quickly became the idol of the club's fans and sparked worldwide interest in Dundee. He had signed an extended contract in February, taking him to June 2003.

The Everton captain Richard Gough has announced his retirement after a playing career that spanned more than 20 years. "With the club safe from any relegation fear, it was time to make this decision," the 39-year-old former Scotland international defender told the Everton website.

"I felt it was right and proper to let people know at Everton as soon as possible and I will be returning to the United States at the end of the season. However, if any offers on the management side of football come along, I would be keen to look at that."

Christian Karembeu last night claimed he is happy to stay at Middlesbrough but admitted that Paris St-Germain are still keen to sign him. "I know that the manager from PSG would like to sign me, but for the moment I'm here," the 30-year-old French international said. "They need to come here and see our manager, but I think I'll continue here."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Ricketts keeps Bolton bubbling
fields.trailText: Michael Ricketts ensured Bolton are still in with a shout at automatic promotion - provided Blackburn fail to beat Preston tonight.
fields.body:
Michael Ricketts' second goal in four days eased Bolton's nerves last night in a game they had to win to retain any chance of overhauling Blackburn in the second automatic promotion berth to the elite.

Sam Allardyce's team's victory over a Wolves side that has forgotten how to score at home means that Rovers are now only one point clear of the third-placed Bolton - but can clinch promotion if they beat Preston at Deepdale tonight.

Having already endured two successive seasons of play-off nightmare, Bolton were curiously unable to stir themselves early on last night as Wolves produced some fine approach work. Many home supporters had given this game a miss as Wolves had failed to score here in April, drawing blank in four home games, but it took some smat goalkeeping by Matt Clarke to deny the home side twice inside 10 minutes.

In the fifth minutes Michael Branch beat Simon Charlton for pace rather than finesse, pushed the ball off the Bolton left-back and galloped past him to deliver a low cross. Temuri Ketsbaia stepped over the ball, which took both the Bolton defence and his team-mate Adam Proudlock by surprise. One on one with Clarke, the teenaged striker dallied and allowed the keeper time to come off his line to block.

Then Andy Sinton worked his way down the left through a posse of defenders before moving the ball to the opposite flank where it found Kevin Muscat. Again a low cross troubled the defence, with Clarke forced into a diving save after a ricochet off the centre-back Gudni Bergsson.

By contrast, the build-up to Bolton's opener owed nothing to such measured approach work. Robbie Elliott lumped the ball forward, perplexing the centre-backs Tony Dinning and Jolean Lescott and allowing Dean Holdsworth to nip in and fire underneath the diving Michael Oakes for his 15th goal of the season.

But that and a save from Ricketts proved to be Oakes's only moments of anxiety as Wolves pressed to level. Twice the home side came close to turning possession into goals before the interval. Showing the predatory instincts that make him such a prospect, Proudlock clipped the outside of Clarke's left-hand post with a shot on the turn.

Within seconds the teenager showed his inexperience when, put through by a defence-splitting long pass from Lee Naylor, he fired straight at the advancing Clarke.

Bolton came out for the second half looking much more ambitious and finally forced Wolves' defence into a second costly muddle. This time Carl Robinson and Lescott misunderstood each other's intentions down the right and Holdsworth nipped in to deliver a delicate chip that landed at the feet of Ricketts.

One on one with Oakes, the striker calmly slotted home his 22nd goal of the season to keep Bolton bubbling.

fields.headline: Liverpool in the driving seat
fields.trailText:
A fine solo effort by Michael Owen and yet another belting free-kick by Gary McAllister restored Liverpool to third and left them three victories away from a Chamnpions league place.
Newcastle 1 - 0 Southampton
fields.body:
It has been a long wait but Liverpool will feel their time has come. After overcoming Bradford here last night Gérard Houllier's team will be flushed by the knowledge that three more Premiership wins will see them reacquainted with the European Cup.

It may be a tall order - Liverpool's hectic schedule not only includes the FA Cup and Uefa Cup finals but league fixtures at home to Newcastle and Chelsea and away to Charlton - but they must feel they are in pole position after leapfrogging Ipswich and Leeds into third position courtesy of second-half goals from Michael Owen and Gary McAllister.

Houllier has repeatedly stressed that, for all Liverpool's success in knockout competitions, their season would still be an anticlimax should they fail to secure a Champions League place.

At this stage of the season it is all about timing and, in voicing his reservations, the Frenchman will doubtless have been mindful of the damaging repercussions of last year's end-of-season tailspin in which his side failed to register a solitary goal in their final five league matches.

This year scoring goals has not been the main hindrance but the sheer weight of matches. This was their second game in a sequence of seven in 21 days and, having come out of an even more gruelling run, it was perhaps inevitable that the gulf between themselves and the Premiership's wooden-spoon club was not always evident.

Throughout the opening exchanges, indeed, Bradford managed to repel most of Liverpool's attacking thrusts with little fuss and will reflect that a free shot for Benito Carbone on the left of the penalty area represented the best chance of the first half. The Italian, however, flashed his shot wide of Sander Westerveld's goal.

Valley Parade echoed to the familiar sound of disillusioned sighs but, for all Liverpool's possession, Liverpool's journey along the M62 was not half as comfortable as might have been expected.

There were opportunities but half-chances rather than clear-cut openings. Markus Babbel was denied by Gary Walsh as early as the first minute and, as the visitors' elaborate passing game started to force Bradford deeper into defence, the goalkeeper had to be alert again to block Emile Heskey's grass-cutter.

Yet, as so often happens after relegation has been confirmed, Bradford seemed to be playing without the weight of pressure associated with a club at the bottom of the table.

It has been anything but heroic failure this season but, in front of their biggest crowd for 31 years, the Yorkshire side were suddenly showing something like self-belief.

Houllier had much to ponder at half-time but within two minutes of the restart his side were ahead. Owen's pace and alertness had been a feature of Liverpool's play and McAllister's through-ball was weighted to perfection.

Andy Myers is no slouch but Owen is positively lightning and after outpacing the Bradford defender into the penalty area his expert finish, lifting the ball over Walsh with a deft flick of his right boot, gave him his 16th goal of the season.

The home side were thrust into depression once again and, almost immediately from the kick-off, another defence-splitting pass, this time from Danny Murphy, would have provided Owen with No17 if Walsh had not dashed off his goalline to save at the striker's feet.

It could easily have been costly. Just before the hour Westerveld inexplicably handled a back-pass from Jamie Carragher to concede an indirect free-kick eight yards from goal. Eoin Jess touched the ball to Carbone whose shot was batted down by Carragher's hands only for the referee Jeff Winter to wave away the long and vociferous penalty appeals.

Bradford smouldered with injustice and, to make matters worse, on 67 minutes McAllister's exquisite free-kick, after Owen had been fouled by Robert Molenaar, put Liverpool two up and considering the possibility of a return to their European Cup days.

fields.headline: Pahars nods Gray into the black
fields.trailText: It came too late to spark any hopeful charge back among the real movers and shakers, but Southampton at least experienced something vaguely unfamiliar last night: after 563 minutes of cringeworthy, shot-shy football they scored a goal. Marian Pahars hardly knew how to celebrate.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield  at St James' Park
fields.body:
It came too late to spark any hopeful charge back among the real movers and shakers, but Southampton at least experienced something vaguely unfamiliar last night: after 563 minutes of cringeworthy, shot-shy football they scored a goal. Marian Pahars hardly knew how to celebrate.

The Latvian had only been on the pitch for 10 minutes when Kevin Davies crossed and the diminutive forward nodded home. Although Matthew Oakley did wonderfully well to clear Carl Cort's shot off the line moments later, the handful of hardy visiting fans deserved the point to comfort them on the 350-mile slog home.

This match kicked off with Tyneside bathed in balmy sunshine, weather better suited to cricket than a less than enticing Premiership contest between two sides swathed in mid-table obscurity. Although it was hard to believe at times, Newcastle did have an incentive to succeed - a pair of home victories and a point of pride at Sunderland rekindling hope of an Intertoto Cup place. It may be a back door into the Uefa Cup, but with their chief rivals for the much maligned competition, Aston Villa, yet to visit the north-east, the scenic route to Europe remains within the grasp of Bobby Robson's side.

Since Stuart Gray succeeded Glenn Hoddle at Southampton in March, a bright season that promised a top-eight finish has dimmed. It is easy to see where his problems lie. When Davies fizzed a cross from the right-flank and Chris Marsden saw his stooping header tipped away by Shay Given, the visiting players cast resigned glances. Their mood hardly improved when Hassan Kachloul's low shot was deflected and claimed at full stretch.

That effort riled the nervy home support, but within seconds they were at ease. Given's punt into the area was flicked on rather fortunately by Cort and Kevin Gallacher calmly lobbed the on-rushing Jones for his third goal of an injury-wrecked season. That lead might have doubled had Jones not reacted smartly to tip away Gary Speed's close-range shot, an off-balance Lomana Lua-Lua spearing the rebound high and wide.

While Southampton bustled around midfield, the hard-fought approach play rarely threatened reward. Their plight was epitomised by James Beattie. The 23-year-old began the season attracting the attention of Nationwide League scouts before a mind-boggling spurt of 11 goals in 10 games at the end of last year priced him out of the market. Now those heady days seem a long way off; there has been only one Premiership goal since December and none in his last 10 games.

As a lone striker, Beattie was anonymous throughout the first half, in contrast to United's Cort. Just before the interval the former Wimbledon forward, in prolific form, exploded a shot at Jones's near-post from outside the area with most expecting a cross.

The fact that the stinging drive brought such excited applause said more about the game than the attempt. The match descended into a scrappy mess from which the visitors' cluttered midfield appeared more likely to profit.

The best chance was spurned without a Newcastle defender in sight. Davies's 69th-minute flick skimmed off Andy O'Brien and through a gaping rearguard; Kachloul charged on to the loose ball and scuffed infuriatingly wide of the post. Then up popped Pahars to spare his blushes.
