fields.headline: Bayern put champions on back foot
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Giovane Elber stunned the European champions when he grabbed an away goal to leave Bayern Munich in the driving seat for a place in the Champions League final.
fields.byline: Giles Tremlett at the Bernabeu stadium
fields.body:
Giovane Elber stunned the crowd into silence last night with a goal which ended the European champions' seven-game streak of home wins in this year's competition and left them with a mountain to climb in the second leg next week.

Real Madrid must now travel to Munich next Wednesday hoping to put an end to another sequence: they have never beaten Bayern at the Olympic stadium.

The German champions, will be without the talismanic Steffen Effenberg, however, as he picked up his second yellow card of the phase for a foul on Luis Figo in the 78th minute.

If Bayern found it intimidating here in the cauldron of the Bernabeu - where they were eliminated in last year's semi-final - then they were determined not show it. A busy first 10 minutes saw the two sides determined to make a mark, though both displayed more energy than precision.

Steve McManaman, now fully established in the coach Vicente del Bosque's starting line-up, began the Madrid surge with a run down the left in the first minute which saw him being hacked down outside the box, though nothing came of the free-kick.

As Real kept up the pressure Bayern quickly showed how dangerous they can be on the break with Effenberg, Mehmet Scholl and Hasan Salahamidzic combining to take the ball deep into the opposing half. Then, in the fifth minute, Effenberg drove a 25-yard free-kick around the wall but safely into the hands of Iker Casillas.

Ten minutes later another attack saw Salahamidzic float a right-wing cross over Casillas's head to the feet of Scholl who, left with a narrow angle, shot into the side-netting.

As Real slowly got a grip on the ball, and the game, the referee earnt the ear-shattering wrath of the 76,300 crowd after ignoring appeals for a penalty after Figo tumbled inside the area. He then called the Portuguese aside and told him to save his diving for the pool.

Figo, however, began to reconfirm his reputation as Europe's most dangerous player, launching a series of piercing runs. In one such surge, after 26 minutes, he shook off Effenberg and Thomas Linke before forcing Oliver Kahn into a fine diving save.

He then played the ball forward for Michel Salgado who broke through the Bayern lines and drove a centre through the area which, had it found anyone, would have been costly.

Real came out for the second half looking as though they were intent on finishing the game there and then. But an intense 10 minutes saw Kahn become an immediate hero.

The best of his saves came from McManaman, who turned and shot in the box only to see the imposing goalkeeper block the effort. The Englishman missed again five minutes later, and then Ivan Helguera missed an open goal.

Madrid were soon counting the cost. Bayern broke down the left and a long, floating pass found Elber 30 yards from goal. He caught the ball with a left-foot volley and fired the ball towards goal, though it bounced over the prone Casillas and squeezed into the net.

Real Madrid (4-4-2): Casillas; Salgado (Munitis, 78min), Hierro, Karanka Carlos; Helguera, Makelele, Figo, McManaman; Guti (Savio, 55), Raul.

Bayern Munich (3-5-2): Kahn; Kuffour, Andersson, Linke; Sagnol, Effenberg, Jeremies, Lizarazu, Salihamidzic; Scholl (Sergio, 72), Elber (Jancker, 74).

Referee : H Dallas (Scotland).

fields.headline: Looking for another Steve Bull
fields.standfirst: Got a question? Email the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to help
fields.trailText: LOWER-DIVISION PLAYERS WHO HAVE PLAYED FOR ENGLAND
fields.body:
LOWER-DIVISION PLAYERS WHO HAVE PLAYED FOR ENGLAND

"Everyone remembers that Steve Bull played for England despite not playing in the top league," remembers David Cassidy. "But I'd like to know which is the lowest division a player has ever been selected from to represent: a) England and b) a top ranking international side."

We can certainly help you with the first part of the question, David. Several Third Division (old) players have played for England, including Tommy Lawton (four times during 1948-1949 while at Third Division South side Notts County); Reg Matthews (five times in 1956-7 while at Third Division South side Coventry City) and the late Johnny "Budgie" Byrne, who played once for England while at Third Division Crystal Palace in 1962, before moving to West Ham.

Going back further still, there are also several non-league players who have proudly worn the three lions on their chest. Bert Coleman, of Isthmain League side Dulwich Hamlet, won an England cap against Wales in 1921, while Edgar Kail (also of Dulwich) won three caps against France, Belgium and Spain in 1929. Meanwhile, Bernard Joy of Corinthians earned his only cap and became the last amateur to play for the senior England team in the 3-2 loss to Belgium in Brussels on May 9 1936.

Thanks to Mark Price, Mark Neale and Seamus20 for their help.

NOSE-BLEEDS OVER THE HALFWAY LINE

Excluding goalkeepers, what is the longest stretch of games a player has played without scoring for his own team? asks David Bates.

The first name which sprang to mind was Rob Jones, the Liverpool right-back, who famously turned out 243 times for the Reds without once sending the net billowing.

Then we thought of Southampton defender Francis Benali, who played 284 times for Southampton before stunning the Dell with a purler against Leicester in 1997. (He celebrated by getting two yellow cards and a red in his next five matches.)

And then we thought well, this is sure to be the tip of the iceberg, isn't it? There's bound to be someone in the mists of time who concentrated so hard on marshalling a defence that he went 600 games without scoring. But who is it? Over to you - email the.boss@theguardian.com with names and stats.

GOAL-SCORING DEMONS

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has a record at Manchester United of 76 goals in 202 appearances or one goal every 2.66 matches. Not bad at all, I think we can all agree. However, what I want to know is, bearing in mind how often he has been used as a substitute, how many goals does he score for every 90 minutes he is on the pitch? Does anyone else have a better ratio of goals per 90 minutes? And who has the best goals per 90 international minutes ratio? I am guessing it is Gerd Muller with 68 goals in 62 caps. His club record should also beat Solskjaer, I think, standing at 447 goals in 490 games. Can anyone else help?" asks Benjamin Hardy.

"The best record for goals per game is Australia's Archie Thompson," points out Dave Gardner. "He has five caps, three as a substitute, for a total of 261 minutes football. In that time he has scored 16 goals, a record of 5.5 goals per 90 minutes - take that Der Bomber!"

WRIGHT NOT RIGHT

Last week we told you that Everton defender Tommy Wright sat on his arse all the way through the 1970 Mexico World Cup.

That was balls. In fact, as many of you have written in to tell us, he came on for his club team-mate Keith Newton in the first game against Romania and played the whole 90 minutes against Brazil.

The bit about Nobby Stiles, Alex Stepney and Emlyn Hughes spending all their time warming the bench was right, though. The altitude must have affected our brains.

CAN YOU HELP?

"What is the origin of the shamrock on the Panathinaikos crest?" asks Diarmuid O'Brien. "Is there any overt Irish connection there, given their crest and green strip, or is it, as my mate claimed in the pub during one drunken Champions League viewing, that Greece is the only place outside Ireland where shamrock grows?"

"Who started the trend among coaching staff of wearing jackets/tops with their initials on? When was this?" asks Justin Toland.

"Can you help me with this riddle?" asks Bob Farrell. "Arsenal do it once every 4 years; Liverpool have done it the most; Man Utd have never done it; Everton did it once; As a player Rio Ferdinand has done it the most and Duncan Ferguson the least."

"During the last European Championship, a TV commentator mentioned that one of the Portuguese team had a brother who has represented Mozambique. Didn't Joe and Gerry Baker play for England/USA in the 60s?" asks David Glass. "Are there any other examples of this phenomenon?"

"Are Rot-Weis Essen the only team in world football that 'does exactly what it says on the tin?'" asks Dave Gibbs. "Translated as Red-White Essen, they are a team from Essen who play in red and white. I can't think of any others, can you?"

"I cannot recall a professional player ever having to leave the field due to a call of nature. I am sure this must have happened; does anyone remember any such incident?" asks M Munro

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From: Paul
fields.trailText: I'm not sure where you are exactly, but I'm English and have lived in Santiago for nearly four years, so I thought I'd give you a few pointers.
fields.body:
Dear Sue,

I'm not sure where you are exactly, but I'm English and have lived in Santiago for nearly four years, so I thought I'd give you a few pointers:

1. In Santiago, visit El Mercado Central (the fish market). The iron structure it's housed in was built in England.

2. Also worth a visit is the Cerro San Cristobal (the hill overlooking Santiago) You can ride a cable car to get up there. From the top you have a beautiful view of the Andes - and the smog.

3. La Moneda (the presidential palace), which is where President Allende committed suicide at the start of Pinochet's Dictatorship.

4. For good, relatively cheap food try one of the three branches of Eladio. I think it's a money-laundering operation, but don't quote me on that.

5. Once you've done all that get out of Santiago asap as, although Chile is a fantastic, beautiful country, Santiago is not at all representative.

6. If you can, visit San Pedro de Atacama, Torres del Paine, Isla Negra, Valle del Elqui (inland of La Serena) and Chiloe (where the potato comes from, as legend has it).

In my opinion the best things about Chile are:

1. The climate 2. The food (the fish, shellfish, fruit, vegetables) 3. The wine 4. The Pacific 5. My wife

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions or anything.

Disfruta,

Paul (O'Toole)

fields.headline: Golden handshakes
fields.standfirst: Donors would rather a more personal relationship with the charities they give to according to new research. They'd also sooner donate cash to the heroes on the lifeboats than the 'berks' that need saving
fields.trailText: Donors would rather a more personal relationship with the charities they give to according to new research. They'd also sooner donate cash to the heroes on the lifeboats than the 'berks' that need saving.
fields.body:
Charities should be fostering a more personal relationship with donors, according to new research by Stephen Lee at the Henley Management Centre.

"Too many charities are wasting their time recruiting new donors when they should be nurturing existing supporters," Lee told delegates at Charityfair last week. He said that it costs between five and 15 per cent more to recruit new donors than to keep existing supporters.

Initial results of a survey conducted among 2,000 donors and 2,000 non-donors have revealed that donors would like a more personal relationship with the charities they support. They are also more interested in the cause rather than the name of the charity.

To develop a relationship with existing donors, Lee said that charities should ask them to choose how much information they wish to receive from the charity.

The biggest difference between givers and non-givers is their attitude to philanthropy. Lee urged charity fundraisers to concentrate on aspects of a charity's work that the public could relate to which may not be the beneficiaries, for example, nurses or lifeboat men or women.

"People support the Royal National Lifeboat Institute because they relate to the heroism of the lifeboat crews, not the 'berks' who need rescuing. Similarly people trust nurses and will relate to that more than the name of a charity that employs nurses."

Lee is looking at what motivates donors to give and why others do not support charities. He is trying to distinguish between the concepts of trust and confidence and said that charities should concentrate on building trust whereas umbrella organisations should develop confidence in the sector.

He said trust must be based on communication, which must be relevant, dynamic and action orientated.

The reasons why people don't give to charity include not wanting to feel obligated, a sense that there are too many appeals and worries that the money does not reach beneficiaries.

The top reasons why people give to charities are:
1. I believe/associate strongly with the cause
2. The work charities undertake is essential for society
3. I give in memory of a loved one
4. I feel it is my duty
5. I benefit from the work charities undertake
6. There are spiritual reasons.

webTitle: Devolution bittersweet pill for Welsh research

fields.headline: Devolution bittersweet pill for Welsh research
fields.trailText: Welsh academics are worried they could miss out on funding, even though devolution allows them greater autonomy in picking research priorities.
fields.body:
Devolution is a bittersweet pill for Welsh research. Academics are worried they could miss out on funding, which is particularly distressing in a region that has already received an inadequate share, even if devolution has allowed them greater autonomy to pick research priorities.

Professor John Furlong, director of this year's new review of educational research in Wales, believes researchers in the devolved authority could already be missing out.

"The Department for Education and Employment has increased the amount of money it is giving in research grants. In the past, Wales could have accessed those funds, but now the relationship is not clear," he said.

Before devolution, the grant made to Wales for teaching and research was set by the Secretary of State for Wales, and so might not have risen with any increase in DfEE funding. The question is whether it is less likely to do so now.

Jane Davidson, the assembly minister for the office of education and lifelong learning, believes that the situation has not changed significantly since devolution.

However, director of the institute for Welsh affairs, John Osmond, agrees there is a danger that Welsh research may lose out by not being linked to central institutions, but he believes there is an even more fundamental imbalance.

"All peripheral areas lose out massively on research and development resources already. We have to look at that imbalance, not just at keeping current levels of funding," he said.

Devolution has also opened up the possibility to prioritise new research areas that are more significant for the Welsh situation. Whereas in the past there were individuals in Whitehall responsible for Wales, there are now 60 elected officials in Cardiff who have to justify their existence by coming up with relevant policies.

The new assembly is clearly willing to make changes. It is already suggesting A-levels be dropped in favour of bacheloriates, and that there should be greater support for new teachers across the first three years of their career.

But at the moment, such revolutionary zeal has not made it through to Welsh thinking on research. Professor Furlong argues that the relationship between Welsh and English research must be clarified.

At the moment, the only place the issues are being broached is in his review. And, unlike the areas the assembly has already tackled, such as secondary education, research is going to be complicated.

Professor Furlong says that research structure and funding cannot be looked at merely within a Welsh context. But there are issues of particular concern to Wales that have to be addressed separately, such as bilingual research and curriculum development.

In both areas, Wales has a much greater interest in research than the rest of the country, and with devolution, it might be able to prioritise them.

Wales' challenge will be to emphasise particular Welsh concerns, without damaging links with either central funding or with British or international researchers.

fields.standfirst: Social psychologist who inspired a generation and pioneered research into unemployment, poverty, crime and discrimination
fields.trailText: T he outstanding social psychologist Marie "Mitzi" Jahoda, emeritus professor at the University of Sussex, has died, aged 94. In a long and eventful life as researcher, writer and teacher, she inspired generations of students and colleagues with her humanistic ideals, her kindliness and her devotion to scientific methods in social research. fields.body:
T he outstanding social psychologist Marie "Mitzi" Jahoda, emeritus professor at the University of Sussex, has died, aged 94. In a long and eventful life as researcher, writer and teacher, she inspired generations of students and colleagues with her humanistic ideals, her kindliness and her devotion to scientific methods in social research. Throughout her career, she focused on problem-oriented research, leaving the laboratory to study social issues, including racial discrimination, anti-semitism, the mental impacts of poverty, crime and pornography, social-class inequities and nationalism.

Marie was born in Vienna, to Carl and Betty Jahoda, and there were three distinct periods in her life: her childhood and youth in Austria; her emigration, wartime experiences and academic career in Britain and the United States; and, finally, an active period of nominal retirement with the science policy research unit (SPRU) at Sussex.

At the time when she was a student, it was not only Freud and Adler, but also Wittgenstein and Popper, Menger and Schumpeter, as well as Mahler and Klimt, who left their mark on Viennese culture. Nor should the progressive tradition of the Austrian Social Democratic party in the government of that city be forgotten; it had a particularly strong influence on the youth culture in which Marie grew up, and she remained loyal to this social democratic tradition. Although she admired the courage of the communists in their resistance to fascism, she was never seduced by their politics.

The work of Freud was probably the most powerful single intellectual influence on her life, but, even as a researcher in her 20s, she showed the independence of mind and freedom from dogmatism that were to characterise all her later activity. Her first big project, known as the Marienthal study (conducted with her first husband, Paul Lazarsfeld, and Hans Zeisel), has become a classic in social psychology, as well as in the economics of unemployment.

Marienthal was an industrial district near Vienna, afflicted by prolonged mass unemployment in the 1920s and 1930s. Using a range of path-breaking methods of disguised observation, the team set out to understand the psychological consequences for the unemployed. In this, and other research, Marie showed that the experience of regular work was a fundamental human need for most people, not only for eco nomic reasons but also for a personal sense of identity, for social contacts, and for the structuring of time.

However, Marie was no armchair philosopher. As a staunch anti-fascist, she came into collision with the repressive Austrian government even before Hitler's Anschluss, and was imprisoned between 1936 and 1937. Fortunately, through the intervention of the French president, Léon Blum, she was released on condition that she left the country. She came to England, where she laboured to obtain exit visas for other Austrians, and conducted research on unemployed miners, volun- tary societies, and the transition from school to work. She also ran the secret radio station, Radio Rotes Wien, under Richard Crossman at the Ministry of Information.

After the second world war, Marie emigrated to the United States, where she was reunited with her daughter, and established herself in academic life. Between 1946 and 1958, while a researcher at the American Jewish Committee, at Columbia University, as professor of social psychology at New York University, and founder and director of the Research Centre of Human Relations, she showed an independence of mind and devotion to the findings of empirical research.

She was deeply involved in the two major issues that dominated the political climate of those years - the civil rights movement and McCarthyism. Whether because of her studies on blacklisting in the entertainment industry, on mining communities in Pennsylvania, on the impact of security measures on the climate of thought of civil servants, being a board member of the American Civil Liberties Union, or as president of the Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues, evidence suggests that she was the subject of an investigation by the FBI.

O n returning to Britain in 1958, she worked as a consultant to the Nuffield Foundation, gave courses at the London School of Economics, the Maudsley hospital and Nuffield College, Oxford, before agreeing to create a degree in social psychology at what became Brunel University. Here she developed a unique sandwich course, in which students spent time in schools, prisons, hospitals and industry, relating their academic studies to real world problems.

All of this made Marie an ideal person for the University of Sussex to recruit in 1965, when it was striving to establish a new map of learning and promote inter-disciplinary research and teaching. For nearly 40 years, she remained the embodiment of this Sussex ideal, and played a full part in the academic life of the university and of its governance. She gained the unstinting admiration of both colleagues and students for her breadth of sympathy, her intellectual generosity and her spirit of tolerance.

As always, Marie also contributed to more public responsibilities through her membership of the newly- created Social Science Research Council (as it was then called) and, later, of the Commission for Racial Equality. She was made CBE for this public service.

Her second marriage, to Austen Albu, whom she had known in wartime England, also opened up possibilities for her political life, as he shared her social democratic ideals and was, for a while, a junior minister in Harold Wilson's Labour governments of the 1960s.

After her official retirement, at the age of 65, Marie began a new period of creative work with the SPRU at Sussex, making major contributions to research programmes on social and technological forecasting. She co-authored World Futures: The Great Debate (1977), which remains the definitive text on methods of forecasting.

She was also able to return to the problem that had been her first love as a young researcher - the social and psychological consequences of prolonged unemployment. She was able to show that, despite the far greater availability of welfare benefits, the consequences remained psychologically devastating. These findings were, and are, of the greatest importance for social and economic policy, as well as for social psychology.

Marie's work was recognised through the prestigious Kurt Lewin Memorial Award by the American Psychological Association, and was belatedly honoured by the German Social Democratic party and by the Austrian Social Democratic government.

She died at her home in Keymer, Sussex, and is survived by her daughter, Lotte, professor of management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Chris Freeman and Howard Rush

fields.headline: Margaret Jones
fields.standfirst: Archaeologist at the sharp end of history
fields.trailText: Margaret Jones, who has died aged 84, was an archaeologist famed for excavations on the Essex coast of the Thames estuary. She bridged the eras of amateur and modern institutional archaeology; through dogged salvage excavation on a grand scale, saving remains before sites were disturbed, her influence was quiet but profound.
fields.body:
Margaret Jones, who has died aged 84, was an archaeologist famed for excavations on the Essex coast of the Thames estuary. She bridged the eras of amateur and modern institutional archaeology; through dogged salvage excavation on a grand scale, saving remains before sites were disturbed, her influence was quiet but profound.

Some may have considered her to be one of the discipline's eccentrics - at the Ministry of Works, her nickname was Boadicea. But while her act- ions could be frustratingly obstructive, her personality could command respect, and even warmth.

Born in Birkenhead, Marg- aret attended Calderstones girls' high school, Liverpool, and read geography at the city's university. Her interest in archaeology grew from acting as a student volunteer on local digs, where she met Tom Jones; they married in 1940. During the second world war, she worked as a postal censor, while her husband was with the army in Palestine. Reunited after the war, they ran a photography business in Birmingham - Tom with the camera, Margaret selling photos and her own journalism.

In 1956, she directed her first excavations, in Bucking hamshire and Yorkshire, where she was paid, like her colleagues, a day-rate available from the Ministry of Works only if they were actually digging, plus food and equipment expenses reimbursed at cost - and nothing more. She long resented the lack of support that would have allowed the proper study and reporting of her life's work.

British institutional archaeology today - particularly as represented by English Heritage, its Welsh counterpart, Cadw, Historic Scotland, and the professional Institute of Field Archaeologists - emerged from a small, impecunious band of diggers in the 1960s. Margaret was of a more politically-minded generation, who, in 1973, formed a campaigning organisation called Rescue, but she shunned the high-profile demands of protest. However, she was just as determined to counter the threat to heritage, whose reality was not always acknowledged by senior academics who had begun their careers before the days of industrial farming, motorways and expanding towns.

At Old Sleaford, Lincoln- shire, in 1960, Margaret and Tom found an important coin mint of the Coritani tribe, the oldest known in Britain. But their great project came in 1965, when they started work in an Essex quarry. Thirteen years later, having accumulated an astonishing - and unmanageable - quantity of finds and records, they stopped digging, finally abandoning the old caravan that had seen them through all weathers, as it moved between the gravel drag-lines and the pursuing landfill.

Mucking, as the site near Thurrock is known, provided a rare opportunity to eke a life from continuous digging, and thus sustain serious research - in the process, convincing the sceptical that winter digging was possible.

The conditions were tough: accommodation ranged from your own tent to leaking huts; food was the cheapest line from the cash and carry, creatively supplemented with wild gleanings (I once asked the cook what was for supper, to learn she had spent her afternoon removing, as instructed, mouse-droppings from a sack of rice); and entertainment consisted of a night-time drive round one of the uncannily-automated oil-refining stations along the coast.

As public money - and renewed television interest - came to archaeology, and projects such as Mucking revealed the enormous scale of the loss in the teeth of new development, it became necessary to systematise work and funds. "Excavation without publication", the charge levelled by institutionally-salaried archaeologists, became a damning mantra.

Living among the graves and houses of hundreds of prehistoric, Roman and, especially, Anglo-Saxon villagers, Margaret could not see the point of spending months in an office while large chunks of her site vanished, unrecorded, into the gravel graders. So she continued to dig.

Much as Margaret would have liked to complete properly-funded "post-excavation" work herself, the task was latterly done by others, under English Heritage management. But had she and Tom not stuck to their trowels and spades, none of us would have known how much had disappeared. Thanks to her, the history of forgotten lives can one day be written.

Tom died in 1993 after a heavy stroke, and, in her final years, Margaret suffered from Parkinson's disease.

Mike Pitts

fields.headline: Teacher makes space in staffroom
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Andrew Lincoln is to take a lower profile in the second series of hit C4 show Teachers, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Andrew Lincoln, who plays the central character in Channel 4 drama Teachers, will take a lower profile role in the second series of the hit show.

The Channel 4 chief executive, Michael Jackson, said Lincoln, who first rose to prominence as Egg in BBC2 drama This Life, would appear in "most but not necessarily all" the episodes in the second run of Teachers.

Lincoln plays unorthodox teacher Simon who is as slack in his relationships as he is in the classroom.

"This will allow us to grow some more characters," said Mr Jackson, indicating that Teachers will become more of an ensemble drama.

Mr Jackson said the drama was likely to come back for an eight or 10-part second run.

He added that while Teachers might not have had as much plot as the critically acclaimed drama North Square, which was controversially cancelled after one series, it had "the right tone and attitude".

"We'll be improving the plots for the second series to get more happening," he added.

The eight-part first series of Teachers is still going out on Channel 4. It is averaging around 2m viewers between 10pm and 11pm on Wednesday night.

Teachers is made by Tiger Aspect Productions. The series producer is Jane Fallon, who also worked on This Life.

webTitle: Fiachra Gibbons on regional arts boards

fields.headline: Bums on seats
fields.standfirst: Few should mourn regional arts boards, creatures of the dog days of the Thatcher cultural revolution
fields.trailText: Few should mourn regional arts boards, creatures of the dog days of the Thatcher cultural revolution.
fields.body:
Where were you on March 15, that black day for local democracy when the regional arts boards were cruelly done to death? Huddled disbelieving in the rain numbed by the same sense of shock you last felt the day Diana died, laying wreaths outside your local RAB office, or leading a protest prayer meeting outside the Arts Council headquarters in Great Peter Street?

Surely you were moved enough to write to your MP to rail at how New Labour was once again preaching devolution and practicing centralisation? Had not another of Tony's business cronies - in this case that "jumped up caterer" Gerry Robinson, the Granada chairman whose name sends a chill through every Little Chef in the land - been let loose with an axe on our cherished public services?

Or, like all but a handful of the population, you might simply have wondered what on earth regional arts boards were, and what were they for. Indeed, that last question has been never far from the mind of anyone who has had anything to do with them over the past 11 years.

You won't find this in their official histories, but the regional arts boards were created in the dog days of the Thatcher cultural revolution to make it as difficult as possible for undeserving arty types to get their hands on taxpayers' money.

That is not exactly what the Wilding report, which set them up, intended, but that was certainly the subtext sold to the shires. It was the familiar story of Tory quangos. Public money was no longer to be handed over to special interests with their "own agendas", but would instead be wisely managed by 11 regional committees of right-thinking business people and down-to-earth aldermen, with the odd house-trained artistic type thrown in for colour.

Before them would come a procession of prostrate petitioners, who would be given another spoonful of gruel on condition they mend their spendthrift ways. Pushing boundaries was all very well, but where were the business plans, marketing initiatives, administrative structures?

There was money aplenty for tiny theatre and dance companies to develop management structures but little for them to stage anything. Eventually, new Byzantine schemes were devised to correct this minor defect, only for the rules to change the following year. To further complicate matters, the Arts Council would occasionally stick its oar in and demand a "shift of emphasis", or a few extra tick boxes to placate the latest minister for fun. This merry-go-round got so surreal that one regional board spent a third of its budget on administration. Form-filling became the great unacknowledged British art form of the 1990s.

Such a constipated bureaucracy meant endlessly delayed decisions on funding, further undermining whatever shaky confidence artists had in the ability of RAB officers to judge work. Put brutally, many feel they are not up to their jobs.

Those companies who could most successfully parrot whatever inane party line was current that month seemed to get the most cash. Some of the most bum-numbing arts events of the last decade tended also to be the best funded. Amid this blizzard of bureaucracy, the work that was presented to the public became more and more impoverished - and the punters began voting with their feet.

It is true that many RABs, most notably Northern Arts, fought heroic rearguard actions to simplify the system and devise ingenious methods of actually smuggling money out to let talented people do wonderful things.

It was against this background that Robinson, the most popular chairman of the Arts Council in decades - having wrung an extra £100m a year from the government - decided to act. In the sort of dawn raid more familiar to the City, he disbanded the RABs and replacing them with regional officers who would both report to the Arts Council and have a say in the formation of national policy.

With the sense of urgency we have come to expect from the RABs, it took them three weeks to respond publicly to the news of their own death. Eight have openly rebelled, dismissing the plans as moronic, ill-thought out and undemocratic.

The reaction from artists themselves has been more positive and immediate. There have been naysayers, but in the main the announcement has sparked a kind of elation last felt when Thatcher was finally savaged by her dead sheep. All agreed something had to be done, even if, like after Thatcher's demise, they can't quite believe the nightmare is over.

For no one really knows how Robinson's reforms will pan out - not even Robinson, it seems. He claims the regions will get more money and have a stronger say at the centre than they do now. It is hard to see, however, how these new regional officers will win hearts and minds. What the arts need is not a new kind of regional bureaucrat but impresarios given the freedom to spend as they see fit.

And even in his bright new dawn, a little of the old doublethink has begun to creep back in. "We are not going to throw money away," Robinson declared, "but people will only be successful by taking risks." That's another one for the Little Book of Arts Council Paradoxes.

fields.bodyText: Where were you on March 15, that black day for local democracy when the regional arts boards were cruelly done to death? Huddled disbelieving in the rain numbed by the same sense of shock you last felt the day Diana died, laying wreaths outside your local RAB office, or leading a protest prayer meeting outside the Arts Council headquarters in Great Peter Street? Surely you were moved enough to write to your MP to rail at how New Labour was once again preaching devolution and practicing centralisation? Had not another of Tony's business cronies - in this case that "jumped up caterer" Gerry Robinson, the Granada chairman whose name sends a chill through every Little Chef in the land - been let loose with an axe on our cherished public services? Or, like all but a handful of the population, you might simply have wondered what on earth regional arts boards were, and what were they for. Indeed, that last question has been never far from the mind of anyone who has had anything to do with them over the past 11 years. You won't find this in their official histories, but the regional arts boards were created in the dog days of the Thatcher cultural revolution to make it as difficult as possible for undeserving arty types to get their hands on taxpayers' money. That is not exactly what the Wilding report, which set them up, intended, but that was certainly the subtext sold to the shires. It was the familiar story of Tory quangos. Public money was no longer to be handed over to special interests with their "own agendas", but would instead be wisely managed by 11 regional committees of right-thinking business people and down-to-earth aldermen, with the odd house-trained artistic type thrown in for colour. Before them would come a procession of prostrate petitioners, who would be given another spoonful of gruel on condition they mend their spendthrift ways. Pushing boundaries was all very well, but where were the business plans, marketing initiatives, administrative structures? There was money aplenty for tiny theatre and dance companies to develop management structures but little for them to stage anything. Eventually, new Byzantine schemes were devised to correct this minor defect, only for the rules to change the following year. To further complicate matters, the Arts Council would occasionally stick its oar in and demand a "shift of emphasis", or a few extra tick boxes to placate the latest minister for fun. This merry-go-round got so surreal that one regional board spent a third of its budget on administration. Form-filling became the great unacknowledged British art form of the 1990s. Such a constipated bureaucracy meant endlessly delayed decisions on funding, further undermining whatever shaky confidence artists had in the ability of RAB officers to judge work. Put brutally, many feel they are not up to their jobs. Those companies who could most successfully parrot whatever inane party line was current that month seemed to get the most cash. Some of the most bum-numbing arts events of the last decade tended also to be the best funded. Amid this blizzard of bureaucracy, the work that was presented to the public became more and more impoverished - and the punters began voting with their feet. It is true that many RABs, most notably Northern Arts, fought heroic rearguard actions to simplify the system and devise ingenious methods of actually smuggling money out to let talented people do wonderful things. It was against this background that Robinson, the most popular chairman of the Arts Council in decades - having wrung an extra £100m a year from the government - decided to act. In the sort of dawn raid more familiar to the City, he disbanded the RABs and replacing them with regional officers who would both report to the Arts Council and have a say in the formation of national policy. With the sense of urgency we have come to expect from the RABs, it took them three weeks to respond publicly to the news of their own death. Eight have openly rebelled, dismissing the plans as moronic, ill-thought out and undemocratic. The reaction from artists themselves has been more positive and immediate. There have been naysayers, but in the main the announcement has sparked a kind of elation last felt when Thatcher was finally savaged by her dead sheep. All agreed something had to be done, even if, like after Thatcher's demise, they can't quite believe the nightmare is over. For no one really knows how Robinson's reforms will pan out - not even Robinson, it seems. He claims the regions will get more money and have a stronger say at the centre than they do now. It is hard to see, however, how these new regional officers will win hearts and minds. What the arts need is not a new kind of regional bureaucrat but impresarios given the freedom to spend as they see fit. And even in his bright new dawn, a little of the old doublethink has begun to creep back in. "We are not going to throw money away," Robinson declared, "but people will only be successful by taking risks." That's another one for the Little Book of Arts Council Paradoxes. fiachra.gibbons@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Bono to address Harvard
fields.trailText: U2's frontman will give one of the more unusual performances of his career early next month, when he is scheduled to address the 2001 graduating class of Harvard University.
fields.body:
Bono, the garrulous frontman of the Irish rock band U2, will give one of the more unusual performances of his career early next month, when he is scheduled to address the 2001 graduating class of Harvard University.

Bono, whose real name is Paul Hewson, a singer who cut short his own post-secondary education in Dublin during the late 1970s in order to form his hugely successful group, has accepted an invitation to deliver a keynote speech to Harvard seniors at their class day ceremony on June 6.

"We're psyched," said Xunhua Wong, one of the student organisers of the festivities for the graduating Class of "U2001".

Bono emerged as the guest of choice for the 1,600-plus Harvard seniors after they were polled earlier in the year to determine their preferences from a list that included the names of civic leaders, media personalities and political figures.

Past speakers at the university's class day ceremonies have included Coretta Scott King, widow of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr, Mother Teresa, and music producer Quincy Jones.

The U2 frontman won out over the others because, notwithstanding his advancing years, he remains "the epitome of cool", according to a press release marking the announcement.

"Everybody here has grown up with U2 - they're a cross-generational kind of band," said Ms Wong, speaking by telephone from Cambridge, Massachusetts. "I mean, like, all our conscious life, they've been there for everybody. You can't think of a time when U2 weren't there."

At the same time, she said, the group's high-profile support for activist groups such as Greenpeace also tipped the choice in Bono's direction.

Jeffrey D Sachs, a professor of economics and well-known social commentator at the university, who perhaps can still remember the world as it was before the emergence of the band, was asked to extend the formal invitation for the 41-year-old performer to appear at the venerable campus.

The two men have worked together in the recent past, publicising the issue of debt relief for the world's poorest nations, a theme Dr Sachs expected Bono to return to during his Harvard address.

Although Dr Sachs will probably share the university stage with Bono, it remained unclear whether the gesture will be reciprocated during the same week, when U2 plays four concerts at the nearby FleetCenter in Boston, where the group kicks off its keenly anticipated Elevation US Tour.

Unfortunately for any fans who have missed out on tickets for the group's already sold-out shows in Boston, Bono's Ivy League performance also promises to be a closed shop, with entrance being restricted to university seniors and members of their immediate families.

fields.headline: Previous unemployment affects work conditions
fields.trailText: Even three years down the road, having been unemployed has a significant impact on pay and employability, according to Dr Wiji Arulampalam, an economist at the University of Warwick.
fields.body:
For unemployed men who thought getting a job was the end of their troubles, new research will come as a blow: even three years down the road, having been unemployed has a significant impact on pay and employability, according to Dr Wiji Arulampalam, an economist at the University of Warwick.

After analysing the British Household Panel Survey, 1991-1997, Dr Arulampalam found that to get back into work, unemployed men have to take a 6% pay cut, and after three years, they will earn 14% less than they could have expected to had they not been out of work.

The impact on pay and employability is much greater where someone was fired or dismissed than where someone was eased into unemployment through redundancy packages.

Dr Arulampalam believes her research highlights the tendancy of men who become unemployed to become trapped in a spiral of lower pay and worse conditions, or indeed to become unemployed once again. According to her research, 81% of unemployed men have faced a period without work at least once before.

There is no indication, however, as to what exactly causes this trend. Dr Arulampalam says the current statistics are not capable of analysing how much of the problem is a result of employer attitudes and how much is simply the result of difficuties in returning to work.

She suggests another theory: the problems of finding work could actually be stopping people staying in a job.

"Men could be getting so tired of being unemployed that they take any job, which pays them less or is short and which, as a result, they leave again in a short time. We just don't know," she said.

webTitle: Mathematicians to investigate structure of ice

fields.headline: Mathematicians to investigate structure of ice
fields.trailText: When our pipes get blocked by ice, most of us just start swearing. But for two mathematicians, it is the start of a crusade to understand how the structure of ice forms and the damage it can cause.
fields.body:
When our pipes get blocked by ice, most of us just start swearing. But for two mathematicians, it is the start of a crusade to understand how the structure of ice forms and the damage it can cause.

"Ice forms in three dimensions in a pipe, both in waves and in fingers moving in. But numerically, it is just formulas, formulas we are going to try to find," said Dr Sergei Timoshin from University College London.

He has just received an £8,000 grant to try to find the answers.

Although you cannot stop water from freezing just by knowing its structure, Dr Timoshin's work could help designers of homes work out where an internal heater could best prevent freezing.

But the final aim is even more pragmatic: the researchers hope to eventually stop aeroplanes falling out of the sky. In North America, several plane crashes have occurred over the years after ice formed on their wings.

The water in clouds can remain liquid even well below zero degrees celsius, as long as it is undisturbed. But when an aeroplane flies through, that water can freeze instantly along its wings, and if a pilot doesn't know how to react, it can cause the plane to fall out of the air.

But when he started looking into the matter, Dr Timoshin realised, "We just didn't know enough about it. So we wanted to start by looking at something else."

webTitle: Partnership to link research and business

fields.headline: Partnership to link research and business
fields.trailText: Attempts to link mathematical research with business practices have been fraught with difficulty, says a leading research director. But a £2m partnership begun within the last three months is attempting to address the issue.
fields.body:
Attempts to link mathematical research with business practices have been fraught with difficulty, says a leading research director. But a £2m partnership begun within the last three months is attempting to address the issue.

The scientific director of Edinburgh's international centre for mathematical sciences, Professor Angus Macintyre, believes that mathematical research has as much potential to impact on business as any other subject, and that all research facilities have been trying to establish links.

"Our experience is that it is not so easy to operate business and academic links in that way. It's difficult to make or maintain any links with corporate institutions. If you asked any research operation in maths, they would have experienced the same problems," he said.

The problem does exist, and is probably due to failings on both sides of the equation, according to the mathematics programme manager at the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC), Dr Alisdair Rose, although he is keen to stress that there have been some positive experiences.

"It could be because business tends to look at the short term and academics at the long term, but this is something the Department for Trade and Industry and EPSRC are trying to help," said Dr Rose.

Within the last few months, the DTI and EPSRC have each pledged at least £1m to bolster the Smith Institute, an organisation that seeks to promote the kind of links that Professor Macintyre has said are so difficult.

The Smith Institute employs "technology translators", who help to explain businesses' needs to mathematicians and academic findings to businesses.

The fact that it can work is evident from a project at Southampton University, in collaboration with GKN Westland Helicopters Ltd and the Department of Trade and Industry, on the world's smartest helicopter, capable of flying in zero visibility.

webTitle: Welsh view to be heard in Whitehall

fields.headline: Welsh view to be heard in Whitehall
fields.trailText: The review of educational research in Wales, begun in January, aims to get its findings heard in Whitehall this summer.
fields.body:
The Welsh view on education research will be heard in Whitehall - at least if a group of Cardiff researchers led by Professor John Furlong have anything to do with it.

The Department for Education and Employment's national education research forum is already examining the future of education research. But after some disagreement about the forum's role, it has become clear it will be focusing primarily on England's needs.

Wales is being left out. And some researchers were worried it could be left behind.

Professor Richard Daugherty, chair and instigator of the review of educational research in Wales, felt there was a need to find out whether Wales had particular issues that needed to be addressed.

He said, "There's nothing wrong with looking at the UK agenda, but the assembly is still establishing its own ways of working, and looking at different issues. We need to inform the discussion about research."

So the review of educational research in Wales was begun in January, and expects to complete its work by summer.

It has already established that there are several issues where Wales has different priorities from England and Scotland, according to Professor John Furlong, director of the review.

Schools are demanding more research into the impact of bilingual study and the best ways to carry it out, something that is of little interest in England. Similarly, the Welsh assembly is considering changes to the support for new teachers in their first three years and to the curriculum.

However, Professor Furlong believes the most important task of his review is not just to look at the differences between Welsh and English needs, but to chart how education research in Wales should relate to research in the rest of Europe and the world.

"Research is as much national and international as regional. I do not know how that relationship is going to work, but we are talking to researchers and to users about what they need," he said.

webTitle: Blunkett rules out cut in school inspections

fields.headline: Blunkett rules out cut in school inspections
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, was yesterday accused of pre-empting the conclusions of a review into the work of the schools watchdog Ofsted, after ruling out any relaxation of the school inspection cycle.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, was yesterday accused of pre-empting the conclusions of a review into the work of the schools watchdog Ofsted, after ruling out any relaxation of the school inspection cycle.

Teachers' leaders claimed that Ofsted's chief inspector, Mike Tomlinson, told them he was considering the possibility of state schools in England being inspected just once every 10 years, compared to six at the moment in most cases.

But in a speech to educationalists yesterday, Mr Blunkett ruled out any changes to the "rigorous" system. He said he believed it would be "a mistake" to change the frequency of inspection, and that the current timescale should continue in order to maintain the balance between freedom and accountability.

Mr Blunkett's speech was based on a paper produced for the left of centre think tank, the Institute for Public Policy Research, and focused on Labour's achievements in education as well as the challenges that lie ahead.

The minister - widely tipped to move to the Home Office after the election - said he believed a review of Ofsted and the way it works was "an excellent way forward". But on the timing of inspections, he said: "Six years seems about right to me, and broadly reflects the school career of a youngster in primary or secondary school, and I know that Mike Tomlinson strongly agrees with me on this."

Mr Blunkett went on to claim that schools often created problems for themselves by "over-preparing" for inspections.

The education secretary's comments disappointed teachers. Members of the second largest classroom union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, were persuaded not to support a motion by their leaders recommending industrial action on the assumption that fundamental changes to the inspection system were on the cards.

They were also impressed by the new spirit of cooperation signalled by Mr Tomlinson, who took over from his controversial predecessor Chris Woodhead at the end of last year.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, claimed that Mr Tomlinson had been forced into a u-turn by the government.

"Mike Tomlinson is backtracking a bit. He has obviously had his knuckles rapped in the usual fashion." Mr de Gruchy said it was disappointing that Mr Blunkett had pre-empted the findings of the review.

Mr Blunkett said in his speech that four years of progress since Labour was swept to power in 1997 had paved the way for higher expectations and the modernisation of secondary education.

He also predicted that as many as one sixth of England's teenagers could be taking new, vocational exams in the future.

At present some 50,000 of the 1.2m 15-year-olds take vocational courses each year, but the education secretary believes that more skills based study might appeal to "three or four times that number".

fields.headline: Scouting for talent
fields.standfirst: Ethnic minority students targeted for civil service fast track
fields.trailText: Ethnic minority students targeted for civil service fast track.
fields.body:
The Cabinet Office will today launch a recruitment drive to attract able undergraduates from ethnic minorities into the fast stream of the civil service - the elite group that can be expected to produce most of the next generation of senior officials.

It has appointed an "outreach scout" to visit university campuses to sign up ethnic minority students for a summer programme to familiarise them with what it would be like to pursue a career in Whitehall.

Faisal Naru, a 24-year-old Oxford graduate, has been contracted to find about 60 potential recruits among students who might have the talent for this kind of work. They will get placements in Whitehall during the summer, coupled with residential training to hone their teamworking skills.

Naru, a maths graduate previously employed by Oxford University to boost its intake from inner-city comprehensives, says: "It's clear from talking to students and community groups that the perception persists that the civil service only offers rewarding careers for white, male, middle-class, middle-aged Sir Humphreys. That is not the case."

The Cabinet Office says the service welcomes applicants from all sections of society. Its existing 500,000 staff include 5.8% from ethnic minorities. This compares with 5.2% of all people in employment and 5.8% of the economically active population.

Among the top 3,500 jobs in the senior civil service, 2.1% are held by ethnic minorities staff. This has risen from 1.6% in 1998, with the government having set a target of 3.2% by 2005.

The programme to attract undergraduates and graduates from the ethnic minorities was piloted last year. Naru says it had two target groups: students who would not have considered a civil service career because they knew little about it; and those who saw it as "a closed domain of white Oxford males".

During the pilot, 70% of students said they would not have applied for the civil service before going on the course; afterwards, 90% said they would apply.

Akhil Patel was based in the prison service during the pilot and went on to apply for fast stream entry. "I had my doubts about the civil service beforehand," he says. "But I found it welcoming and supportive. People I trained with were open to ideas and I felt the work I was given was important and was making a real difference."

Shalini Chandru, another fast track applicant, was based in the Treasury last year. "On the programme, I had responsibility from the start and realised how important, worthwhile and diverse the work can be," she says. "Afterwards, I was motivated to apply and the training I received gave me more confidence to do so."

Naru, whose university visits start this week in Bradford and Leeds, says he was pleasantly surprised when he took on the civil service contract. "I was expecting it to be quite cliquey, but my experience has been different. I was supported during the month of fasting that I had as a Muslim. In some organisations that can be difficult. But flexible working hours in the civil service let me change around my days to keep up with my religious commitments as well as continuing with work I like doing."

Students attending the summer course will be encouraged to apply for the fast track entry in the September after they graduate. A further winter course will aim to boost applications for the January entry.

Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, says the proportion of ethnic minority recruits to the fast stream doubled over the past two years from 3% to 6%. "But we are not complacent about diversity in the civil service. Initiatives like this are crucial if the civil service is to reflect the society it serves."

This has risen from 1.6% in 1998, with the government having set a target of 3.2% by 2005. The programme to attract undergraduates and graduates from the ethnic minorities was piloted last year. Naru says it had two target groups: students who would not have considered a civil service career because they knew little about it; and those who saw it as "a closed domain of white Oxford males". During the pilot, 70% of students said they would not have applied for the civil service before going on the course; afterwards, 90% said they would apply. Akhil Patel was based in the prison service during the pilot and went on to apply for fast stream entry. "I had my doubts about the civil service beforehand," he says. "But I found it welcoming and supportive. People I trained with were open to ideas and I felt the work I was given was important and was making a real difference." Shalini Chandru, another fast track applicant, was based in the Treasury last year. "On the programme, I had responsibility from the start and realised how important, worthwhile and diverse the work can be," she says. "Afterwards, I was motivated to apply and the training I received gave me more confidence to do so." Naru, whose university visits start this week in Bradford and Leeds, says he was pleasantly surprised when he took on the civil service contract. "I was expecting it to be quite cliquey, but my experience has been different. I was supported during the month of fasting that I had as a Muslim. In some organisations that can be difficult. But flexible working hours in the civil service let me change around my days to keep up with my religious commitments as well as continuing with work I like doing." Students attending the summer course will be encouraged to apply for the fast track entry in the September after they graduate. A further winter course will aim to boost applications for the January entry. Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, says the proportion of ethnic minority recruits to the fast stream doubled over the past two years from 3% to 6%. "But we are not complacent about diversity in the civil service. Initiatives like this are crucial if the civil service is to reflect the society it serves."

fields.headline: Where le fairplay still rules
fields.standfirst: The French skated around the Thatcherite revolution - and their economy is none the worse for that
fields.trailText: When Motorola ignored ministerial pleas and announced the closure of its Bathgate plant last month the government expressed disappointment and politely asked for its regional development aid back. In France when Marks & Spencer and food group Danone announced closures and mass lay-offs, workers took to the streets and the government reached for the statute book.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and M ark Milner
fields.body:
When Motorola ignored ministerial pleas and announced the closure of its Bathgate plant last month the government expressed disappointment and politely asked for its regional development aid back. In France when Marks & Spencer and food group Danone announced closures and mass lay-offs, workers took to the streets and the government reached for the statute book.

The reaction from the government and workers speaks volumes about France's very French approach to capitalism. True, the news from M&S and Danone was followed by a warning from Dim, the underwear maker, that "major restructuring" is on the way; Moulinex, the household appliance manufacturer, has decided to scrap 1,500 jobs in France; Alcatel, the electronics firm, is to sell one of its French mobile phone plants; and 2,700 staff at two domestic airlines have been told their jobs will go by June.

The global economic about-turns and shifting consumer behaviour patterns that explain this rash of large-scale redundancies matter little in France. What counts is the corporate response - and except in cases of dire, bankruptcy-looming necessity, selling off, shutting down, cutting back or pulling out are just not acceptable courses of action.

That is why Marks & Spencer's decision was described as "brutal", "unacceptable", "inhumane" and "scandalous", not just by furious French trade unions but by an equally furious Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, in what looked at first suspiciously like a bout of Brit-bashing.

In a front-page rant, Le Monde Diplomatique asked whether one could expect any better of a country that had for more than 20 years been "a laboratory for ultra-liberal market economics" where "perverted minds" had favoured profit over sensible state regulation.

Overwhelming revulsion

A fierce Gallic rejection of what are known here as "Anglo-Saxon business practices" in part explains the superstar status accorded to figures like José Bové, the pipe-smoking peasant activist who won fame by trashing a McDonald's restaurant.

Now that native French companies are up to the the same sort of thing, it is clear there is more to it. Danone's plan, inspired not by present financial woes but by a desire to shore up future profits, was described as "completely unjustifiable" by 85% of respondents in a recent survey.

So why such overwhelming revulsion at a straightforward, if tough, business decision? One answer is that France, which despite the influence of an omnipresent state has always been reluctant to place too much power in any one person's hands, never had its equivalent of the Thatcher revolution with its diet of deregulation and privatisation.

In France the great mass of public opinion believes companies have a real social responsibility. "Stock-market layoffs", designed to please shareholders, are unacceptable, and employees, as a trade unionist said, "cannot be treated like pawns to be sacrificed on a chess board".

What the French do want and expect from their employers is a virtue they have, paradoxically, imported from the English: le fairplay. Most also believe it is up to the government to ensure businesses do play fair.

According to Stéphane Rozès of the CSA polling organisation, in a period of economic growth "the very idea of redundancies is insupportable. People are not stupid - when times were bad, they were content to ask the government to limit the damage. Now they demand regulation."

Regulation is what they got. Seizing on the perfect opportunity to make up lost ground after a poor showing in last month's local elections, Mr Jospin's government announced a package of measures to deter companies from mass firings.

These included doubling the minimum redundancy pay, forcing companies to offer staff six months of retraining to help them to find other work, and fining those that fail to help develop replacement activities on sites they shut down. Employees are also to be given more say in restructuring plans, and allowed to hire management consultants to come up with alternatives.

It was a revival of the kind of orthodox French statist intervention that seems a million miles from Tony Blair's response to Motorola's Bathgate closure. In traditionally dirigiste France it plays well, and for some it did not go far enough. Mr Jospin's Communist coalition partners demanded that all layoffs by profit-making companies be made illegal.

France's highly regulated labour market and the hefty social costs of employing workers may be decried by the 200,000 or so French people who have moved to London in recent years to find work, and by the hundreds of young French entrepreneurs who have set up shop in Britain or America where job laws are more flexible, meaning it is easier and cheaper to hire and fire.

They do not, at the moment, appear to be doing a great deal of harm to France's economy, which is faring just as well as Britain's and, according to the International Monetary Fund, will grow at 2.6% this year and next - leaving a slowing US economy in its slipstream.

Last year the French economy generated 500,000 new jobs. This year, accord ing to Stéphane Déo at investment bank UBS Warburg in Paris the total is likely to be 300,000.

Then there is the 35-hour week. The Jospin administration's job-creating brainchild was greeted with hoots of derision when it was announced in 1997. It is now in place for companies employing more than 20 people, and to the surprise of many observers has won over most of its opponents.

Underlying reality

Surveys have shown 80% of the 5m French men and women benefiting from three or four weeks' extra holiday a year felt the shift to 35 hours had been "positive or very positive" for them personally.

Of company directors, 60% believe the law has helped to increase productivity through renewed dialogue with the workforce, reforms to outdated and inflexible working practices, and increased morale.

Proof that the Anglo-Saxon camp is wrong? Not quite. The underlying reality is that France has introduced a number of significant economic reforms. Large sections of the economy have been privatised.

Little of the banking industry remains in the state sector. Much of the defence industry has been privatised and merged with German and Spanish partners. National symbols such as France Télécom and Air France have been sold to investors.

Jospin's Socialist government has been no less willing than some of its rightwing predecessors to roll back the frontiers of the state. Despite France's reputation for strikes, the economy has benefited from wage restraint for much of the 1990s. Many of France's leading companies, like the vast new media conglomerate Vivendi which owns Universal studios, are lean, mean business machines very much on the Anglo-Saxon model.

For all the changes France has not embraced the the symbol of the liberal market; shareholder value. The country clings to the notion that employers owe rather more to their employees than the equivalent of a P45 in exchange for a few pence on the share price.

fields.headline: The state we're in
fields.standfirst: Tyrannical rulers, squabbling underlings . . . No wonder Shakespeare's history plays still seem fresh, says Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Tyrannical rulers, squabbling underlings . . . No wonder Shakespeare's history plays still seem fresh, says Michael Billington.
fields.body:
I have only one serious complaint about the RSC's eight-play Shakespeare history cycle: it hasn't been seen nearly often enough. Only twice in April was it possible to view the plays in strict chronological sequence. Contrast that with 1964, when Peter Hall staged a similar cycle at Stratford. Admittedly, the Henry VI trilogy was condensed into two plays under the generic title of The Wars of the Roses. But the seven-play cycle, from Richard II to Richard III, was performed countless times through a Stratford summer. What was then a popular success has become a collector's item.

But mention of 1964 shows how the histories constantly shift their meaning. Two key influences dominated Hall's version: Bertolt Brecht and the pioneering Polish critic Jan Kott. What emerged was a vision of Plantagenet England as an endless treadmill of violence: in the words of the New Statesman's Ronald Bryden, "a lightless tunnel of historical error down which leaders and commons trudged deathward through mounting pain and obscenity, pulling their small victualling wagons".

The anti-heroism of the 1960s still pervades the latest cycle. But the effect is surprisingly different. Hall and his co-directors gave the plays a deliberate continuity, as if we were watching the enactment of a curse. Today the plays are called This England, and the sense is of fragmentation, as if to mirror our current national divisions. Four directors tackle the eight plays in radically diverse styles, and they are staged in a range of venues, from the Barbican to the Young Vic. And England is symbolised in differing ways: a mound of earth, the flag of Saint George and jingoistic hymns in Steven Pimlott's Richard II; a curving wall of steel in Michael Boyd's Henry VI trilogy. The shifting perspectives echo the central idea: that any cohesive sense of national identity has been lost and is only briefly, and horrifically, resurrected through a foreign war.

Shakespeare himself is now under attack today. Does he have anything to say in a hi-tech, multicultural, globally capitalist world? When you see the plays performed, the questions become literally academic. In particular, the so-called "history cycle" is grossly misnamed. In reality, it is an eight-play political cycle that constantly returns to key issues of the corrupting isolation of power, the difficulty of combining justice and liberty, and the danger of division spreading through a factionalised land. But these ideas are not abstractly debated. The genius of Shakespeare is that he explores through drama the daily process of politics.

Though nominally about England, the plays have international application. Anthony Sampson recently nailed the absurdity of the ANC's proposed proscription of the pessimistic tragedies by pointing out the dependence of Nelson Mandela and his fellow Robben Island prisoners on their own heavily annotated copy of Shakespeare. But, shortly after reading last week of the internal plotting against the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, I found myself watching a precise replication of the process on stage in Henry VI Part Two. It is exactly the means by which the English nobles get rid of the all-powerful Lord Protector.

You'd be hard-pressed to find any country where the plays' analysis of power, justice and the fragile tension between order and chaos is not immediately relevant. But there is a danger in always justifying Shakespeare by his prophetic insight into current events, as if he were some kind of theatrical Nostradamus. Followed closely by Schiller, he was the best of political dramatists because he understood the mechanism of power. What I also took away from the RSC cycle was a heightened awareness of Shakespeare's moral ambivalence: his uncanny ability to see both private character and public events from every perspective.

Shakespeare's private obsessions also emerge when you see the plays in bulk. People often say we know little of Shakespeare. I'm always astonished at how much we do actually learn about him from the plays. On a trivial level, I've never noticed anyone comment on his fixation on body odour and halitosis. More seriously, sequential exposure to the histories reveals a preoccupation with fathers and sons. Was it because his own son, Hamnet, died at the age of 11? Whatever the reason, Shakespeare's obsession permeates these plays - a point brilliantly grasped by Michael Boyd, who, in the second tetralogy, casts Keith Bartlett and Sam Troughton as a succession of fathers and sons. Nothing in the whole cycle is more moving than the soldierly Talbot's belief, as he cradles his dead son in Henry VI Part One, that the two of them will somehow cheat tyrannical death by being "coupled in bonds of perpetuity".

But what you also get from seeing the plays together is a sharpened sense of the polyphonic variety of Shakespeare's language. At a lively public debate about the histories last week at the Barbican's Pit, Maureen Duffy ended the session with the observation that Shakespeare is "our linguistic rainforest". It's a dazzling aphorism, implying both multifarious variety and imminent decimation. And Duffy earlier argued that, because English risks dilution through being adopted as the language of commerce and travel, we need more than ever to hold on to the democratic abundance of Shakespearean speech.

And if any moral emerges from the RSC's big idea of staging all the histories, it is that Shakespeare should not be viewed as an elitist hobby for the lucky few but as a source of political understanding and linguistic empowerment. Even at this late date, is it too much to hope that this cycle can somehow be preserved on television?

 Henry VI and Richard III continue at the Young Vic, London SE1 (020-7928 6363), until May 26.
