fields.headline: Global's good side
fields.standfirst:
A new index of globalisation produces some results which would surprise many of yesterday's anti-capitalist protesters

Special report: May Day 2001
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: A new index of globalisation produces some results which would surprise many of yesterday's anti-capitalist protesters.
fields.body:
You would not normally call Saudi Arabia or even the United Arab Emirates "global" countries, especially in the boo-word sense used by yesterday's protesters. But they are in fact remarkably open to the world; they emit a lot more telecoms traffic than they receive. Contrast those Islamic countries with Pakistan, where incoming calls hugely outnumber messages out.

The chart shows some of the imbalances in international telecoms. They have to do with diaspora. Poland, Egypt and Vietnam are "deficit" countries in the telecoms stakes probably because large numbers of people emigrated from those countries but call home a lot. These figures are surely an indicator of globalisation. It is often painted as an anonymous process, to do with capital flows, but is also about intensely personal contact. Add to telephony remittances sent home and tourists and the picture starts to round out. It is not necessarily more positive but it is certainly more human.

Globalisation has been much blamed but little measured, the latter perhaps explaining the former. What you cannot put dimensions to is easy to fear as an unstoppable juggernaut. When you put numbers in it immediately looks less oppressive and - this is the gist of a recent essay in Foreign Policy - may even diminish. The magazine recently broke new ground by publishing an index of globalisation. It claims the rate at which globalisation has been growing has started to fall in recent years.

A word of caution, especially for those who equate globalisation with American cultural imperialism. Foreign Policy is published by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which is a not-for-profit foundation with good internationalist credentials. But the index has been compiled in collaboration with AT Kearney (a global consultant) which is owned by EDS. This is the company that bid to run UK air traffic control and, at some considerable cost, supplies IT services to the UK government. It is a company with a vested interest in... globalisation.

Which of course needs to be measured in terms of the flow of goods, services and capital. Obvious indicators include investment, capital flows and foreign income as a proportion of national income and convergence between domestic and international prices. Information technology is a proxy for "openness" so the population online and the number of internet hosts or secure servers per capita become significant. Foreign Policy's list is not exhaustive or unexceptionable. The point is, not all the indicators move in the same direction or at anything like the same speed. And the American way is not, it turns out, the global way.

The winner of the "most globalised" country prize goes to Singapore. Anti-capitalist protests would not be welcome in Lee Kuan Yew's Asian paradise but they would have to respect how he managed to insulate the country while pursuing an aggressively open policy in trade and finance. And it is open. Singapore's outgoing telephone traffic is nearly 390 minutes per year per head, four times as much as from the US.

In a different way, the countries ranked second to eighth on Foreign Policy's list of most globalised show that cultural differences or indeed versions of socialism need not be casualties of economic liberalism. For top dogs after Singapore are the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, Finland, the Irish Republic and Austria. With the exception of the Republic of Ireland, they are notoriously collectivist. The Dutch and Swedes seem to have found a way to combine trade, technological advance and tourism with high tax and public spending. Dutch foreign investment is worth 19% of GDP. Some 44% of Swedish households are online, while Finland and Norway have more than 70 web-connected servers (internet hosts) per 1,000 people.

And generous welfare benefits. Someone should tell Tony Blair and Gordon Brown that they too can have free trade and investment and social security. Foreign Policy comments "the fact that Sweden, Finland and the rest of Scandinavia have been able to nurture fast moving technological developments with lumbering regulatory and tax regimes offers an unexpected contradiction". But only to Americans and Mr Blair's advisers.

The UK comes next in the list followed by - Scandinavians again - Norway and Denmark. Then the US, not as open as all that. Proportionately, the US receives one sixth of Singapore's tourists and travellers. And Swiss citizens spend 400% more time on international phone calls than Americans. The US "posted relatively low scores in measures of economic integration and personal contact with the rest of the world" - which may be one reason for George Bush and national missile defence (Read the leader).

Israel and Malaysia feature in the top 20, signalling once again that globalisation tells you very little about domestic policy. There is no Fukuyama-esque logic here. Meanwhile many countries remain "stalled at much lower levels of integration with little indication of change". Coca-colonisation, as it used to be called, does not have much effect on underlying values and the arrival of McDonald's does not rule out progressive taxation.

On this index moreover globalisation is positively correlated with fairness. The most open countries have more equitable income distribution and score well on measures of honesty in public and commercial affairs and political pluralism.

Contrast those Islamic countries with Pakistan, where incoming calls hugely outnumber messages out. The chart shows some of the imbalances in international telecoms. They have to do with diaspora. Poland, Egypt and Vietnam are "deficit" countries in the telecoms stakes probably because large numbers of people emigrated from those countries but call home a lot. These figures are surely an indicator of globalisation. It is often painted as an anonymous process, to do with capital flows, but is also about intensely personal contact. Add to telephony remittances sent home and tourists and the picture starts to round out. It is not necessarily more positive but it is certainly more human. Globalisation has been much blamed but little measured, the latter perhaps explaining the former. What you cannot put dimensions to is easy to fear as an unstoppable juggernaut. When you put numbers in it immediately looks less oppressive and - this is the gist of a recent essay in Foreign Policy - may even diminish. The magazine recently broke new ground by publishing an index of globalisation. It claims the rate at which globalisation has been growing has started to fall in recent years. A word of caution, especially for those who equate globalisation with American cultural imperialism. Foreign Policy is published by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which is a not-for-profit foundation with good internationalist credentials. But the index has been compiled in collaboration with AT Kearney (a global consultant) which is owned by EDS. This is the company that bid to run UK air traffic control and, at some considerable cost, supplies IT services to the UK government. It is a company with a vested interest in... globalisation. Which of course needs to be measured in terms of the flow of goods, services and capital. Obvious indicators include investment, capital flows and foreign income as a proportion of national income and convergence between domestic and international prices. Information technology is a proxy for "openness" so the population online and the number of internet hosts or secure servers per capita become significant. Foreign Policy's list is not exhaustive or unexceptionable. The point is, not all the indicators move in the same direction or at anything like the same speed. And the American way is not, it turns out, the global way. The winner of the "most globalised" country prize goes to Singapore. Anti-capitalist protests would not be welcome in Lee Kuan Yew's Asian paradise but they would have to respect how he managed to insulate the country while pursuing an aggressively open policy in trade and finance. And it is open. Singapore's outgoing telephone traffic is nearly 390 minutes per year per head, four times as much as from the US. In a different way, the countries ranked second to eighth on Foreign Policy's list of most globalised show that cultural differences or indeed versions of socialism need not be casualties of economic liberalism. For top dogs after Singapore are the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, Finland, the Irish Republic and Austria. With the exception of the Republic of Ireland, they are notoriously collectivist. The Dutch and Swedes seem to have found a way to combine trade, technological advance and tourism with high tax and public spending. Dutch foreign investment is worth 19% of GDP. Some 44% of Swedish households are online, while Finland and Norway have more than 70 web-connected servers (internet hosts) per 1,000 people. And generous welfare benefits. Someone should tell Tony Blair and Gordon Brown that they too can have free trade and investment and social security. Foreign Policy comments "the fact that Sweden, Finland and the rest of Scandinavia have been able to nurture fast moving technological developments with lumbering regulatory and tax regimes offers an unexpected contradiction". But only to Americans and Mr Blair's advisers. The UK comes next in the list followed by - Scandinavians again - Norway and Denmark. Then the US, not as open as all that. Proportionately, the US receives one sixth of Singapore's tourists and travellers. And Swiss citizens spend 400% more time on international phone calls than Americans. The US "posted relatively low scores in measures of economic integration and personal contact with the rest of the world" - which may be one reason for George Bush and national missile defence (Read the leader). Israel and Malaysia feature in the top 20, signalling once again that globalisation tells you very little about domestic policy. There is no Fukuyama-esque logic here. Meanwhile many countries remain "stalled at much lower levels of integration with little indication of change". Coca-colonisation, as it used to be called, does not have much effect on underlying values and the arrival of McDonald's does not rule out progressive taxation. On this index moreover globalisation is positively correlated with fairness. fields.headline: Museums surrender over entry charges
fields.trailText: The coalition of national museums holding out against the government's free admission policy crumbled spectacularly last night with the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Science Museum announcing they would scrap charges.
fields.body:
The coalition of national museums holding out against the government's free admission policy crumbled spectacularly last night with the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Science Museum announcing they would scrap charges.

The surprise development leaves the Natural History Museum and the Imperial War Museum the only top London attractions continuing to charge, and is a victory for the culture secretary, Chris Smith.

He had made his annoyance clear at the museums' refusal to go free after changing the VAT laws in the March budget to help cushion the blow to their finances.

The V&A will be the first to abolish charges at the end of November, but its director, Mark Jones, who started the job yesterday, said the museum would also have free entry every Wednesday this month to celebrate museums and galleries month.

The Science Museum, its neighbour in South Kensington, said it too would go free in December.

The move puts pressure on the boards of the Imperial War Museum and the Natural History Museum, due to meet shortly to consider their response.

Mr Smith said: "This is very good news indeed. The government is determined to ensure that our national museums and galleries are free for all visitors, and recent tax changes in the budget have made that possible, but only if the charging museums wish it to be so.

"I wholeheartedly congrat ulate the V&A on being the first charging museum to come out in favour of free admission."

Mr Jones, who has been given six months by Mr Smith to begin to rethink how the V&A can change its slightly fuddy duddy image, timed the abolition of the £5 charge for adults to coincide with the opening of the museum's British galleries, its £31m gamble to draw back the crowds. The series of galleries will tell the story of British style and design from the Tudors to 1900.

Although the success of the V&A's blockbuster art nouveau show helped buck years of declining attendances, the outgoing director Alan Borg made no secret of his disappoint ment at the board's refusal to back him at his farewell party on Monday night.

Dr Borg, whose most cherished ambition - the building of a dramatic spiral extension to the V&A - has been put on ice, used the former chancellor, Lord Howe's, cricketing metaphor to express his sense of betrayal. "It was like going out to bat only to discover your bat has already been broken in the pavilion."

Mr Jones was more upbeat yesterday: "The British galleries are the most important project at the museum in half a century, making four centuries of British design accessible to all our visitors. And it will be wonderful to be able to open them to everyone free of charge."

webTitle: Back to basics for New Labour young artists

fields.headline: Back to basics for New Labour young artists
fields.trailText: Tie dye, embroidery, pottery, Plasticine, wood carving - it can only be the next big thing from the cutting edge of contemporary art.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Tie dye, embroidery, pottery, Plasticine, wood carving - it can only be the next big thing from the cutting edge of contemporary art.

The works might seem a refreshing change of tone at the Saatchi Gallery, whose last show included photographs of naked children and attracted the attention of the Metropolitan police obscenity squad.

However, the reclining nude modelled in French fries and the Grecian urns decorated with graphic sex scenes and a video of a Plasticine woman masturbating are unlikely to turn up in the crafts tent at a village fete.

They have in common that they are all hand made, with exquisite craftsmanship, and the work of the latest generation of young artists to be snapped up by Charles Saatchi, collector of contemporary art. He has become notorious for buying entire graduate shows of young artists, or the entire studios of work of artists he admires.

He came up with the title of the exhibition - New Labour - but the government spoiled his joke by postponing the general election, which would have coincided with the exhibition opening.

Curator Jenny Blyth said: "It's not right to talk about craft or handiwork; there's nothing folksy or crafty about these works. We are seeing a reaction to some of the machine made art and a new interest in artists making things themselves."

The artists include Enrico David, born in Ancona, Italy, in 1966 and a graduate of Central St Martins, whose images of high heeled flower headed women, worked in wool and embroidery on dyed canvas, have been described as "cro cheted super-villains of Marvel comics".

Ms Blyth has had to stretch curator-speak to the limits to describe the artists in the exhibition. She describes the work of DJ Simpson, as "somewhere between a chainsaw massacre and the dance of a bumblebee". His huge panels are first cousins to posh work tops, laminated in aluminium or Formica on to chipboard, and then assaulted with an electric router. The gouged surface is then said to recall the Australian outback, with gullies and dried river beds in a parched landscape.

She regards the 32 large pots made by Grayson Perry, who was born in Essex in 1960, as among the most beautifully made works in the show. Some are shaped like Chinese Ming vases, others like Grecian urns, with incised decoration.

"They appear classically perfect and beautiful, but when you look closely at the surface you can see that he has applied a completely contemporary twist _ he's very interested in consumerism, so there are lots of images such as mobile phones and sex scenes - like the ancient Greeks, adorning their pots with sexual encounters _ I think they're going to be a revelation."

fields.headline: Insurers 'broke code on gene information'
fields.standfirst: Watchdog attacks company for asking applicants to disclose results of breast cancer susceptibility tests
fields.trailText: The head of Britain's genetics watchdog, Lady Helena Kennedy, has attacked the insurance industry, accusing it of breaking promises of voluntary restraint in the use of genetic tests.
fields.body:
The head of Britain's genetics watchdog, Lady Helena Kennedy, has attacked the insurance industry, accusing it of breaking promises of voluntary restraint in the use of genetic tests.

She said a scientist advising both sides had a conflict of interest and hit out at the insurers Norwich Union for using a genetic test for susceptibility to breast cancer which had never been approved for insurance purposes.

Lady Kennedy is chairwoman of the human genetics commission, which yesterday called for a three year moratorium on the use of genetic tests by insurance companies, saying the existing system had failed.

The Association of British Insurers responded with a voluntary two year ban on genetic tests being factored into insurance policies worth up to £300,000.

Lady Kennedy welcomed the insurance companies' move, but said it had taken too long. She added: "We have pro found misgivings about the industry's handling of this information and its ability to keep its own house in order."

The HGC is furious that the insurance industry has not played by the rules it helped set up in the mid-1990s, when it agreed to the setting up of an advisory body, the Genetics and Insurance Committee, which would review genetic tests for susceptibility to disease and judge on whether they were scientifically reliable enough for insurance purposes.

Lady Kennedy said it had been understood that the insurance industry would only use genetic tests which the GAIC had approved.

Instead, insurers decided that they would use genetic tests until the GAIC told them not to.

She singled out the Norwich Union for demanding that insurance applicants disclose results of genetic tests for genes which predispose them to breast cancer, even though the GAIC had never ruled on whether this was acceptable.

"Here you have one of the major players breaking the industry's self-imposed code of practice. This is one of the things that quite outraged the commission," she said.

The HGC's anger was deepened when they saw that the genetics adviser to the ABI, who told the Norwich Union it was all right to proceed, was also a member of the GAIC - Sandy Raeburn, a geneticist based at Nottingham University. "The GAIC has to decide for itself how it manages itself," Lady Kennedy said. "But I would have thought [Professor Raeburn] must see his position is somewhat compromised."

Prof Raeburn's dual role has already been criticised by the Commons science and technology committee, which in March criticised him for helping the insurance industry draw up applications to use specific genetic tests and then sitting in judgment on the same applications.

"Whilst we wish in no way to cast doubt upon the integrity or ability of Prof Raeburn, who assures us he takes all possible steps to declare his relevant interests, we believe that it is an unacceptable conflict of interests for a geneticist nominated by the ABI to judge his own test application as a member of the GAIC," MPs concluded. Prof Raeburn was not available for comment yesterday.

A spokeswoman for the ABI said: "We don't accept that there is a conflict of interest. Both the GAIC and the ABI genetics advisory roles are part time, and there are obviously people on the GAIC who work in other areas too."

Growing links between diseases and particular versions of genes is leading to a growth in genetic testing for medical purposes. But while some single genes are accurate predictors of future illness, most are mere indicators of an increased risk of disease.

There is fear that a valuable diagnostic tool, and genetics research in general, could be threatened if insurers are too eager to demand disclosure of the results of tests.

Insurers argue that they should have access to glimpses into a customer's medical future, just as they have access to their medical history. But they have now offered the two-year moratorium, as recommended by the Commons committee.

In a letter to Lady Kennedy, the ABI director general, Mary Francis, said the industry recognised the depth of public concern about use of genetic information.

fields.headline: Guide to contract research
fields.trailText: There are pitfalls as well as benefits to working as a contract researcher, as Alan Williams explains in the first of this two-part feature.
fields.body:
Introduction | Doing your own research | Joining a union | Understanding your position | Hours | Authorship | Understanding your contract rights| Employment rights | Finance and pensions| Joining a pension scheme | Isolation|

Introduction
Most research in universities is carried out by contract research staff (CRS), who are on fixed-term contracts and often funded by external research contracts, where each one is directly linked to a particular piece of funding for a specific research project.

This guide is aimed at those who are considering contract research and those who have just started as CRS. It gives tips from other contract researchers indicating what you should think about before deciding to do contract research, how to get the most out of it and how to avoid some of the problems caused by the nature of contract research.

Of course, no guide will ever be a substitute for getting detailed personal advice on your particular situation from your union - the CRS experience varies enormously, even within the same department, and it is therefore impossible to cover all circumstances.

However, it is important to emphasise that, despite all of these problems, academic research is often extremely rewarding. It is a great opportunity to pursue something which you are passionately interested in, and offers flexibility, supportive colleagues in a stimulating environment, and the chance to make world-shattering discoveries, at the cutting edge of knowledge.

On the other hand, the very use of fixed-term contracts is often the cause of many of the difficulties highlighted below. Higher education unions argue that they are also extremely inefficient and do not enable institutions and researchers to pursue their work in the most productive way. The Association of University Teachers (AUT) is campaigning against the casualisation of academic staff and for the vast majority to be employed on a long-term basis.

You may agree with this (and wish to participate in union campaigns against casualisation), but here we will only look at getting the most out of the current situation, one where almost all researchers in universities are employed on fixed-term contracts.

Doing your own research
There are a lot of advantages to being a member of CRS. Hours are generally more flexible than in many jobs (but you need to check) and, in the right research group, you can enjoy your work. You may also be somewhat more protected in terms of the teaching and administration that you can be required to undertake, but you will need to find out what your position would actually be.

Find out what being CRS really involves and understand what you would be getting into. Make use of national CRS networks or look at research into CRS issues, for example Colin Bryson's research. Do you actually want to do it? Does it fit in with your career plans? One reason CRS run into trouble is because they are not clear about what they may be expected to do.

The research environment: If you decide CRS is for you, then go and meet the people that you would be working with, or who are in the same unit or department. Is it friendly and does it provide a good working atmosphere, or is it likely that you will be working in a small room isolated from everyone else? Will you have your own office or laboratory space? Will appropriate equipment be available and supported, or will you end up as the lab technician?.

The institution: This is a bit wider than the immediate research group but just as important. After all, the institution is your employer.

Not all institutions treat CRS in the same way. Find out if your institution has a code of practice for employing CRS. This should cover project management, maternity leave and pay (check carefully any qualification conditions), and provision for support at the end of a project, including bridging and redundancy. Will you get redundancy pay and does the institution operate a meaningful redeployment scheme? Do CRS have parity with established lecturing staff with respect to their terms and conditions? Will you be treated as a member of staff (as you should be), or essentially as a student? Do you have equal access to the library? Are relocation expenses paid? Will the institution charge you fees if you wish to take a further degree?

Then check if the code is actually implemented. The two important principles are that it is the university that is your employer (not the research funder or your project manager) and that you are a full member of staff (rather than a glorified student).

The research funder: Contract research is paid for from a variety of sources, including the government-funded research councils, various charities, the European Union and commercial enterprises.

All have their own interests and requirements. You should check what the particular rules attached to your funding would be, and whether they will restrict you. For example, will you be able to spend a proportion of your time on work not directly related to the project (training, teaching, your own research)? Are there any restrictions on publication or ownership of the work? Is the funder committed for the full duration of the project or is there a possibility they will stop the funding, perhaps because they are not satisfied with interim results? Does the funder allow CRS to apply for research grants in their own name?

As part of their mission, the main research councils are required to provide trained researchers. As well as funding postgraduate students, some interpret this as requiring a continuous flow of CRS, and so their policies are designed to discourage CRS from staying in universities for more than a couple of contracts.

By arming yourself with this information before you begin, you will go a long way to saving yourself from some nasty surprises or disappointments later on.

Joining a union
Fixed-term contracts themselves are the cause of many of the problems described here. Contract researchers are more vulnerable than any other staff group to being unfairly treated or dismissed, and missing out on legal entitlements. You may find it difficult to stand up for yourself unless you know that your situation is wrong and that there are people to support you. Reliable information and advice may not be available. You will not have a very loud voice on your own.

It is therefore essential that you join a union. You may not want to get actively involved, but think of it as insurance. Only a union can help effectively if anything bad happens to you, but like any insurance it can only help if you have been a member for some time prior to a crisis.

You may see your current job as a short-term thing that will end soon anyway. But there may be problems within your first contract. This may well be extended, sometimes several times, so unless you join at the start there is a danger you will be without insurance for a long time.

Also, only the unions can have any hope of influencing your pay and conditions, and then only if they're seen to represent enough CRS.

You may also wish to become active in the union in order to fight against casualisation and the second-class academic citizenship of CRS.

The AUT has a CRS committee which initiates and coordinates campaigns, responds to national developments and liaises between CRS members and the national AUT. The National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education (NATFHE) represents academic staff (more in post-1992 universities) and is also committed to reducing casualisation. The Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union (MSF) opposes short-term contracts among scientific workers and promotes greater participation by women in science, engineering and technology.

Understanding your position
Before accepting a job you should find out specifically what will be expected of you.

Will you be required to undertake any teaching, supervision or administration? Again, if you know about this beforehand, you can take appropriate action if you are not happy.

Do not let managers offload inappropriate tasks onto you, such as arbitrary teaching or administrative duties. Any teaching should have been agreed with you at the start and, in general, should be related to your research. You are there to do research - and a little teaching if that's what you want - so do not get distracted.

This is particularly true if your post is being funded by a research council or a commercial enterprise that has asked for a particular piece of work. Questions will be asked if the work is not completed, and you may get the blame, even if it's not your fault.

However, check that you will have the opportunity for personal development via training, or have some proportion of your time to pursue your own non-project research.

If you are sharing your time between more than one project, or if you are to be employed part-time, check that it is clear how much time you will be expected to allocate to a particular project. There is always the danger that the sum of the parts will be greater than the whole.

It is also useful to see the proposal for the project that you are working on. This will probably lay down quite clearly what is expected of you.

Hours
One of the perceived benefits of academic research is that you have very flexible hours and are free to work when you wish, as long as you get the job done. Many contracts do not specify hours, saying you will be expected to work "reasonable hours".

However, you should check if there are times when you will be expected or required to work. For example, will you be required to work weekends? If there are required hours, you may be happy to accept them (if they are reasonable), but at least it will be far easier to walk away or to negotiate if you are not happy. It is one thing voluntarily working certain hours, but may well be a problem for you if you have to do it.

Also check that your department's position on working from home fits in with your own wishes, working style and circumstances. Some departments forbid working from home, whereas other departments are happy for employees to work from home on a regular basis.

Authorship
When you accept, but before the project starts, get a written agreement from your project team members about authorship of papers. Make sure you are clear about the circumstances under which someone will appear as an author, and about how the order of authors will be determined. That way, the principles are laid down and you know where you stand.

Although different disciplines have their own conventions, in general, if you contribute directly (by writing) or indirectly (for example, by producing results) to a paper, then you should be included as an author.

A related and particular thorny topic concerns the inclusion in the author list of one's manager or project supervisor, even if they have made little or no contribution.

Understanding your contract rights
You should be issued with a written contract before you begin work.

Read it carefully before you accept and make sure that you understand what it is saying. Seek advice from your union if you are not certain. If it refers to other documents, get hold of them and make sure you know what they say.

 Duration: The contract should normally last as long as the project. Check that there are no probationary periods or other reviews that you did not expect.

 Conditions: Check that these match what you have been told. It is not reasonable for the contract to introduce conditions you were not already aware of. Again, ask advice from your union if you are unsure before you sign. Equally, you should question anything that you think is missing - it is dangerous to rely on verbal agreements.

When offered a research post, always check that annual increments will be applied to move you up the pay scale step by step - this doesn't always happen. Also, try to find out what your colleagues are earning, especially if you are a woman or a member of an ethnic minority. You could be a victim of unjustified discrimination.

Find out what your employment rights are so that you will be in a position to determine whether they are being honoured.

They cover important things such as maternity, pension, sick leave, pay scales, redundancy or dismissal, holiday, hours, and disability rights. If you will be working part-time, ensure that you have the same (pro-rata) conditions as your full-time colleagues.

The area is far too big to list in detail, but clearly, your union will be able to assist you. Your CRS colleagues will also be able to help, both within your institution and outside. However, it is always worth confirming any information because they may be misinformed.

Equally, do not rely on what your manager or personnel officer tells you - always double check.

It is best to resolve problems as soon as you start and to ensure that your contract makes all of the conditions of your employment clear. Verbal agreements and reassurances are not usually much use later on.

Do not let your employer get away with things just because you do not know any different - be sure to complain if they try.

Some long-term CRS have put off getting a mortgage for many years due to job insecurity, fear of unemployment or the need to move to the other end of the country to get a job in their field. In fact, much of the academic system seems to assume that people can move around at will, often for the dubious benefit of getting a short contract somewhere else.

However, due to family circumstances you may wish to settle in one area and commit to home ownership. In many cases your contract will be extended, and many mortgage lenders recognise this and are more prepared to offer a loan to CRS. You should ensure that you know when to leave well in advance of the end of your contract.

Joining a pension scheme
Just as you may think it's not worth bothering joining a union because you are only on a short-term contract, you may also think that there's no point in joining a pension scheme. But, as before, this contract may be the first of many and, before you know it, you'll have missed out on many years of pensionable service.

So join a pension scheme as soon as you start. The Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS) operates within pre-1992 universities and the Teachers* Pension Scheme (TPS) within post-1992 universities.

Isolation
This is a common situation, especially for individual researchers. Even if you join a research team, you may end up with a very restricted view of your unit or institution as a whole. You may not really be considered a member of the department - for example, you may not be "expected" to attend departmental meetings - so you have to try hard to get involved. In many departments, you may find you are pushing at open doors, although sadly, in others you may still find yourself excluded from departmental meetings because of the nature of your contract.

Find out what CRS forums operate in the institution. For instance, does the institution actively support networks of CRS representatives?

Seek to broaden your horizons by, for example, developing an interest in Fixed-Term Contract Staff (FTCS) issues via your union or CRS networks, or serving on senate. This is obviously important if situations develop in your research environment which need changing. Here you can also seek the support of the FTCS mailing list, because part of the solution is often the knowledge that you are not alone.

However, it is important to emphasise that, despite all of these problems, academic research is often extremely rewarding. It is a great opportunity to pursue something which you are passionately interested in, and offers flexibility, supportive colleagues in a stimulating environment, and the chance to make world-shattering discoveries, at the cutting edge of knowledge. Higher education unions argue that they are also extremely inefficient and do not enable institutions and researchers to pursue their work in the most productive way. webTitle: Labour advising Tory peer in race row

fields.headline: Labour advising Tory peer in race row
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Conservative party
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Lord Taylor, the black peer at the centre of the Conservative race row, has been taking advice from Trevor Phillips, the influential Labour politician, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Lord Taylor, the black peer at the centre of the Conservative race row, has been taking advice from Trevor Phillips, the influential Labour politician, it emerged last night.

Mr Phillips, a former broadcaster who is now chairman of the Greater London assembly, has been the key contact between the disaffected Lord Taylor and the Labour party.

Last night Mr Phillips said Lord Taylor was not ready to defect. But he added: "It would be terrific if John decided he wants to subscribe to Labour - if he genuinely feels we are the party that coincides with his instincts. If he decided to come across we would welcome him."

The discussions between Mr Phillips and Lord Taylor, who have known each other for more than 10 years, will fuel fears at Tory central office that Labour has played a key role in orchestrating the peer's attacks on the Tory leadership, which began when William Hague refused to withdraw the whip from John Townend after the MP made remarks about a "mongrel nation".

Lord Taylor demonstrated his continuing unease when he offered only grudging support for Mr Hague's belated action in forcing Mr Townend to withdraw his comments and apologise. The barrister indicated he would remain in the Tory party for the time being after Mr Townend and another rightwing MP, Laurence Robertson, were forced to apologise for racist outbursts. "I have made my point and am not currently planning to take the matter further," he said.

He offered support for a Tory "open letter" to the media in which black and Asian Tories praised the party for its commitment to tackling racism.

However, he indicated he was reluctant to add his name to the letter when he said: "I concur with the open letter from the Conservative parliamentary candidates. I have achieved my goal of getting the Conservative party to clearly state its commitment to a vision of Britain where racial intolerance and bigotry are totally unacceptable."

Lord Strathclyde, the Tory leader in the Lords, welcomed his statement. But Tory sources will be alarmed by the talks between Mr Phillips and Lord Taylor. Mr Phillips played down the significance of his involvement, saying he was too lowly a member of the Labour party to be involved in signing up Lord Taylor. "If [he] decided to leave there would be lots of people who will be there to help guide him across," he said.

The treatment of Lord Taylor has exposed divisions in the shadow cabinet. Mr Hague said on Monday he could not allow a Tory peer to "agonise publicly" about whether he supported the party. Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, was more understanding. He said Lord Taylor was "a loyal Conservative and I hope he will be able to relax now the position of John Townend and the party has been made so clear".

webTitle: Second MP forced to retract remarks

fields.headline: Second MP forced to retract remarks
fields.standfirst:
Hague may have calmed race row but new crop of candidates with rightwing views suggests problem will not go away

Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: William Hague asserted his authority over the Tory right for the second time in 24 hours yesterday when he forced another Conservative backbencher to retract and apologise for controversial remarks over race.
fields.body:
William Hague asserted his authority over the Tory right for the second time in 24 hours yesterday when he forced another Conservative backbencher to retract and apologise for controversial remarks over race.

In a frosty 10 minute encounter with the Tory whips, Laurence Robertson was given the same ultimatum as the outspoken rightwinger John Townend who withdrew his "mongrel" race remarks on Monday.

The MP for Tewkesbury, who praised Mr Townend on Monday night and warned of the dangers of "cramming" members of different ethnic groups into Britain, was told to sign an apology or face immediate expulsion from the party. Mr Robertson complied, raising hopes in central office that it could at last lay to rest the row over race.

His statement, which was drafted by central office, said: "I apologise for saying that John Townend's comments were right, and I retract my own comments to that effect. I undertake not to cause further embarrassment to the Conservative party, nor to give further offence to others. Nor will I repeat my remarks under any circumstances."

The leadership moved against Mr Robertson after he defied orders from the whips not to give any interviews in the wake of Mr Townend's climbdown. Mr Robertson appeared on BBC2's Newsnight on Monday night to describe his fellow rightwinger's remarks as "basically true".

The action by the whips was instrumental in persuading the Tories' most prominent black member, Lord Taylor, to declare last night that he would remain in the party. A Tory source said that the chief whip, James Arbuthnot, and the junior whip, James Cran, delivered a "tough and uncompromising message" to Mr Robertson.

However, some Tories wondered how Mr Cran could reconcile his role in forcing Mr Robertson to sign an anti-racist statement with his public refusal to sign the commission for racial equality's anti-racism pact.

Some senior Tories said last night that the statements from Mr Robertson and Lord Taylor marked an end to the Tory row over race.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said: "William Hague has used this as an opportunity to define the Conservative party to make clear we will not tolerate racism or inflammatory language and anyone who transgresses that will be dealt with."

However, Mr Hague faced renewed pressure when Lord Tebbit came close to endorsing Mr Townend's warning that Labour is turning Britain into a "mongrel race".

The former cabinet minister said he agreed with Mr Hague's action against Mr Townend, but added that he had doubts about the merits of promoting a multicultural society. "I do not know of any happy multicultural society," he told Radio 4's Today programme.

Mr Hague also faced embarrassment when the British National party said that the Tory leader was fast becoming its most effective "recruiting sergeant". In a statement on the BNP's website, the party chairman, Nick Griffin, said: "William Hague ... has managed to play the race card with sufficient vigour to break the liberal taboo on discussing the issue in public".

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide should be sold
fields.trailText: Peter Bazalgette, the man behind some of TV's biggest hits including Changing Rooms and Big Brother has called for BBC's commercial arm to be privatised, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Peter Bazalgette, the man behind some of TV's biggest hits including Changing Rooms and Big Brother has called for BBC's commercial arm to be privatised.

In an online chat with MediaGuardian, the creative director of Endemol Entertainment branded BBC Worldwide "anti-competitive".

And he said the BBC could lose its way because it was consumed by a "mania" that it had to be bigger than anyone else.

"BBC Worldwide should be privatised.

"It's anti-competitive to use publicly funded programmes to drive books, videos, magazines etc in a BBC-owned company.

"All the publishers and magazine companies should be allowed to bid for BBC business and the BBC should be paid royalties on its intellectual property," he said.

"This intellectual property 'board' at the BBC should also be allowed to take minority stakes such as the UKTV investment to ensure that it gets a return from channels with BBC programmes where there has been capital growth as a result of those programmes.

"Sometimes the BBC has a mania to be bigger and bigger but that is not actually the point of the organisation," he said.

He added that the biggest challenge for Greg Dyke "is to stay radical and not go native."

Mr Bazelgette also said that he believed the BBC was moving in the right direction by moving the Nine O'Clock News and introducing a new-look schedule on BBC1.

"I advocated moving the Nine O'Clock News two years ago in the Guardian. Greg did it because he's competitive and good for him.

"I don't really buy all these "public service" justifications. What's absurd is having politicians and regulators trying to schedule channels when there are four 24-hour news channels as well as radio, the internet etc," he said.

And he said the BBC was right to get involved in digital television. "None of us have any idea whether anything in the digital world will work. But we have to be there and the BBC's no exception. The question is how many channels, at what cost and how to ensure fair competition."

"All the publishers and magazine companies should be allowed to bid for BBC business and the BBC should be paid royalties on its intellectual property," he said. "This intellectual property 'board' at the BBC should also be allowed to take minority stakes such as the UKTV investment to ensure that it gets a return from channels with BBC programmes where there has been capital growth as a result of those programmes. "Sometimes the BBC has a mania to be bigger and bigger but that is not actually the point of the organisation," he said. He added that the biggest challenge for Greg Dyke "is to stay radical and not go native." Mr Bazelgette also said that he believed the BBC was moving in the right direction by moving the Nine O'Clock News and introducing a new-look schedule on BBC1. "I advocated moving the Nine O'Clock News two years ago in the Guardian. Greg did it because he's competitive and good for him. "I don't really buy all these "public service" justifications. What's absurd is having politicians and regulators trying to schedule channels when there are four 24-hour news channels as well as radio, the internet etc," he said. And he said the BBC was right to get involved in digital television. "None of us have any idea whether anything in the digital world will work. But we have to be there and the BBC's no exception. The question is how many channels, at what cost and how to ensure fair competition."

webTitle: St Andrews to tame its caddies

fields.headline: St Andrews to tame its caddies
fields.standfirst: One of the game's great characters, the irascible but canny Old Course guide, faces gentrification
fields.trailText: There were a lot of stunned people around St Andrews last year as Tiger Woods tore up the Old Course to win the Open by eight strokes but such dismay may prove to be as nothing compared with the feelings of a whole generation of young locals who thought they had long since done with exam papers.
fields.body:
There were a lot of stunned people around St Andrews last year as Tiger Woods tore up the Old Course to win the Open by eight strokes but such dismay may prove to be as nothing compared with the feelings of a whole generation of young locals who thought they had long since done with exam papers.

The job of caddie on the St Andrews links has historically been the last resort of the maverick. It was the calling of a man who had, often with the assistance of drink, determined his own priorities, was set in his own ways and was prepared to be accepted or rejected accordingly.

But now the St Andrews Links Trust, for reasons best known to itself, is establishing a formal caddie qualification, to be known as the St Andrews Standard. The caddie is to become qualified and certified like a common or garden doctor or dentist, or, worse still, a lawyer or a teacher.

The wonderful variety of misfits and ne'er-do-wells that have hung about the caddie shelter for generations at St Andrews is to be replaced by an assembly, doubtless forming an orderly queue, of the certified. The day of the real characters on the links is all but gone; this event heralds their official demise.

For generations the square pegs that could not be fitted into the round holes of the school room have found a place for themselves on the town's links. The renegades, for whom book learning was an anathema, flourished and flowered when they got a bag on their back on the 1st tee. They ranged from the erudite to the utterly incomprehensible, from the obsequious to the downright rude, but either way they were unforgettable.

The fact is that the St Andrews caddie was unique and was no small part of the experience of playing the Old Course. At least one American has gone home happy in the recollection that his caddie knew Old Tom Morris well. Does it really matter that his caddie was a slightly tipsy 30-year-old and that Old Tom died in 1908?

The idea of qualified, registered caddies is not new, of course. In the 1890s a local statute obliged caddies to wear tin-plate badges "at all times". To be seen without the badge warranted a small fine; to be found in a state of inebriation merited a somewhat larger penalty. In fact the badge was no great ornament in Victorian St Andrews, when the caddie was considered to be the lowest of the low, a caste of society approaching the untouchable.

In recent times the caddies have been categorised as gold, silver and bronze, to distinguish them from mere bag-carriers, according to a system based upon the individual's knowledge and experience of the links. But this system has come in for much criticism and caused disputes in the ranks of the caddies.

That said, a system of state certification based upon the Scottish Qualifications Authority is not likely to come into force without a degree of humour. It was almost inevitable that the Links Trust would aspire to an SQA-recognised test: having all but institutionalised every other aspect of the game in the town, the caddie, as a central part of the golfing experience, was not likely to be excluded from the process.

Even so it will be fascinating to see the caddies' curriculum for the educational programme and the exam for certification. For generations golf's writers have held forth about what constitutes a good caddie. In the 19th century the onus was on his prowess at the game, for he was often a playing partner in foursomes as well as the club-carrier. Later he became a guide and mentor with the emphasis on his knowledge of the playing capabilities of "his man". A "man" would have one caddie and no other for this reason.

In the early 20th century Bernard Darwin wrote of the "character" of the caddie. His personal high point came on the links at Muirfield where the boy who carried his clubs showed him a larks' nest in the rough. Darwin could not recall how he played but what he learned that round remained with him for the rest of his life.

It was not until the arrival of the American obsession with yardage and the lining up of a putt that the role of the modern caddie came about. St Andrews resisted the change and, according to childhood memory, an elderly caddie once asked a mediocre American player why he wanted to know how far away the flag was when even he knew he could not reach it.

When a player went into a bunker about which he had been forewarned, he was rightly chastised. The line to the hole on a green is one thing but propelling the ball with the right force along that line is another, and not a few caddies have painstakingly explained this fact.

Education has always been regarded as the role of the caddie and there is a world of difference between educating and conveying facts.

Companionship has come to be regarded as an important aspect of the caddie's job in recent times. With rounds of four hours commonplace there is a premium on the caddie being interesting and entertaining. For the dullest and dimmest, having a caddie that sounds like a textbook may be a good thing but the aficionado making a pilgrimage to St Andrews is unlikely to appreciate it.

Leave it to Tip

Consider Tip Anderson. Tip is a living St Andrews legend who carried a bag to three Open successes for two great champions. It is impossible to imagine Tip measuring any course, far less sitting an exam. Yet he knew the shot needed before his "man" got muddled.

One "man" who was happy to let Tip do the choosing was Tony Lema. The American known as Champagne Tony met the caddie only the day before the Open at St Andrews in 1964, having never previously laid eyes on the Old Course, and because of Arnold Palmer's absence was able to get Tip to carry his bag. Palmer had tipped Tip some $450 of his $1,350 winning prize-money after the Scot had caddied the American to the first of his two Open wins in 1961 and had urged Lema to hire him.

In gale force winds Tip gave Lema the club and called every shot. The rest is hostory: when Lema took that Open, beating Jack Nicklaus by five shots, he acknowledged that Tip had done as much as he had in the triumph and rewarded him accordingly. Lema died in an air crash in 1966 and Tip mourns his passing to this day.

David Malcolm is a golf historian

fields.headline: Wimbledon opens to kids
fields.trailText: Tennis
fields.body:
Tennis

The All England Club is opening its grass courts to children and juniors for the first time in an effort to produce future Wimbledon champions.

The home of Wimbledon has launched a junior coaching initiative to encourage children to stay in the sport and set an example to other clubs.

Britain's No1 Tim Henman said the "Road to Wimbledon initiative makes the club more accessible for younger players.

"If the premier club in the country is not doing anything [for juniors], then that is going to send out the wrong signals," he added.

"We want to change that. Some of these youngsters will witness not just what goes on in the [Wimbledon] champi onships but what goes on at the club throughout the year."

Around 1,200 local children will take part in tennis and general sport skills training sessions at the club and be given free coaching on most weekends, starting on May 12.

In addition boys and girls under-14 from the 2,400 clubs affiliated to the Lawn Tennis Association will take part in singles competitions, with finals to be played at Wimbledon on August 19-24.

The All England's chairman Tim Phillips said the club wanted more children to take up the sport: "If we are serious about wanting young people to play tennis, to stay in tennis and to dream of playing at Wimbledon, we must give them the opportunity to turn those dreams into reality."

webTitle: Wallace takes advantage of pale Swail

fields.headline: Wallace takes advantage of pale Swail
fields.trailText: Snooker
fields.body:
Snooker

Patrick Wallace, who started the season at No59 in the world rankings, took a 6-2 overnight lead against his fellow Northern Irishman Joe Swail in their best-of-25-frames world championship quarter-final at the Crucible yesterday.

Wallace may have been as surprised as anyone. "We've been practising together for about 12 years. Joe invariably wins," he had said in assessing his prospects. "I'm quite tired after winning two matches 10-2 [against Alan McManus] and 13-5 [against Mark King]. Joe is a laid-back character and playing doesn't seem to take an awful lot out of him."

Perhaps he underestimated how much nervous energy Swail had invested to beat Sean Storey, the world No99, from two down with three to play and the defending champion Mark Williams 13-12 from the unpromising position of 7-11.

Swail, a semi-finalist last year, may also have felt a burden of expectation. Certainly he played poorly although, with two sessions to play today, there is scope for recovery.

A year ago Wallace lost 10-8 to Dominic Dale in the final qualifying round and, as he sat at home watching Dale play Swail in the quarter-finals, realised it could so easily have been him instead.

Yesterday it was but he did not reproduce the form of his first two matches. There were at least three frames which he did not clinch at his first clear-cut opportunity but this was a day when he was getting two or even three chances, and he also compiled five of the session's six breaks over 40, of which his 65 was the highest.

John Higgins, finding the concentration which has eluded him since he won the UK title in November, took a 5-3 overnight lead over the 1997 champion Ken Doherty.

Reaching 3-1 with consecutive breaks of 114 and 91 Doherty was flying but a frame-winning 72 started Higgins' four-frame streak to go two frames ahead at the close.

Peter Ebdon, displaying no sign of mental fatigue from his 10hr 49min 13-12 win over Stephen Lee on Monday night, split his opening session with Ronnie O'Sullivan 4-4.

Ebdon, excruciatingly slow at times against Lee, who felt that he was "pushing the limit" in that respect, was immediately into his higher gears yesterday morning, twice leading by the odd frame through runs of 69 and 101 before O'Sullivan levelled with one of 82 and then led 3-2.

Ebdon's 40 clearance gave him the sixth on the black and, with 98, he led 4-3 before O'Sullivan's 108 brought him to 4-4 at lunch.

Matthew Stevens, at last reproducing the consistency which carried him to last year's final, went to 5-1 against Stephen Hendry, hoping to win an eighth world title two years after his seventh and 19 months after his last world-ranking title. Hendry responded with 108 but an underhit safety late in the last frame of the morning saw him return to four behind.

webTitle: Go-Racing deal gets the nod from RCA

fields.headline: Go-Racing deal gets the nod from RCA
fields.trailText: The Racecourse Association has recommended the Go-Racing media rights contract to all courses, writes Ken Oliver.
fields.body:
The Racecourse Association has recommended the Go-Racing media rights contract to all courses. Keith Brown, the RCA chairman, said: "We have thoroughly examined the contract and firmly believe that this is in the best long-term interests of the industry.

"We originally set about achieving a contract for all 59 racecourses and we are sorry that a few have fallen by the wayside. However, the remainder acting together provide a solid foundation as we move to the next stage of our strategy in partnership with the British Horseracing Board.

"The Go-Racing contract will help to keep horseracing as a mainstream British sport. It will encourage more people to follow the sport and attend race meetings."

British-trained colts were in action in Rome yesterday for the Italian 2,000 Guineas with Cauvery faring best of the three challengers.

The Sean Woods-trained colt was held up in mid-division by Frankie Dettori and made good headway in the final quarter of a mile to finish fourth behind Giovane Imperatore.

Richard Hannon's Bram Stoker and the Mick Channon-trained Cd Europe were both unplaced in the Group Two contest.

Clive Brittain's Zaheemah faded into fifth place under Dettori in the Prix Regina Elena (Italian 1,000 Guineas) after racing prominently from her outside draw. The Group Two contest was won by Bugia.

Commanche Court has been installed 8-1 co-favourite by local bookmakers Paddy Power to repeat last year's vic tory in the £130,000 Powers Gold Label Irish Grand National at Fairyhouse on Sunday.

Ted Walsh's eight-year-old heads the weights for the marathon on 12st with Micko's Dream, from the Willie Mullins' stable, next on 11st 10lb. Foxchapel King, who was runner-up last year and 8-1 co-favourite, has 10st 13lb.

The Powers Irish Grand National is the highlight of the final day of the Easter Festival at Fairyhouse which has been delayed because of the foot and mouth disease precautions.

On Saturday, the £65,000 Powers Gold Cup and the £80,000 Powers Gold Label Handicap Hurdle are the feature races.

Sackville could be opposed by Limestone Lad in the Powers Gold Cup Novice Chase over two and a half miles, while Friday evening's session that opens the three-day meeting features three of Ireland's top jumpers in the Dan Moore Handicap Chase over an extended two miles.

Mullins can chose between Florida Pearl (12st) and Micko's Dream who is rated 10lb inferior.

Moscow Express, who defeated Florida Pearl last time, has risen sharply in the weights and is now just 3lb below the top weight.

The Group Three Sagaro Stakes, over two miles, due to have been run at today's abandoned Ascot meeting, will now be included in the 2,000 Guineas programme at Newmarket on Saturday.

Kempton Park's sprint course is unraceable for the track's meeting on Monday. The sprint races have been replaced by two conditions events over one mile.

webTitle: Aldwych wins but still on trial

fields.headline: Aldwych wins but still on trial
fields.standfirst: Charlton colt will travel to York before booking his Derby ticket
fields.trailText: Aldwych, touted as Roger Charlton's Derby colt, failed to impress as a genuine Classic contender in beating the maiden When In Rome by three-quarters of a length in the Bristol Casino Tattenham Corner Stakes yesterday.
fields.body:
Aldwych, touted as Roger Charlton's Derby colt, failed to impress as a genuine Classic contender in beating the maiden When In Rome by three-quarters of a length in the Bristol Casino Tattenham Corner Stakes yesterday.

A flashy chestnut colt, he carried his head high and raced freely early on as Pat Eddery tried to anchor him and perhaps it was no surprise that after coming to win his race two furlongs out there was not much left in the locker.

Eddery got off to tactfully tell Charlton that Aldwych had needed the race badly and had run out of steam in the final furlong.

"He's having a helluva blow and he needs at least another run, probably in the Glasgow Stakes at York, before we can make any decision about the Derby," said Charlton.

"I haven't been able to do the work with him that I wanted because the gallops have been waterlogged but at the moment I'd say he was all of a 25-1 shot for the race.

"Having said that he'll improve and he should stay a mile and a half. I'm not that excited but remember at this stage nobody thought Quest For Fame (Charlton's 1990 Derby winner) was going to win."

Of more immediate concern for Charlton is Saturday's 2,000 Guineas and his runner Frenchmans Bay, second to Munir in the Greenham Stakes on his reappearance.

"He worked well with Welcome Friend yesterday morning and Pat was very happy with him," said Charlton. "He's got to improve on his Greenham running but he got bumped there two or three times and the race turned into a sprint. I'd say we've got a realistic shot at the race. I think it's a very open Guineas."

The decision of Richard Hills to ride Munir for his father Barry rather than Nayef has come as no great surprise and Hills senior commented: "It's nothing to do with sentiment or family ties; Richard believes he's chosen the better horse.

"Munir hasn't done a lot since winning the Greenham but will work tomorrow morning - they thrive on nourishment rather than punishment.

"This horse has got a turn of foot and if the ground continues to dry at Newmarket it will suit him. I've no worries about the extra furlong there finding him out."

In other jockey news John Carroll was handed the ride on Godolphin's Rumpold. In his only race to date the colt beat subsequent Middle Park Stakes winner Minardi by five lengths in a maiden at Ascot last July. Rumpold won the Godolphin colts' 'trial' last month under Frankie Dettori, who will be on the team's ante-post favourite Tobougg (third) this Saturday.

Bryan McMahon sent out his third first-time-out two-year- old winner of the season when Guns Blazing ran on strongly after being slowly away to beat Boxer Bill in the opener at Bath.

Guns Blazing was pretty fit for his racecourse debut but needed plenty of assistance in the saddle from Willie Supple to overcome his tardy start.

McMahon has 16 juveniles but the stable star is the five-year-old Now Look Here who won the Cammidge Trophy at Doncaster. He goes for the Palace House Stakes at Newmarket on Guineas day.

Sylvester Kirk, former assistant to Richard Hannon, had his first turf winner since he started training at Lambourn in January when Silver Tango survived a stewards inquiry in the second division of the opening maiden.

Lee Newman was banned 14 days for misjudging the finish on Lady Two K who finished second to April Stock in the Showcase Handicap

"Having said that he'll improve and he should stay a mile and a half. I'm not that excited but remember at this stage nobody thought Quest For Fame (Charlton's 1990 Derby winner) was going to win." Of more immediate concern for Charlton is Saturday's 2,000 Guineas and his runner Frenchmans Bay, second to Munir in the Greenham Stakes on his reappearance. "He worked well with Welcome Friend yesterday morning and Pat was very happy with him," said Charlton. "He's got to improve on his Greenham running but he got bumped there two or three times and the race turned into a sprint. I'd say we've got a realistic shot at the race. I think it's a very open Guineas." The decision of Richard Hills to ride Munir for his father Barry rather than Nayef has come as no great surprise and Hills senior commented: "It's nothing to do with sentiment or family ties; Richard believes he's chosen the better horse. "Munir hasn't done a lot since winning the Greenham but will work tomorrow morning - they thrive on nourishment rather than punishment. "This horse has got a turn of foot and if the ground continues to dry at Newmarket it will suit him. I've no worries about the extra furlong there finding him out." In other jockey news John Carroll was handed the ride on Godolphin's Rumpold. In his only race to date the colt beat subsequent Middle Park Stakes winner Minardi by five lengths in a maiden at Ascot last July. Rumpold won the Godolphin colts' 'trial' last month under Frankie Dettori, who will be on the team's ante-post favourite Tobougg (third) this Saturday. Bryan McMahon sent out his third first-time-out two-year- old winner of the season when Guns Blazing ran on strongly after being slowly away to beat Boxer Bill in the opener at Bath. Guns Blazing was pretty fit for his racecourse debut but needed plenty of assistance in the saddle from Willie Supple to overcome his tardy start. McMahon has 16 juveniles but the stable star is the five-year-old Now Look Here who won the Cammidge Trophy at Doncaster. He goes for the Palace House Stakes at Newmarket on Guineas day. Sylvester Kirk, former assistant to Richard Hannon, had his first turf winner since he started training at Lambourn in January when Silver Tango survived a stewards inquiry in the second division of the opening maiden. Lee Newman was banned 14 days for misjudging the finish on Lady Two K who finished second to April Stock in the Showcase Handicap

webTitle: Weekes tweaks a measure of revenge

fields.headline: Weekes tweaks a measure of revenge
fields.trailText: Surrey 146-2 v Middlesex Match abandoned
fields.body:
Surrey 146-2 v Middlesex Match abandoned

The battle of London was an anticlimax after all. The players were forced off by rain at 12.55 and there was no protest when the match was abandoned three hours later.

Before the obligatory southern monsoon arrived, the home side were threatening to preserve the established order. Surrey have not lost to Middlesex in any competition since 1995 and they were making confident progress towards a match-winning total.

Ian Ward again demonstrated the compact technique and judicious stroke play that has turned him into an England possible. He struck his first ball of the day to the boundary, a classy forcing stroke through square cover off Angus Fraser, and reached 71 not out from 95 balls.

There is nothing flashy about his batting but he has developed the useful knack of making the most of his ability. He needs to impress to make his mark in this Surrey side. He was the only batsman in their line-up yesterday not to have played for England.

There was little in the pitch so Fraser's decision to put Surrey in must have been based on a preference for chasing the target. Only one delivery beat the bat before Mark Butcher was caught behind off Simon Cook in the 12th over.

Surprisingly Mark Ramprakash's arrival at the crease brought no discernible rise in the noise level from his former colleagues. Instead they chose to freeze him out.

Ramprakash seemed determined to make the most of what is likely to be his only innings this season against his old county. He turned his second ball through square-leg for four and, when Chad Kee gan came on for his first bowl for the county, he glanced the pace bowler to the rope and later forced him through extra-cover for another boundary.

For 36 deliveries Ramprakash was untroubled. But the 37th was a beauty. Paul Weekes defeated him in the flight as he pushed forward and the ball spun back to hit the top of off-stump. The celebrations were enthusiastic yet well controlled.

fields.headline: Taylor enforces the old order
fields.standfirst: Benson & Hedges Cup
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 213-9 Gloucestershire 213-6 Gloucestershire won having lost fewer wickets
fields.body:
Warwickshire 213-9 Gloucestershire 213-6 Gloucestershire won having lost fewer wickets

The one-day wizards of Gloucestershire conjured up an extraordinary last-ball trick yesterday having seemed dead for most of the match. When the diminutive Chris Taylor stepped back and carved Vasbert Drakes to the extra-cover boundary the visitors had levelled the scores, winning because they lost three fewer wickets.

Warwickshire had seemed in control ever since recovering from the early loss of four batsmen, until some uncultured yet exhilarating biffing by Matt Windows and Mark Al leyne suddenly revived the Gloucester corpse.

The visitors started well, reducing Warwickshire to 39 for four, but a revival was fashioned by Dominic Ostler and his new skipper Mike Powell, who added 136 in 28 restorative overs, posting a fifth-wicket record for the county in this competition. They were gaining momentum and moving towards a commanding total on a quiet pitch when Powell heaved his opposite number Alleyne to Windows on the mid-wicket boundary. Then Ostler was yorked by Ian Harvey and the innings fell away to close modestly at 213.

The Australian all-rounder Harvey achieved his best B&H figures of five for 32 when Richard Williams stumped Keith Piper to complete the home innings. Williams has spent his career as Jack Russell's understudy, one of the more frustrating jobs in cricket, and over 10 seasons has appeared only 66 times in all competitions. But Russell is nursing a slipped disc that will sideline him for another month and Williams took his chance, claiming four victims.

In the second half of the piece the home bowlers threw a lasso around the Gloucestershire batsmen. Though Rob Cunliffe and Kim Barnett added 77 after the early loss of Tim Hancock - the first scalp for Melvyn Betts in his new home - they could progress at only three runs per over. The bowling of Mohammad Sheikh was particularly stifling; in 10 overs of steady medium pace he let slip only 27 runs and snapped up a reflex caught-and-bowled to dismiss the experienced Barnett.

Cunliffe's steady 75 may prove an important innings for a batsman now in his eighth season at Bristol. He could not establish a regular place in last year's all-conquering one-day side and in the championship his average barely crawled into double figures. He was just beginning to pick up speed when Dougie Brown clean-bowled him; and, when Brown immediately produced the same ball for the dangerous Harvey, Gloucestershire's cause seemed hopeless.

Warwickshire should question whether they let the noose slacken a little with the kill almost complete but that would be to take away from Windows' inspired cameo, holding firm for 42 before being caught by Powell off Betts.

From the last four overs 37 were required; when Windows and Alleyne were dismissed with a triumphalist roar a further nine were needed from the final over to tie.

For the penultimate ball Drakes produced a perfect yorker but then panicked, conceding an overthrow with a needless shy at the stumps. When Taylor crashed the last ball into the fence, the crowd departed in silence.

webTitle: Stand-in captain leads from the front

fields.headline: Stand-in captain leads from the front
fields.trailText: Glamorgan 232-6 Somerset 233-4 Somerset won by six wickets
fields.body:
Glamorgan 232-6 Somerset 233-4 Somerset won by six wickets

Twice in a matter of days Marcus Trescothick has scored a hundred at Sophia Gardens. The statistics alone tell nothing. This was batting of a high order, something to be watched and applauded.

The marvel of Trescothick is the way he has visibly grown in confidence, acquiring stature, wisdom and above all a mature technique. It would be premature to talk of Woolley but here is a Somerset boy of equable temperament and innate skills, exhibited partially under the tutelage of Duncan Fletcher, moving magically into another sphere.

He was captain in this match because Jamie Cox had a groin strain and he manifested all the enthusiasm of a cricketer who wants to play every match for his county, not just when his central contract dictates.

Somerset won with three overs to spare. Trescothick's innings, halted just before the end when he was out to a well-judged running catch by Michael Powell, contained 10 boundaries and came off 118 balls.

Whether driving Darren Thomas through the covers, square-cutting Steve Watkin or turning effortlessly off his pads, there was a lethal proficiency about him. One can overlook Watkin's failure to hold on to a return catch as he followed through.

Keith Dutch, the Middlesex exile, was significantly promoted in the batting order. His answer was a good-looking 55, almost his best one-day score.

Briefly Trescothick and Mark Lathwell were together at the wicket, recalling erstwhile images of Somerset's supposedly long-term openers. Lathwell's first appearance of the season still carried hints of technical torment and then, within the game's crueller context, he was run out following an overthrow.

Glamorgan had earlier done themselves a disservice with their running. Steve James went that way to Mike Burns at midwicket, Adrian Dale to a direct throw in the deep from Richard Johnson, and Matthew Maynard as he tried to give Powell a third run.

All were untimely; James and Maynard had been in no discomfort and Somerset were fielding better than they were bowling. The best of their batting came from Powell, firm and judicious with his shots and, as everyone in the principality has agreed since his double century debut in 1997, offering reminders of the richness of his promise.

 Jimmy Daley hit 70 and Neil Killeen took four for 18 from eight overs as Durham beat Lancashire, last year's semi-finalists, by 54 runs at Liverpool.
