fields.headline: Push for all-year England players
fields.standfirst: Fletcher and Graveney want full control over nucleus of Test stars
fields.trailText: England's top players could soon be employed on year-round central contracts. Ideally the England coach Duncan Fletcher and David Graveney, chairman of selectors, would like a nucleus of up to 16 players over whom they could exert total control for 12 months.
fields.body:
England's top players could soon be employed on year-round central contracts. Ideally the England coach Duncan Fletcher and David Graveney, chairman of selectors, would like a nucleus of up to 16 players over whom they could exert total control for 12 months.

In so doing they would be removing the players from any small influence that the first-class counties may still maintain over their stars. At present 12 players are expected to sign contracts for the summer, the second season such a system has operated.

However, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) would wish to ensure that full-time contracts would not leave them with players unable to make the international squads at home or winter touring parties but still receiving extra payment, as happened last year with the Lancashire leg-spinner Chris Schofield and the former Kent fast bowler Dean Headley, who has since retired because of injury.

Two solutions are likely to be proposed, neither of which would carry massive appeal to all the cricketers. Contracts could be revised to consist of a retainer backed up with substantial appearance money; or the longer-term contracts could apply to just a select band of players certain to be involved in Tests throughout the year.

However, the factional element that the latter could bring into the dressing room is not likely to gain the approval of Fletcher or the captain Nasser Hussain.

For the moment, though, the dozen select players must settle for a six-month commitment. According to a board source, the latest contracts had a few strictly finance-based "wrinkles" to iron out but these have been sorted and the contracts, approved and dispatched, now await only signature and return.

Already, though, the players have started to come under Fletcher's control. Yesterday, after addressing Cricket Live 2001, the ECB's world cricket coaches conference and exhibition at Telford, he revealed that, with the first Test against Pakistan due to start a fortnight tomorrow, there was an imperative to get cricket for all the players.

Fletcher admitted, though, that the poor weather was a cause for concern. "Of course it is," he said, "but it will be the same for the Pakistanis. They will get the same situation and play in rain-affected games as well, so it equals out. However, we shall be doing all we can.

"We want our guys to be prepared for the first Test but this is something that happens every year with the weather playing its part."

Fletcher had been keen for the England touring party to get proper rest after the most rigorous winter that anyone can recall and until yesterday's round of Benson & Hedges Cup matches only five contracted players - Marcus Trescothick, Michael Vaughan, Nasser Hussain, Dominic Cork and Matthew Hoggard - had appeared in matches.

Hoggard sustained a rib injury in his appearance for Yorkshire at Canterbury last week and Fletcher hopes to hear the results of a scan today and to get him bowling again.

"All the players will be playing for their counties from here on in," Fletcher stressed, "although Darren Gough and Craig White will be missing two one-day games". There is, however, only one round of County Championship games before the opening Test at Lord's.

Pakistan, meanwhile, only hours before they were due to depart for England, have confirmed that the English-born South African Richard Pybus is to coach them during their tour, with the possibility of an extension beyond that. The Pakistanis had removed their previous coach Javed Miandad, one of nine incumbents in the position in four years, after the recent tour of New Zealand. Pybus coached the side during the 1999 World Cup but was later sacked.

Pakistan have also published a report which says their pace bowler Shoaib Akhtar's action has always been legal because he has an "abnormal" arm.

The Pakistan Cricket Board added that Shoaib, who has twice been reported for throwing, has agreed to remodel his action to reduce the risk of injury, not because his action was faulty.

webTitle: Big Brother to go on radio

fields.headline: Big Brother to go on radio
fields.trailText:
Big Brother will be broadcast on the radio, as well as Channel 4, when it returns for a second run later this month. By Jason Deans.

02.05.2001: How Baz answered your questions

02.05.2001: Big Brother 2 for end of May
fields.body:
Big Brother will be broadcast on the radio, as well as Channel 4, when it returns for a second run later this month.

Peter Bazalgette, the creative director at Big Brother producer Endemol Entertainment UK, revealed the show's new dimension during an online chat on the mediatheguardian.com website this afternoon.

"Big Brother this summer will be really exciting because as well as the terrestrial TV and web, as last year, we'll have the UK's first major enhanced TV offering on E4, an SMS text messaging service, and radio packages," said Mr Bazalgette.

He also talked about a new Endemol show for Channel 4 called Bar Wars, which gives a novel twist to the reality game show genre launched by Big Brother.

Several thousand wannabe contestants have already responded to late night on-air Channel 4 advertisements for the show.

Bar Wars will pit two teams of six contestants against each other in a bid to run the most successful bar in a Spanish resort.

The series will be shot this summer.

Related stories

fields.headline: £100m promised to maternity services
fields.trailText: A £100 million cash injection for maternity services to ensure every woman has one-to-one, continuous care with a midwife during labour was announced by health secretary Alan Milburn today.
fields.body:
A £100 million cash injection for maternity services to ensure every woman has one-to-one, continuous care with a midwife during labour was announced by health secretary Alan Milburn today.

An extra 2,000 midwives will also be on wards in England by 2005, with 500 in place by the end of next year, Mr Milburn pledged.

All 250 NHS maternity units in England will receive extra funds to refurbish and modernise facilities in a bid to eliminate big variations in the standard of maternity care throughout the UK.

Mr Milburn announced the extra investment at the Royal College of Midwives (RCM) annual conference in Torquay this morning.

He told delegates: "Today I am setting a new ambition for the health service: modern maternity services as the foundation for giving each and every child in our country the very best start in life.

"Maternity services that give women and families more choice over the care they receive so that every child, regardless of background or circumstance, has the best possible start in life."

The RCM has warned that chronic staff shortages and lack of investment in maternity services are putting women's lives at risk and driving midwives from the health service.

Women are often left alone during labour because there are not enough staff to provide continuous care, a situation which some claim is linked to the rising rate of Caesareans and other interventions during childbirth.

The £100 million will be used to modernise maternity units, provide single rooms for more privacy and equip them with televisions and telephones.

There will also be rooms on maternity units for new fathers, particularly for those whose babies need special care.

A National Service Framework (NSF) on maternity services is to set down new national standards which will ensure that every woman has access to a midwife, dedicated to them, throughout labour.

Mr Milburn said the NSF would end the "lottery of childbirth choices" for women in England.

Mothers-to-be would be given more choices, including the right to have a home birth, the health secretary said.

Mr Milburn said that trained midwives who want to return to the NHS and first need to complete a refresher course will be given a one-off payment of £1,500 to help them through the retraining period.

Mr Milburn said: "We need to increase the number of midwives and make midwifery a more rewarding career. Choice for women cannot be there when there are shortages of midwives in too many parts of our country.

"Continuity of care cannot be there when there are too many variations in standards and in access to services.

"Those parts of the country with the greatest need - and the biggest shortages - will benefit from the biggest expansion in midwife numbers."

The RCM's deputy general secretary Louise Silverton broadly welcomed the announcement but said she needed to see "more detail" on how the initiatives would be implemented.

Professor Robert Shaw, President of The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists said the cash for capital improvements in obstetric services would help to improve the environment in which obstetricians and midwives work and provide better facilities for patients.

"Those parts of the country with the greatest need - and the biggest shortages - will benefit from the biggest expansion in midwife numbers." The RCM's deputy general secretary Louise Silverton broadly welcomed the announcement but said she needed to see "more detail" on how the initiatives would be implemented. Professor Robert Shaw, President of The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists said the cash for capital improvements in obstetric services would help to improve the environment in which obstetricians and midwives work and provide better facilities for patients.

fields.headline: Murdoch group denies May Day downplay
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: News International has refuted suggestions of a group-wide policy to downplay the importance of the May Day protests. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
News International has refuted suggestions of a group-wide policy to downplay the importance of the May Day protests.

A spokeswoman for the company said the decision to push the coverage back in both the Sun and the Times had been at the discretion of each paper's editor.

Aside from the Express Group, Rupert Murdoch's News International was the only newspaper group that didn't splash with the story.

Asked why this was the case at the Sun, a spokeswoman said: "Because we had a very good exclusive on the front page."

The Sun's front page was a poll that said had the election not been postponed, Tony Blair would have won a resounding victory on May 3.

The Sun relegated its May Day story to page 12, but of all the papers, it took the strongest view against the protests.

Lines such as "Yobs take to streets" and "Riot mob face ring of steel by police" were used next to agency pictures of "raging" and "screaming" protestors.

If this wasn't enough to convince readers that the Sun was taking a stand against the protests, a small leader was.

"The police did a marvellous job in tackling the May Day protest... Our policemen and women are a superb bunch."

Fellow Murdoch-owned paper the Times waited until page four to mention the protests.

The Times editorial position chimed with that of the Sun's criticising the "anarchists".

webTitle: What drives a father to kill his entire family?

fields.headline: What drives a father to kill his entire family?
fields.standfirst: Angela Neustatter on an unthinkable tragedy
fields.trailText: Angela Neustatter on an unthinkable tragedy.
fields.body:
It is the broad smile on the face of Robert Mochrie that makes the family photograph, taken when his wife Cathy was awarded a degree at Cardiff University, so striking. There he stands, every bit the proud paterfamilias, surrounded by the four children he is said to have cared for devotedly. Yet this same father, described by his wife's closest friend as "one of the least aggressive men I knew", coolly plotted to kill his entire family - cancelling the milk and his daughter's lift to school so that he would not be disturbed when bludgeoning them, one by one, to death.

Of all violent crimes, those where the parent is the criminal are the most grimly baffling. How can parents turn on their children, hearing their cries, perhaps, and seeing their terrified faces, and murder them? The fact that it is so hard for most of us to get close to understanding gives an urgency to the question: how could a father like Robert Mochrie do it?

We will never know the answer from Mochrie himself, a hotel owner from Haverfordwest in South Wales because, a Cardiff inquest was told last week, he hanged himself after murdering his wife, Cathy, along with Bethan, 10, Luke, 14, Sian, 16, and James, 18, in July last year. What we do know is that, although these homicide-suicides (as they are known) are rare enough to shock profoundly, this was not a freak case. According to Edinburgh-based forensic psychologist Dr Keith Ashcroft, whoseresearch has shown over years an average of around 0.2 per 100,000 of the population, "It appears they are becoming more common."

In recent years we have seen a series of disturbing paternal murders. Last month, Phillip Austin attacked his wife Claire with a mallet, threw her downstairs and stabbed her to death. He then collected their children from school, drugged them with sleeping pills and strangled them. In March last year, when Zainulabedin Zaidi arrived to pick up his children for an access visit, he slashed the neck of his ex-wife Shazia with a knife in front of their two children. Then, ignoring the screams of "Don't kill me, Daddy", he stabbed both to death. In both cases, the men were arrested and convicted, but most often, says Ashcroft, these fathers kill themselves afterwards.

Such was the case with John Chetwynd, who in 1997 attacked his wife with a baseball bat before driving to Beachy Head, Sussex, where he jumped to his death, taking with him his three sons; and Justin Philpott, who, during a custody dispute in 1998, killed himself and his two young sons in a fume-filled car.

Gerard Bailes, a psychologist with the East Anglia regional forensic service, describes the kind of murder it appears Mochrie committed. They are, he says, the result of a psychotic breakdown in which the father becomes disassociated from reality: "He may be driven by delusions that make him think he is acting out of love, saving his children from intolerable or dangerous circumstances, or he may believe that his children are possessed. In this state, normal empathy has gone and the man is flooded with overwhelming feelings, hallucinations and compulsive drives. The father may indeed be able to look at the children he is killing but, because he is so cut off from feeling, what he sees has no meaning. It is not unusual for these men to plan their actions calmly and, indeed, during the planning stage, they may feel very calm. They are simply doing what must be done."

Although such extreme behaviour often seems to erupt without warning, once a picture of the background is pieced together, there are often indications that the man has been struggling with stress, sleeping and eating badly and possibly drinking too much, so that his emotional thermostat is off kilter. Depression is a common symptom, too. Mochrie is described as having been stressed at work; he had serious financial problems and had suffered acute depression, which he kept secret from his family and treated with anti-depressants. He visited prostitutes regularly, and it emerged that his wife had been having an affair, all of which suggests there were serious domestic problems. At the inquest, psychiatrist Dr Brian Harris concluded that Mochrie had "delusions of doom and disaster coming to his family and he was trying to protect them".

The more familiar type of paternal killing occurs when a relationship has broken down and the man feels he has been rejected by his wife and lost his children. Zaidi's wife, for example, had obtained a divorce and remarried a man who had taken on the children. In another instance, Kenneth McKay, whose partner had left him to escape a violent relationship, clearly intended to kill his six-year-old son and four-year-old daughter when he took them hostage at their home in Fleetwood, Lancashire, and slashed at their throats with a six-inch knife. When his son managed to push a key under the door and the police forced their way in, McKay cut his own throat in front of his children.

'The overwhelming urge in these men is to hurt the mother as much as they can," argues Adam Jukes, a psychotherapist working with violent men and author of Why Men Hate Women (Free Association Books), "They know that the cruellest thing they can do is to kill the children and leave her alive. It is the ultimate act of revenge. They are propelled by the same desire to control that frequently means these men have used intimidation and violence to control their partners in other circumstances."

Vic Seidler, author of Man Enough (Sage), a sociological study of masculinity, takes a similar view. "These men cannot bear the idea that another man may take their place in their children's lives, so they decide to kill them. The rationalisation is: 'It would be intolerable for them to live without me.' " Although nothing, Seidler stresses, justifies what they do, we would do well to recognise how unequally men are still treated as regards children when relationships break down.

"At the same time, many of today's men no longer have the traditional role they once did, and they may have invested more in their children than generations of men before have," he continues. "So the sense of loss is greater and there is a feeling of injustice - that they have done what they are told is right and been involved fathers but, when it comes to a split, that counts for nothing. They feel very distressed and angry."

This is an argument that the campaigning group Families Need Fathers also advance: that women too often punish their former partners by doing all they can to prevent contact. Bradshaw, Stimson, Skinner and Williams, the authors of Absent Fathers? (Routledge), find similarly that men in regular contact with their children were likely to be calmer than those who did not: "A major grievance was the difficulties fathers had seeing their children," they note.

The tragedy is that these deaths might have been prevented if the men had gone for help and acknowledged their stresses and fears. One of the reasons men commit these murders more often than women, suggests Bailes, is that they feel "it is not macho to admit that they can't cope". Instead, he says, "They insist even to themselves that nothing is wrong." So, tragically, it seems to have been with Robert Mochrie - a man whose neighbours declared "was the last person on Earth you would expect to do anything like this", and yet committed the most unimaginable of acts.

fields.headline: Asking daddy for the moon
fields.standfirst: Lots of work to do, parents everywhere looking tense - must be science project time again, says Paul Morley
fields.trailText: Lots of work to do, parents everywhere looking tense - must be science project time again, says Paul Morley
fields.body:
Did you know that when the Apollo 12 astronauts landed on the moon, the impact caused the moon's surface to vibrate for 55 minutes? That Neil Armstrong first stepped on the moon with his left foot? And that, as recently as 1988, 13% of the American population thought that there was some portion of the moon that was actually made of cheese?

Yes, it's school-science-project time, and my nine-year-old daughter Madeleine, Jetsons lover and Futurama freak that she is, has decided to marvel at the moon, earth's nearest neighbour in space. It was either that or the different temperatures at which metals melt, and the moon in the end had the bigger pull. That's the great thing about the moon - its pull. For something that has no global magnetic field, it has a hell of a pull.

Maddy, who can ask more "why?" questions per hour than anyone on the planet, had a series of questions about the moon, ranging from its age and weight to whether she'll be able to holiday there when she's a teenager. They all sounded pretty scientific to me, so a project was born.

Once Maddy had decided on her topic, she handed it over to her team, which consists, in the modern way, of various parents, step-parents and grandparents. It's no use pretending otherwise - science-project time means that the child adopts theposition of auteur, handing out instructions with needy cool, and parents et al scurry around to fulfil the tasks demanded of them, adopting the roles of set designer, scriptwriter, cinematographer, etc.

It's her thing. She'll have her name on it. She's driving it. But I hope when she's handed her award, she'll remember the little people behind the scenes that helped her make that moon model, and worked out just what kind of cheese the moon would be if it actually was made of cheese. And when she sings her chosen moon song in her presentation - either Moon Shadow or Walking on the Moon (we've not quite made our minds up yet) - I hope she remembers that the song was my idea. Unless, of course, the school decides a song isn't very scientific and deducts a few points. Then I hope she remembers that I was only joking, although I am considering suggesting that she begin her presentation with a quick version of Michael Jackson's moonwalk.

You can tell it's science-project time by looking around at the other parents, and noticing how tense they all look. They're all under pressure to ensure that their child's dreams for a science project come true, and that the result is somewhere between Einstein and Disney and includes a handful of patents pending. It's a big production version of the daily homework thing. The school politely asks that the child does the homework, not the parent, but you notice that child A, or E, seems a little more, shall we say, perfect than might be the case. You suspect parental help, so you help your own child a little bit. The last thing you want is a sign of your child slipping behind.

Very soon, you realise that there is widespread parental help involved in all children's homework, and the school gradually increases the difficulty of homework in response to this, and there becomes a greater need for parental help. (If the parents suddenly stopped helping, there would be three hours of homework a night, and a mass child revolution.) This competitive spiral increases in intensity until science-project time, and by then you imagine that child A, or E, with various degrees of parental influence, may come up with some unified theory of everything, or a perpetual motion machine.

There's nothing like helping your child do their science project for raising your game. Faced with the thought of child A's time machine - A asks her team for a time machine, and you imagine that, on previous form, she'll get it - I have been trying to track down Neil Armstrong so that he can make a personal appearance at Maddy's presentation, asked Brian Eno to write some accompanying music, and lined up Tom Stoppard to do a polish on the script.

Seriously, in case any of Maddy's teachers are reading this (hello, Mr Bain), Maddy had all the ideas. She has been to the dark side of the internet and back. Her team has just bought the materials and encouraged her when she lost her motivation. By the end of this year's project, she will know more about the moon than the man in the moon. It doesn't really matter how good her rivals - er, classmates - are, as long as she comes out of this with moon passion intact. But being competitive just for a moment (because, after all, I'm only a parent), if she achieves her vision, only the time machine can beat her. Then again, I'm a little worried about that boy and his experiment with the turnip. I wish Neil would hurry up and get back to me.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst:
The question: In her will Linda McCartney left money in trust for her children rather than giving it to them all at once. Would you do the same?

Interviews by Diane Taylor
fields.trailText: In her will Linda McCartney left money in trust for her children rather than giving it to them all at once. Would you do the same?
fields.body:
Lisa Fabian Lustigman
Head of family law, Rayner de Wolfe

It depends on individual circumstances, but I think that for a wealthy, media-oriented family such as the McCartneys, Linda did the right thing. Leaving money to her husband, with a trust fund for the children, is a sensible thing to do. If you are making a will when your children are young, you may not want them to come into millions at 18 because how much common sense do 18-year-olds have? This is a course of action I would recommend to all clients: even if parents don't have vast wealth, they often have a house to leave which may be worth quite a lot.

Mike Boyle
Policy director for asylum seekers

This sounds a bit like a private version of the government's bond scheme - but there's probably more in the McCartney trust fund! I think the course of action depends on the age of your children (with luck, most parents will still be around when their grandchildren are born). It's a good idea to put money into trust because, for most people, it's not healthy to come into large sums of money too young; it's better to stagger the payments over time. If my estate is worth anything by the time I die, I would want to do what Linda McCartney has done.

Greg Hadfield
Chairman, schoolsnet education website

My son Tom is 18, my daughter Lucy 22; both are old enough to be trusted with fairly big decisions about money. I think once they are 18, they can handle money. It's not just Linda McCartney - 66% of us own our own houses - the trickle-down effect is coming to the second, even third generation. When you die, you have to trust succeeding generations to behave responsibly. My son has been wealthy on paper since his mid-teens. It's important that, from an early age, you educate children so that they can put money and material possessions into context.

So Lin Jeffery
Local government head of communications

Leaving your home to your children doesn't feel the same as leaving them a lot of money in your will. If I did have a lot of money to leave, I would think of ways and means of leaving it so that a windfall couldn't be spent all at once. It's important that children understand the value of money. When you give money away, it's a kind of love because it's your blood, sweat and tears that have earned that money to pass on. For a child to receive all that in one lump sum means they might not appreciate what their parents had been through to earn the money.

Neil Taylor
Literary agent, TaylorMilner

Everything I want to leave to my kids is everything money can't buy - love and time. I think the words of the Beatles song are very true - Money Can't Buy You Love - not when you're six feet under, anyway. I think it's good the way Linda McCartney has arranged things for her children: she must have known her kids would never be hard up, but I think it's great that they have all got jobs and are working. I haven't got lots of money to leave to my kids, but I do have a first-edition literary collection and a poster collection, but my kids probably wouldn't want them - they might be better off in a museum.

Laurence Oates
Official solicitor and public trustee

Not everyone has the assets Linda McCartney had. For anything but a simple legacy, it is usual for a trust to be created when assets are left to a child under 18. To set up a trust fund yourself has the advantage that it enables you to determine the circumstances. For under 18s, the trust enables capital to be invested until the child receives the money and meanwhile allows control by the trustees over how the income and capital are applied. For an adult, the assets are usually paid immediately. A trust fund could still be considered, depending upon his or her financial competence.

I think the words of the Beatles song are very true - Money Can't Buy You Love - not when you're six feet under, anyway. I think it's good the way Linda McCartney has arranged things for her children: she must have known her kids would never be hard up, but I think it's great that they have all got jobs and are working. I haven't got lots of money to leave to my kids, but I do have a first-edition literary collection and a poster collection, but my kids probably wouldn't want them - they might be better off in a museum. For anything but a simple legacy, it is usual for a trust to be created when assets are left to a child under 18. To set up a trust fund yourself has the advantage that it enables you to determine the circumstances. For under 18s, the trust enables capital to be invested until the child receives the money and meanwhile allows control by the trustees over how the income and capital are applied. For an adult, the assets are usually paid immediately. A trust fund could still be considered, depending upon his or her financial competence.

fields.headline: Give us a break
fields.standfirst: The government's new parental leave scheme seems a lifesaver for parents who struggle to balance work and family. But, as Anna Macarthur reveals, there's a catch
fields.trailText: The government's new parental leave scheme seems a lifesaver for parents who struggle to balance work and family. But, as Anna Macarthur reveals, there's a catch.
fields.body:
It is the perpetual fear of all working parents: that dreaded phone call in the middle of the morning rush from the childminder who is too sick to work. Or perhaps one of the children has developed a temperature and, just to be on the safe side, the nursery staff think she would be better off at home.

Either way, the parents are in limbo and due at their desk within the hour. It's decision time, with most guardians torn between confessing the truth to the personnel department, which retaliates by quickly snatching the last few precious days of annual leave; and opting for the more devious route of phoning in sick and listening to the boss grumbling about never employing a parent again.

What mums and dads desperately need is a "get out of work free" card - and the EU's parental leave directive appears to fit the bill. It allows all parents with children born after December 15 the chance to take up to 13 weeks' extra unpaid holiday. And, following a 16-month campaign by the TUC, which included the threat of high-court action by Cherie Booth, the government finally backed down and agreed last week to extend the right to all parents with children under the age of five.

At last, there seemed to be a chance for parents to take a deep breath and stop panicking every time their offspring need immunisation, or a check-up with the health visitor, or simply go down with one of those things children are always going down with. On the face of it, the new law is a triumph for working parents, heralding a new era of family-friendly practices in the workplace.

But there is a snag. While the extension of the EU directive might be a step in the right direction, parental leave is not all it is cracked up to be. Not only is it unpaid, but it must be taken in blocks of one week, is only available to workers who have been with their company for more than a year, and is conditional on employees giving their companies at least three weeks' notice.

To cap it all, if the employer can prove that the granting of parental leave would be detrimental to their business, your leave can be postponed for up to six months. Not too handy if the childminder called in sick this morning.

The Department of Trade and Industry's senior policy adviser for employee relations, Graham Morton, agrees that there has been some confusion over what the new entitlement is for. "There is a misunderstanding, as it is not meant for emergencies," he said. "The kind of situation it might be used for is if care is provided informally by the extended family, who are going on holiday." The parents can then book additional time off from work to stay at home and look after their kids. But they would still be forced to take the leave in blocks of one week, each time losing that whole week's wages. Unless parents are able to negotiate a special deal with their employers, they could end up severely out of pocket - with no salary and a bill for the childminder's holiday pay.

According to the GMB's head of equal rights, Karen Constantine, this explains why there has been a slow take-up of the scheme. Her union surveyed 200 members last year, and found that only one had taken advantage of the parental leave directive. "Parents can't afford a period of time where they are unpaid," she says. "If they are working a 60-hour week to make ends meet, how are they going to afford to take time off unpaid?

"The majority will end up robbing Peter to pay Paul. And it will be nigh on impossible for single-parent families to capitalise on the scheme."

Full-time working mother Liz Easton says that she would relish the chance to spend more time at home with her two-year-old son Pip: "I've been thinking about taking him to the clinic just to check up on his weight and height, but it's only open during working hours. I'd like to think that I could take some time off as a bonding time with Pip and not just use up holidays for emergencies.

"The 13 weeks would be useful if we had a real crisis, but I wouldn't really be able to afford it and would need to rely on my credit card."

The only hope for parents forced to fritter away their annual vacation on the odd day here and there is to negotiate with their employers. Some companies have proved to be more sympathetic than others. Easton's previous employer, a large insurance company, could afford to be "quite family-friendly", offering 25 days' annual leave plus flexitime, which meant that Liz could leave work at 3.30pm or save up overtime to pay for extra days off. But working for a smaller company makes it difficult to take advantage of such rights. Fashion worker and mother of two Ann Hodge, who recently quit her part-time job, felt it was unlikely that her company would have been receptive to the idea of additional holidays on top of annual leave.

"Working for a small firm, they would have frowned upon it if I'd mentioned extra holidays," she says. "If I had stuck to my guns and taken it, then it would have made relations in the office strained and life difficult."

Terrence Libby, who employs 50 men and women at his manu-facturing company in Northamptonshire, explains why the parental leave directive is a strain on small business: "There has already been an excessive extension of employees' rights over the last 18 months. Adding another 13 weeks is just another burden.

"Small companies do not have specialist departments: we may have just one person in the payroll department, for example, and if they are away, it is incredibly disruptive."

But according to Margery Carey, president of retail workers' union USDAW, the onus is on employers first. "The government has put the basic there - it's up to the employers to build on it," she argues. "As a union we now have to put the meat on the bones and negotiate with companies. You don't get what you want overnight - we need to build on that."

In the meantime, if your children are sent home from nursery tomorrow, there is another alternative to fibbing to the boss: time off for dependents was introduced alongside the parental leave directive and offers one or two days off for domestic emergencies. Sadly, it remains unpaid but, as notice is not required, it could go some way to bridge the gap until paid, flexible parental leave is finally introduced.

webTitle: We're not revolting, but do we protest too much?

fields.headline: We're not revolting, but do we protest too much?
fields.standfirst: The British are not revolutionary by nature, but we do relish a riot. Derek Brown looks back at some of our more notable uprisings
fields.trailText: The British are not revolutionary by nature, but we do relish a riot. Derek Brown looks back at some of our more notable uprisings.
fields.body:
We may not care much for those who rule over us, but by and large, we let them go about their business in peace. The last time - some would say the only time - that we overthrew the system was in the 1640s. Trading-in Charles I for Oliver Cromwell was frankly quite stupid, so we've never done it again. One Civil War was quite enough, thank you.

Bonnie Prince Charlie made a mild stab at revolution in 1745, but that was more to do with changing the management than changing the system. Since then, there have been plenty of radical attempts to change the order of things, but the outcome of most of them, like the wretched Cato St conspiracy of 1820, was pathetic.

When it comes to protesting, though, the British are past-masters, with a long, proud tradition of dismantling property and hurling bits of it at the authorities. The Peasants' Revolt of 1381 was an early example. Wat Tyler and the others didn't want power, they wanted rid of the poll tax. It ended in tears, of course, but it worked - just as it worked again in 1990. But let's not get ahead of ourselves.

A vintage period for homogenous Anglo-Saxon rioting, especially in London, began in 1750. Any excuse was good enough: in 1752 Britain decided to join the European common time zone, represented by the new-fangled Gregorian calendar, devised nearly 300 years earlier. Eleven days were removed from the old Julian version, causing simple minded people to believe their lives had been shortened, and giving them just the excuse they wanted to bash up the town. In 1780 Lord George Gordon roused the mob with fearful tales of what would befall if Roman Catholics were given civil rights. The army was called out, more than 100 rioters were shot dead, and at least 20 were hanged. Lord Gordon was acquitted, partly at least because he was barking mad.

The early 1800s were vintage riot years. Town and country were both seething with unrest in the depressed aftermath of the Napoleonic wars. The authorities quelled the unrest with bloody rigour. Sometimes, as in the Peterloo massacre of 1819, they went in for pre-emptive quelling. But the unrest was real enough on other occasions. In the woeful (but wonderfully named)l Plug Plot riots, factory workers disabled their machines by removing the plugs from the boilers. Luddites - followers of the mythical General Ned Ludd - smashed the industrial machinery which was destroying their craft jobs. They've been doing it ever since. A more political protest erupted in the 1830s and 40s with the Chartist movement, campaigning for radical social and parliamentary reform. This was a time when revolutionaries were creating mayhem across Europe. The Chartists, being British, organised marches, got up petitions, and chucked the odd brick.

The second half of the 19th century was more decorous, but the 20th started in fine style with the movement for women's suffrage and a new surge of industrial unrest. The end of the first world war saw the first outbreak of what was to become, sadly, a new British phenomenon: the race riots of 1919 presaged the nasty confrontation in Notting Hill in 1958, and a dismal succession of similar events.

Growing prosperity has, on the face of it, done nothing to blunt our enthusiasm for a 'donnybrook' (an excellent Irish expression meaning riotous assembly). In the 1980s inner city rage exploded in Liverpool, Bristol, Birmingham and, most bloodily perhaps, in Brixton in South London and the Broadwater Farm estate in North London. The most spectacular spasm of violence in recent times was the poll tax riot of 1990. It may have been 609 years after the Peasants' Revolt, but Wat Tyler would have recognised the rage, the fear, and the exhileration of a nation indulging in one of its favourite pastimes.

dbrown445@aol.com
Special report: Mayday 2001

fields.headline: Tourism gets £12m boost
fields.trailText: Tourism bosses have welcomed a £12m injection of government cash to tempt visitors back to Britain after the foot and mouth crisis, writes Claire Cozens
fields.body:
Tourism bosses have welcomed a £12m injection of government cash to tempt visitors back to Britain after the foot and mouth crisis.

Culture secretary Chris Smith said the money would support the British Tourist Authority's new advertising campaign to hammer home the message that Britain is still a great place for a holiday.

It is hoped the adverts will help reverse estimated losses to the tourism industry of up to £2.5bn of its £13bn-a-year trade.

The cash adds to a previous £6m boost for tourism advertising and brings to more than £250m the total government support given to business in the wake of the outbreak.

Mr Smith said the countryside was "returning to normal" and that it was vital to get the message across to potential visitors from overseas that Britain was open for business.

"The British countryside is returning to normal and it is important that we get this message across both at home and abroad," he said. "Tourists need to know what we all know - that Britain is a great holiday destination. This money will help that effort."

The new cash will go to Britain's tourist boards to be spent on adverts and other marketing initiatives, which Whitehall sources said had been shown to produce £30 of tourist spending for every £1 spent.

New research by the BTA has shown that 85% of attractions are now open and 93% of events are due to go ahead as planned, despite the disruption caused by foot-and-mouth.

The UK's top 10 visitor attractions and top 10 admission fee-charging heritage properties are all open.

"I am pleased the government has recognised the urgent need to invest in overseas tourism promotion," said BTA chairman David Quarmby said. "We can now get straight on with promotional activities in all the affected markets to boost visits from overseas for the summer, and with initiating a longer-term programme to re-present Britain to the world, starting in the autumn."

webTitle: CIA knew about Waldheim's Nazi past

fields.headline: CIA knew about Waldheim's Nazi past
fields.standfirst: Newly released US intelligence documents show that officials knew about Kurt Waldheim's history long before he was appointed UN secretary general, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Newly released US intelligence documents show that officials knew about Kurt Waldheim's history long before he was appointed UN secretary general, writes Kate Connolly in Austria.
fields.body:
Twenty files on Adolf Hitler, Josef Mengele and other top Nazis were released by the US intelligence service, the CIA, at the end of last week, including material on the former Austrian president Kurt Waldheim. They prove that, by 1945, the CIA already knew, via British intelligence agents, about Mr Waldheim's wartime curriculum vitae.

As a 24-year old, the document confirmed, Mr Waldheim had worked as a fairly junior Wehrmacht officer in a Nazi intelligent unit in the Balkans which was renowned for the atrocities it committed. However, the document was forgotten by the time Mr Waldheim was first suggested as UN secretary general years in 1971. A CIA check on him at the time revealed nothing suspicious.

The opening of the files has now debunked allegations that Mr Waldheim had acted as an informer for the CIA and also that the KGB used knowledge of his past to blackmail him. He served two terms as UN secretary general until 1981.

Five years later he became Austrian president, despite allegations having been made about his Nazi past. His single term in office was clouded as a result and his refusal to resign ushered in a damaging and unprecedented period of isolation for the Alpine republic.

In 1988 an international commission of historians presented no information to back the allegations, but concluded that Mr Waldheim had been "in close proximity to some Nazi atrocities, knew they were going on and made no attempt to stop them". It accused him of making his army service appear harmless once it had come to light.

Now 82, the former Austrian president, who still remains on the US government's "watch list", compiled to keep Nazi suspects out of America, made a rare appearance on Austrian television this week to insist that the files cleared him of wrongdoing - although he did not elaborate.

In the past he has always denied his involvement in war crimes. The re-emergence of the Waldheim case has, incredibly, received little coverage in the Austrian press. Commentators and ordinary Austrians admit that it is an issue which "still traumatises us".

The flak received from abroad was a huge setback in the international development of a country which, after 1945, had successfully managed to develop a cosy image built around Mozart and mountain yodellers.

In her insightful book on recent Austrian history, Guilty Victim, looking back to 1986, Hella Pick says that it was "inevitable that the case against [Waldheim] would develop into a case against Austria".

The anti-Waldheim campaign was a painful time for Austria as the international community put it in the dock, accusing it of portraying itself as a Nazi victim rather than acknowledging its perpetrator role.

In short, the Waldheim era forced Austrians into an important, though painful, bout of soul searching and historical reappraisal. An unprecedented, and hugely passionate, nationwide debate was sparked.

"Once the stigma of guilt had appeared on Waldheim's forehead, it led to turbulent clashes between young and old, black [conservatives] and red [socialists]," writes journalist Arnim Thurnherr in his critical examination of Austria, The Trauma, A Life.

Ms Pick writes that "Austria had suddenly come to the realisation that it could not live in the present, continuing to see itself as a 'blessed isle' floating happily with a good conscience in quiet waters away from the turbulence of the east-west relationship".

She quotes Edgar Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, as saying: "The issue is not Kurt Waldheim. He is a mirror of Austria. His lies are of secondary importance. The real issue is that Austria has lied for decades about its own involvement in the atrocities Mr Waldheim was involved in."

Tabloid headlines at the time, which claimed that Mr Waldheim was a "Nazi butcher", were grossly untrue. In truth, Mr Waldheim's wartime role was similar to that of the average Austrian soldier, few of whom got out with clean hands from a war that was so ridden with atrocities.

But Mr Waldheim's problem was precisely because he was a "monument to Austrian averageness", as Thurnherr puts it. He found himself at the centre of a long-awaited inter-generational conflict in which young people started asking questions of their elders such as: "How did you do it?", "Why did you do it?" and "Why didn't you stand up against Hitler?" The reply was generally: "How dare you young people criticise us - you weren't there, you know nothing."

It was a questioning process that had already begun in Germany some 20 years before. "It was the war generation's lack of remorse and their arrogance that they were right which got to us," says a Viennese man who was a 17-year old student at the time.

"Waldheim represented perfectly the attitude of getting away with it, of being part of a regime and managing to resurface after it, which represents the attitudes of a whole generation."

Recently, Peter Michael Lingens, the former editor of the news magazine Profil, which carried some of the heftiest criticism of Mr Waldheim in Austria, admitted that Mr Waldheim was a pawn in the process of forcing Austria to look at its Nazi past. He said that Profil had done wrong by Mr Waldheim, but added that it had a point to make and that the former Nazi offered a way to make it.

The examination of Austria throughout the Waldheim saga undoubtedly helped to sharpen the world's attention towards other cover-ups, namely in France and the Channel Islands. However, there is little doubt that it also created a nationalist surge back home as some Austrians acutely felt, and took personally, the relentless international criticism.

Is it a coincidence that in the same year that Mr Waldheim came to power, Jörg Haider took over the leadership of the Freedom party, steering it away from its fairly liberal agenda towards the far right. Another man who has successfully managed to pit little Austria against the rest of the world.

An unprecedented, and hugely passionate, nationwide debate was sparked. "Once the stigma of guilt had appeared on Waldheim's forehead, it led to turbulent clashes between young and old, black [conservatives] and red [socialists]," writes journalist Arnim Thurnherr in his critical examination of Austria, The Trauma, A Life. Ms Pick writes that "Austria had suddenly come to the realisation that it could not live in the present, continuing to see itself as a 'blessed isle' floating happily with a good conscience in quiet waters away from the turbulence of the east-west relationship". She quotes Edgar Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, as saying: "The issue is not Kurt Waldheim. He is a mirror of Austria. His lies are of secondary importance. The real issue is that Austria has lied for decades about its own involvement in the atrocities Mr Waldheim was involved in." Tabloid headlines at the time, which claimed that Mr Waldheim was a "Nazi butcher", were grossly untrue. In truth, Mr Waldheim's wartime role was similar to that of the average Austrian soldier, few of whom got out with clean hands from a war that was so ridden with atrocities. But Mr Waldheim's problem was precisely because he was a "monument to Austrian averageness", as Thurnherr puts it. He found himself at the centre of a long-awaited inter-generational conflict in which young people started asking questions of their elders such as: "How did you do it?", "Why did you do it?" and "Why didn't you stand up against Hitler?" The reply was generally: "How dare you young people criticise us - you weren't there, you know nothing." It was a questioning process that had already begun in Germany some 20 years before. "It was the war generation's lack of remorse and their arrogance that they were right which got to us," says a Viennese man who was a 17-year old student at the time. "Waldheim represented perfectly the attitude of getting away with it, of being part of a regime and managing to resurface after it, which represents the attitudes of a whole generation." Recently, Peter Michael Lingens, the former editor of the news magazine Profil, which carried some of the heftiest criticism of Mr Waldheim in Austria, admitted that Mr Waldheim was a pawn in the process of forcing Austria to look at its Nazi past. He said that Profil had done wrong by Mr Waldheim, but added that it had a point to make and that the former Nazi offered a way to make it. The examination of Austria throughout the Waldheim saga undoubtedly helped to sharpen the world's attention towards other cover-ups, namely in France and the Channel Islands. However, there is little doubt that it also created a nationalist surge back home as some Austrians acutely felt, and took personally, the relentless international criticism. Is it a coincidence that in the same year that Mr Waldheim came to power, Jörg Haider took over the leadership of the Freedom party, steering it away from its fairly liberal agenda towards the far right. Another man who has successfully managed to pit little Austria against the rest of the world. fields.headline: Multinationals dismiss May Day action
fields.standfirst: Click here to see how each store reacted
fields.trailText:
4pm: Nike and McDondald's have dismissed the effect of the May Day anti-globalisation protests, reports Julia Day.
Click here to see how each store reacted
fields.body:
Multinationals have dismissed the effect of the May Day anti-globalisation protests on the companies they were aimed at.

Sports giant Nike, which was one of the main targets of the demonstrations in London, said there was "no possibility" of a dialogue with any violent group.

And McDonald's branded the protests "misplaced".

PR experts agree that the campaign will have no effect.

"The protest won't affect the way companies operate, not at all. I suspect it will not make a difference to the way McDonald's makes and serves food. It may make them review their security measures," said Charles Stewart-Smith, a crisis management consultant.

Mr Stewart-Smith, who heads up PR consultancy Luther Pendragon and who lists the Hindujas and Wrigley's among his clients, said the wide-ranging protest against global capitalism is unachievable compared with targeted environmental protests.

"The protesters were calling for an end to global capitalisation but the companies exist in a capitalist society - it is how and why they exist. I can't see companies saying they'll be less capitalist," said Mr Stewart-Smith.

"But if protests are about environmental measures it's a different debate and campaigners are changing companies."

Burson-Marsteller's managing director of corporate and public affairs, Gavin Grant, said yesterday's protests were not good for the protesters or companies.

"The substance of corporate responsibility in a globalised world and the impact of customers and citizens gets lost because of the fear of violence," said Mr Grant.

"The role of corporate responsibility is being taken very seriously by companies as the role of national governments declines. Many companies do want to engage in that debate," he added.

Nike said it would be happy to have a dialogue with protesters, but not when violence was involved.

"We would want to talk to people who come to us in a peaceful and sensible way, we are a transparent and responsible company. But there is no possibility for dialogue in this situation," said a spokesman.

A spokesman for McDonald's said: "We respect individuals' right to protest as long as it is democratically legitimate and peaceful.

"But we regard the points raised on the May Day Monopoly website - about our wages, selling meat and environmental issues - as misplaced," he added.

webTitle: I was IRA chief, admits McGuinness

fields.headline: I was IRA chief, admits McGuinness
fields.standfirst: Special report: Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: The Sinn Fein deputy leader, Martin McGuinness, this afternoon admitted that he was the IRA's second-in-command in Derry on the day of the Bloody Sunday killings.
fields.body:
The Sinn Fein deputy leader, Martin McGuinness, this afternoon admitted that he was the IRA's second-in-command in Derry on the day of the Bloody Sunday killings.

Mr McGuinness, who is Northern Ireland's education minister, made the admission today at a press conference.

He has also sent a draft statement to Lord Saville's inquiry into the deaths of 14 unarmed civilians shot by paratroopers on January 30 1972.

Mr McGuinness insists the organisation ordered its members not to open fire on soldiers in an attempt to keep the demonstration peaceful. And he categorically denies intelligence claims that he precipitated the violence by firing the first shot.

webTitle: Four Conservative hardliners who could win seats at the election

fields.headline: Four Conservative hardliners who could win seats at the election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: The row over racism in the Conservative party took on a new dimension when the former Tory prime minister Sir Edward Heath said that the party dare not tackle the issue because it was in the grip of the "extreme right".
fields.body:
The row over racism in the Conservative party took on a new dimension when the former Tory prime minister Sir Edward Heath said that the party dare not tackle the issue because it was in the grip of the "extreme right".

A survey of some of the key Labour marginals and winnable Tory seats shows it is not only on race that some candidates take rightwing views.

Hardline positions against abortion and in favour of capital punishment and the castration of persistent rapists are taken by some while others would outlaw the handling of euros by business. Here are four candidates with controversial views who have a good chance of getting on the Tory backbenches next month even if Tony Blair wins a majority in excess of 100.

Andrew Rosindell
33
Conservative candidate for Romford
Labour majority: 649
Swing required: 1.5%
Number 11 on Tory target list

Mr Rosindell was chairman of the European Young Conservatives between 1993 and 1997 and is international director of the Eurosceptic European Foundation.

History

Born and educated in Romford where his mother was a dinner lady at his primary school. He was bullied at school. At seven, he joined the Salvation Army, and became a Tory after hearing Margaret Thatcher speak when he was 14.

He has been chairman of the Young Monday Club, Young Conservatives' National Advisory Committee, and supporter of Conservative Way Forward and the Freedom Association. Contested the Labour stronghold of Glasgow Govan in 1992 where he went round the city with Spike, his pet Staffordshire bull terrier which was dressed in union flag colours. Spike will be campaigning with him again in Romford.

He was a Commons researcher to rightwing former MP Vivian Bendall, who is seeking re-election after losing Ilford North last time.

Latest reported faux pas

Embarrassed both William Hague and Eric Ollerenshaw, leader of the Tory opposition at the Greater London assembly earlier this year, by trying to bring a delegation of the Italian rightwing Alleanza Nazionale to meet them in London. Both refused to see them.

Views

He wants the return of the death penalty (with a choice of methods) and the introduction of flogging for violent thugs. Persistent rapists should be castrated. Abortion should be outlawed. He is also a strong critic of "leftwing" teachers, "trendy vicars" and left leaning judges.

"They should pay more attention to the Gospel rather than the Guardian," he told the Tory party. He supported the Keep Sunday Special campaign. He was also a supporter of arming the Contras in Nicaragua.

Strengths

He is a formidable campaigner - having won the Chase Cross ward on Havering council with a swing of 25% from the Liberal Democrats in 1990, he has held it with 88% of the vote, the highest Conservative share of the local vote in the capital.

Website says

Nothing - he says Tory central office has been slow in putting up his details.

Mark Macgregor
35
Thanet South
Labour majority: 2,878
Swing required 3.2%
Number 46 on the Tory target list

History

Came to fame in the 1980s when he won chairmanship of the Federation of Conservative Students just before it was closed down by Lord Tebbit. Educated at Emanuel school, Wandsworth, south London and Edinburgh University.

He started his political career as chairman of the Scottish Federation of Conservative Students in the mid 1980s, moving on to chair the main student body. In 1992 he was campaign adviser to both Lord Forsyth, the arch-privatiser and close admirer of Lady Thatcher, and Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary. He contested the Labour stronghold of West Ham in 1997. More recently he was dubbed one of the "Pimlico Portillistas" behind the return of the MP to parliament. He belongs to the rightwing Conservative Way Forward.

Views

Opponent of the peace settlement in Northern Ireland. In 1986 he took a trip to Northern Ireland and co-signed a postcard sent to Conservative central office chiefs supporting hard line unionists. It showed a wall mural with the words "Shankill, No Surrender" and read: "Having a loyal time performing our patriotic duty."

As chairman of the Federation of Conservative Students he presided over policies condemning the release of Nelson Mandela as furthering Marxist sectarianism, calling for the privatisation of the railways, the BBC, and Britain's withdrawal from the UN. The student organisation was closed after an inquiry into claims that its members went on the rampage at Loughborough University, causing £30,000 worth of damage. He maintains that this was "wildly exaggerated".

He believes councils should be banned in East Kent from spending any money on how to handle euros - even though they will be common currency across the channel next year.

Strengths

Invaluable to Michael Portillo. Expect him to back him for the leadership should Mr Hague wobble after June.

Website says

Presents himself as a regular churchgoer, a supporter of Crystal Palace football club. Student career glossed over. Supports tough Tory policy on detaining refugees but not a new detention centre in his constituency because it will discourage tourists.

Mark Field
36
Cities of London and Westminster
Conservative majority: 4,881
Regarded as safe Tory seat

Key organiser in Young Conservatives who is now seen as the man who would run Mr Portillo's campaign if he stood for the party leadership against Mr Hague after the election.

History

Educated at Reading School and St Edmund Hall, Oxford. Practised as a solicitor in a City law firm before setting up his own headhunting business, employing 12 staff. He is a local councillor on neighbouring Kensington and Chelsea borough. He is a member of the Conservative Way Forward.

Views

He attacked Aids campaigns as a waste of taxpayers' money and wanted mandatory tests for Aids. "... Many charitable trusts set up to help counter Aids in the mid-1980s became little more than a gay rights front," he wrote in Crossbow in 1991. Later, after he campaigned for Mr Portillo to get his Kensington seat, he said that whether people are or were gay was a "non-issue" for members of the Kensington and Chelsea Conservative Association.

He is also a supporter of looser rules on MPs' outside earnings: "If you're earning several hundred thousand a year in the City, are you going to give it up for £47,000 a year in the Commons?" He is expected to get quick promotion - especially if Mr Portillo gets the leadership.

Website says

"We should uphold traditional values, such as individual freedom, respect for the elderly and the promotion of civility, manners and tolerance."

Peter Bone
48
Wellingborough
Labour majority: 187
Swing required: 0.2%
Number 6 on the Tory target list.

History

Born in Billericay, Essex. He was educated at Westcliff-on-Sea grammar school and is an accountant. He is former financial director of an Essex electronics engineering company; and a former chief executive of an electro-magnetic sign company. He is managing director of Palm Travel, a Newport holiday firm. Plays cricket for local village team and has run eight London marathons. Former Tory candidate in Islwyn and Pudsey (1997).

Views

Strongly opposed to the minimum wage. Was dubbed Britain's "meanest boss" by the Daily Mirror in 1995 when he defended paying a 17-year-old trainee 87p an hour to work for his travel company. He boasted at the Tory conference that he would not have given her a job if the government had a minimum wage - then thought to be £2.50 an hour. He said at the time: "The minimum wage would condemn hundreds of thousands to the dole queue."

He now says that this was a training scheme salary and not a minimum wage. He said that his firm offered a good "apprentice" scheme including foreign travel for trainees to Florida. As for the minimum wage he now says he accepts it - but as an employer, he could not tell the Guardian what the present rate is.

In Pudsey he called for the total withdrawal of all benefits from single parents, saying they should not receive any financial assistance from the state.

Last year the subject of a Commons motion condemning his views on asylum seekers after he claimed that ethnic minority children had lost language support because this had been diverted to refugees. He will never support or use the euro. Business deals abroad can be done using the US dollar, he said.

Strengths

Comes from business background which is becoming rarer in the Tory party.

Website says

Attacks Labour's "soft" approach to crime by letting criminals out early but has no views on the minimum wage or single parents.

fields.headline: May Day: how the multinationals reacted
fields.trailText: A round-up of how four targeted corporations reacted to the May Day protests in London.
fields.body:
Nike
Closures: Nike Town was boarded up.
Damage: Protesters tried to set light to hoardings outside Nike Town.
Reaction: "We have not experienced this type of violence against the store before. There is every right to protest but potentially putting people at risk is very negative, disturbing and counter-effective. The protesters were not expressing a point of view. Any other time protesters come to us with special issues, of course we take them seriously. We would want to talk to people who come to us in a peaceful and sensible way, we are a transparent and responsible company. But there is no possibility for dialogue in this situation."

McDonald's
Closures: A small number of restaurants were closed during the day, on the advice of the police.
Damage: None.
Reaction: "We respect individuals' right to protest as long as it is democratically legitimate and peaceful. But we regard the points raised on the May Day Monopoly website - about our wages, selling meat and environmental issues - as misplaced. We welcome discussions with credible groups and non-governmental organisations but it is difficult with loosely organised and widely orchestrated anarchist campaigners where McDonald's is not the only target."

Starbucks
Closures: 20 outlets, on the advice of the police.
Damage: None.
Reaction: "We wouldn't look at this from the point of view of how much money we lost from closing. The safety of our staff and customers was our priority. Of course Starbucks supports the democratic right to peaceful protest but we couldn't condone any violence."

webTitle: The issue explained: Son of Star Wars

fields.headline: Son of Star Wars
fields.standfirst:
The US is pressing ahead with its missile defence system, despite widespread international criticism. Mark Tran and Derek Brown explain why.

Interactive guide to missile defence

Special report: Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US is pressing ahead with its missile defence system, despite widespread international criticism. We explain why.
fields.body:
Why is Bush so keen?
Missile defence is a totem for the American right, even after the end of the cold war. President George Bush says that the USA must shield itself from attack from so-called rogue states "for whom terror and blackmail are a way of life".

Why are other countries not keen?
China and Russia in particular believe the project will oblige them to beef up their own defences, at massive cost. Several European countries also believe that Washington's move could spark a new arms race, and throw doubt on longstanding US-Soviet arms control treaties. Bush says the world has nothing to fear, and that America's allies could benefit - not least from cuts he is proposing in the US nuclear arsenal.

Is this the same as the old Star Wars project beloved by Ronald Reagan?
Not exactly, though the old Strategic Defence Initiative, popularly known as Star Wars, also relied on satellites to detect incoming enemy missiles. The SDI scheme was to deploy counter-missiles in space. The missile defence system more modestly relies on defensive missiles to be fired from the ground or from ships.

How is missile defence supposed to work?
Once an enemy missile is detected by early-warning radar, the information is fed into a war room. A point of interception is calculated and a defensive missile is launched. The interceptor is made up of a booster rocket and a "kill vehicle", programmed to distinguish between the incoming warhead and any debris or decoys.

Using thrusters, it would separate from the booster and manoeuvre towards a high-speed collision. The process has been described as shooting a bullet with a bullet.

Will it work?
Leading scientists have mocked the project as untested and unproved. The only anti-missile system ever tested in combat was the Patriot, deployed in Israel and the Gulf during Operation Desert Storm in 1991. It was fired 44 times at Iraqi Scud missiles, failing to destroy most of them.

Where does Britain fit in?
The system will rely on early-warning radar installations in Massachusetts, California, Alaska, Greenland - and the UK. Specifically, the US satellite tracking base at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire. As America's closest ally, Britain is expected to offer full cooperation. As an EU member, it will be under pressure to tone down its support for missile defence.

How much will missile defence cost?
According to a recent report from the US government general accounting office, even a limited system would cost between $18bn (£12.5bn) and $28bn. Some estimates run as high as $50bn.

When could it be in place?
Washington says that 2005 would be a realistic date for deployment.

The SDI scheme was to deploy counter-missiles in space. The missile defence system more modestly relies on defensive missiles to be fired from the ground or from ships. How is missile defence supposed to work? Once an enemy missile is detected by early-warning radar, the information is fed into a war room. A point of interception is calculated and a defensive missile is launched. The interceptor is made up of a booster rocket and a "kill vehicle", programmed to distinguish between the incoming warhead and any debris or decoys. Using thrusters, it would separate from the booster and manoeuvre towards a high-speed collision. The process has been described as shooting a bullet with a bullet. Will it work? Leading scientists have mocked the project as untested and unproved. The only anti-missile system ever tested in combat was the Patriot, deployed in Israel and the Gulf during Operation Desert Storm in 1991. It was fired 44 times at Iraqi Scud missiles, failing to destroy most of them. Where does Britain fit in? The system will rely on early-warning radar installations in Massachusetts, California, Alaska, Greenland - and the UK. Specifically, the US satellite tracking base at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire. As America's closest ally, Britain is expected to offer full cooperation. As an EU member, it will be under pressure to tone down its support for missile defence. How much will missile defence cost? According to a recent report from the US government general accounting office, even a limited system would cost between $18bn (£12.5bn) and $28bn. Some estimates run as high as $50bn. When could it be in place? Washington says that 2005 would be a realistic date for deployment. Interactive guide By George! webTitle: 'A gamble based on technology that doesn't exist'

fields.headline: 'A gamble based on technology that doesn't exist'
fields.standfirst: George Bush tried to gift wrap his controversial missile defence plans in a promise of unilateral nuclear weapons cuts yesterday. Here is how six major US newspapers' editorials responded to his speech
fields.trailText: How six major US newspapers' editorials responded to Mr Bush's speech, giftwrapping his controversial missile defence plans in a promise of unilateral nuclear weapons cuts yesterday.
fields.body:
"A missile defence is not inherently a bad idea, but plainly it is a premature one, given the formidable technical barriers yet to be crossed. Bush promises close consultation with the allies on his plans. The president would do well to consult first with the significant number of scientists who doubt that an effective system can be deployed any time soon. Their doubts merit the president's respectful attention before he sets the United States and the world on a new and potentially perilous course."
LA Times

"Though he made clear that the administration intends to discard the ABM treaty, Mr Bush stopped short of announcing a unilateral US withdrawal. Instead, he said that senior administration officials will visit allied capitals in the coming weeks to consult about the initiative. That is the right approach. In the end the United States cannot grant other nations veto power over its pursuit of its own defence. But Mr Bush appears to have embraced an important principle: if missile defence is to increase the safety of the United States, it must also enhance the safety and stability of the world."
Washington Post

"Mr. Bush has now defined his goals. The world will get a better picture of his specific intentions later this year when he fills in the details. At that point, it will not be hard to tell whether he is following the patient and deliberate course he set yesterday or instead is embarked on an irresponsible effort to dismantle the ABM treaty and erect a missile defence system before he has made the necessary diplomatic and technical preparations."
New York Times (registration required)

"If his missile defence plan wins the day, President Bush will be eroding a core strategy of United States security: deterring an enemy by guaranteeing its destruction. Rather than counting mainly on warhead yields, the US will be betting on antimissile shields. But at what price? Mr. Bush's speech on Tuesday set a challenge for Americans to rethink what makes a secure world and who their enemies are. The president will need popular support for such a costly and risky change of strategy."
Christian Science Monitor

"The most troubling parts of Bush's address yesterday were his vague commitment to missile defence and his saying: 'We must move beyond the constraints of the 30-year-old ABM treaty.' That treaty, severely limiting the building and deployment of antiballistic missile systems, has been the cornerstone for an effective structure of nuclear arms-control agreements. To dismantle that structure for the hypothetical possibility that missile defence will be technologically possible a decade from now is to make a foolish gamble with national security."
Boston Globe

"For all his assurances about the need for a new defence strategy - and Mr Bush pitched his radical idea admirably - the president's proposal for a missile defence shield still raises far more concerns than he had answers for. [Missile defence] is a gamble based on technology that doesn't exist, a timetable most reliably counted in decades and costs sure to soar into the hundreds of billions of dollars. Thus, Mr Bush's plan has the potential of reviving the very cold war thinking that he eschews."
Miami Herald

webTitle: Government to target number of B&B homeless

fields.headline: Government to target number of B&B homeless
fields.trailText: A new unit dedicated to finding permanent homes for more than 9,000 families forced to live in bed and breakfast (B&B) accomodation is to be set up by the government.
fields.body:
A new unit dedicated to finding permanent homes for more than 9,000 families forced to live in bed and breakfast (B&B) accomodation is to be set up by the government.

The unit, which will be recruited this summer and will be in place for the next two years, will set targets for reducing the numbers housed in B&Bs after conducting research on the problem.

The move comes after the success of the rough sleepers unit (RSU) which is on course to cut the number of people sleeping on the streets by two-thirds as revealed by SocietyGuardian.co.uk last month.

The latest figures show that the number housed in B&Bs last year rose by 22% to 9,078. The problem is most acute in London and the south-east where the shortage of affordable housing is greatest (see tables below).

Announcing the new unit in parliament yesterday, housing minister Nick Raynsford said: "Housing families in bed and breakfast is good for no one, it is expensive, it is inadequate and it has unacceptable long-term effects."

Homelessness charity Shelter welcomed the move but called for a "tough" government target to tackle the problem.

It said that in 1999/2000 councils spent more than £150m providing B&Bs for homeless households. It also claimed that the cost of B&B is three times as expensive as using private rented housing.

Chris Holmes, director of Shelter said: "Having nearly 10,000 households living in B&Bs undermines attempts to promote social inclusion, improve education and increase equality of opportunity for children."

He added: "We have been saying for some time that there was a growing crisis. We are delighted with the government's announcement, but believe a tough target is vital if the unit is to succeed."

A government spokeswoman said: "The main object is to reduce the use of bed and breakfasts for homeless families with children. Once the unit has reviewed the situation it will need to set targets, but it will also be important for authorities to set targets at the local level."

The unit has a budget of £1m over two years. Its focus will be on coordinating existing resources and spreading good practice.
