webTitle: Legal threat to morning-after pill sales

fields.headline: Legal threat to morning-after pill sales
fields.trailText: Britain's longest established anti-abortion group today won permission for a high court action to try to stop sales of the morning-after pill to women over 16 from pharmacists, without a prescription.
fields.body:
Britain's longest established anti-abortion group today won permission for a high court action to try to stop sales of the morning-after pill to women over 16 from pharmacists, without a prescription.

The Society for the Protection of Unborn Children [SPUC] will now dispute the legality of the government's reclassification of the Levonelle-2 pill at a full hearing before the end of July.

The drug, which SPUC says delivers 50 times the dosage of the daily mini-pill contraceptive, was made available from pharmacists without the need for a doctor's prescription in January this year.

The society's counsel, Richard Gordon QC, told Mr Justice Scott Baker that the change was unlawful under 19th century legislation because it permitted the commission of the administration or supply of poisons or instruments with the intent to procure miscarriage.

The 1861 Offences Against the Person Act prohibits the supply of "any poison or other noxious thing... with intent to procure the miscarriage of any woman, whether she be or be not with child".

Mr Gordon said that there was a strongly arguable case which raised very serious medical and legal issues. "It is the wider availability and the concomitant social effects which has caused SPUC to be concerned," he said.

Granting permission, the judge said he was persuaded that an issue existed that required resolution and it was better that it was decided in the civil courts than by way of private prosecutions brought in respect of specific supplies of the drug.

"There is an arguable case on what is fundamentally a very important question," he added.

John Smeaton, SPUC's national director, said recently: "Our case centres on the undeniable fact that the morning-after pill can cause the death of a newly conceived human being by preventing his or her implantation in the womb.

"Thus the morning-after pill can cause an early abortion, and should be subject to the controls set out in the 1967 Abortion Act."

Mr Smeaton said SPUC was "morally obliged" to oppose the wider availability of the morning-after pill and said that the pill could not be accurately described as a contraceptive because "it can cause the death of a newly-conceived embryo."

"It denies distinct and unique human individuals their right to life, and we cannot stand back and let this deception continue without raising our voices to defend the truth," he added.

webTitle: Birmingham makes bid for national stadium

fields.headline: Birmingham makes bid for national stadium
fields.trailText: Birmingham City Council is to open talks with the FA and the Government about an alternative venue for the new national stadium.
fields.body:
Birmingham City Council is to open talks with the FA and the Government about an alternative venue for the new national stadium.

The move follows the FA's announcement last night that it was pulling out of financing Wembley stadium, claiming that the plan could bankrupt the organisation.

Yesterday, the Government said it would not bankroll the shortfall in funding for the multi-million pound Wembley scheme. However, it is still committed to the idea of a national stadium and would work with sports authorities to seek a way forward.

That could let in Birmingham - whose council leaders said today that the city would be in a position to consider an alternative bid.

The local authority's deputy leader, Councillor Andy Howells, said: "Birmingham and our neighbouring authorities have an excellent track record of delivering major development projects on time and within budget.

"The midlands has the advantage of being easily accessible with good transport infrastructure already in place," he added. "Indeed Birmingham is the perfect site for such a stadium on both planning and business grounds.

"We will be talking with the Government and the FA and if there is an opportunity to put Birmingham forward as an alternative site for the national stadium, we would certainly be interested in putting together a new bid."

webTitle: Sky political editor takes swipe at BBC over Bland

fields.headline: Sky political editor takes swipe at BBC over Bland
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: A top Sky News journalist has taken a swipe at the BBC's coverage of Sir Christopher Bland's appointment as BT chairman, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
One of Sky News's most respected journalists has taken a swipe at the BBC over its coverage of Sir Christopher Bland's appointment as the chairman of BT.

At today's launch of Sky News's election coverage, Adam Boulton, the station's political editor, criticised the BBC's business editor, Jeff Randall, who was the first to broadcast the BT story.

Mr Boulton said: "We don't have to decide - as the BBC did last week with the announcement its chairman Sir Christopher Bland was to be the chairman of BT - whether to hold something for 5 Live or to give it to the Today programme."

His remarks follow Mr Randall's robust denial this week that he was "given" the Today programme's exclusive story about Sir Christopher's appointment.

Speaking as he and Nick Pollard, Sky News's head of news, unveiled Sky News's election coverage, Mr Boulton said Sky News "did not suffer from brand dilution", unlike the BBC and ITN.

He argued that Sky News's round-the-clock coverage meant it was better able to avoid the "soundbite culture" that dogged the terrestrial bulletins.

"We've got the time to broaden that coverage out beyond simply reporting what the party spokesmen say," he said.

Sky News's interactive service, Sky News Active, will offer "party channels" with coverage of each political party's activity in the run-up to the election.

Mr Pollard would not comment on the progress of the bid by the Channel Three consortium - which includes Sky News - for the ITV news franchise.

But he said he was confident about Sky News's reputation for quality and impartiality.

He said: "The idea that you could point to any part of our output and say it is biased or slanted or shows in effect a corporate view [reflecting its parent company BskyB] is nonsense."

fields.headline: Xfm draws on Tank Girl's powers
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: Xfm is launching a new advertising campaign designed by Tank Girl creator Jamie Hewlett, reports Julia Day.
21.03.2001: Sleaze Nation launches aspirational music title
24.01.2001: Capital boosts revenues
fields.body:
Xfm is launching a new advertising campaign designed by Tank Girl creator Jamie Hewlett.

The campaign will see the station's DJs immortalised in cartoon form by the artist who is also behind the illustrations for Damon Albarn's "virtual pop group" Gorillaz.

Mr Hewlett has been commissioned to design illustrations of the Xfm DJs for tube cards on London Underground, and press adverts in a number of key titles such as the Face, I-D, NME and Dazed & Confused.

The Xfm DJs to be transformed into cartoon characters include T4's Dermot O'Leary; Poptones boss Alan McGee; Soccer AM's Tim Lovejoy; MTV host Zane Lowe; and legendary producer Arthur Baker.

The illustrations feature the little radio which appears in the current TV campaign along with the strapline, "Don't be afraid".

Xfm has bought all the advertising space on three London Underground trains for May. This will be supported by press adverts throughout May and June.

Xfm's head of marketing, Charlotte Soussan said: "With the TV and cinema campaign building the profile of Xfm as a whole, it is essential potential listeners understand that they can get a completely different experience of Xfm depending on when they tune in for the first time."

This campaign follows the release of Xfm's latest "Don't Be Afraid" TV and cinema advertising campaign, produced by Quiet Storm.

webTitle: The real Martin McGuinness stands up

fields.headline: The real Martin McGuinness stands up
fields.standfirst:
The Sinn Fein deputy's admission that he was an IRA leader during Bloody Sunday will surprise no one, especially not those journalists who worked in the province in the 1970s and came to respect his style of leadership, says Derek Brown

Special report: Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: The Sinn Fein deputy's admission that he was an IRA leader during Bloody Sunday will surprise no one, especially not those journalists who worked in the province in the 1970s and came to respect his style of leadership, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Thirty years ago, Martin McGuinness used to hold court in the unlikely setting of the Bogside gasworks in Derry. There he would grant interviews to visiting journalists, patiently explaining the republican cause for which he fought.

It was not considered the done thing to ask for his rank and standing in the Provisional IRA, which had then been in existence barely a year. It was tacitly understood - and never denied - that McGuinness was, in the grandiloquent language of the movement, the Derry brigade commander.Today, more than a generation later, McGuinness has broken cover and admitted, to the surprise of absolutely nobody, that he was indeed a ranking IRA man in the first and bloodiest days of the modern Troubles.

He has told a press conference that he was the IRA's second-in-command in Derry on the day of the Bloody Sunday killings.

We are in no position to contradict him, but those of us who reported regularly from Derry (our datelines said Londonderry) in the early 1970s had the clear impression that he ruled the IRA roost.

Then, as now, McGuinness was softly spoken, courteous, and greatly given to barrack-room lawyering. His language was convoluted; his loyalty and commitment unmistakable. Unlike other IRA leaders, he understood the value of putting over his message to the British press, in spite of its almost unqualified hostility to militant republicanism.

In 1971, there was an ugly spate of attacks on Catholic girls who went out with British soldiers based in the city. At least three had their heads shaved and were publicly daubed with tar. It was in the days when Bogside and the neighbouring estate of Creggan were no-go areas for the police, and the army could only enter in armoured vehicles. Reporters could come and go with relative ease, for example to the Bogside gasworks which functioned as the IRA's ad hoc headquarters, but during the tar-and-feathering episode, we were made distinctly unwelcome.

On one occasion, following up a report that yet another young woman had been publicly humiliated, I walked into Bogside, and was confronted by a youth who told me to leave in no uncertain terms. I argued with him and dropped some names of republican contacts, including that of Martin McGuinness. The young man scowled, opened his jacket, and produced the biggest automatic pistol I had ever seen. I made an excuse and left.

McGuinness would not, I think, have sanctioned such crudeness. Indeed, a couple of days later he organised an unprecedented press conference, held in a council house in Creggan, at which four IRA men pledged there would be no more attacks on army girlfriends. The pledge was fulfilled.

That was just three months before Bloody Sunday. Now McGuinness is to appear before the Saville inquiry to admit his leading IRA role - and to deny with vehemence the suggestion, repeated by his enemies over the years, that he fired the shot which provoked the mass killing.

Indeed, the suggestion seems ludicrous. McGuinness always took pride in the discipline of the Derry brigade, and the care it took to avoid civilian casualties. He used to boast, quietly, that his men never planted a bomb without warning, and would never countenance sectarian assassination. That he or any other member of the IRA would have opened fire in the midst of a peaceful mass march, is barely credible.

It was tacitly understood - and never denied - that McGuinness was, in the grandiloquent language of the movement, the Derry brigade commander.Today, more than a generation later, McGuinness has broken cover and admitted, to the surprise of absolutely nobody, that he was indeed a ranking IRA man in the first and bloodiest days of the modern Troubles. He has told a press conference that he was the IRA's second-in-command in Derry on the day of the Bloody Sunday killings. We are in no position to contradict him, but those of us who reported regularly from Derry (our datelines said Londonderry) in the early 1970s had the clear impression that he ruled the IRA roost. Then, as now, McGuinness was softly spoken, courteous, and greatly given to barrack-room lawyering. His language was convoluted; his loyalty and commitment unmistakable. Unlike other IRA leaders, he understood the value of putting over his message to the British press, in spite of its almost unqualified hostility to militant republicanism. In 1971, there was an ugly spate of attacks on Catholic girls who went out with British soldiers based in the city. At least three had their heads shaved and were publicly daubed with tar. It was in the days when Bogside and the neighbouring estate of Creggan were no-go areas for the police, and the army could only enter in armoured vehicles. Reporters could come and go with relative ease, for example to the Bogside gasworks which functioned as the IRA's ad hoc headquarters, but during the tar-and-feathering episode, we were made distinctly unwelcome. On one occasion, following up a report that yet another young woman had been publicly humiliated, I walked into Bogside, and was confronted by a youth who told me to leave in no uncertain terms. I argued with him and dropped some names of republican contacts, including that of Martin McGuinness. The young man scowled, opened his jacket, and produced the biggest automatic pistol I had ever seen. I made an excuse and left. McGuinness would not, I think, have sanctioned such crudeness. Indeed, a couple of days later he organised an unprecedented press conference, held in a council house in Creggan, at which four IRA men pledged there would be no more attacks on army girlfriends. The pledge was fulfilled. That was just three months before Bloody Sunday. Now McGuinness is to appear before the Saville inquiry to admit his leading IRA role - and to deny with vehemence the suggestion, repeated by his enemies over the years, that he fired the shot which provoked the mass killing. Indeed, the suggestion seems ludicrous. McGuinness always took pride in the discipline of the Derry brigade, and the care it took to avoid civilian casualties. He used to boast, quietly, that his men never planted a bomb without warning, and would never countenance sectarian assassination. That he or any other member of the IRA would have opened fire in the midst of a peaceful mass march, is barely credible. dbrown445@aol.com Related articles 02.05.2001: I was IRA chief, admits McGuinness 02.05.2001: Special branch accused of suppressing confession 01.05.2001: McGuinness vows to clear IRA of role in Derry killings More on Guardian Unlimited Special report: Northern Ireland Special report: Bloody Sunday Interactive guide: People, history and politics in Northern Ireland Useful sites Sinn Fein Sinn Fein profile of Martin McGuinness Belfast Telegraph Irish Times Irish News Bloody Sunday chronology: Conflict Archive on the Internet Saville Inquiry

webTitle: Samaritans target farmers with TV adverts

fields.headline: Samaritans target farmers with TV adverts
fields.trailText: The Samaritans are rushing out a TV campaign urging farmers to seek help following a series of suicides related to the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The Samaritans are rushing out a TV campaign urging farmers to seek help following a series of suicides related to the foot and mouth crisis.

The hard-hitting commercial uses real news footage showing the effects of foot and mouth on the farming community.

It is designed to highlight the isolation of those hit by the crisis in farming and tourism, and forms part of the charity's Emergency Rural Stress campaign.

The Samaritans wants to persuade those affected by the crisis that there is no shame in seeking help.

The group said volunteers at 203 branches throughout the UK and Ireland will be available to provide confidential emotional support 24 hours a day by phone, letter or in person.

"In a very compelling way this film shows the huge pressure that people are under," said Simon Armson, the chief executive of the Samaritans.

"We can provide a light at the end of the tunnel for those enduring enormous emotional distress as a result of the rural crisis and who may be worried about loss of livelihood."

The commercial was created by Ogilvy & Mather, with media planning and buying by MindShare.

"It is vital we display true empathy with the emotional distress and dispair that people faced by this crisis are experiencing," said Steve Dunn, the executive creative director of O&M.

The advert will be screened for the first time later this week.

webTitle: Illegal immigrants seized in dawn raids

fields.headline: Illegal immigrants seized in dawn raids
fields.trailText: Police and immigration officers detained 20 suspected illegal immigrants in Southampton this morning in the third wave of a major operation to clamp down on unauthorised workers and human trafficking.
fields.body:
Police and immigration officers detained 20 suspected illegal immigrants in Southampton this morning in the third wave of a major operation to clamp down on unauthorised workers and human trafficking.

The Home Office said that most of those arrested this morning were Polish. They were being questioned by immigration officials at Waterlooville police station in Hampshire. A sweep in Southampton yesterday resulted in 16 detentions.

Three men - two Poles and a Briton - have been charged in connection with the illegal entry of people into the UK.

The latest detentions in Southampton are part of Britain's biggest operation against illegal immigrants. So far, the campaign - codenamed Operation Leighton - has resulted in the detention of 129 suspected illegal immigrants, 95 on a single day last week. Eighteen people suspected of human trafficking have also been arrested.

The majority of the immigrants came from Poland although there were individuals from Afghanistan, Belarus, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

Immigration officials have acted swiftly to deport those detained, sending 74 people back within 24 hours. Most of those detained were put on flights back to their homelands, leading to charges from immigrant welfare groups of a potential breach of human rights.

Tauhid Pasha, the legal policy director for the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants, said the operation, which has been billed by authorities as a human rights exercise, is a potential breach of human rights.

"The JCWI wholly supports the comments of the police that these people are innocent victims of human traffickers," he said. "But these victims have been denied the right to full legal advice. Some of them may have a right to stay. If they have family in the UK, they have a right to family life under section eight of the Human Rights Act. And they may have rights under the Geneva Convention to asylum."

A Home Office spokesman said that all persons cautioned are offered legal representation, but in this case only a few of those detained took up that offer. None of those detained chose to claim asylum, he said.

In today's raid 30 police and immigration officers stopped two vans and a car travelling out of Southampton at about 6am. Police said the vehicles were going to an unspecified work location when they were stopped.

Chief Inspector Bob Rose said that deportations were likely later today.

Chief Inspector Rachel Green said: "Unfortunately there are possibly several hundred more immigrants living in appalling conditions, living here illegally. We are trying to target the criminal element who are exploiting people in this way."

fields.headline: Big Brother 2 for end of May
fields.trailText:
Big Brother addicts are set to get their third fix of the show as Channel 4 brings forward plans for a new series, writes Lisa O'Carroll.

Special report: Big Brother
fields.body:
Big Brother addicts are set to get their third fix of the show as Channel 4 brings forward plans for a new series.

Just weeks after the nation was transfixed with Vanessa Feltz's apparent breakdown in front of the cameras comes the second series starring nominally "ordinary" people.

The show is expected to begin in three weeks' time with at least half the contestants already chosen for the Big Brother house.

Executives on the show insist there will be no unusual stunts and deny reports that participants will be allowed "conjugal visits" as part of an attempt to boost ratings.

"The show will only work if the format works. That has already been demonstrated. What will make it work is the selection of the right of the mix candidates," said one insider.

MediaGuardian.co.uk special report

fields.headline: Public pressure keeps Opengov open
fields.standfirst: Internet news
fields.trailText: The UK's first official government website has won a last-minute reprieve after plans to close it provoked a huge outcry from both the press and public.
fields.body:
The UK's first official government website has won a last-minute reprieve after plans to close it provoked a huge outcry from both the press and public.

Open.gov.uk, which was launched by the then-prime minister John Major in 1994, was due to close at the end of next month, to be replaced by the multi-million pound UKonline site.

However, a spokesman for the Office of Government Commerce, which runs the highly-respected open.gov.uk, confirmed today that due to "lots of emails" from users, the site is now to be saved.

He said: "There are many facilities on opengov that ukonline could not replicate, so the URL will stay. Public opinion and an outcry from the press certainly played a part in this decision."

Only last month the open.gov site itself was announcing its own demise, saying it would "gradually be withdrawn over the next few months." In fact, the plan was for open.gov to close down at the end of June after responsibility had been transferred to the new Office of the e-Envoy, operating out of the Cabinet Office.

Ukonline has already created controversy over a £400,000 advertising budget since its launch in February. More than £4m of taxpayers money was spent on setting up the site, which now employs 30 journalists with an annual salary bill of around £1m.

Many users preferred the open.gov site's alaphabetical list of government departments and agencies, despite an assurance from a spokesperson for ukonline that their site has "more headroom and more expandability."

Inside the civil service, the ukonline site, which was launched in January with expensive seven-page "advertorials" in tabloid newspapers, is dubbed "pravda.com" for its adherence to the official line.

Open.gov was developed in house, whereas the UK Online team works closely with BT on all areas of the portal including the search engine.

Today Opengov carries the announcement of its reprieve: "The features available on open.gov.uk will be carried across in a familiar format so that existing open.gov.uk users will continue to have access to the services they use and value. The www.open.gov.uk URL will be retained. We hope that you find the additional services available on ukonline.gov.uk to be useful."

fields.headline: Lazio receive one-match home ban
fields.trailText: Lazio have been banned from the Stadio Olimpico for one match and fined 60m lire (£20,000) for their fans' racist behaviour at Sunday's Rome derby.
fields.body:
Lazio have been banned from the Stadio Olimpico for one match and fined 60m lire (£20,000) for their fans' racist behaviour at Sunday's Rome derby.

Lazio fans booed Roma's Brazilian players Cafu and Aldair as well as French-born defender Jonathan Zebina whenever they had the ball in Sunday's 2-2 draw.

They also held up a banner carrying the words: "Black squad, Jewish home end."

The ban will come in to effect for Lazio's May 20 home match against Udinese, which will be played at a venue yet to be decided.

Roma were also fined 20m lire (£6,500) for the unruly behaviour of their fans, who threw bottles at players during Sunday's derby.

webTitle: Legal threat to morning-after pill sales

fields.headline: Legal threat to morning-after pill sales
fields.trailText: Britain's longest established anti-abortion group today won permission for a high court action to try to stop sales of the morning-after pill to women over 16 from pharmacists, without a prescription.
fields.body:
Britain's longest established anti-abortion group today won permission for a high court action to try to stop sales of the morning-after pill to women over 16 from pharmacists, without a prescription.

The Society for the Protection of Unborn Children [SPUC] will now dispute the legality of the government's reclassification of the Levonelle-2 pill at a full hearing before the end of July.

The drug, which SPUC says delivers 50 times the dosage of the daily mini-pill contraceptive, was made available from pharmacists without the need for a doctor's prescription in January this year.

The society's counsel, Richard Gordon QC, told Mr Justice Scott Baker that the change was unlawful under 19th century legislation because it permitted the commission of the administration or supply of poisons or instruments with the intent to procure miscarriage.

The 1861 Offences Against the Person Act prohibits the supply of "any poison or other noxious thing... with intent to procure the miscarriage of any woman, whether she be or be not with child".

Mr Gordon said that there was a strongly arguable case which raised very serious medical and legal issues. "It is the wider availability and the concomitant social effects which has caused SPUC to be concerned," he said.

Granting permission, the judge said he was persuaded that an issue existed that required resolution and it was better that it was decided in the civil courts than by way of private prosecutions brought in respect of specific supplies of the drug.

"There is an arguable case on what is fundamentally a very important question," he added.

John Smeaton, SPUC's national director, said recently: "Our case centres on the undeniable fact that the morning-after pill can cause the death of a newly conceived human being by preventing his or her implantation in the womb.

"Thus the morning-after pill can cause an early abortion, and should be subject to the controls set out in the 1967 Abortion Act."

Mr Smeaton said SPUC was "morally obliged" to oppose the wider availability of the morning-after pill and said that the pill could not be accurately described as a contraceptive because "it can cause the death of a newly-conceived embryo."

"It denies distinct and unique human individuals their right to life, and we cannot stand back and let this deception continue without raising our voices to defend the truth," he added.

fields.headline: Viewers scared off by Savages
fields.trailText: 1pm: The latest BBC1 sitcom from the creator of Men Behaving Badly has shed more than 1m viewers, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The latest BBC1 sitcom from the creator of Men Behaving Badly has shed more than 1m viewers between its first and second episodes.

The Simon Nye-scripted comedy, the Savages, about a couple juggling parenthood and careers was watched by just 4.2m viewers down from 5.6m the week before, according to unofficial overnights.

It went out between 9pm and 9.30pm on BBC1 last night but lost out to ITV prison drama Bad Girls, which pulled in 8.1m viewers and a 35% share.

Long-running Channel 4 documentary strand Cutting Edge opened its new run strongly last night, with the evocatively titled Bus Pass Bandits pulling in nearly 3m viewers.

Bus Pass Bandits - which featured OAPs who turn to crime, including Sunday school teacher turned embezzler Bunty McSkimming - went out between 9pm and 10pm on Channel 4.

The Cutting Edge documentary had 2.9m viewers and a 12% audience share.

IPC will announce today it is closing the relaunched version of the 60s and 70s style bible, Nova.

Staff are being informed of the closure, which will be confirmed later today.

Nova, which was relaunched last summer under the editorship of Deborah Bee, was positioned as an edgy, fashion based lifestyle magazine.

However, it was revamped just months after its launch by the former Sunday Times Style editor, Jeremy Langmead.

webTitle: Fat lady prepares to sing for Pavarotti

fields.headline: Fat lady prepares to sing for Pavarotti
fields.standfirst: The opera superstar Luciano Pavarotti will take on the role of defendant as he faces charges of tax evasion, writes Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: The opera superstar Luciano Pavarotti will take on the role of defendant as he faces charges of tax evasion, writes Rory Carroll.
fields.body:
Days after celebrating 40 years as an opera superstar, Luciano Pavarotti will today start a new role that could end not in applause but a three-year jail sentence.

The tenor will go on trial for alleged tax evasion in his birthplace, the northern Italian city of Modena, after failing to squash a legal saga. The biggest-earning opera virtuoso in history is accused of dodging £13m between 1989-95, when he catapulted to world fame singing Nessun Dorma for the 1990 World Cup.

He thought his tax troubles were over last July after agreeing with the finance ministry to pay almost £8m in arrears. Photographers were summoned to record his handshake with the then finance minister, Ottaviano del Turco. "I feel light of heart and of wallet," said Mr Pavarotti.

The accord appeased the government but not, it turned out, the prosecutors. They ordered him to stand trial. He is not expected to appear in court today but will be called upon to testify soon, as will other artists, friends and business managers.

Some will be flown in from the US for what the Italian press describes as the climax of Big Lucy's woes. A messy divorce and faltering voice are expected to accelerate his retirement.

At the heart of the trial will be claims that he pretended to reside in the tax haven of Monte Carlo instead of Modena. Prosecutors will say he rarely visited Monte Carlo and did not even know the location of his £200,000 flat.

In his hometown, however, he had a villa, a show-jumping complex and myriad investments and bank accounts. He is estimated to earn £35m annually and have a £300m fortune.

Since 1996, prosecutors, with the help of European and American colleagues, have pursued celebrities and businessmen who claim residence in Monaco. Mr Pavarotti, 66, denies fraud and says he paid tax in the countries where he performed. "He is a citizen of the world," said his lawyer.

Despite charity work and the adulation of loyalists, criticism has swelled in the past year that he was greedy and way past his peak. A concert last weekend in Modena, to celebrate the anniversary of his debut in La Bohème at Reggio Emilia in 1961, marked the last phase of his career.

"If this is not a swansong, it is something very close to it," he told La Repubblica. Critics say his golden years were in the 1970s. By the time Nessun Dorma stormed the charts in 1990 he was in decline. He admitted miming during a BBC broadcast in 1992 and has given several duff performances.

The American tycoon Donald Trump demanded his money back last year after a disastrous show at his Taj Mahal casino in the New Jersey gambling resort of Atlantic City. Mr Pavarotti made amends by returning months later to give a free, better-prepared performance.

Notwithstanding time and taxes, his retirement need not be imminent. Concerts are planned in Asia and the United States this and next year.

His father, Fernando, was optimistic. "I am still singing and I'm 89, so who knows how long Luciano can go on for."

webTitle: TUC head urges tube strike suspension

fields.headline: TUC head urges tube strike suspension
fields.trailText: John Monks, the general secretary of the TUC, today urged a rail union to call off the London Underground strike scheduled to begin this evening.
fields.body:
John Monks, the general secretary of the TUC, today urged a rail union to call off the London Underground strike scheduled to begin this evening.

He said that if the 24-hour walkout went ahead a proposed deal on jobs and safety would be withdrawn.

The Rail and Maritime Transport Union (RMT) is calling the strike over the government's planned partial privatisation of the tube.

It fears safety will be affected by the action and jobs will be lost.

Mr Monks has been involved in lengthy talks between the RMT and London Underground. A proposed agreement was reached but the rail union's executive decided last night that it fell short of the guarantees it was seeking.

In a letter to the RMT, Mr Monks said that "very considerable progress" was made during the talks and warned that if the strike went ahead an agreement already accepted by the driver's union, Aslef, would be withdrawn.

He invited the RMT executive to meet the TUC executive to try to find a way of resolving the dispute.

"In the meantime, however, to enable these discussions to take place with any chance of success, I would formally request the RMT's executive committee to suspend the industrial action," he said.

webTitle: At last, the chance to build a proper national stadium

fields.headline: At last, the chance to build a proper national stadium
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of Wembley
What's left now for the Wembley project?
fields.trailText: After months of fudge and evasion, yesterday's good news about the Wembley stadium project came in the form of the Football Association's long-awaited admission that the scheme is too big for them. At last it can be said: something in England is bigger than football.
fields.body:
After months of fudge and evasion, yesterday's good news about the Wembley stadium project came in the form of the Football Association's long-awaited admission that the scheme is too big for them. At last it can be said: something in England is bigger than football.

Of course the FA could afford to rebuild Wembley. It is drowning in money. Its bright-eyed young chief executive, Adam Crozier, announced a few days ago that next year the association's profit would probably reach £125m. On Monday the Premier League, the elite corps of English football, unveiled a new title sponsorship deal worth £48m over three years, on top of a television contract which will bring the clubs £800m over the same period. This is, after all, a game which pays 20-year-olds £20,000 a week.

But football is afraid to put its money where its dreams are, into a patch of land atop an unlovely hill in north London. Initially it asked for £120m of lottery money to buy the old stadium from its owners, granted on the basis that the total cost of the scheme would be around £340m, that the rest of the money would be found from City sources, and that the result would be a true national stadium suitable for the staging of a variety of major sporting events, with the FA acting not just as owners but as benevolent administrators.

It kept none of these promises. With a remarkable display of arrogance, the members of the board of the FA's Wembley National Stadium Ltd inflated the scheme to a cost of more than £600m, engineered a constructive dismissal of the other sports, and then failed to come up with the money. Backers who, in the words of WNSL's chief executive, Bob Stubbs, were "queuing up to talk to us" turned out to have been queuing up to say no. And now, having blundered into a cul de sac, the FA is telling the government that without a £150m subsidy, the project is dead.

In an effort to increase the pressure on ministers who would see the disappearance of a national stadium as a loss to the nation, the FA's spin doctors are putting it about that the temporary solution of playing international matches at club grounds and cup finals in Cardiff is working well enough to be considered as a permanent solution. This is nonsense. There are merits in taking some of England's games to Derby, Newcastle and Manchester, but who would wish to see the FA Cup final played for ever more in Wales, or the attendance for a match between England and Brazil match restricted to Old Trafford's 66,000?

Predictably, the circumstances have strained New Labour's love affair with New Football to the limit. The minister, Chris Smith, quite rightly resents the way he was hoodwinked over the removal of athletics from the scheme. A Downing Street spokesman said yesterday that the government was unwilling to become "a banker of last resort".

The best way out of the mess is straightforward enough. Since the FA has proved that it cannot be trusted with the task, it should forfeit its control. Taking heart from the success of Tate Modern and the London Eye, and encouraged by what the Millennium Stadium and the Stade de France have done for Cardiff and Paris, the government should use whatever lottery funds are necessary to build and run a national stadium fit for any kind of sporting event likely to attract a crowd of between 60-90,000, along with the necessary transportation facilities.

Having endured such a prolonged humiliation over the Dome, the government understandably distrusts grands travaux. Here, in a project which combines practical and symbolic value while genuinely catering to the national interest, is an opportunity to recover its nerve.

fields.headline: Top Banana: Calvin Klein
fields.standfirst: Banana skin and top banana is a new must-read awards section courtesy of MediaGuardian.co.uk. Every week you can nominate your heroes and villains - those men or women who have impressed or distressed you most with their media performance. This week, step forward and collect your coveted top banana trophy... Calvin Klein
fields.trailText: Why Tony Blair making a spectacle of himself was a PR scoop for Calvin Klein.
fields.body:
Winner: Calvin Klein
Age: 58
Description: grey-haired, aging guru of understated chic

Top Banana
Another greying, aging guru of understated chic, Tony Blair has unwittingly championed Clavin Klein's trendy spectacles this week.

Result
Almost blanket media coverage of Mr Blair's "coming out" with front-page coverage virtually everywhere. The Daily Telegraph reveals the model Mr Blair was seen wearing may have been borrowed when he left his Calvin's at home. Although the brand of the glasses is disputed - the PM has two pairs, one off-the-shelf and one CK pair - it is the fashion house that gets all the credit.

Effect 1
The brand therefore appears to have been endorsed by the most powerful man in Britain.

Effect 2
Mr Blair becomes a prime contender to follow in the footsteps of Martine McCutcheon, Natalie Appleton, Mel Sykes and Mel B and win the annual "Spectacle Wearer of the Year" award.

A Downing Street spokesman says
"I cannot comment on the brand of Mr Blair's glasses. But I can say that he's not the first 40-something to face up to wearing glasses and he won't be the last. You can't put off the inevitable forever."

A leading fashionista says
"His clear, single-minded point of view sets him apart. He reached back to his own beginning and revived the stark, yet sensual, styling that earned him the 'Mr Clean' badge." (Mary Rourke, former fashion editor of the Los Angeles Times was talking about Calvin, not Tony, of course.)

Next question
Does Mr Blair favour that other popular item of Calvin Klein menswear?

fields.headline: Wembley project nears collapse
fields.standfirst:
What now for the Wembley project?

Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: The long-running Wembley saga moved closer to complete fiasco last night when the Football Association announced that it was pulling out of financing the new national stadium, claiming that the plan could bankrupt the organisation.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary, Michael White and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
The long-running Wembley saga moved closer to complete fiasco last night when the Football Association announced that it was pulling out of financing the new national stadium, claiming that the plan could bankrupt the organisation.

The FA pleaded with the government to intervene in the construction of a new Wembley stadium and a working group, led by the home secretary, Jack Straw, will now examine a number of options. Its decision will not be announced until after the expected June election.

The options include building on a greenfield site away from London, or even abandoning the idea of a stadium for England. In that case the national team would play at club grounds around the country.

But the government last night ruled out financial support for a new national football stadium, either from taxpayers or lottery funds, claiming that it "cannot step in as a banker of last resort" for the troubled project.

The plan to open the stadium at the end of 2004 has been scrapped.

Tony Blair, while acknowledging the national interest is at stake, wants to stay at arms length after the Dome fiasco. However, the government is almost bound to be drawn in, as it has been to refinance Railtrack and other privatised disasters.

A government spokesman said: "We have made it clear that we remain committed to the proposals for a new national stadium and we will work with the various authorities to look at different options but that doesn't mean the government can simply write blank cheques or act as a national bank for projects which encounter difficulties."

The FA chief executive, Adam Crozier, said last night that a number of City institutions had asked his organisation to underwrite the entire £400m loan required for a new national stadium as well as contribute £125m towards it. In addition, the FA was being asked to repay £55m per annum in interest on the loan.

The FA had appointed the American bank Chase Manhattan, now known as JP Morgan, to raise the finance.

Mr Crozier said that the FA was not in a position to make such a financial commitment and that the government needed to provide such assurances, as has happened with the construction of stadiums in France and Australia.

Mr Crozier said: "We have to be clear and professional about what our role is. We are here to develop the game and we have to be realistic about how much money we can put into the project. It is not right for us to act as the sole sponsor of the scheme."

Mr Crozier also gave the strongest hint to date that the FA was prepared to not have a national stadium at all, with England matches being played at club grounds.

He added: "There's a huge appetite for England being on the road. We know that it can work. There are other countries who don't have national stadiums and it works quite well for them. Maybe it could work quite well for us as well."

When asked why public money should be given to football, the country's richest sport, Mr Crozier replied: "Everyone agrees that we would like a national stadium."

City insiders appeared shocked last night that the FA had apparently put the government over a barrel.

A spokesman for JP Morgan said: "We continue to believe that Wembley stadium is a viable project that should be able to ultimately attract the necessary levels of financing."

fields.headline: Plots thicken in South Africa
fields.standfirst: Thabo Mbeki's presidency is dogged by a bizarre array of conspiracy theories yet he has done little to set the record straight, writes Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: Thabo Mbeki's presidency is dogged by a bizarre array of conspiracy theories yet he has done little to set the record straight, writes Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
There comes a point in many supposed conspiracies when it all becomes too mad to make any sense.

That moment in the saga of whether or not there is a plot within the upper echelons of the ruling African National Congress to oust President Thabo Mbeki from office came when the security minister who made public the original allegations himself denied that he was trying to grab power.

Amid the questions around the charges and counter charges - Were heroes of the liberation struggle plotting to harm Mr Mbeki? Was the whole thing cooked up by Mr Mbeki's henchmen to crush any challenge to his rule? - the conspiracy had come full circle.

It was the security minister, Steve Tshwete, who set the whole debacle in train by publicly naming three leading anti-apartheid politicians - former ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa, and former provincial premiers Mathews Phosa and Tokyo Sexwale - as conspiring to "physically harm" and oust Mr Mbeki.

Mr Tshwete announced that a special police investigation was underway. It turned out to be on the flimsiest of evidence, principally the word of a disgraced ANC youth leader facing 77 counts of fraud.

But now it is Mr Tshwete himself who is the latest to deny he is part of a plot, this one supposedly an attempt to oust the deputy president, Jacob Zuma. South Africans may be confused but they can hardly be surprised. They have been subjected to a litany of alleged conspiracies against the president since he took power just two years ago.

If Mr Mbeki and his allies are to be believed the world's multinational businesses, the British government, the American central intelligence agency, even lowly doctors and nurses are perpetually plotting against him. And then there are the white South Africans regularly accused of everything from "subverting transformation" to besmirching the country's good name abroad.

Among the more derided of Mr Mbeki's recent theories was his claim that the CIA was working to destabilise him because he is challenging the world economic order. The problem with this theory is that South Africa's president is doing no such thing.

He is praised in western capitals and by the likes of the International Monetary Fund for his conservative economic policies and his obsession with foreign investment. It is at home that his financial priorities are none too popular.

Mr Mbeki also said that his advisers are seeking to discover who is spreading the idea that he is "deranged", and that too is part of a conspiracy against him. The sense of perpetual conspiracy is kept alive on the state radio, particularly a morning phone-in show on the South African Broadcasting Corporation.

A steady stream of Aids dissidents, historians and even an obscure German writer - who seemed to believe that while Britain's history made it unfit to advise anyone else on how to run their country, his nation provided a shining example to all - have got an airing in recent days.

They have one thing in common - they all reinforce the argument that Mr Mbeki is the victim of some undefined but usually neo-colonial international conspiracy to undermine his rule. These views go largely unchallenged by the show's host, Tim Modise.

Such theories usually have one central flaw - they ignore the fact South Africa is simply not so important to most of the rest of the world that other governments would spend much of their time conspiring to undermine Mr Mbeki.

The one person who has hardly been heard from throughout the most recent crisis is Mr Mbeki himself, and that has further fuelled the climate of suspicion. He has attempted to shrug off the political upheaval as overblown by the media, and entirely of Mr Tshwete's making.

But when he had the opportunity to criticise his own security minister for naming Mr Ramaphosa and the other suspects, he did not. Instead, he has also tried to portray the investigation as beyond his influence or control. Therefore, if it all turns out to be horribly embarrassing, Mr Mbeki will no doubt be able to dismiss it as another plot to discredit him.

webTitle: This was the vision. What's left now for the Wembley project?

fields.headline: This was the vision. What's left now for the Wembley project?
fields.standfirst:
Ministers to coordinate rescue attempt after collapse of FA plans

Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: Ministers are  to coordinate a rescue attempt for the Wembley stadium project after the FA announced it was pulling out of financing the deal. Vivek Chaudhary looks at the chances of success for the various options.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, will meet with a group of specially appointed officials in the next few weeks to discuss the Wembley stadium debacle and how it can be rescued from financial ruin. The ministerial working group, which includes the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and representatives from the City and football, will appoint an outside expert to examine the different options for salvaging the £660m national stadium project, which has caused severe embarrassment within government and sports circles as it has lurched from crisis to crisis.

Last December, Chelsea chairman Ken Bates, who headed Wembley National Stadium Ltd, the FA subsidiary company set up to oversee the project, was forced to step down after his plans proved too elaborate and costly. This resulted in City institutions refusing to fund the project. Sir Rodney Walker, head of the UK Sports Council, replaced Mr Bates and has spent the last few weeks assuring the City that the FA was willing to pledge £100m to the project.The FA was attempting to raise £400m from the City.

The latest setback has put the government in the driving seat and Mr Straw and his team will examine a number of options to revive the project. The working group will also attempt to resolve the vexed question of £120m of lottery money, which was given to WNSL to buy the Wembley site. The money has been spent but will have to be paid back if existing plans for a national stadium are changed.

A number of options will be presented to Mr Straw's ministerial working group:

1 Refurbishing the existing Wembley

This is an option that few within government or the FA favour. The current Wembley stadium is derelict and the pitch already dug up. Under this proposal, the outside structure of the stadium would not change but catering facilities, seats and pitch would be modernised. The capacity of a redeveloped Wembley stadium would only be around 65,000. This is considered a short term option that would not help a future England bid for a major tournament such as the World Cup or European Championship. Privately, the FA has already told the government that it is against refurbishment. But it would prove to be cheap and the stadium could be reopened within two years. It would also mean that the FA would not have to pay back the £120m lottery money it was given because a revamped stadium falls within the lottery agreement.
Chances 1/10

2 New site for a national stadium

Both Ken Bates, former chairman of WNSL, and Sir Rodney Walker, the current chairman, told a select committee of MPs they were not in favour of a new national stadium being constructed on the site of the existing Wembley stadium. Mr Bates backed Manchester while Mr Walker said that a stadium somewhere in the midlands - perhaps Milton Keynes - would have been a better option. The min isterial working group and influential people within the FA, are keen that a new site option is closely examined. A stadium in the midlands, the favoured option, would allow easy access to the majority of the country if it was constructed close to a motorway and railway station with enough room for parking and conference facilites. Land and construction costs would be much cheaper.

Some within the FA believe a state-of-the art national stadium outside London could be built for under £300m. This option is backed by a number of football chairmen. Like Wembley, the neutral venue would be used for England international matches, end of the season play-off matches and all cup finals. If this option is chosen the lottery money would have to be returned.
Chances 8/10

3 Ground share national stadium

Sources within the FA have revealed that a possible ground share with a Premiership team playing at a national stadium is another option they are considering. Some talks have taken place with Arsenal on a possible ground share at a new Wembley. This would please City institutions, who would be more willing to fund the project knowing that there was going to be regular income. At least two home matches a month would take place at the new stadium, and all construction and running costs could be split with the football club that shares it.

One of the main problems could lie with Brent council, the local authority. It has said that planning permission has been granted for a national stadium and not for a league stadium, where regular matches would take place. Wembley residents are against such a plan. The lottery funding agreement would also have to be changed with the £120m returned.

David Dein, who is on the FA board and deputy chairman of Arsenal, supports this option. The north London club want to move from their ground at Highbury to a new ground close by, a plan opposed by residents. Mr Dein believes that sharing the national stadium could solve his problems if Arsenal are denied planning permission for a new ground in north London.
Chances 5/10

4 No national stadium

Argentina, Brazil, Spain, Portugal and other leading football nations do not have a national stadium. The FA chief execu tive, Adam Crozier, has said that the current practice of England touring around the country has worked well, leading to large crowds and good atmospheres, even for friendlies -something that was not always the case at the old Wembley. Given that a number of Premiership grounds have a capacity of over 50,000, hosting England internationals would not be a problem.

The FA is prepared to do without a national stadium if the project cannot be rescued by the government. There could however, be problems in fixing dates for matches if internationals are only played at club grounds (matches could clash) and it would also be a major dent to the FA's prestige, given the importance once attached to Wembley.
Chances 4/10

5 Stick with existing plans

That would mean the government underwrites the entire project and a new stadium is built as currently planned.
Chances: Will probably depend on the outcome of the general election

6 Return to the orginal brief

Wembley would become an 80,000-capacity stadium capable of hosting athletics and other sports. It would also allow for a British Olympic bid. This option would also include an adjoining athletics track for warming up. Opponents claim that spectators would be too far away from the pitch during football matches, affecting the atmosphere, and the sight lines in the stadium make for poor viewing.
Chances 6/10

Countdown to failure

September Australian construction company Multiplex will sign contract to build stadium for £326.5m. Plans to open the new ground with the 2003 FA Cup Final are shelved

October Demolition work put back indefinitely as bankers Chase Manhattan fail to raise the £410m required

December Sir Rodney Walker appointed chairman of WNSL in place of Chelsea chairman Ken Bates

February 2001 Bates quits the WNSL board, claiming senior government and FA figures undermined him

May 1 FA admits the project is doomed unless the government bails it out

webTitle: Russia and China attack US missile plan

fields.headline: Russia and China attack US missile plan
fields.standfirst:
China today accused the US of threatening world peace by pushing ahead with plans for a missile defence system

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: China today accused the US of threatening world peace by pushing ahead with plans for a missile defence system.
fields.body:
China today accused the US of threatening world peace by pushing ahead with plans for a missile defence system. Russia offered more mixed reactions to President Bush's speech last night, but military sources warned the plans could spark a new arms race.

Chinese state news agency Xinhua, often a mouthpiece for the Chinese government, highlighted criticism of the plan by experts.

"Analysts said the US plan to build a missile defence system will not only spark a new arms race and create a proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, but will also threaten world peace and security in the 21st century," Xinhua reported.

US defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld has partially justified Mr Bush's announcement by citing China's missile build-up. Tensions between the US and China have risen since American labelled China as a "strategic competitor" and because of the row over the American spy plane that collided with a Chinese fighter.

China feels aggrieved by America's project as it could render useless its small nuclear deterrent of 20 warheads.

Mr Bush yesterday vowed to press ahead with the deployment of the missile defence system, arguing that the world had moved beyond the outdated framework of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty with Russia. The treaty banned missile defence systems, in order to curb the temptation of a first-strike nuclear attack during the cold war.

Russian misgivings about ditching the ABM treaty were reiterated by Russian MP and head of the parliamentary foreign affairs committee, Dmitry Rogozin. "If the United States actually go through with their intention to abandon the 1972 treaty, that would destroy the entire security system we have today," Mr Rogozin told the Interfax news agency.

While Moscow reacted positively to proposed cuts in the US nuclear arsenal, which it said could pave the way for "a renewal of Russian-US consultations on strategic stability in general", Russian military and diplomatic sources re-iterated warnings of the dangers of scrapping the ABM treaty.

The sources were quoted by Interfax as saying: "Many in Washington understand that the destruction of ABM and deploying an anti-missile shield could undermine the system of strategic stability which exists in the world today and lead to a new arms race"

South Korea also signalled unease over the US plan by appealing to Mr Bush to closely consult with allies before deploying its missile shield, designed to defend the US and its allies from missile attacks by "rogue" states such as North Korea and Iraq.

The Japanese response was more reticent, with Japanese officials saying that Tokyo would decide whether to support Mr Bush's proposals after examining the diplomatic and security implications of the new US nuclear strategy.

But Japan is concerned that the "son of star wars" project will cause a regional arms race as China speeds up its missile build-up, triggering similar moves in India and Pakistan.

webTitle: Housing Corporation attacked for £1.5m housing fraud

fields.headline: Housing Corporation attacked for £1.5m housing fraud
fields.trailText: An influential committee of MPs has attacked the Housing Corporation for failing to prevent a £1.5m fraud in one of the country's largest housing associations, despite six early warnings.
fields.body:
An influential committee of MPs has attacked the Housing Corporation for failing to prevent a £1.5m fraud in one of the country's largest housing associations, despite six early warnings.

Two former employees of Birmingham-based Focus housing association and a property dealer were jailed a year ago over bribes in connection to the purchase of 47 houses between 1991 and 1995, many at inflated prices.

The fraud eventually cost Focus £1.5m, which has mostly been borne by the association's tenants.

In a report today, the Commons' public accounts committee says the losses could have been reduced, or avoided altogether, if Focus and the corporation had acted earlier. It also criticised the way the investigation was handled and attacked the corporation for blocking a separate national audit office (NAO) investigation into the case.

The report points out that between them, Focus and the corporation had been warned of impropriety six times before action was taken.

It says the way the corporation inspected the case "fell below the standards expected of a regulator." It says allegations of impropriety were handled in an "unsystematic and informal way".

The fraud investigation has also become a key battle in a turf war between the housing corporation and national audit office over access to housing associations' files.

As parliament's spending watchdog, the NAO was asked to investigate the way the corporation supervised Focus in the wake of the fraud allegations. The NAO was only given access by the corporation six months after the first request was made.

Committee chairman David Davis said: "My committee would not expect to see another case of such complete disregard for parliamentary scrutiny."

The report says: "The Focus case underlines the need for a statutory right of access to allow the NAO to report to parliament about the proper use of public funds."

The NAO produced a separate study on the case last year. The committee's report, which is a response to that study, calls for a raft of changes to help detect fraud in future.

It called for better record keeping in housing associations and for more openness about data on property transactions. It also calls for the corporation to be designated under the Public Interest Disclosure Act to protect whistleblowers in the housing association sector.

The report adds: "The corporation should provide its staff with clear guidance on action to be taken when allegations of impropriety are received, and ensure that all allegations are properly investigated."

Mr Davis added: "Suggestions of corruption should always be taken seriously and investigated promptly and thoroughly. In this case warning signs were ignored for too long, leaving public funds unnecessarily exposed."

webTitle: Young Tories speculate on demise of Hague

fields.headline: Young Tories speculate on demise of Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: William Hague's future as leader of the Conservative party, the barminess of Ann Widdecombe and the disloyalty of Michael Portillo are openly being discussed by Conservative Future, the party's official youth wing, leaked papers show.
fields.body:
William Hague's future as leader of the Conservative party, the barminess of Ann Widdecombe and the disloyalty of Michael Portillo are openly being discussed by Conservative Future, the party's official youth wing, leaked papers show.

The papers also reveal members of Conservative Future - which has two full time staff at central office - speculating on the extent to which Hague has to cut Labour's Commons majority to survive. The revelations come in a string of private emails to an internet chat-room and will embarrass Mr Hague as he tries to maintain the fiction that his leadership is not under threat.

One contributor, Georgina Hill, suggested: "If Labour win by between 80 and 120, Hague's position will be difficult. If it is between 120 or more, then his position would be seriously under threat.

"As for the best successor in the event of him going there are serious question marks over the three leading candidates - 1 Portillo (selling out and being ineffectual against Brown), 2 Widdecombe (barmy, especially on drugs), 3 Clarke (Europe, but perfect apart from that)".

Contributor Charles Morelli admits in an email dated April 20: "It is clear that certain people inside or outside the parliamentary party have given up on the general election and are now focusing on their own careers after it.

"The speculation over the leadership and the controversy over the commission for racial equality pledge have been like a re-run of the 1997 campaign. This can only lead to the same result ..."

Eliot Gold, a member of the Conservative Future national executive, complains "the parliamentary party is the most disloyal part of the Conservative party".

fields.bodyText: William Hague's future as leader of the Conservative party, the barminess of Ann Widdecombe and the disloyalty of Michael Portillo are openly being discussed by Conservative Future, the party's official youth wing, leaked papers show. fields.headline: Nova dies despite relaunch
fields.trailText: The relaunch of Nova, the quintessential style bible of the 1960s, coincided with a spirit of British optimism not seen since that heady decade, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The relaunch of Nova, the quintessential style bible of the 1960s, coincided with a spirit of British optimism not seen since that heady decade.

At the time of its 1999 relaunch, pundits pointed to the parallels of the magazines, both launched just after a general election had swept away a long-period of Tory rule, both celebrating a new sense of joie de vivre and national pride.

Less than two years on, that joie-de-vivre is notably absent from the publishing industry.

With the prospect of a recession looming and the Labour honeymoon period very much over, it seems almost fitting that the magazine should be biting the dust.

Magazine journalism veterans claim that Nova Mk II was always a pale shadow of its former self.

Launched in 1965 by what was then the Mirror Group's magazines division (which became IPC), under editor Dennis Hackett, Nova had a huge impact on the fashion of the day, launching the career of the renowned Molly Parkin.

Its design became synonymous with the kind of style we now think epitomises the cusp of the 60s and 80s.

Nova never shied away from the kind of fodder which would now be written off as too highbrow for women's magazine reader, famously carrying a feature about homosexual law reform.

And it showed that aspirational and intelligent are not mutually exclusive, showcasing the culinary talents of the venerable Elizabeth David.

Caroline Baker, a journalist on the original magazine and now fashion director at You magazine, said she was not surprised by the closure.

"It was exactly like all the other magazines and failed to capture the British public's imagination. They should have left the old one alone, not tried to bring it back."

fields.headline: Marketing Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: May 3
fields.trailText: The £10m Carphone Warehouse advertising account is poised to leave TBWA London, following the decision by two senior staff, Simon Clemmow and Johnny Hornby, to set up an agency.
fields.body:
The £10m Carphone Warehouse advertising account is poised to leave TBWA London, following the decision by two senior staff, Simon Clemmow and Johnny Hornby, to set up an agency.

Red Bull, the UK's biggest selling energy drink, is facing a European embargo that could destroy exports to the Continent after the Norwegian government classed it a medicine and banned sales in retail outlets.

Abbey National has appointed the savings and banking director, Janet Connor, to the role of retail marketing director.

Trinity Mirror is looking for a marketing director for all its major titles following the departure of Margaret Harvey, who left her job last week.

Procter & Gamble is launching a powder that aims to make water safer to drink in third world countries.

McDonald's has come under fire from the Independent Television Commission. The watchdog ruled a teaser advert for a "buy one get one free" promotion was misleading.

Freeserve has appointed the former AOL marketing chief, Keith Hawkins, to the newly created position of managing director of marketing.

Perrier will be relaunched in plastic bottles this summer in an effort to make the brand more appealing to a wider market.

Audley Harrison, the British Olympic heavyweight boxing champion, has set up a company, A-Force, to deal in sponsorship and TV rights.

The Premier League football club, Ipswich Town, has signed a three season shirt sponsorship deal with the electricity and gas supplier, TXU Europe. The deal is worth up to £7m.

Prudential is reviewing its £20m direct marketing business.

Barclaycard has eight days to notify Granada Enterprises whether it wants to sponsor ITV's coverage of the FA Premier League.

fields.headline: Wednesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours wish Shaggy, a factory worker from Peterborough, would cut his hair
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle will attempt an "oldies revolution" to kickstart Tottenham's fortunes, reports the Daily Express. The paper believes that Hoddle is keen to recreate the effect that his signing of the then 32-year-old Ruud Gullit had on Chelsea. The names in the zimmer frame include Oliver Bierhoff, Emmanuel Petit, Steffen Effenberg, and even Denis Irwin.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle will attempt an "oldies revolution" to kickstart Tottenham's fortunes, reports the Daily Express. The paper believes that Hoddle is keen to recreate the effect that his signing of the then 32-year-old Ruud Gullit had on Chelsea. The names in the zimmer frame include Oliver Bierhoff, Emmanuel Petit, Steffen Effenberg, and even Denis Irwin.

Emmanuel Petit has begged Arsenal to take him back to Highbury, according to the Mirror. They quote Arsene Wenger as saying: "I've not made a decision yet but I know that Manu is really interested in having a new experience with us." Petit has been offered for sale to English clubs for £8m, but the Mirror believes Arsenal will go no higher than £5m for the 30-year-old.

Midas Soccer reports that Everton defender Michael Ball is a £3.5m target for Celtic.

The Daily Express believes Fulham will end David Ginola's Aston Villa "despair" and bring him to Craven Cottage for £1.5m. Jean Tigana is a big fan of the ageing winger, according to the paper.

Having been linked with the managers' job at Rangers, Crystal Palace and Southampton, today's Sun suggests that George Graham could be set for some work at Middlesbrough, if Terry Venables leaves the club in the summer.

Boro's Paul Okon is a target for Valencia. Teamtalk believe that Hector Cuper is a fan of the Australian utility player, who has only recently broken into the Boro first team. The Champions League semi-finalists may make a bid this summer, if Cuper is still in charge by then.

Even more Middlesbrough news: the club are considering a £2m bid for Nantes' on-loan playmaker Stephane Ziani. The 29-year-old has helped steer Nantes towards the French title, but according to The Times, Boro are confident he will swap Champions League football for the north-east in the summer.

Chelsea and Aston Villa both want Manchester United's Dwight Yorke. But the striker doesn't want to move. "I've got two years remaining at this club, and they know that I want to stay here and that I want to be a Manchester United player for as long as possible," he told Midas Soccer.

In more scintillating Nantes news, Sedan midfielder Olivier Quint has revealed to Planet Football that he turned down a move to Liverpool in favour of joining the Canaries. "With Liverpool the offer was really concrete as Pascal Urano [Sedan club president] and Gerard Houllier were in negotiations," said Quint. Midas Soccer however believe he's never been approached by Liverpool at all.

Sunderland's quest for a new striker has taken them to Germany and 18-year-old Christian Bienemann. According to Teamtalk, Peter Reid is looking to snatch the forward from under the noses of FC Schalke and Borussia Dortmund after he impressed at a recent trial.

fields.headline: Samaritans target farmers with TV adverts
fields.trailText:
11.45am: The Samaritans are rushing out a TV campaign urging farmers to seek help following a series of suicides. By >B>Claire Cozens.

Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Samaritans are rushing out a TV campaign urging farmers to seek help following a series of suicides related to the foot and mouth crisis.

The hard-hitting commercial uses real news footage showing the effects of foot and mouth on the farming community.

It is designed to highlight the isolation of those hit by the crisis in farming and tourism, and forms part of the charity's Emergency Rural Stress campaign.

The Samaritans wants to persuade those affected by the crisis that there is no shame in seeking help.

The group said volunteers at 203 branches throughout the UK and Ireland will be available to provide confidential emotional support 24 hours a day by phone, letter or in person.

"In a very compelling way this film shows the huge pressure that people are under," said Simon Armson, the chief executive of the Samaritans.

"We can provide a light at the end of the tunnel for those enduring enormous emotional distress as a result of the rural crisis and who may be worried about loss of livelihood."

The commercial was created by Ogilvy & Mather, with media planning and buying by MindShare.

"It is vital we display true empathy with the emotional distress and dispair that people faced by this crisis are experiencing," said Steve Dunn, the executive creative director of O&M.

The advert will be screened for the first time later this week.

MediaGuardian.co.uk special report

webTitle: Letters: We're fixing those leaks, says Transco

fields.headline: We're fixing those leaks, says Transco
fields.trailText: Transco is responsible for the safe operation of 24m gas pipes under 800,000 streets, and nothing is more important than public safety. Following your article (Gas safety crisis highlighted by insiders, April 30), I wish to reassure your readers about the safety of the British gas system.
fields.body:
Transco is responsible for the safe operation of 24m gas pipes under 800,000 streets, and nothing is more important than public safety. Following your article (Gas safety crisis highlighted by insiders, April 30), I wish to reassure your readers about the safety of the British gas system.

Measured objectively by the performance of Transco's emergency service and other yardsticks, and recently confirmed by major audits undertaken by the health and safety executive, the industry's public safety standards today are considerably higher than those of the old nationalised industry. Specifically: Transco has sufficient engineers to ensure safety, and continues to exceed the regulatory requirement to attend at least 97% of all reports of gas emergencies within an hour. The article refers to an increase in those escapes assessed as posing no danger and left for later repair. Nationally the number of such escapes has dropped substantially in the last year.

Transco is addressing its obligations under the working time directive and is in discussion with the trade unions about recruiting and training several hundred engineers, as well as 150 apprentices, to meet the demands of next winter.

Transco has long used competent contractors, but less than 5% of emergency work is undertaken by them. Transco's current restructuring will enhance the drive for improving public safety standards and this will be safeguarded by the need for HSE's consent to any organisational change affecting the safety case. Transco's programme to replace metal mains is devised in agreement with the HSE. Meanwhile, the case for accelerating the programme is under discussion with the HSE and Transco's economic regulator, Ofgem.

Phil Nolan
Chief executive, Transco

 You quote "Transco ... is 950 engineers short". On the following page we learn that "Transco made 1,000 engineers redundant four years ago". Why are they redundant if the jobs are still there? Who believes anybody anymore? Pass the lighter: I think there is a leak somewhere.

Ray Chalker
London ray@educom-111.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Prescott defends PPP
fields.trailText: Your leader (May 1) says we will be paying for the government's tube plans for 30 years. The truth is we are all paying for decades of under-investment in the London underground. The last government averaged £395m a year investment in the tube. And although this government has raised core investment to over £500m a year, we need to secure much more to transform the tube.
fields.body:
Your leader (May 1) says we will be paying for the government's tube plans for 30 years. The truth is we are all paying for decades of under-investment in the London underground. The last government averaged £395m a year investment in the tube. And although this government has raised core investment to over £500m a year, we need to secure much more to transform the tube.

That is what the public private partnership (PPP) will do. It will end the short-term financial uncertainty that has plagued the tube for years and it will guarantee long-term investment on an unprecedented scale. It will deliver better reliability, improved safety and security (with CCTV in every carriage). Every train will be replaced or refurbished and every station will also be refurbished or modernised, with many stations completely rebuilt.

The PPP is not privatisation. Most staff and functions will remain with the publicly owned London Underground, which will operate all the trains, signals and stations. The assets will remain in public ownership. Private contractors will rebuild or fix the infrastructure, on 30-year contracts and, on completion, the infrastructure will be returned to London Underground. What is so special about the PPP is that major companies will be paid by results, be responsible for overspends and invest their own capital in improving the tube.

You suggest the PPP is unsafe. I challenge you, as I have done the mayor, to back that up with evidence. London Underground is already one of the safest metros in the world - with a better safety record than cities like New York or Paris. Under the PPP, London Underground will continue to have overall responsibility for safety. We have always made clear the PPP cannot go ahead unless the safety case is approved and accepted by the independent health and safety executive (HSE).
John Prescott MP
Deputy prime minister
