fields.headline: In support of the protests
fields.trailText: That oxymoron "police intelligence" cropping up in your story on the expected violence in London shows once again the length the authorities will go to to stifle expression of genuine concerns (Blair attacks "spurious" May Day protests, May 1). Six years ago, I experienced "police intelligence" first hand while demonstrating against live animal exports in Brightlingsea and elsewhere. It is accompanied by riot gear and shifts everything in its way by brute force. I am not a young "anarchist". I am 60 and used to think the police did a good job in difficult circumstances. The reality is they are used more and more to enforce minority interests on the decent majority.
fields.body:
That oxymoron "police intelligence" cropping up in your story on the expected violence in London shows once again the length the authorities will go to to stifle expression of genuine concerns (Blair attacks "spurious" May Day protests, May 1). Six years ago, I experienced "police intelligence" first hand while demonstrating against live animal exports in Brightlingsea and elsewhere. It is accompanied by riot gear and shifts everything in its way by brute force. I am not a young "anarchist". I am 60 and used to think the police did a good job in difficult circumstances. The reality is they are used more and more to enforce minority interests on the decent majority.

The C4 survey (Confusion reigns as police brace for mayhem, May 1) shows the vast majority don't want GM food, hunting with hounds, animal testing of household chemicals, pollution, domination of peoples' lives by non-elected big money interests. Unfortunately, we've got it and we're stuck with it. Good luck to all those who demonstrated in London. Would that more of us had the courage.

Derek Metson
Brightlingsea, Essex

 Somewhere in Whitehall there must be a supply of statements and quotes which can easily be trotted out in times when people decide to take direct action. In a book that documents the lives of some 50 great people in history, my 10-year-old daughter had chosen Emmeline Pankhurst. It tells how, when they were unable to get women "included" in civic society, since the men would not listen or respond, the suffragettes turned to direct action - presumably an earlier example of "protesters, in the name of some spurious cause" seeking "to inflict fear, terror, violence and criminal damage on our people and property".

I am intrigued as to what my daughter will make of Tony's comments. After all, Emmeline Pankhurst eventually joined the Conservative party.

Cliff Allum
Birmingham

 Those who choose to contrast the anti-capitalist protests with the peaceful events of Nelson Mandela's visit forget that armed struggle was needed to challenge the apartheid system. This kind of strategy is overwhelmingly rejected by the new movement against global capitalism, in spite of the government's recent attempts to label us all as "terrorists".

John Cooper
Birmingham

 George Monbiot argues (May 1) cogently against those who justify their anti-capitalist violence by pointing to capitalist violence. Gandhi put it better: an eye for an eye makes a blind world.

Joe Devas London

 What would Tony Blair suggest as a more effective way of protesting against the growth of corporate and multinational power and the attendant democratic deficit? Voting Labour every five years in the hope that they might address some of these issues? Or perhaps writing a nice letter to one of the new peers?

Rob Manwaring
London

 I do admire the tactics of the May Day protesters. They wound up the powers-that-be to such an extent before that the latter overreacted, trying to anticipate what would happen. Result: everything they thought might be a "target" boarded up. Riot police (on overtime) lurking round street corners. Clever.

Deborah Loe Maidenhead, Berks

Deborah.Loe@tvu.ac.uk

 I could see who was out on the streets of London looking for trouble yesterday and it wasn't the people calling themselves protesters.

Laura Collignon London

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide should be sold
fields.trailText: Peter Bazalgette, the man behind some of TV's biggest hits including Changing Rooms and Big Brother has called for BBC's commercial arm to be privatised, writes Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
Peter Bazalgette, the man behind some of TV's biggest hits including Changing Rooms and Big Brother has called for BBC's commercial arm to be privatised.

In an online chat with MediaGuardian, the creative director of Endemol Entertainment branded BBC Worldwide "anti-competitive".

And he said the BBC could lose its way because it was consumed by a "mania" that it had to be bigger than anyone else.

"BBC Worldwide should be privatised.

"It's anti-competitive to use publicly funded programmes to drive books, videos, magazines etc in a BBC-owned company.

"All the publishers and magazine companies should be allowed to bid for BBC business and the BBC should be paid royalties on its intellectual property," he said.

"This intellectual property 'board' at the BBC should also be allowed to take minority stakes such as the UKTV investment to ensure that it gets a return from channels with BBC programmes where there has been capital growth as a result of those programmes.

"Sometimes the BBC has a mania to be bigger and bigger but that is not actually the point of the organisation," he said.

He added that the biggest challenge for Greg Dyke "is to stay radical and not go native."

Mr Bazelgette also said that he believed the BBC was moving in the right direction by moving the Nine O'Clock News and introducing a new-look schedule on BBC1.

"I advocated moving the Nine O'Clock News two years ago in the Guardian. Greg did it because he's competitive and good for him.

"I don't really buy all these "public service" justifications. What's absurd is having politicians and regulators trying to schedule channels when there are four 24-hour news channels as well as radio, the internet etc," he said.

And he said the BBC was right to get involved in digital television. "None of us have any idea whether anything in the digital world will work. But we have to be there and the BBC's no exception. The question is how many channels, at what cost and how to ensure fair competition."

fields.headline: Tourism gets £12m boost
fields.trailText: Tourism bosses have welcomed a £12m injection of government cash to tempt visitors back to Britain after the foot and mouth crisis, writes Claire Cozens
fields.body:
Tourism bosses have welcomed a £12m injection of government cash to tempt visitors back to Britain after the foot and mouth crisis.

Culture secretary Chris Smith said the money would support the British Tourist Authority's new advertising campaign to hammer home the message that Britain is still a great place for a holiday.

It is hoped the adverts will help reverse estimated losses to the tourism industry of up to £2.5bn of its £13bn-a-year trade.

The cash adds to a previous £6m boost for tourism advertising and brings to more than £250m the total government support given to business in the wake of the outbreak.

Mr Smith said the countryside was "returning to normal" and that it was vital to get the message across to potential visitors from overseas that Britain was open for business.

"The British countryside is returning to normal and it is important that we get this message across both at home and abroad," he said. "Tourists need to know what we all know - that Britain is a great holiday destination. This money will help that effort."

The new cash will go to Britain's tourist boards to be spent on adverts and other marketing initiatives, which Whitehall sources said had been shown to produce £30 of tourist spending for every £1 spent.

New research by the BTA has shown that 85% of attractions are now open and 93% of events are due to go ahead as planned, despite the disruption caused by foot-and-mouth.

The UK's top 10 visitor attractions and top 10 admission fee-charging heritage properties are all open.

"I am pleased the government has recognised the urgent need to invest in overseas tourism promotion," said BTA chairman David Quarmby said. "We can now get straight on with promotional activities in all the affected markets to boost visits from overseas for the summer, and with initiating a longer-term programme to re-present Britain to the world, starting in the autumn."

fields.headline: Tourism gets £12m boost
fields.trailText: Tourism bosses have welcomed a £12m injection of government cash to tempt visitors back to Britain after the foot and mouth crisis, Claire Cozens
fields.body:
Tourism bosses have welcomed a £12m injection of government cash to tempt visitors back to Britain after the foot and mouth crisis.

Culture secretary Chris Smith said the money would support the British Tourist Authority's new advertising campaign to hammer home the message that Britain is still a great place for a holiday.

fields.headline: Closing in on Saddam
fields.trailText: Your leader (April 26) on the decision by the attorney general to send Indict's files to Scotland Yard is correct in pointing out that Saddam Hussein and his co-conspirators have never been formally indicted for war crimes, crimes against humanity and other gross breaches of human rights under the international conventions to which Iraq is party - that is why the decision is so important. The process is certainly not an academic exercise. If warrants are issued, Saddam or Aziz could be arrested if they travel to any country which is a signatory of the Taking of Hostages convention or which has extradition arrangements with the UK. Any country failing to honour an arrest warrant would breach the terms of the convention - a step likely to have lasting diplomatic and political repercussions.
fields.body:
Your leader (April 26) on the decision by the attorney general to send Indict's files to Scotland Yard is correct in pointing out that Saddam Hussein and his co-conspirators have never been formally indicted for war crimes, crimes against humanity and other gross breaches of human rights under the international conventions to which Iraq is party - that is why the decision is so important. The process is certainly not an academic exercise. If warrants are issued, Saddam or Aziz could be arrested if they travel to any country which is a signatory of the Taking of Hostages convention or which has extradition arrangements with the UK. Any country failing to honour an arrest warrant would breach the terms of the convention - a step likely to have lasting diplomatic and political repercussions.

Indict is advised by a leading QC in the Pinochet case that the evidence already gathered is "more than sufficient" to provide a realistic prospect of conviction. As to the power of detectives, they have no need to investigate inside Iraq, as thousands of British hostages are resident in the UK and the hostage-taking took place primarily in Kuwait. It is inconceivable that the Kuwait government will not cooperate fully with any investigation there.

Perhaps even more important, the case, we believe, will establish, in line with the Pinochet ruling in the Lords, that heads of state, as well as former heads of state, do not have immunity from prosecution for international human rights abuses, especially where they disturb international order.

Ann Clwyd MP

fields.headline: Last chance saloon for midwifery
fields.standfirst: Maternity services are about to get a £100m investment -  which may just help give the profession  the recognition it deserves, says Jane Sandall
fields.trailText: Maternity services are about to get a £100m investment - which may just help give the profession the recognition it deserves, says Jane Sandall.
fields.body:
Health secretary Alan Milburn has pledged to invest £100m in improving midwifery services for women. His speech shows he has responded to many of the arguments and carefully martialled evidence that the House of Commons maternity care working party, women's organisations and the Royal College of Midwives (RCM) have been proposing.

I welcome Mr Milburn's recognition of the contribution of that midwives make. What midwives need now is the authority within existing structures to implement this vision.

I welcome the commitment to more pay and the development of leadership in midwifery and the appointment of more consultant midwives.

The challenge to delivering increased choices for women and greater levels of continuity of carer are about recognising the nature of the midwifery workforce.

Some 99.9% of midwives are women, over 50% work part time. Many have caring commitments and the NHS has a long way to go on delivering family friendly working patterns.

This is not about childcare, this is about recognising and valuing the contribution of part-time midwives and accommodating their needs by reviewing out-of-date working practices.

Yes, we have a shortage of midwives, but one of the reasons midwives have left the NHS is that they can't get on with the job they do best.

There needs to be a major review of how health professionals work in maternity care and the greater contribution that can be made by clerical staff and maternity assistants.

I welcome the commitment to providing women with the choice of where they give birth, although thought needs to be given as to how this is practically achieved.

One of the reasons that there are wide variations in the home birth rate is due to the commitment of midwifery managers and the organisation of midwifery services so that midwives can provide and offer home birth without detriment to their personal lives.

If there were a commitment to providing each midwife who provides home birth with her own equipment and a mobile phone, this would increase women's choices, but of course it costs money.

I welcome the targets for reducing health inequalities, but the range of sure start schemes around the country need to be rigorously evaluated.

Let's not fall into the trap we fell into following Changing Childbirth (the review of maternity services in the early 90s), where numerous short-term pilot schemes were evaluated on a shoestring due to lack of funding and seven years down the line, we still have a poor evidence base for how we organise maternity care.

We also need to invest in the research and development that provides the evidence base for midwifery care.

In sum, we've been here before. When Changing Childbirth was published, midwives and women's groups were delighted with the proposed changes.

But one of the major causes of disillusionment among midwives has been the thankless task of developing new ways of working with no extra funding, at a personal cost to their private lives, to find that good schemes were shut down due to lack of resources.

I welcome the commitment to improving the care of pregnant women and their families, but if there is no funding for implementation and if midwives are excluded from determining at a local level how care should be organised and delivered, then I really do worry that in five years' time, we will not have a midwifery profession, but an overmedicalised, dehumanised system of care staffed by obstetric nurses.

 Jane Sandall is professor of midwifery and women's health King's College London

fields.headline: Gianluca Vialli factfile
fields.trailText: 1964: Born Cremona, Italy, July 9. The son of a millionaire, he is brought up in a castle.
fields.body:
1964: Born Cremona, Italy, July 9. The son of a millionaire, he is brought up in a castle.

1980: Signs for local club Cremonese but his first full season is unspectacular with just five goals in 31 appearances.

1984: After scoring 10 goals for Cremonese he is signed by Sampdoria.

1985: Wins Italian Cup with Sampdoria, a feat he repeats in 1988 and 1989. Makes debut for Italy against Poland.

1986: Included in Italy squad for Mexico World Cup finals.

1990: Sampdoria win European Cup Winners' Cup with Vialli scoring twice. Plays in the Italian team that finishes third in World Cup.

1991: Sampdoria win Italian championship. Vialli finishes as Serie A's top scorer with 16 goals.

1992: Plays in European Cup final but finishes on losing side against Barcelona at Wembley. Juventus pay a world record £12.5m to bring him to Turin.

1993: Wins Uefa Cup with Juventus, beating Borussia Dortmund in final.

1994: Left out of Italy's 1994 World Cup squad by Arrigo Sacchi.

1995: Juventus win league and cup double with 16 goals from Vialli. Scores spectacular goal in second leg of Uefa Cup final against Parma, but Juventus lose. Voted world player of the year.

1996: Skippers Juventus to victory in the 1996 European Cup final in his last game for the club. Joins Chelsea on a free transfer in the summer for £1m a year after rejecting offer from Rangers.

1997: Feud develops with Chelsea coach Ruud Gullit as he is regularly left out of the starting line-up. Wins FA Cup winners' medal after coming on as 89th-minute substitute in 2-0 final victory over Middlesbrough.

1998: Installed as Chelsea's new player-manager following Gullit's shock departure. Takes Chelsea to victory in the Coca-Cup final against Middlesbrough at Wembley and in the European Cup Winners' Cup against Stuttgart in Stockholm.

2000: Misses out on qualification for the Champions League but guides the Blues to an FA Cup final victory over Aston Villa.

September: Chelsea take just six points from their first five Premiership matches of the 2000/01 season and Vialli is sacked. The Blues said in a statement: "It is in our best interests to seek a change of direction."

2001: Vialli embarks on a Uefa coaching course as he looks to improve his motivational and man-management skills before targeting a return to management.

May 2: Appointed boss of First Division Watford as successor to the retiring Graham Taylor.

HONOURS:

Serie A championships: 1991 and 1995. Italian Cups: 1985, 1988 and 1989. European Cup: 1996. European Cup Winners' Cup: 1990, 1998. UEFA Cup: 1993. FA Cup: 1997. Coca-Cola Cup: 1998.

fields.headline: Murdoch in DirecTV merger talks
fields.trailText: 11am: Rupert Murdoch's bid to set up a global satellite TV network is a step closer after America's DirecTV agreed to merger talks, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's audacious bid to set up a global satellite TV network complete with a US arm has moved a step closer after the owners of America's DirecTV formally agreed to start merger talks.

The takeover bid has been in the offing for more than six months and on several occasions looked as if it would be stymied.

But Mr Murdoch's decision last week to personally intervene in the talks appears to have paid off.

General Motors, the owner of DirecTV's parent company, Hughes Electronics, last night agreed to start merger negotiations with Mr Murdoch's media group.

Although the GM board has far from rubber-stamped a deal, it is a huge step forward for Mr Murdoch, who appeared to have given up on the takeover a month ago.

A News Corp spokesman described the GM decision as "a vote of confidence" in the revised offer.

GM's hand was forced after it failed to find a rival bidder for its subsidiary, and Mr Murdoch took charge of negotiations with the car manufacturer's reluctant executives.

A successful deal will see Mr Murdoch realise his dream of forming the world's largest satellite TV broadcaster, with stations spanning the US, Latin America, Asia, Australia and Europe.

The group, to be called Sky Global Networks, will include News Corp's 37.5% holding in BSkyB and will take Hughes Electronics's US stock market listing.

However, it is almost certain Mr Murdoch has been forced into a series of compromises in order to push the complex deal to its latest stage.

It is believed News Corp's proposed holding in the group has been reduced from 35% to 30%, while the management of Hughes Electronics will have greater influence in the newly formed company.

DirecTV provides the perfect gateway to the US satellite TV market, with 9.5m subscribers.

webTitle: Heath Ledger in talks to takeover redneck saga role

fields.headline: Heath Ledger in talks to takeover redneck saga role
fields.standfirst: Plus: Jennifer Lopez considers thriller; Alicia Silverstone among stars set for bank robber comedy
fields.trailText: Plus: Jennifer Lopez considers thriller; Alicia Silverstone among stars set for bank robber comedy
fields.body:
Rising Australian star Heath Ledger is currently in hurried negotiations to step into the Wes Bentley role in the redneck family saga Monster's Ball for director Marc Foster. Bentley, best known for his work on The Claim and American Beauty, bailed out of the picture last week for unknown reasons. Monster's Ball stars Billy Bob Thornton as a racist prison guard who falls in love with the black wife (Halle Berry) of a Death Row prisoner. Ledger would play the role of Thornton's son, who works alongside him at the electric chair.

Jennifer Lopez is in talks to star in the real-time thriller Tick-Tock for Columbia Pictures. Lopez would play the role of an amnesiac implicated in the planting of various bombs around Los Angeles. But the film is still hunting a director. Danny (Trainspotting) Boyle had signed to helm the project but dropped out last month because of creative differences.

Woody Harrelson, Rachael Leigh Cook and Alicia Silverstone will join forces in the ensemble indie comedy Scorched. Directed by Gavin Grazer, Scorched will spin the tale of a trio of bank employees who each hatch individual schemes to rob their own small-town branch on the same sleepy weekend. The film goes before the cameras at the end of May.

fields.headline: Jackson bullish about advertising revenue
fields.trailText: 11am: The Channel 4 chief is confident the broadcaster can withstand the downturn in advertising revenue, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Michael Jackson, the Channel 4 chief executive, is confident the broadcaster can withstand the downturn in advertising revenue, despite a dip in audience share in the first quarter.

Mr Jackson said Channel 4 was ahead of its advertising revenue targets so far this year.

"In peaktime we're ahead in ABC1 adults and 16 to 34-year-olds, that's why our income is ahead of last year. I see this continuing for the rest of the year," he said.

In the first three months of 2001, Channel 4's audience share across all hours was 9.8%, down from 10.6% in the same period last year.

"The total advertising market is likely to decline but I think, within that environment, Channel 4 is likely to do better than it's competitors," Mr Jackson said.

"In a situation where advertisers are prudent about where they spend their money, they are going to spend it where they get the most efficient return. We are a very important provider of the key demographics.

"Quality is important in a recessionary period," he said.

webTitle: New rules to extend maternity leave

fields.headline: New rules to extend maternity leave
fields.trailText: Mothers will be able to take up to a year off work around the birth of their baby under an overhaul of the complex maternity rules unveiled by the government yesterday.
fields.body:
Mothers will be able to take up to a year off work around the birth of their baby under an overhaul of the complex maternity rules unveiled by the government yesterday.

The move, which extends unpaid leave by three months, was welcomed by family campaigners, though there were calls for the government to grant new parents the right to work flexible or reduced hours.

Ministers are still debating the option, which has not been ruled out but is met with caution in Downing Street because of business opposition - reinforced by the CBI yesterday.

In the latest of a string of pre-election announcements targeted at women and the family, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will today give details of a £100m upgrade of maternity units across the country, designed to give mothers more choice over how and where their babies are delivered.

He will address the Royal College of Midwives the day after members warned that they felt their role was undervalued and pressed for more government funding for the service.

Steps to extend maternity leave are part of a package of measures to improve and streamline maternity rights, while seeking to keep employers on board.

In March, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced in the budget an increase in the flat rate of statutory maternity pay from £60.20 a week to £100 a week from April 2003. It will be paid for 26 weeks instead of the present 18.

The latest reform will add an extra 12 weeks to the maximum of 40 weeks which women can take before and after the birth of a child. It will also simplify the framework of pay and leave by standardising the qualifying periods - a move to please employers frustrated at the bureaucracy of the current system.

Mothers will have to give employers an extra week's notice of when they intend to start and return times. The CBI said employers wanted even more notice.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "With more women in work it is vital to put in place measures that allow working mothers to combine being a good parent with holding down a job.

"The right to take a year's maternity leave will make a real difference to a child's first year of life." The Maternity Alliance, which has long pressed for improved maternity pay and leave, welcomed the changes as a, "step in the right direction", but warned that many families earning just too much to qualify for benefits could find themselves unable to afford to take up the unpaid leave.

The National Family and Parenting Institute also praised moves to bring British parents' rights closer to those of their European counterparts.

Campaigners argued that a right to come back to work on flexitime or part time would encourage more women to return to work. One in three new mothers do not return to work, but the DTI estimated that if 10% of those went back to work, employers could save £35m a year in recruitment.

Mr Milburn will today invite the 250 maternity units in England to bid for extra funding to update equipment and increase staffing to provide expectant mothers with greater continuity of care. He wants the NHS to make home births more easily available and to provide more home-like birthing suites in hospitals.

In the latest of a string of pre-election announcements targeted at women and the family, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will today give details of a £100m upgrade of maternity units across the country, designed to give mothers more choice over how and where their babies are delivered. He will address the Royal College of Midwives the day after members warned that they felt their role was undervalued and pressed for more government funding for the service. Steps to extend maternity leave are part of a package of measures to improve and streamline maternity rights, while seeking to keep employers on board. In March, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced in the budget an increase in the flat rate of statutory maternity pay from £60.20 a week to £100 a week from April 2003. It will be paid for 26 weeks instead of the present 18. The latest reform will add an extra 12 weeks to the maximum of 40 weeks which women can take before and after the birth of a child. It will also simplify the framework of pay and leave by standardising the qualifying periods - a move to please employers frustrated at the bureaucracy of the current system. Mothers will have to give employers an extra week's notice of when they intend to start and return times. The CBI said employers wanted even more notice. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "With more women in work it is vital to put in place measures that allow working mothers to combine being a good parent with holding down a job. "The right to take a year's maternity leave will make a real difference to a child's first year of life." The Maternity Alliance, which has long pressed for improved maternity pay and leave, welcomed the changes as a, "step in the right direction", but warned that many families earning just too much to qualify for benefits could find themselves unable to afford to take up the unpaid leave. The National Family and Parenting Institute also praised moves to bring British parents' rights closer to those of their European counterparts. Campaigners argued that a right to come back to work on flexitime or part time would encourage more women to return to work. One in three new mothers do not return to work, but the DTI estimated that if 10% of those went back to work, employers could save £35m a year in recruitment. fields.standfirst:
 15 due in court
 92 arrests; 50 injured
 Shops survey damage

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: Fifteen people were appearing in court today after the May Day anti-capitalist demonstration ended with skirmishes between the police and protesters, with some protesters penned into Oxford Circus for up to eight hours.
fields.body:
Fifteen people were appearing in court today after the May Day anti-capitalist demonstration ended with skirmishes between the police and protesters, with some protesters penned into Oxford Circus for up to eight hours.

As the clean-up operation got under way in central London to repair the damage caused after yesterday's stand-off at Oxford Circus, 14 protesters were due to appear before Bow Street magistrates and one at West London.

Police made 92 arrests yesterday - including eight people from Denmark, Poland, Belgium and the United States - and among the weapons seized were a loaded airgun and a martial arts weapon.

Over 50 people were injured and 29 needed hospital treatment, the London ambulance service said. They included three police officers, one of whom was a female officer who lost consciousness in the crush but was later discharged from hospital.

This morning, shopkeepers returned to Tottenham Court Road, the scene of the worst vandalism when protesters smashed the windows of several stores. The windows of the Habitat store were boarded up today after large sections of the shop front were smashed in.

A nearby Heal's furniture shop had also been forced to put up boarding, after a large pane of glass was smashed. Boarding had also been put over smashed windows and fronts at branches of Abbey National, Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds, and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Demonstrators smashed in large sections of the glass front of the Tesco branch in Goodge Street, off Tottenham Court Road. Store manager Leigh Haynes said the supermarket was open at the time but that staff and shoppers had been evacuated before the attack took place.

But Sovat Din, an employee of The Pier, a furnishing store in Tottenham Court Road, said that shop remained open throughout yesterday.

"We had a meeting in the morning to prepare for any problems and we went through evacuation procedures just to protect ourselves and customers," he said.

Shop fronts were boarded up this morning as businesses sought to return to normal.

fields.standfirst: Operatic diva limited by an easy-going approach to her art
fields.trailText: Brünnhilde, Wotan's naughty daughter, was the perfect role for Rita Hunter, the diva from Wallasey, who has died in Sydney, aged 67. The whole point about Brünnhilde is that she is human and wilful even before she is deprived of her immortal status. fields.body:
Brünnhilde, Wotan's naughty daughter, was the perfect role for Rita Hunter, the diva from Wallasey, who has died in Sydney, aged 67. The whole point about Brünnhilde is that she is human and wilful even before she is deprived of her immortal status. The fact that Rita, at 20-stone, would have been quite a challenge for any horses in the Ride Of The Valkyries did not remotely disqualify her from shining memorably in the role at the Coliseum in 1973.

It was a space-age Ring anyway, in Andrew Porter's English vernacular, which suited Rita and her Siegfried, Alberto Remedios - not to mention Norman Bailey's rather noble, soft-grained Wotan. And it was a performance grounded, somewhat naively, in the truth of feelings, not in metaphysical speculation.

Rita Hunter had a beautiful, and highly individual, voice of formidable strength, as well as a lovely, irrepressibly cheerful smile. But the sound she made was not just sweet, and the smile masked a certain lack of realism. There could be a mewling, almost feline, twang in her lower register.

She became distinctly less cooperative as her career took off. The voice could develop a sufficiently admonitory timbre from time to time, without which she could not have compassed the tragic sentiment that is essential in the Ring. But the limitations of her career, as also in a way of Remedios's, following the huge and well-deserved success of the English Ring that really made her name, demonstrated all too clearly that the conductor Reginald Goodall's musical preparation and inspiring leadership had been crucial factors in setting her up as a credible star.

Goodall was her real Svengali - not Eva Turner, from whom she acquired a few distinctive vocal habits, when she took lessons from her for six months. "What I got from Eva was not so much vocal progress as a mental attitude to things," she said. "I had a very piercing sound, which was fine and loud and raised the roof. But I knew there was something else I wanted, a round, nice warm tone - because I was a great lover of Tebaldi."

She quite quickly turned her back on the sorts of demands that Goodall represented, though treasuring, perhaps too confidently, his brilliant advice to her: "Don't move. Do it with your face." Hunter's vocal gift was indeed rare, but not sufficient to compensate for the disadvantages of her personality - for her cheerful, insouciant arrogance as an artist, and a growing disinclination to work hard enough at musical preparation, and at the appropriately polished and imaginative theatricality.

What was wonderful about that initial Brünnhilde was that it triumphed over all the many problems of her shape and mobility - though she was quite capable of being delicate in her movements, as well as dramatically urgent. But in the end, and quite quickly, the international invitations stopped coming because the voice, by itself, was not enough.

She was a quick student, who learnt from listening, but not really much good at foreign languages. In any case, she was increasingly not bothered to keep her technique sufficiently in the sort of shape it needed to be in. Opera audiences can work their imaginations quite hard if the vocal quality is there, as the thunderous careers of Jane Eaglen and Ben Heppner prove. Hunter was glorious, but in the end, sadly, pas sérieuse as far as the wider market was concerned.

Her occasional recitals were demonstrations of rebellious unconcern: it might be the Queen Elizabeth Hall, but she would treat the event as if it were taking place in a working-men's club which just happened to have been taken over by a load of screaming opera queens, for whom her camp cool and laid-back informal stardom were cause for ribald celebration.

For those who listened and longed for her to realise her enormous promise as a Wagnerian star, it was depressing to notice how casually she broke up phrases to seize a breath, how irresponsibly she would just get by. Her alibi for not trying harder was the sense that the glandular disorder which made her so huge - her Bellini, in New York, was greeted with the headline "Enorma" - was something she could not help, and it was size that was stopping her being cast by opera house managements.

T he daughter of a boilermaker, Hunter's first singing lessons came from Olive Lloyd, who conducted the local pantomime society orchestra, and who taught her to hold her breath for "a long, long time". She was also taught by Harry Burgon, the music teacher at the next-door boy's school, who cast her as Little Buttercup, in HMS Pinafore, at the age of 13.

Her next teacher, Edwin Francis, predicted she was a young Eva Turner, and later introduced her to her future Siegfried, Remedios. She joined the Sadler's Wells chorus in 1954, aged 21, and after a couple of years - and nothing more exciting than singing one of the bridesmaids in Figaro - transferred to the Carl Rosa company because her teacher, Edward Renton, encouraged her to think it was "better to be a large pea in a small pod".

When the Carl Rosa merged with the Wells, she got a six months' study grant with Eva Turner, who once declared Hunter would never make a singer, and would have to scrub floors for a living. Then she went to her husband's teacher Redvers Llewellyn, and - back on the Sadler's Wells books - began to get roles: Marcellina, in Figaro, whose single and very difficult aria gave her a big chance, and, in 1964, her first Wagner, Senta, in Flying Dutchman. She was also Odabella, in Verdi's Attila, and Musetta, in Bohème. The birth, in 1968, of her daughter, Mairwyn, coincided with the Wells sacking her. She was quite quickly welcomed back, though, since she was Goodall's Brünnhilde in the making.

Her career was full of might-have-beens. She sang Third Norn at Covent Garden in 1963. When she did Leonore, in Trovatore, at the ENO in February 1983, it was a mixed blessing: she had not sung since the previous November (though she confidently assured me that her voice would be fully fit again after just a few days' rehearsal).

In 1979, she was supposed to be Turandot to Luciano Pavarotti's Calaf at the New York Metropolitan Opera, but, following a stagehands' strike, she jetted off to do Nabucco in Sydney, where she was to be offered a whole roster of big roles.

T his emigration was a mix of sour grapes about the rest of the world's failure to use her talent, and opportunism - an Australian Ring was in the offing. In 1983, she told me: "I love Lady Macbeth because she's such a wicked old bag, and Lazaridis's costumes for her in Australia are not little. You need a good pair of shoulders to cart them around. Obviously, I'm not going into trousers and doing Fidelio. I wouldn't inflict that on anybody."

Hunter's self-deprecating sense of humour, which led to lots of chat-show appearances down under, should have been exploited in opera. She never sang Alice Ford, which might have been ideal for her at Covent Garden.

The Australian Opera was once said to be considering casting Joan Sutherland as Josephine in Pinafore, opposite Hunter as Buttercup. But of that suggestion, she said: "I would hate to be considered a large funny lady." Her autobiography was Wait Till The Sun Shines Nellie (1985); and her triumph as Brünn- hilde in the Goodall Ring is still available on CD.

Mairwyn survives her; her husband, John Darnley, died in 1994.

Tom Sutcliffe

Rita Nellie Hunter, singer, born August 15 1933; died April 29 2001

fields.headline: Dundee offer Caniggia to Rangers
fields.trailText: Rangers chairman David Murray has confirmed that Claudio Caniggia has been offered to the Ibrox club by Dundee.
fields.body:
Rangers chairman David Murray has confirmed that Claudio Caniggia has been offered to the Ibrox club by Dundee.

Dundee have now made it public that they will accept an offer for the 34-year-old if it meets their valuation, believed to be more than £1m.

Caniggia has been linked with both Old Firm clubs but Rangers have emerged as by far the stronger favourites.

Murray told rangers.co.uk: "As far as Caniggia goes, there is no denying that we have shown some interest.

"Peter Marr at Dundee is openly making the player available and last week a third party approached us to see if we were interested."

Caniggia is not the only front-man to have attracted Rangers' attention, with Bastia's Pierre Yves Andre having been given a guided tour of Ibrox.

But the Frenchman is coveted by other clubs, including Sunderland, and French champions-in-waiting Nantes are the favourites to sign him.

Reports from across the Channel that he has signed a pre-contract agreement with Nantes have yet to be confirmed.

Murray added: "We have had three or four players at Ibrox in recent weeks but not everyone wants to come and play in Scottish football.

"All things being equal we could do something, but if something is on offer in the Premiership then we could lose out. We have to be realistic about that."

The need for a new striker could be made all the more acute if Michael Mols cannot regain full fitness following his knee reconstruction surgery more than a year ago.

Ronald de Boer has backed him to do just that but also admitted he feared Mols might have to quit if he failed to make a successful comeback this time.

Mols is currently back in Holland on a rehabilitation course which it is hoped will finally end his injury blues after three operations and several attempted comebacks .

De Boer said: "I think Michael will return - he won't give up. But maybe, and I say maybe, this is his last chance because if it goes wrong again then it will be very, very hard on him mentally.

"It could be the end. Personally, though, I don't see that happening.

"He is back in Holland now and he has all the time he needs to get back. He can go away and focus completely on getting fit for next season.

"I think it will do him good and I'm pretty sure Michael will return and kick-start his Rangers career. He is strong.

"Michael Mols has so much quality that it goes without saying he will increase the level of the team and personally I would love to team up with him next season when we are both fit."

Meanwhile, on-loan French star Fabrice Fernandes has accused Rangers manager Dick Advocaat of wasting his time by bringing him to Ibrox.

The winger turned whinger insisted Advocaat had gone back on his word by not giving him more than a few minutes of first team football.

He told The Scottish Daily Express: "When I came to Rangers I expected to play. Dick Advocaat told me that.

"He said that if I played well for Rangers I would be in his side every week. His word was good enough for me."

The Rennes player had been on loan at Fulham when Rangers paid £200,000 to borrow him for the rest of the season.

The 20-year-old made an amazing, instant impact by coming off the bench at Motherwell to blast a stunning long-range goal with only his third touch.

But since then he has remained on the bench with Rod Wallace, a player who will be leaving Ibrox in the summer, preferred in the starting line-up.

Rangers have made it clear they will not be taking up a summer option to buy and Fernandes is looking to return to England.

Meanwhile, Rangers youth coach Jan Derks has been banned until August by the Scottish Football Association's disciplinary panel for abusing a referee during an under-14 game.

Dundee United coach Willie Pettigrew received a similar ban for an incident with a referee during an under-15 game.

fields.headline: Vialli named new Watford manager
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli has been confirmed as the new manager of Watford.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli has been confirmed as the new manager of Watford.

The 36-year-old Italian has signed a three-year deal and will take over at the end of the season when Graham Taylor retires. Ray Wilkins is likely to be brought in as his assistant.

At a press conference at Watford this morning, Vialli told reporters: "I have missed you."

"I was probably a bit tired when I was relieved of the job by Chelsea," he added. "I took some time off and had plenty of time to think what I wanted to do next.

"I had a great time at Chelsea and obviously things happen in life and things go wrong," he continued. "I am not resentful of Chelsea, I am just here to do a good job and take this club to the next level, and improve my skill as a manager."

"I had to think carefully about this proposal but it took me a couple of weeks to realise that this is the club where I want to start again, where I want to give my best. I want to take Watford to the next level.

But Vialli denied he had to anything to prove at Watford. "I think I have showed something in the past - that's why they came to speak to me," he said.

"It is the most exciting management appointment we could have made. I am sure Luca will build an incredible team. I know the supporters will support him.

"I can't wait for the beginning of next season. It is great that such a man of international status has taken over."

webTitle: Travolta lawsuit settled out of court

fields.headline: Travolta lawsuit settled out of court
fields.trailText: A long-running exchange of lawsuits between John Travolta and the production companies Mandalay Entertainment and Liteoffer was finally put to bed yesterday
fields.body:
A long-running exchange of lawsuits between John Travolta and the production companies Mandalay Entertainment and Liteoffer was finally put to bed yesterday. The opposing parties are not releasing any details of the final settlement, although Travolta attorney Richard Possell insisted to Variety the dispute had been "settled to everyone's satisfaction".

The dispute dates back to 1996, when Mandalay and Liteoffer sued Travolta for breach of contract after the actor walked off the set of Roman Polanski's picture The Double in France. After Travolta's exit the picture was never completed.

Travolta immediately fired back a counter-suit alleging that Mandalay had reneged on a deal promising him the starring role in Mike Newell's Mafia movie Donnie Brasco. The film was eventually released to rave reviews in 1997 with Al Pacino and Johnny Depp in the lead roles. Since then Travolta's grievances have festered on throughout a protracted legal process. Today it looks as if they have finally been laid to rest.

webTitle: Full text: Bush's speech on missile defence

fields.headline: Full text: Bush's speech on missile defence
fields.standfirst: Speech by the US president, George Bush, on missile defence at the National Defence University, May 1, 2.40pm
fields.trailText: Speech by the US president, George Bush, on missile defence at the National Defence University, May 1, 2.40pm.
fields.body:
Thank you very much, Mr. Secretary. I appreciate you being here. I also want to thank Secretary Powell for being here as well. My National Security Advisor, Condi Rice is here, as well as the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, General Myers. I appreciate Admiral Clark and General Ryan here, for being here as well. But most of all, I want to thank you, Admiral Gaffney, and the students for NDU for having me here today.

For almost 100 years, this campus has served as one of our country's premier centers for learning and thinking about America's national security. Some of America's finest soldiers have studied here: Dwight Eisenhower and Colin Powell. Some of America's finest statesmen have taught here; George Kennan. Today, you're carrying on this proud tradition forward, continuing to train tomorrow's generals, admirals and other national security thinkers, and continuing to provide the intellectual capital for our nation's strategic vision.

This afternoon, I want us to thank back some 30 years to a far different time in a far different world. The United States and the Soviet Union were locked in a hostile rivalry. The Soviet Union was our unquestioned enemy; a highly-armed threat to freedom and democracy. Far more than that wall in Berlin divided us.

Our highest ideal was -- and remains -- individual liberty. Theirs was the construction of a vast communist empire. Their totalitarian regime held much of Europe captive behind an iron curtain.

We didn't trust them, and for good reason. Our deep differences were expressed in a dangerous military confrontation that resulted in thousands of nuclear weapons pointed at each other on hair-trigger alert. Security of both the United States and the Soviet Union was based on a grim premise: that neither side would fire nuclear weapons at each other, because doing so would mean the end of both nations.

We even went so far as to codify this relationship in a 1972 ABM Treaty, based on the doctrine that our very survival would best be insured by leaving both sides completely open and vulnerable to nuclear attack. The threat was real and vivid. The Strategic Air Command had an airborne command post called the Looking Glass, aloft 24 hours a day, ready in case the President ordered our strategic forces to move toward their targets and release their nuclear ordnance.

The Soviet Union had almost 1.5 million troops deep in the heart of Europe, in Poland and Czechoslovakia, Hungary and East Germany. We used our nuclear weapons not just to prevent the Soviet Union from using their nuclear weapons, but also to contain their conventional military forces, to prevent them from extending the Iron Curtain into parts of Europe and Asia that were still free.

In that world, few other nations had nuclear weapons and most of those who did were responsible allies, such as Britain and France. We worried about the proliferation of nuclear weapons to other countries, but it was mostly a distant threat, not yet a reality.

Today, the sun comes up on a vastly different world. The Wall is gone, and so is the Soviet Union. Today's Russia is not yesterday's Soviet Union. Its government is no longer Communist. Its president is elected. Today's Russia is not our enemy, but a country in transition with an opportunity to emerge as a great nation, democratic, at peace with itself and its neighbors. The Iron Curtain no longer exists. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are free nations, and they are now our allies in NATO, together with a reunited Germany.

Yet, this is still a dangerous world, a less certain, a less predictable one. More nations have nuclear weapons and still more have nuclear aspirations. Many have chemical and biological weapons. Some already have developed the ballistic missile technology that would allow them to deliver weapons of mass destruction at long distances and at incredible speeds. And a number of these countries are spreading these technologies around the world.

Most troubling of all, the list of these countries includes some of the world's least-responsible states. Unlike the Cold War, today's most urgent threat stems not from thousands of ballistic missiles in the Soviet hands, but from a small number of missiles in the hands of these states, states for whom terror and blackmail are a way of life. They seek weapons of mass destruction to intimidate their neighbors, and to keep the United States and other responsible nations from helping allies and friends in strategic parts of the world.

When Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in 1990, the world joined forces to turn him back. But the international community would have faced a very different situation had Hussein been able to blackmail with nuclear weapons. Like Saddam Hussein, some of today's tyrants are gripped by an implacable hatred of the United States of America. They hate our friends, they hate our values, they hate democracy and freedom and individual liberty. Many care little for the lives of their own people. In such a world, Cold War deterrence is no longer enough.

To maintain peace, to protect our own citizens and our own allies and friends, we must seek security based on more than the grim premise that we can destroy those who seek to destroy us. This is an important opportunity for the world to re-think the unthinkable, and to find new ways to keep the peace.

Today's world requires a new policy, a broad strategy of active nonproliferation, counterproliferation and defenses. We must work together with other like-minded nations to deny weapons of terror from those seeking to acquire them. We must work with allies and friends who wish to join with us to defend against the harm they can inflict. And together we must deter anyone who would contemplate their use.

We need new concepts of deterrence that rely on both offensive and defensive forces. Deterrence can no longer be based solely on the threat of nuclear retaliation. Defenses can strengthen deterrence by reducing the incentive for proliferation.

We need a new framework that allows us to build missile defenses to counter the different threats of today's world. To do so, we must move beyond the constraints of the 30 year old ABM Treaty. This treaty does not recognize the present, or point us to the future. It enshrines the past. No treaty that prevents us from addressing today's threats, that prohibits us from pursuing promising technology to defend ourselves, our friends and our allies is in our interests or in the interests of world peace.

This new framework must encourage still further cuts in nuclear weapons. Nuclear weapons still have a vital role to play in our security and that of our allies. We can, and will, change the size, the composition, the character of our nuclear forces in a way that reflects the reality that the Cold War is over.

I am committed to achieving a credible deterrent with the lowest-possible number of nuclear weapons consistent with our national security needs, including our obligations to our allies. My goal is to move quickly to reduce nuclear forces. The United States will lead by example to achieve our interests and the interests for peace in the world.

Several months ago, I asked Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld to examine all available technologies and basing modes for effective missile defenses that could protect the United States, our deployed forces, our friends and our allies. The Secretary has explored a number of complementary and innovative approaches.

The Secretary has identified near-term options that could allow us to deploy an initial capability against limited threats. In some cases, we can draw on already established technologies that might involve land-based and sea-based capabilities to intercept missiles in mid-course or after they re-enter the atmosphere. We also recognize the substantial advantages of intercepting missiles early in their flight, especially in the boost phase.

The preliminary work has produced some promising options for advanced sensors and interceptors that may provide this capability. If based at sea or on aircraft, such approaches could provide limited, but effective, defenses.

We have more work to do to determine the final form the defenses might take. We will explore all these options further. We recognize the technological difficulties we face and we look forward to the challenge. Our nation will assign the best people to this critical task.

We will evaluate what works and what does not. We know that some approaches will not work. We also know that we will be able to build on our successes. When ready, and working with Congress, we will deploy missile defenses to strengthen global security and stability.

I've made it clear from the very beginning that I would consult closely on the important subject with our friends and allies who are also threatened by missiles and weapons of mass destruction.

Today, I'm announcing the dispatch of high-level representatives to Allied capitals in Europe, Asia, Australia and Canada to discuss our common responsibility to create a new framework for security and stability that reflects the world of today. They will begin leaving next week.

The delegations will be headed by three men on this stage: Rich Armitage, Paul Wolfowitz, and Steve Hadley; Deputies of the State Department, the Defense Department and the National Security staff. Their trips will be part of an ongoing process of consultation, involving many people and many levels of government, including my Cabinet Secretaries.

These will be real consultations. We are not presenting our friends and allies with unilateral decisions already made. We look forward to hearing their views, the views of our friends, and to take them into account.

We will seek their input on all the issues surrounding the new strategic environment. We'll also need to reach out to other interested states, including China and Russia. Russia and the United States should work together to develop a new foundation for world peace and security in the 21st century. We should leave behind the constraints of an ABM Treaty that perpetuates a relationship based on distrust and mutual vulnerability. This Treaty ignores the fundamental breakthroughs in technology during the last 30 years. It prohibits us from exploring all options for defending against the threats that face us, our allies and other countries.

That's why we should work together to replace this Treaty with a new framework that reflects a clear and clean break from the past, and especially from the adversarial legacy of the Cold War. This new cooperative relationship should look to the future, not to the past. It should be reassuring, rather than threatening. It should be premised on openness, mutual confidence and real opportunities for cooperation, including the area of missile defense. It should allow us to share information so that each nation can improve its early warning capability, and its capability to defend its people and territory. And perhaps one day, we can even cooperate in a joint defense.

I want to complete the work of changing our relationship from one based on a nuclear balance of terror, to one based on common responsibilities and common interests. We may have areas of difference with Russia, but we are not and must not be strategic adversaries. Russia and America both face new threats to security. Together, we can address today's threats and pursue today's opportunities. We can explore technologies that have the potential to make us all safer.

This is a time for vision; a time for a new way of thinking; a time for bold leadership. The Looking Glass no longer stands its 24-hour-day vigil. We must all look at the world in a new, realistic way, to preserve peace for generations to come.

God bless.

webTitle: Shares unsteady Allied profits up but meagre marketing spend raises doubts

fields.headline: Shares unsteady Allied profits up but meagre marketing spend raises doubts
fields.trailText: Spirits and wines group Allied Domecq said yesterday that global economic uncertainty was having no impact on customers' thirst.
fields.body:
Spirits and wines group Allied Domecq said yesterday that global economic uncertainty was having no impact on customers' thirst.

The company reported pretax profits of £236m - an increase of 16% on the previous year, and ahead of analysts' expectations - on sales up 12% at £1.46bn.

Chief executive Philip Bowman said: "There is no clear trend emerging to suggest that there is any significant slowdown - and I think the latest economic figures out of the US are helpful, particularly if they translate back into consumer confidence.

"As things look at the moment, we are confident of showing good growth in the second half of the year."

However, shares in Allied dropped 22.75p to close at 405.25p as investors expressed their concern that advertising and promo tional spending had grown by just 1%.

Mr Bowman said: "We are committed to being a dynamic, marketing-led brands business and are driving the pace of change within the business to achieve this. We are putting a lot of efforts into improving the effectiveness of our A&P [advertising and promotion] spend - and we are getting the benefits."

More than half of marketing spend was on Allied's four core brands - Ballantine's scotch, Kahlua liqueur, Beefeater gin and Sauza tequila. Mr Bowman stressed that the company would report a 4% increase in A&P spending at the end of its financial year.

Allied lost out in December to Diageo and Pernod Ricard in the takeover battle for Seagram and has focused on single-brand acquisitions including Captain Morgan rum, still the subject of a legal battle.

fields.headline: Ford kicks off web football campaign
fields.standfirst: Click here to play the game
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Ford has launched a viral marketing football game to support its sponsorship of the Uefa Champions League, writes Julia Day.
Click here to play the game
fields.body:
Ford has launched a viral marketing football game on the internet to support its sponsorship of the Uefa Champions League.

The pan-European football game, called Keep It Up, is a first for Ford.

It has been launched across Europe on UK, German, Spanish, Italian and French sites belonging to Sportal, the sports information provider.

The game was the brainchild of the online marketing specialist, Tangozebra.

Tangozebra also implemented an innovative internet advertising campaign, called "destination football", which was created by Bruce Dunlop Associates.

The adverts have been billed as the web's first TV-style online sponsorship.

It is hoped Keep It Up will capture the imagination of football fans across Europe in the run-up to the Champions League final on May 23.

The game allows users to control a football player by moving the cursor keys to keep the ball off the ground.

The arrow keys are used to kick the ball, move the player left and right or to perform special moves, which score extra points.

The game can be forwarded to friends - providing the viral aspect of the game - and scores can be registered.

This will enable Ford to capture users' names and email addresses for future use.

Registering scores will also allow a league table of the top 100 scorers across Europe to be published.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: A reader from Dulwich forwards a letter from Friends Provident. "You recently received some correspondence offering you the opportunity to invest in a Friends Provident ISA," it reads. "You may have been surprised by the accompanying letter." Hmm? The mailing house used to stuff envelopes mixed up FP's info and the Great Ormond Street charity. Oops!
fields.body:
A reader from Dulwich forwards a letter from Friends Provident. "You recently received some correspondence offering you the opportunity to invest in a Friends Provident ISA," it reads. "You may have been surprised by the accompanying letter." Hmm? The mailing house used to stuff envelopes mixed up FP's info and the Great Ormond Street charity. Oops!

A humble apology by FP follows - but there was a silver lining, according to the FP headquarters in Salisbury. "People replied saying they made a donation to Great Ormond Street that they wouldn't have made otherwise," said an FP executive. Excellent, can I check the spelling of your name? "It's D-e-r-y-c-k, Deryck Murray." That's an unusual spelling - there was a famous West Indian cricket player with the same name. "I know." Do you follow cricket? "Yes, I do." Errr ... are you the same Deryck Murray who played in the great West Indies team of the 1970s? "Yes." Are you pulling my leg? "No." What are you doing working for Friends Provident in Salisbury? "It's a long story. After cricket I tried various things and ended up in financial services." Blimey. The rest of that long story, readers, will have to wait.

 So the anti-globalisation (et al) protest turned out to be something of a damp squib. The lessons are: hold the rally in July when the weather's better.

And several months beforehand get "sleepers" to take jobs as security guards in City institutions. For details, see the movie Fight Club.

 The latest feedback from our City Diary focus groups reveals that quizzes are very popular among our key demographic. So as a way of entertaining readers and filling space - which is this column's mission statement - here is a short quiz based on some of the more remarkable facts that have recently arrived here. Answers at the bottom. 1. How many caravans are stolen each year in Britain? a) 50, b) 500, c) 5,000. 2. How many million pounds worth of frozen pizzas were sold in 1998? a) £3.4m, b) £34m, c) £340m. 3. How much will foot and mouth cost the economy, according to the Centre for Economic and Business Research? a) £2.7bn, b) £9bn, c) £10.2bn.

 Five bricklayers in Milan have just completed 11 years on full pay doing absolutely nothing. They sit playing cards and drinking coffee on a half-finished building site after the builder who employed the men forgot to dismiss them when the site was abandoned. Now, under Italian law, they can't be sacked without union agreement.

Answers to quiz: 1. (c) - "Approximately 5,000 touring caravans are stolen each year," according to Jardine Lloyd Thompson press release. 2. (c) £340m, according to Birds Eye Wall's Frozen Food Factfile. 3. Trick question - all three are right. The CEBR forecast (a) £2.7bn on March 1; (b) £9bn on March 18; (c) £10.2bn on April 15.

fields.headline: Canary fanciers in flight
fields.trailText: If anybody is in a position to judge the impact of the investment banking slowdown at Canary Wharf, the London Docklands office complex, it is Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the US investment bank.
fields.body:
If anybody is in a position to judge the impact of the investment banking slowdown at Canary Wharf, the London Docklands office complex, it is Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the US investment bank.

Not only is the site home to its European operations but the firm also recently announced plans to shed 1,500 jobs after posting a 30% fall in first-quarter earnings.

Therefore, many traders interpreted yesterday's news that Morgan Stanley had downgraded its rating on Britain's most valuable property company to "outperform" from "strong buy" as a signal to sell. The shares closed down 27p at 513p, one of the worst FTSE 100 performers.

According to Morgan Stanley, its downgrade reflected uncertainty over future demand from investment banks, which occupy much of the site. Canary Wharf recently announced plans to develop 8m sq ft of office space.

fields.headline: Clocking Off ticked off by Collins
fields.trailText: BBC1 drama Clocking Off slumped to its lowest ratings yet on Monday night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1 drama Clocking Off slumped to its lowest ratings yet on Monday night, dropping below 5m viewers against ITV's Michelle Collins drama, Perfect.

Clocking Off was on between 9pm and 10pm.

It was down to just 4.9m viewers and a 22% audience share, after managing 6.1m in the same slot the previous Monday, according to unofficial overnights.

Clocking Off was up against the concluding episode of two-parter Perfect, which had 7.7m and a 35% audience share.

This was an improvement on the previous week, when Perfect had 7.4m.

But ITV comedy drama Bob Martin, which stars Michael Barrymore as a TV gameshow host, continued to struggle in its 10.50pm slot.

The second episode drew just 2.4m viewers and a 20% audience share; after last week's series opener had 2.5m.

Bob Martin was up against BBC1 documentary Hollywood Greats: Gene Kelly, which was on between 10.35pm and 11.20pm.

The documentary had 3.2m viewers and a 24% audience share.

webTitle: Doctors may protest, but they've never had it so good

fields.headline: Doctors may protest, but they've never had it so good
fields.standfirst: The BMA cry out that their members are mistreated and overworked
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee: Doctors cry out that their members are mistreated and overworked but it is hard to listen patiently to hectoring BMA leaders who adopt extreme and unwarranted tactics.
fields.body:
While anti-capitalists stole the headlines, one group of wildcat strikers made a smaller splash yesterday. Hundreds of GPs shut up shop in protest at overwork, bureaucracy and other gripes. Meanwhile the BMA is balloting GPs to resign from the NHS if they don't get everything they want - the result designed to embarrass the government days before the election.

The BMA says its members are working harder than ever, taking over chronically ill patients from hospital outpatient departments, looking after people leaving hospital sicker, filling in more forms, shouldering a bigger burden in running the NHS - all of which is undoubtedly true. "Morale has never been lower," says the BMA, (but then NHS morale always is at the rock-bottom, along with teachers, BBC staff or anyone else asked by their unions).

However, alongside teachers, doctors top the poll in public trust, with 84% saying they do their job well. Most GPs work hard with great dedication, especially those in over-stretched inner-city practices where doctors are hard to recruit and patients need most care. But while there are plenty of idealistic, energetic GPs, as in all occupations, there are the other kind too - running practices with too many patients to clock up fat capitation fees, not delivering good enough care. Alan Maynard, professor of health economics at York University, says due to its private status, general practice is a data free zone, with no in formation on what GPs are prescribing drugs for, huge variations in prescribing and no outcome measurements. Until now GPs have not been appraised, while working to very vague contracts.

The virulence of this GP protest is odd. Doctor magazine, which called yesterday's strike, is in cut-throat competition with other drug advertising financed weeklies vying for GPs' fleeting attention with ever more lurid stories of an NHS in terminal collapse, doctors exploited in a life of medical hell. Their own survey claimed 90% of GPs "stressed", with eight out of 10 saying they would not recommend anyone to join their profession. The BMA is calling on GPs to "work to rule", with disgraceful actions for a responsible profession. They include: obstructing the NHS by referring more patients to hospital for minor treatments, calling out more ambulances, sending patients to other parts of the NHS or to the benefits agency medical service for second opinions.

It asks GPs to give "maximum publicity to health service failures or deficiencies", assuring them, "We have been advised that GPs taking these actions would not be in breach of their terms of service". The BMA leopard never changes its spots. It always opposes all change, including opposition to the NHS itself in 1948. From Bevan to Castle, to an assault upon the mostly sensible Thatcher/Clarke reforms, the BMA is short-sighted and grasping, but dismally predictable with its veneer of concern for patients thinly covering sectional interests.

Most GPs remain small businessmen, independent contractors, a concession forced on Bevan when he famously "stuffed their mouths with gold" to get them into the NHS at all. Mouth-stuffing has remained at the heart of their contractual relationship ever since. Every new treatment requires more money in their pockets for doing it - from diabetic care to contraception, flu jabs to infant inoculation. When they complain about paperwork and bureaucracy, the overwhelming majority of it is the bits of paper chasing their items of service, which make up the largest slab of their pay. One of their duties is to undertake 30 hours training a year: their most popular course is accountancy.

How much worse is their workload? The curiosity of this outburst is its timing. For the first time in doctors' memories things look set to get much better in the NHS - and for GPs especially. Indeed, when the leader of the BMA heard the chancellor's 2000 budget speech, with its biggest ever real 6.1% a year increase for four years, he tore up his usual sour press release and wrote remarkably, "We are delighted". At least 2,000 more GPs are promised: the number in training, which dropped 16% between 1990-1996, has now increased by 9%, with more promised. What's more, the GPs are the focus of power in the new NHS Plan: grouped in primary care trusts, they will soon control 75% of the NHS budget. No longer the neglected corner of the system, they will be its key purchasers. For too long the big money was syphoned off into hospital waiting lists, but this should push money back into community and preventative care, where some 95% of treatment is carried out.

By no means all GPs support the BMA and Doctor magazine's intemperate behaviour. Dr Tim Winch, chair of the primary care group in Kent Weald, formerly from an inner-city practice, is appalled and the BMA's obstruction of reform of GP practices. Calling for nationalisation of the whole GP service, his pithy press release dismisses GP leaders as "mass whingers". He thinks GPs do well with a minimum income of some £56,000 - many earning closer to £80,000 (or more) with extra payments for looking after local old peoples homes or myriad other paid jobs, plus good expenses.

It is odd that GPs are protesting about stress now, when their working hours have become more civilised. Since 1995 GPs rarely have to drag themselves out of bed at night, with locums doing night calls instead. Daytime home visits by GPs have halved during the last decade. Dr Winch thinks GPs just don't realise how much harder everyone else works these days: their grumbling puts off new recruits to a decent profession with reasonable hours. The red book, which prescribes GPs work, requires only 4.5 days a week, 26 hours a week face-to-face with patients (which includes home visits), and nothing much else fixed. It is unclear why most surgeries have no evening or weekend sessions, when their patients work long hours, too. Official figures show the number of consultations GPs conduct a year has dropped slightly over the last 20 years, not risen as the BMA claims - though their patients are older and sicker. However, GPs do have many more nurses and other support now.

Agreeing a good new GP contract is vital for the success of the NHS Plan. GPs do need appraisals and greater quality control. However, the government's passion for performance indicators can lead to bizarre outcomes, distorting what people do to hit paper targets: they need to listen to what GPs say. But it is hard to listen patiently to hectoring BMA leaders who adopt such extreme and unwarranted tactics. A balance has to be struck between trusting GPs as respected, well-resourced professionals, while insisting on more scrutiny of what they do. Observers despair at the BMA's brutish ham-fisted behaviour. If GPs want a good contract that works well, their leaders' aggressive posturing makes it less likely.

fields.headline: Calm masks telecoms storm
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: It seemed to the outside observer to be an exceptionally dull day in the Square Mile. The FTSE 100 ended 38.9 lower at 5,928 pulled down by a weak performance from the banking sector, which was hit by profit taking. HSBC fell 19p to 902p, while Royal Bank of Scotland lost 29p to £15.90.
fields.body:
It seemed to the outside observer to be an exceptionally dull day in the Square Mile. The FTSE 100 ended 38.9 lower at 5,928 pulled down by a weak performance from the banking sector, which was hit by profit taking. HSBC fell 19p to 902p, while Royal Bank of Scotland lost 29p to £15.90.

Only 1.6bn shares changed hands, with many City professionals using the anti-capitalist demonstrations and the closure of Europe's bourses for the May day holiday as an excuse to stay at home. Those at their desks were more interested in tracking the progress of the protesters than trying to drum up any business.

But behind the scenes some brokers were frantically working on one of the biggest share placings the London market has seen. The select few were locked on to Vodafone , its most liquid stock.

Word had spread by late afternoon that one of Vodafone's financial advisers, either Goldman Sachs or UBS Warburg, will today attempt to place more than £3bn of new Vodafone stock with City institutions.The shares, which accounted for 15% of trading yesterday, fell 6p to 206.25p.

It is understood Vodafone will put the cash towards the acquisition, announced yesterday, of BT's holdings in Japan Telecom and Airtel, the Spanish mobile phone company.

BT finished 47p higher at 599p - the best blue chip performer - as the market welcomed the first serious attempt to tackle its debt. Dealers expect the shares to come under heavy selling pressure today. The size of the Vodafone offering means institutions will have little appetite for the £5bn rights issue BT is plotting.

The FTSE TechMark 100 fell 19.74 points to 2.080.68, with investors booking recent gains in the likes of Autonomy , down 61p to 530p and optical components maker Bookham Technology , off 18p to 341.5p.

Back among the leaders, ITV company Carlton Communications advanced 7p to 434p after Dresnder Kleinwort Wassertein initiated coverage with a "buy" recommendation, while Lattice , up 5.5p to 136p, bounced back from Monday's drubbing courtesy a strong push from JP Morgan.

The retail sector had a tough day as investors digested the latest gossip from the industry. Retail analysts say sales in the past two weeks have been poor as shoppers stay at home because of wet weather.

Marks & Spencer , down 4p to 264p yesterday, is said to have been hit hard by the trend, with womenswear sales falling 12% and homeware 14%. Debenhams is thought to have experienced sluggish sales growth. It finished down 25p at 415p, one of the worst performers in the FTSE 250.

By contrast PowderJect was one of the best, rising 27p to 436p after positive noises from Goldman Sachs. The US bro ker feels the share price does not reflect the change in the company's focus from a drug delivery company to a vaccines specialist with drug delivery capabilities.

Goldman believes events in the coming year will offer the company a chance to rebuild its tarnished reputation. In the meantime it has upgraded its stance on the stock to "market outperform" and set a 720p target price.

Among the small caps, QXL Ricardo moved up 1p to 6.75p in heavy trade on talk that the internet auction house has been approached by US rival, Ebay. Dealers thought the tale plausible. Although Ebay is the dominant force in the industry it lacks critical mass in Europe. Buying QXL would be a relatively painless way of solving that problem.

Elsewhere, Redstone Telecom dropped 7.5p to 52p on rumours that the company is in refinancing talks. Sector specialists poured scorn on the story pointing to comments made by the company at the time of third-quarter results in February. Redstone said it anticipated being able to move to a cash positive position without the need for further financing.
