fields.headline: The best of both worlds
fields.standfirst: Their mix of African and Latin music made them stars. Then they got into gold lamé and it all went horribly wrong. Can Orchestra Baobab ever recover? By Jane Cornwell
fields.trailText: Their mix of African and Latin music made them stars. Then they got into gold lamé and it all went horribly wrong. Can Orchestra Baobab ever recover? By Jane Cornwell.
fields.body:
In the bougainvillea-strewn courtyard of Dakar's Cultural Centre, Rudi Gomis flicks through a tatty photo album and sighs nostalgically for the 1970s, the decade when Orchestra Baobab were the biggest band in Senegal. "Everyone loved us," he says. "Young, old, rich, poor. Everyone."

Black-and-white snaps document guest appearances before prime ministers, judges and the military; at the selection of Miss Senegal and the inauguration of the former president, Abdou Diaf. Yellowing flyers advertise concerts in Guinea, Tunisia and France. The band's 13-strong line-up beam out from the pictures, wearing the wide-lapelled shirts of their heyday; a few pages later they are sporting the blue and gold lamé numbers that coincided with their demise.

Orchestra Baobab formed in 1970, taking their name from the swanky Baobab Club, and disbanded in the mid-1980s. Senegalese music was largely ignored outside Africa until 1985, the year Peter Gabriel met Youssou N'Dour in Dakar and brought to the west the singer's mbalax sound - where electric instruments follow the rhythms played by sabar drums. In his wake, local stars Baaba Maal and, to a lesser degree, Cheikh Lo achieved Anglo-American success in the 1990s. But before them all came Orchestra Baobab, packing houses and stadiums in an age when the band - not the individual - was the thing. Their delicate balance of Latin and African styles set them apart; their re-formation, for a one-off London gig at the Barbican this Saturday, promises to recall the understated cool of their prime.

"Baobab were different from other bands because we spent a lot of time working on harmonies and arrangements," says Gomis, now a teacher of French and Wolof, Senegal's national language. "We had a more open attitude and better musicians. We were the first band to blend the Wolof folklore of the griots [traditional Senegalese storytellers] with salsa. All our members came from different regions. We were a métissage - a mix of everything."

The 54-year-old would prefer to forget the lamé period, when "we brought in traditional sabar drums alongside kit-drums, congas and timbales. We wanted to keep up with the times, but it was too much - a cacophony," he says.

It was a far cry from the laid back Afro-Cuban rhythms and mellow arrangements of Werente, their 1982 studio session. This spawned a bootlegging frenzy, eventually getting a 1989 album release under the title Pirate's Choice. Baobab's slow, sensuous reworkings of Cuban tunes enjoyed heavy attention from British world music fans, and the DJs Andy Kershaw and Charlie Gillett. Pirate's Choice has remained on lists of top 10 world music albums ever since. Recorded straight to two-track, its lo-fi tropical mix marks a time when Senegal was breaking away from the Latin sounds that had been coming through the port of Dakar since the 1940s. The country was rediscovering its own musical identity. "We were," offers Gomis, "the link between Cuban salsa and Youssou N'Dour's mbalax."

Orchestra Baobab's line-up included griot singers, a jazz-influenced Malian saxophonist, a Moroccan guitarist, a Nigerian clarinet player and a Gambian drummer, all carried along by the fluid guitar of Barthelemy Atisso from Togo and the Latin-influenced songwriting of Gomis from Guinea Bissau. Vocalists took turns on the microphone, delivering dance turns and love songs in Spanish, Wolof, French and Portuguese Creole.

Their fame stemmed, in part, from the fact that they were the first band to reconcile Dakar's chattering classes with the populace. For left- wing intellectuals, their Cuban influences helped to reinforce the severing of colonial ties, while their indigenous elements were embraced by people on the street. Above all, in a country that sways to innumerable rhythms, Orchestra Baobab defied audiences not to dance. "Our fathers were dancing to Cuban bands like Sexteto Habanera in the 1930s," says Gomis. "We felt in line with changa, salsa and cha cha cha. Our tunes are still played on the radio every day. Young people tell me they remember them as lullabies."

When Baobab eventually broke up, the members dispersed to forge other careers. Some now play in bands in the hotels of the Petite Cte, Senegal's Riviera. Atisso works as a lawyer. Gomis has had a couple of solo salsa releases but makes a living from teaching. They all, he insists, earn a pittance. Baobab's gigs once earned them the relatively huge sum of £800 a night and it was this that inhibited attempts to get them back together.

"Everyone thought we'd be too expensive, when we would simply have been happy to play our music. This is the beginning of something important." At the very least, with Gold and World Circuit behind them, their renaissance seems inevitable.

Something similar to the Buena Vista Social Club phenomenon, perhaps? "Maybe that's our destiny," Gomis grins. "Now we just need a big film to let the world know about us."

It is an optimism shared by other core members of the band, reunited at a Dakar restaurant the following day. Atisso has flown in from Togo for the first time in five years to join rehearsals for the Barbican and lay down demo tracks for a new album that will, if all goes well, be produced by N'Dour and released by World Circuit.

After much general hilarity, pipe-smoking and comparing of stomachs ("My bump is bigger than yours!"), Gomis, Atisso, the vocalist Balla Sidibe and the drummer Mountaga Kouyate speak enthusiastically about their combined future. "You see," says Gomis proudly, "we are just like the tree we were named after. The baobab lives for years and years. Storms and cyclones can rustle it, but it always stands firm. As strong as ever."

 Orchestra Baobab play the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), on Saturday as part of the Urban Beats series, featuring music from Dakar, Caracas, Tokyo and New York. Pirate's Choice is re-released, with additional tracks, on June 8 by World Circuit records.

webTitle: Bush starts selling 'Son of Star Wars'

fields.headline: Bush starts selling 'Son of Star Wars'
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush tried to gift wrap his controversial missile defence plans in a promise of unilateral nuclear weapons cuts yesterday, a strategy designed to make the "Son of Star Wars" less objectionable to Russia, China, and America's sceptical Nato allies
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington,  Richard Norton-Taylor, Michael White,  and Ian Traynor  in Moscow
fields.body:
George Bush tried to gift wrap his controversial missile defence plans in a promise of unilateral nuclear weapons cuts yesterday, a strategy designed to make the "Son of Star Wars" less objectionable to Russia, China, and America's sceptical Nato allies

Conspicuously dropping the word "national" from what have hitherto been called "national missile defence" plans, he said the US intended to defend "ourselves, our friends and our allies".

He confirmed that the US would go ahead with the untested scheme, developed under the Clinton administration, to position interceptor missiles on land, and perhaps at sea, but he said it would "consult closely" its allies before deciding on the final plan.

He offered no details and only a few general hints of the form that the missile shield will take, but made it clear that the US would not be constrained in its efforts by the 1972 anti-ballistic-missile treaty with the former Soviet Union.

That treaty, Mr Bush said, "does not recognise the present or point us to the future. It enshrines the past."

There were no details, either of his proposed cuts in nuclear weapons, nor any suggestion that they would be negotiated with Russia or anyone else.

"The United States will lead by example to achieve our interests and the interests for peace in the world," he said.

But he said he wanted to "reach out" to Russia, which he addressed at some length, as well as China, which he mentioned once in passing.

Shortly before he made his announcement on the steps of the National Defence College in Washington, Mr Bush gave President Vladimir Putin - the latest of several foreign leaders to receive it - his 12- minute telephone sales pitch.

He told reporters that he had told Mr Putin he would love to meet him, "look him in the eye, and let him know how sincere I am about achieving a new way of keeping the peace".

He said he was sending teams of envoys to Canada, Europe, Asia and Australia to discuss the plan.

Tony Blair was warned last night that he was being put in a near-impossible position by Mr Bush's campaign.

As the Conservatives challenged him to offer the US "clear support" on the project, in contrast to the doubts in other EU capitals, Donald Anderson, Labour chairman of the Commons foreign affairs committee said: "This may be the moment of truth. It will be seen in the context of Kyoto and growing unilateralism in Washington.

"It is a problem for Russia and China, and for Tony Blair. He tries to be a bridge, but how can you be a bridge between such contrary views?"

Downing St said it welcomed Mr Bush's "very open approach" and his intention to develop a framework for consultation, and that it shared his interest in doing this.

But ministers and officials are sceptical about the project, which will involve upgrading the early warning radar at Fylingdales on the North York Moors and building a 6.8-hectare (17-acre) X-band radar station.

Nevertheless, Whitehall and other capitals contrasted the promise of consultation with the peremptory way the White House announced its decision to pull out of the Kyoto protocol on reducing greenhouse gases.

Germany, after initial hostile reaction to the project, seems to have come round to the inevitable. France remains opposed, fearing that it will trigger a new arms race. Nato officials described the package as "sellable", pointing to the offer to cut the US nuclear stockpile.

fields.headline: Silence is golden
fields.standfirst: How Bill Paterson became a star - without anyone noticing. By Brian Logan
fields.trailText: How Bill Paterson became a star - without anyone noticing. By Brian Logan.
fields.body:
B ill Paterson has come a long way since his days in fringe theatre but without making too much fuss about it. A fan's website describes the 55-year-old Glaswegian as "a highly acclaimed, slightly secret actor". And that's OK by him. "Secrecy seems to suit me fine," he says.

The coming weeks may blow his cover. Tonight he takes to the National Theatre stage in Edward Albee's Marriage Play, a one-acter about mid-life crisis and marital discord. He's also in the re-run of Channel 4's 1989 drama series about the heroin trade, Traffik, from which theOscar-winning film Traffic was adapted. Paterson plays the Michael Douglas role, a government minister who discovers his daughter is an addict. He is, wrote one critic recently, "preferable to Douglas like Chateauneuf du Pape is preferable to a McDonald's shake".

Characteristically, Paterson credits others, especially director Alistair Reid, for Traffik's success - Baftas and Emmys rained down upon it. But his own involvement was no less intense."We started filming in Karachi within a week of the fatwa on Salman Rushdie," he recalls. "To say tensions were running high is putting it mildly." The tension intensified as Traffik was drawn into the world it sought to depict. "For one scene, we actually made heroin, and when the police guarding us realised we were destroying it after filming, they said, 'We could get rid of that for you, boys. You don't need to destroy it, just pass it over.' It was very, very strange."

Lesser actors might have felt out of their depth, but Paterson is an old hand at making drama that impinges upon real life. After two years as a quantity surveyor, then training as a drama teacher, he got his break as a performer in an Edinburgh Festival agitprop extravaganza by the young Billy Connolly. The Great Northern Welly Boot Show was a satire on the predicament of the striking Upper Clyde Shipbuilders. It went on to become " the event of 1972. Suddenly, there was a popular political show that had crossed the boundaries, as everybody said the festival ought to do."

Paterson caught the eye of socialist writer-director John McGrath, who invited him to join The Cheviot, the Stag and the Black, Black Oil. It was an entertainment in the style of a Highland ceilidh that made connections between the Clearances and the foreign exploitation of North Sea oil. Paterson acted, MC'd, sang and played the bagpipes in the whisky-soaked shindig into which each gig evolved.

"It was a life-changing experience," says Paterson, "and it really did open doors." Thirty years on, The Cheviot looks almost exotic - a stirring example of how performance can tackle the politics that directly affect people's lives in a rumbustious, participatory way. "What made it work," says Paterson, "was that everybody was encouraged to bring their own material to it." Does he miss that? "I wouldn't mind having half the energy to do it again." He has recently approached McGrath about revisiting The Cheviot, "to look again at what we got right and what we got completely wrong".

He's clearly still a political animal, so is he nostalgic for socially committed theatre? "I always hate to say nobody is doing it now, because there are probably plenty of people who are." He cites Sarah Kane's Blasted, which his wife, Hildegard Bechtler, designed, as proof "there are political plays being written, without a doubt. But they're not as cheery as Cheviot."

Paterson's latest play finds him a long way from the Highlands, but Marriage Play has been given a British spin, and Paterson hopes to locate it in a world we'll all recognise. "If they'd said it's got to be set in New England, I might have said, 'Get somebody else.' I do accents as well as the next actor, but I'd rather find a way to make this man as close to me and, therefore, as close to others, as possible."

But surely Paterson - 30 years into a successful career that he admits he was lucky to tumble into - doesn't share his character Jack's despair that "no matter what we have done, or where, or with whom, nothing has made any difference, nothing is enough"? "I don't have that pessimistic view," he agrees. "But I do think we'd all like our existence to have made a difference."

It's only a small leap from Jack's mid-life crisis to the insecurities with which actors are all too familiar. "You keep thinking you'll get found out, and when this opens I probably will. A well-known director once described me as 'the most improved actor in recent years'. I thought that was a fantastic phrase because I must have been dire before. And I keep thinking now that I've improved as much as I ever will and it'll never get any better."

Paterson's agitprop days may be behind him - although he's confident Marriage Play will agitate audiences - but his life, unlike Jack's, picks up momentum as it hits middle age. "The more grown-up you are as an actor," he says, "the more chance you have of keeping at it. Because there are fewer of you around. You can balance your mid-life crisis with the simple fact that you're lucky to have stayed around this long."

fields.headline: A raspberry to Stalin
fields.standfirst: A musical blockbuster about a tower block? Some say Shostakovich was taking the mickey with Paradise Moscow.  Alfred Hickling is not so sure
fields.trailText: A musical blockbuster about a tower block? Some say Shostakovich was taking the mickey with Paradise Moscow. Alfred Hickling is not so sure.
fields.body:
Paradise Moscow is the most curious thing the Russian composer Dmitry Shostakovich ever wrote. Dating from the late 1950s and originally entitled Cheryomushki, this unclassifiable work takes a satirical swipe at spineless apparatchiks, socialist realism and the Soviet passion for urban planning. It is the only musical blockbuster ever written about a tower block.

Cheryomushki itself is a monolithic overspill development on the outskirts of Moscow - the kind of grim post-war monstrosity that purported to offer the ultimate in urban living. In Shostakovich's comedy, developers and party workers are so busy feathering their own nests that the tenants have to seize their prefabricated paradise by force.

It is not really an opera, but nor is it quite a musical. Cheryomushki's boppy rhythms and fixed-grin bravado suggest that Shostakovich could have made a profitable career as a jingle-writer for Radio 2, or perhaps he ought to be acknowledged as the grandfather of Europop. But who do you engage to perform such a hybrid? Opera singers? Musical actors? S Club 7?

Cheryomushki requires a large, exceptionally versatile cast who can act, sing and dance, the difficulty being that Shostakovich took light music very seriously indeed. Much of the vocal writing lies outside the compass of the average musical actor, while the high-octane dance routines are beyond the capabilities of most opera singers. The director of Opera North's new "English-language" production, David Pountney, has opted for a pick-and-mix approach, drawing his cast from the worlds of opera and musical theatre.

Cheryomushki thus provides a rare opportunity to encounter performers as diverse as Alan Oke and Janie Dee on the same stage. Oke is a tenor who recently starred in the Madame Butterfly in-the-round spectacular at the Royal Albert Hall, while Dee won the Olivier award for best actress last year for her role in an Alan Ayckbourn play.

Oke and Dee admit they initially found it odd working together. "I soon discovered that the big difference between opera and musicals is the amount of attention paid to the voice," says Dee. "When these singers were training they spent six or seven hours a day on their voice - I did barely a quarter of that."

Oke interprets this the other way round. "Being a singer is a bit like being a bodybuilder," he says. "You are constantly working to refine a very select group of vocal muscles. It doesn't necessarily make you particularly mobile or a natural actor."

Cheryomushki is the kind of piece that encourages everyone to develop new talents. In the final run-through Dee is casually flung over her partner's shoul der as they perfect the choreography of a jitterbug pastiche. Chorus members practise balancing motionlessly on pedestals in the guise of heroic monuments to the Russian construction industry. Oke swings past, singing his aria from a trolley upstage. He later reveals that he will deliver this number in a basket, suspended from a crane.

Not surprisingly, musical opinion has tended to dismiss Cheryomushki as the ugly duckling of Shostakovich's career, but the remarkable thing is that it was written at all. Soviet opera was a sombre affair. Dour, state-approved organisations such as the Association of Proletarian Musicians were responsible for such ideological conceits as renaming Tosca the Struggle for the Commune, and altering the story so that the painting of the Madonna was turned into a fresco glorifying the international Red Army. Tosca, as one wag pointed out, became toská - the Russian word for despair.

The avant-garde impulse of Shostakovich's early works was unlikely to remain unchecked for long. In 1936 the composer's operatic career was curtailed when Stalin attended a performance of Shostakovich's second full-length opera, Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District. The assessment of the work as degenerate resulted in a vicious media onslaught, and for a time the composer was fearful for his life.

But if Lady Macbeth was the opera Stalin didn't want to hear, Cheryomushki is the piece musicologists prefer not to talk about. For those who would rather dissect the meaning of the great symphonies and string quartets, Cheryomushki remains a perpetual embarrassment - an encapsulation of the banality and spiritual impoverishment of social realist art. In truth, Shostakovich was simply thawing out in the post-Stalin climate and having fun in a genre he enjoyed. It is the sound of a serious composer blowing a raspberry.

The conductor Jim Holmes points out that Shostakovich had a lively sense of humour. "He used to earn a crust from playing piano accompaniment to silent movies, and throughout his career he continued to write brilliant, witty ballets, film scores and incidental music," Holmes explains. "The tragedy is that the Communist party drove him from the stage - but when Stalin's death finally made it possible for him to write another opera, he came up with a genuinely popular, proletarian comedy. Cheryomushki really is music for the masses - which makes it almost impossible to tell whether Shostakovich was toeing the line or taking the mickey."

Of course it is not impossible that he was doing both at the same time. Since the composer's death in 1975, critics have been squabbling over whether Shostakovich spent his career openly exulting Communism, or secretly excoriating it. Attention has invariably been focused on the message behind the "serious" works: but perhaps there are more clues to be found in this disposably light-hearted, deadly serious little musical. Cheryomushki is a perfect example of Noel Coward's remark about the amazing potency of cheap music.

 Paradise Moscow is at the Grand Theatre, Leeds (0113-222 6222), from May 3 to 12, Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020-7863 8000), from May 23 to 26, and then tours. It will be broadcast live on BBC Radio 3 at 7.10pm on Saturday.

webTitle: Talks fail to avert tube strike

fields.headline: Talks fail to avert tube strike
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Commuters in London are facing major disruption tomorrow after 18 hours of talks failed to avert a 24-hour tube strike.
fields.body:
Commuters in London are facing major disruption tomorrow after 18 hours of talks failed to avert a 24-hour tube strike.

London Underground staff belonging to the Rail, Maritime and Transport union will walk out at 8pm tonight following the failure of prolonged negotiations at the conciliation service Acas. The union confirmed that the strike would go ahead because of its continued fears for safety on the network under the government's proposals for a public private partnership.

The strike, scheduled to end at 8pm tomorrow night, follows a similar shutdown at the end of March which led to a day of chaos for commuters, many of whom were forced on to congested roads. An Underground spokeswoman said yesterday: "If they [union members] come out in force, then it is going to be a grim day."

The Corporation of London said the last strike cost at least £100m because of lost work, production and commerce.

The union said last night that measures proposed by London Underground still fell short of the guarantees it was seeking over safety.

Bob Crow, the RMT assistant general secretary, said: "The RMT made a real attempt to resolve our differences during 18 hours of negotiations. The fact remains, however, that LU management had reserved the right to cut staffing levels, which we believe has serious implications for safety."

He added: "We want the public to know that we greatly regret the inconvenience our strike action will cause but they are likely to face a lot more inconvenience in years to come if a PPP goes ahead as planned."

A London Underground spokeswoman said: "We are very disappointed after 18 hours of talks entered into with goodwill on both sides that the RMT executive should choose to continue with the strike."

She added: "The union say the strike is about safety and that they are concerned about reductions in job numbers, but we are hiring not firing. Recently we have employed 100 new train operators and are currently recruiting 100 new station staff."

webTitle: Special branch accused of suppressing confession

fields.headline: Special branch accused of suppressing confession
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An RUC officer claimed yesterday that special branch suppressed a taped confession he obtained from the loyalist gunman who said he shot the Catholic solicitor Pat Finucane.
fields.body:
An RUC officer claimed yesterday that special branch suppressed a taped confession he obtained from the loyalist gunman who said he shot the Catholic solicitor Pat Finucane.

The allegations will heighten calls for an independent tribunal into the murder of Mr Finucane, who was shot dead in front of his family at his north Belfast home in 1989.

Detective Sergeant Johnston Brown, who recently took early retirement after 30 years in the force, said he gave special branch two tapes of conversations he had with a member of the Ulster Freedom Fighters in October 1991.

But he says they only passed on the second, containing no reference to the murder, to the inquiry, headed by the Metropolitan police chief, Sir John Stevens, which is investigating collusion claims.

"Someone, within a week of that confession being in our domain, made the decision not only not to go forward with the investigation but to obstruct and ensure anyone like myself and my colleague coming forward would be ridiculed," he said, on Ulster TV last night. No one from special branch was available for comment.

Mr Brown has given affidavits to the Stevens inquiry with details of both conversations he had with the east Belfast paramilitary.

Mr Brown said special branch officers threatened to wreck his career and discredit his family if he pursued the matter.

William Stobie, an ex-Ulster Defence Association quartermaster and self-confessed police informer accused of supplying the guns for the Finucane murder, could walk free in three weeks as it is understood the main prosecution witness has withdrawn his evidence on medical grounds.

Stobie claimed he warned special branch there was to be an assassination but they did not act.

fields.headline: Railtrack asks army for help
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack has appealed to the army for hundreds of skilled recruits to help it tackle acute shortages of engineers and signalling staff on key projects throughout its 11,000 mile network.
fields.body:
Railtrack has appealed to the army for hundreds of skilled recruits to help it tackle acute shortages of engineers and signalling staff on key projects throughout its 11,000 mile network.

It said last night that it was looking for skilled staff from among the hundreds of people leaving the armed forces or retiring. "The situation is serious. We need skilled engineers immediately," said Railtrack.

Richard Middleton, Railtrack's technical director, said: "There is a worldwide shortage of these engineers. They are in very short supply."

Railtrack needs at least 300 engineers and signallers immediately on several plans, including the £6.3bn project to develop the west coast main line from Glasgow to London, and its £400m plan to install a safety system on all trains following the Paddington rail crash in October 1999.

Mr Middleton said: "We are talking to the army which has people with electrical skills and signalling competency in the hope that we might be able to pick up some of these people as they retire or move on."

Mr Middleton, a civil engineer, who was appointed technical director as part of Railtrack's move to create a stronger engineering base after the Hatfield rail crash last October, said civil and structures engineers were also in short supply.

Railtrack has also been searching overseas for skilled staff. It said it had recruited Italians to work in the Manchester area on important schemes. It is also recruiting engineers in Germany, India, and Romania.

First Engineeering, one of Railtrack's contractors, said that it had spent thousands of pounds recruiting engineers from abroad because no suitable candidates existed in Britain. "It is a result of the fast track investment in regenerating the railways," it said.

The crisis comes as a direct result of the Hatfield crash, where years of neglect and underfunding were exposed when hundreds of cracks on the system were discovered during a huge inspection exercise by Railtrack.

Railmen who took early retirement have been encouraged to return to fill 1,000 jobs. But this has only been partly successful, so the army has been asked to lend a hand.

Railtrack's problems began after privatisation when it lost many experienced members of staff who realised that the company was bent on sub-contracting out most of its engineering work.

Questions about the wisdom of this policy have grown and Railtrack has now reversed the trend with a new emphasis on in-house skills. Schools and colleges are also being targeted to attract new recruits.

Jackie Chappell, chief executive of the rail industry training council, said: "A higher level of recruitment will be needed over the next three to five years because there will be more trains, higher investment and because there is an ageing workforce."

The crisis comes as a direct result of the Hatfield crash, where years of neglect and underfunding were exposed when hundreds of cracks on the system were discovered during a huge inspection exercise by Railtrack. Railmen who took early retirement have been encouraged to return to fill 1,000 jobs. But this has only been partly successful, so the army has been asked to lend a hand. Railtrack's problems began after privatisation when it lost many experienced members of staff who realised that the company was bent on sub-contracting out most of its engineering work. Questions about the wisdom of this policy have grown and Railtrack has now reversed the trend with a new emphasis on in-house skills. Schools and colleges are also being targeted to attract new recruits. Jackie Chappell, chief executive of the rail industry training council, said: "A higher level of recruitment will be needed over the next three to five years because there will be more trains, higher investment and because there is an ageing workforce."

webTitle: New rules to extend maternity leave

fields.headline: New rules to extend maternity leave
fields.standfirst:
Government acts to give mothers more choice

Advice on the world of work
fields.trailText: Mothers will be able to take up to a year off work around the birth of their baby under an overhaul of the complex maternity rules unveiled by the government yesterday.
fields.body:
Mothers will be able to take up to a year off work around the birth of their baby under an overhaul of the complex maternity rules unveiled by the government yesterday.

The move, which extends unpaid leave by three months, was welcomed by family campaigners, though there were calls for the government to grant new parents the right to work flexible or reduced hours.

Ministers are still debating the option, which has not been ruled out but is met with caution in Downing Street because of business opposition - reinforced by the CBI yesterday.

In the latest of a string of pre-election announcements targeted at women and the family, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, will today give details of a £100m upgrade of maternity units across the country, designed to give mothers more choice over how and where their babies are delivered.

He will address the Royal College of Midwives the day after members warned that they felt their role was undervalued and pressed for more government funding for the service.

Steps to extend maternity leave are part of a package of measures to improve and streamline maternity rights, while seeking to keep employers on board.

In March, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced in the budget an increase in the flat rate of statutory maternity pay from £60.20 a week to £100 a week from April 2003. It will be paid for 26 weeks instead of the present 18.

The latest reform will add an extra 12 weeks to the maximum of 40 weeks which women can take before and after the birth of a child. It will also simplify the framework of pay and leave by standardising the qualifying periods - a move to please employers frustrated at the bureaucracy of the current system.

Mothers will have to give employers an extra week's notice of when they intend to start and return times. The CBI said employers wanted even more notice.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "With more women in work it is vital to put in place measures that allow working mothers to combine being a good parent with holding down a job.

"The right to take a year's maternity leave will make a real difference to a child's first year of life." The Maternity Alliance, which has long pressed for improved maternity pay and leave, welcomed the changes as a, "step in the right direction", but warned that many families earning just too much to qualify for benefits could find themselves unable to afford to take up the unpaid leave.

The National Family and Parenting Institute also praised moves to bring British parents' rights closer to those of their European counterparts.

Campaigners argued that a right to come back to work on flexitime or part time would encourage more women to return to work. One in three new mothers do not return to work, but the DTI estimated that if 10% of those went back to work, employers could save £35m a year in recruitment.

Mr Milburn will today invite the 250 maternity units in England to bid for extra funding to update equipment and increase staffing to provide expectant mothers with greater continuity of care. He wants the NHS to make home births more easily available and to provide more home-like birthing suites in hospitals.

fields.headline: How 'zero tolerance' worked in practice
fields.standfirst:
Police chief decided to hem in protesters

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: With mounted police, helicopters, and 6,000 officers available - outnumbering the protesters by several hundred - the police strategy should have been easy to deploy.
fields.body:
With mounted police, helicopters, and 6,000 officers available - outnumbering the protesters by several hundred - the police strategy should have been easy to deploy.

It had two simple aims: where possible and appropriate - during the smaller demonstrations earlier in the day - officers were instructed to "disrupt and disperse"; otherwise, orders to the frontline were to "isolate and contain".

The operation was choreographed from a control room at New Scotland Yard which receives pictures from CCTV cameras all over London.

Though officers knew trouble would almost certainly flare at Oxford Circus, the police did not try to prevent people gathering there. Sir John Stevens, the Met commissioner, wanted to hem them in.

Protesters were allowed into the throng, but were warned they would not be allowed out again. The tactic only partially succeeded. At the height of the demonstration, 5,000 people had converged on Oxford Street, but when the protesters surged forward, they often broke through the police lines and peeled off into sidestreets.

As the police regrouped, there were stand-offs and scuffles. Protesters threw bottles, wood and concrete. The police retaliated with baton charges.

By late afternoon, three protest groups had emerged; outside the John Lewis store in Holles Street, in Oxford Circus, and towards Cavendish Square.

Assistant commissioner Mike Todd promised and delivered "in your face" policing. Though it probably intimidated some protesters, it undoubtedly aggravated others who considered it provocative.

Dozens of police "spotters" in plain clothes mixed with the demonstrators, helping uniformed officers target potential trouble-makers.

As the afternoon wore on, there were regular loudspeaker announcements from the police in Oxford Street. One said: "You are being detained here to prevent a breach of the peace and criminal damage to property. You will be released in due course."

Another was more plaintive, saying: "Why don't you just go home?"

The demonstrators more or less stuck to the itinerary described on the May Day Monopoly website. But they had a few surprises. At appointed times in the afternoon, ringleaders in Oxford Street handed flyers telling protesters to move on - to Holborn, Marble Arch, Trafalgar Square.

Pockets of the quickest demonstrators were able to outwit officers in riot gear. Police often found themselves isolated, triggering further charges to rescue them.

Scotland Yard knew "zero tolerance" was a high-risk strategy. Rather than focusing attention on the businesses which are normally the target for the anti-capitalist demonstrators, it focused attention on the officers themselves.

Sir John calculated that talking tough gave him two advantages. It would deter many demonstrators from taking part, leaving the force, theoretically, with a "no-lose" situation. If violence erupted, the Met could say: "I told you so." If the day passed peacefully, he could claim the strategy had worked. Secondly, flexing police muscle played well politically, at a national and local level.

There was another ingredient. Nobody had to tell Sir John that the demonstration would probably be just before a general election. A graduate of the no-nonsense school of policing, he brooded over his options. He felt his force had been made to look foolish last May, and vowed it would not happen again.

fields.headline: Give us a break
fields.standfirst: The government's new parental leave scheme seems a lifesaver for parents who struggle to balance work and family. But, as  Anna Macarthur reveals, there's a catch
fields.trailText: The government's new parental leave scheme seems a lifesaver for parents who struggle to balance work and family. But, as Anna Macarthur reveals, there's a catch.
fields.body:
It is the perpetual fear of all working parents: that dreaded phone call in the middle of the morning rush from the childminder who is too sick to work. Or perhaps one of the children has developed a temperature and, just to be on the safe side, the nursery staff think she would be better off at home.

Either way, the parents are in limbo and due at their desk within the hour. It's decision time, with most guardians torn between confessing the truth to the personnel department, which retaliates by quickly snatching the last few precious days of annual leave; and opting for the more devious route of phoning in sick and listening to the boss grumbling about never employing a parent again.

What mums and dads desperately need is a "get out of work free" card - and the EU's parental leave directive appears to fit the bill. It allows all parents with children born after December 15 the chance to take up to 13 weeks' extra unpaid holiday. And, following a 16-month campaign by the TUC, which included the threat of high-court action by Cherie Booth, the government finally backed down and agreed last week to extend the right to all parents with children under the age of five.

At last, there seemed to be a chance for parents to take a deep breath and stop panicking every time their offspring need immunisation, or a check-up with the health visitor, or simply go down with one of those things children are always going down with. On the face of it, the new law is a triumph for working parents, heralding a new era of family-friendly practices in the workplace.

But there is a snag. While the extension of the EU directive might be a step in the right direction, parental leave is not all it is cracked up to be. Not only is it unpaid, but it must be taken in blocks of one week, is only available to workers who have been with their company for more than a year, and is conditional on employees giving their companies at least three weeks' notice.

To cap it all, if the employer can prove that the granting of parental leave would be detrimental to their business, your leave can be postponed for up to six months. Not too handy if the childminder called in sick this morning.

The Department of Trade and Industry's senior policy adviser for employee relations, Graham Morton, agrees that there has been some confusion over what the new entitlement is for. "There is a misunderstanding, as it is not meant for emergencies," he said. "The kind of situation it might be used for is if care is provided informally by the extended family, who are going on holiday." The parents can then book additional time off from work to stay at home and look after their kids. But they would still be forced to take the leave in blocks of one week, each time losing that whole week's wages. Unless parents are able to negotiate a special deal with their employers, they could end up severely out of pocket - with no salary and a bill for the childminder's holiday pay.

According to the GMB's head of equal rights, Karen Constantine, this explains why there has been a slow take-up of the scheme. Her union surveyed 200 members last year, and found that only one had taken advantage of the parental leave directive. "Parents can't afford a period of time where they are unpaid," she says. "If they are working a 60-hour week to make ends meet, how are they going to afford to take time off unpaid?

"The majority will end up robbing Peter to pay Paul. And it will be nigh on impossible for single-parent families to capitalise on the scheme."

Full-time working mother Liz Easton says that she would relish the chance to spend more time at home with her two-year-old son Pip: "I've been thinking about taking him to the clinic just to check up on his weight and height, but it's only open during working hours. I'd like to think that I could take some time off as a bonding time with Pip and not just use up holidays for emergencies.

"The 13 weeks would be useful if we had a real crisis, but I wouldn't really be able to afford it and would need to rely on my credit card."

The only hope for parents forced to fritter away their annual vacation on the odd day here and there is to negotiate with their employers. Some companies have proved to be more sympathetic than others. Easton's previous employer, a large insurance company, could afford to be "quite family-friendly", offering 25 days' annual leave plus flexitime, which meant that Liz could leave work at 3.30pm or save up overtime to pay for extra days off. But working for a smaller company makes it difficult to take advantage of such rights. Fashion worker and mother of two Ann Hodge, who recently quit her part-time job, felt it was unlikely that her company would have been receptive to the idea of additional holidays on top of annual leave.

"Working for a small firm, they would have frowned upon it if I'd mentioned extra holidays," she says. "If I had stuck to my guns and taken it, then it would have made relations in the office strained and life difficult."

T errence Libby, who employs 50 men and women at his manu-facturing company in Northamptonshire, explains why the parental leave directive is a strain on small business: "There has already been an excessive extension of employees' rights over the last 18 months. Adding another 13 weeks is just another burden.

"Small companies do not have specialist departments: we may have just one person in the payroll department, for example, and if they are away, it is incredibly disruptive."

But according to Margery Carey, president of retail workers' union USDAW, the onus is on employers first. "The government has put the basic there - it's up to the employers to build on it," she argues. "As a union we now have to put the meat on the bones and negotiate with companies. You don't get what you want overnight - we need to build on that."

In the meantime, if your children are sent home from nursery tomorrow, there is another alternative to fibbing to the boss: time off for dependents was introduced alongside the parental leave directive and offers one or two days off for domestic emergencies. Sadly, it remains unpaid but, as notice is not required, it could go some way to bridge the gap until paid, flexible parental leave is finally introduced.

fields.headline: Police trap for protesters
fields.standfirst: Massive presence contains demonstrators
fields.trailText: A"zero tolerance" police operation which involved corralling thousands of protesters in a tight, strictly marshalled cordon around the West End of London last night led to accusations of unlawful detention at the end of another May Day marked by occasional violence and vandalism.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins, Vikram Dodd  and  Rebecca Allison
fields.body:
A"zero tolerance" police operation which involved corralling thousands of protesters in a tight, strictly marshalled cordon around the West End of London last night led to accusations of unlawful detention at the end of another May Day marked by occasional violence and vandalism.

Although 65 people had been arrested by midnight and there were sporadic skirmishes between the two sides throughout the afternoon - including baton charges in Oxford Street and missile throwing - the scenes did not compare with the chaos visited on Parliament Square last year.

The protesters, however, complained that the aggressive police tactics were unnec essarily provocative and were to blame for the clashes.

Though the Met was insisting last night that the tough tactics were necessary, the decision to ring Oxford Circus with officers in riot gear meant thousands of peaceful protesters, and some tourists, were trapped for up to six hours.

The stand-off between the two sides in a confined area, with officers and protesters crushed together, agitated an already tense situation.

As the evening wore on, the police strictly controlled the release of protesters from Oxford Circus. According to eyewitnesses, the demonstrators were only allowed out one at a time and many had their photographs taken by police cameramen. Officers are only supposed to do this when there are strong grounds to suspect a person has been involved in criminality.

Protesters also complained about the indiscriminate use of stop and search powers.

The civil rights group Liberty said last night that hemming in protesters for such a long period may constitute unlawful detention.

"No one wants to defend people that have gone out to cause criminal damage," said Roger Bingham.

"But the big question is going to be whether the police tactics were proportionate, or whether they went too far.

"We need to ask whether the right to peaceful protest was subdued for the sake of reducing criminal damage. At the moment, it is too early to tell."

The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, defended the police strategy.

He pointed to the damage caused by 50 demonstrators who broke through police lines and went on the rampage in Tottenham Court Road.

"This appalling vandalism shows the decision to contain the protesters was right. The immediate turn to violence on dispersal indicates that this was the core objective of the organisers."

A Scotland Yard spokesman added: "Although the majority of those involved were protesting peacefully, it only takes 100 or so protesters to cause anarchy. "

Though not on the scale of last year's protests, the toll for this year's demonstrations was still high. Twenty-eight protesters suffered injuries, including a man who was hit by a missile. Eight of those arrested came from Denmark, Poland, Belgium and the USA.

Three police officers were hurt, including a WPC who collapsed unconscious after being crushed. She was later discharged from hospital.

The cost of closing businesses and banks considered vulnerable has been estimated at £20m.

Six thousand police officers were deployed by the Met commissioner Sir John Stevens to deal with the demonstrators, targeting, in particular, a hard core of 1,000 that Scotland Yard had identified as serious troublemakers.

With only 5,000 protesters joining in - half last year's total - there was early hope that the day would pass off peacefully. But trouble erupted in the early afternoon when thousands of protesters converged on Oxford Circus.

Officers are only supposed to do this when there are strong grounds to suspect a person has been involved in criminality. Protesters also complained about the indiscriminate use of stop and search powers. The civil rights group Liberty said last night that hemming in protesters for such a long period may constitute unlawful detention. "No one wants to defend people that have gone out to cause criminal damage," said Roger Bingham. "But the big question is going to be whether the police tactics were proportionate, or whether they went too far. "We need to ask whether the right to peaceful protest was subdued for the sake of reducing criminal damage. At the moment, it is too early to tell." The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, defended the police strategy. He pointed to the damage caused by 50 demonstrators who broke through police lines and went on the rampage in Tottenham Court Road. "This appalling vandalism shows the decision to contain the protesters was right. The immediate turn to violence on dispersal indicates that this was the core objective of the organisers." A Scotland Yard spokesman added: "Although the majority of those involved were protesting peacefully, it only takes 100 or so protesters to cause anarchy. " Though not on the scale of last year's protests, the toll for this year's demonstrations was still high. Twenty-eight protesters suffered injuries, including a man who was hit by a missile. Eight of those arrested came from Denmark, Poland, Belgium and the USA. Three police officers were hurt, including a WPC who collapsed unconscious after being crushed. She was later discharged from hospital. The cost of closing businesses and banks considered vulnerable has been estimated at £20m. Six thousand police officers were deployed by the Met commissioner Sir John Stevens to deal with the demonstrators, targeting, in particular, a hard core of 1,000 that Scotland Yard had identified as serious troublemakers. With only 5,000 protesters joining in - half last year's total - there was early hope that the day would pass off peacefully. But trouble erupted in the early afternoon when thousands of protesters converged on Oxford Circus. fields.headline: 'Buddha' joke falls flat on regulators
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A TV shopping channel that compared a statue of Buddha to 'a podgy Jew' has come under fire from watchdogs. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A TV shopping channel that compared a statue of Buddha to "a podgy Jew" has come under fire from the industry watchdog.

The comment was made by a QVC presenter who was describing a miniature jade Buddha. During the presentation he said: "If I continued eating until Christmas... I'd look like this little Buddha... it could be me, like a podgy Jew".

QVC said the description had been self-deprecating and referred to his own appearance. It pointed out that the presenter was black, saying this diminished any offence created.

But the Independent Television Commission ruled that the presenter had used stereotyped imagery that could cause offence.

The ITC also banned an advert that showed a mother throwing a drill in front of her children because of fears it could encourage dangerous behaviour.

The watchdog ruled that the advert, for Bosch power tools, had broken its code of conduct by appearing to condone careless use of the products.

The watchdog said it had noted Bosch's defence that the situation in the commercial was intended to be unrealistic, but said it should not be shown again in its current form.

The ITC also censured McDonald's over a campaign to promote its two for the price of one offer.

The watchdog upheld complaints from 40 viewers that the campaign was misleading because it implied the offer was available on all the fast food chain's products. In fact, it only applied to certain products on specific days.

Insurance proved a contentious issue, with three advertisers coming under fire. A Lunn Poly advert promoting an offer of travel insurance was banned, as were commercials for Direct Line and Cornhill Insurance.

webTitle: A day of skirmishes then stalemate

fields.headline: A day of skirmishes then stalemate
fields.standfirst:
Early optimism turns sour as protests develop into game of cat and mouse

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: For once, the anarchists turned up early. A little after 2pm yesterday, almost two hours before the official start of the grand finale of the Mayday Monopoly action, more than 1,000 protesters began converging on Oxford Circus in central London.
fields.byline: Reporting team: John Vidal, Vikram Dodd, Rebecca Allison, Tania Branigan, Jeevan Vasagar and Stuart Millar
fields.body:
For once, the anarchists turned up early. A little after 2pm yesterday, almost two hours before the official start of the grand finale of the Mayday Monopoly action, more than 1,000 protesters began converging on Oxford Circus in central London.

Despite the rain, they arrived in high spirits. A series of protests across the city had been low-key but upbeat. The police had been out in force - in places outnumbering demonstrators by 20 to one - but dire warnings of serious trouble had proved unfounded. In the hub of the West End, the shopping and tourist centre of London, all that changed.

The protest leaders had dubbed the Oxford Street event the Sale of the Century, the culmination of the day's action scheduled to kick off at 4pm. They insisted it was to be a massive street party; police claimed the real purpose was to attack and loot the stores lining the street. Determined to take no chances, the "zero tolerance" operation went into action.

When the first protesters reached Oxford Circus after 2pm, they were met by a wall of police, backed up by dozens of vans and mounted officers.

The protesters tried to continue north along Regent Street but were forced back. As chants of "Whose street? Our street!" rang out, police in riot gear formed a sec ond line of defence behind the uniformed officers, and a line of police vans was moved to form a surge barrier. Oxford Circus underground station was closed. Within minutes, all four routes out of the crossroads were blocked and about 1,000 protesters were sealed into the junction in what amounted to a mass arrest.

For a while, the crowd remained good-natured. They continued to chant and shout. A football was tossed around, between the banners and huge cardboard cutouts of cartoon fat cats.

But by 3pm, with the weather deteriorating, the crowd was still sealed in tight together by lines of police in riot gear, and the mood was rapidly turning sour.

Many bystanders were hemmed in with the protesters. Two German tourists missed their flight home after being sealed in by police and refused permission to leave, even though they showed them their passports and airline tickets.

Carol Nahra, 33, who works in Poland Street, near Oxford Circus, had popped out for her lunchbreak only to be caught in the stand-off. "There's nowhere to go to the bathroom, and people are having to use the stairs into the tube station," she said. "Everyone is so cold and they're trying to jump up and down to keep warm.

"I think the crowds would have dissipated a long time ago if the police had let people go. A lot of people are resigned to be stuck here for a while, but as soon as it starts to rain they get angry."

Fainted
As the stalemate continued, Garfunkels on Great Castle Street became the riot police cafe, shelter and emergency treatment centre for the few protesters who were injured or traumatised. In two hours, four people who had fainted were brought in for sweet tea.

But mainly Garfunkels was where the riot police went to use the toilet. First, they had to unzip their flame-proof trousers, then remove a cricket box, burrow through another pair of trousers and then reach their underpants. "It's a bloody nightmare, this," said No 721. (For a woman PC it is even worse: "I have to almost completely get undressed. It takes about half an hour. Not much good in a riot," said one).

Outside, the mood was becoming increasingly volatile. Just after 3pm, there was a countdown from 10 to one at which point the crowd trapped at the crossroads tried to break through the police line up Regent Street. A firework went off behind the police lines. Bottles were thrown but police succeeded in pushing the surging protesters back. A lot of shoving, but still nothing serious.

Around the corner, Inspector Simon Earle was content with events. "Although there are a lot of them, the mood was quite pleasant. The odd bottle was thrown but most of them have been sensible and it doesn't seem to have escalated."

Responding to the suggestion that police containment tactics might be provoking problems, he shrugged. "We are wrong if we do and wrong if we don't."

But with hundreds of protesters continuing to arrive in the West End for the Sale of the Century event, police found themselves constantly having to establish and defend new containment areas to keep the increasingly angry crowds apart. As they moved through the maze of side streets in west Soho and east Mayfair which border Oxford Street, a tense game of cat-and-mouse began to unfold.

At 4.40pm, around 500 protesters managed to outflank the police and break through from Holles Street into Oxford Street, just 50 yards from the main group. After several minutes, riot police were brought in to force them back, with several protesters injured in the struggle. Assistant commissioner Mike Todd conceded that officers "needed to regain control".

A few hours earlier, it had looked as if serious trouble was going to be avoided. For six hours, London enjoyed its quietest May Day in years and for the 5,000 protesters it was a dream: 6,000 sweet-as-pie police officers, the City eerily empty, and thousands of journalists concentrating not on the violence but why people had taken the day off to protest.

The first throw of the Monopoly dice was a bike ride converging on King's Cross from Marylebone station to the west and Liverpool Street to the east. As the police whizzed around in their rented vans, the 250 cyclists fluffed around, lay in the middle of Euston Road reading books, ate their giveaway veggie burgers outside arch-enemy McDonald's. "We are celebrating life, we are not interested in violence," said a man in rainbow-striped clothes calling himself Prof Kayoss.

Three miles away, at Hyde Park Corner, another tribe was meeting. The homeless and asylum seekers and their supporters were, it was said, going to build a symbolic cardboard hotel on Park Lane, just like in the Monopoly game. It was more like a studio flat in Peckham; one small man managed, just, to get in it.

Across the Thames on the Elephant and Castle roundabout, the south London mayday collective had invited protesters to an anti-capitalist picnic. "One of the best things about the layout of these demonstrations is that there are a lot of different, small actions," said Alistair. "There are not enough people here for this to get out of hand."

At the time, his words seemed reasonable enough. A few hours later, they had been proved wildly optimistic.

As darkness fell on Oxford Street, police faced escalating attacks from protesters furious at being penned in all day. Outside the John Lewis department store, officers struggled on three fronts to contain various groups of protesters. A few used the shop's canopy as a platform to drop missiles down on police and it was more than an hour before police regained control.

Late last night, sporadic skirmishes were continuing from Oxford Street into Soho, with several shops and banks being attacked.

Police were continuing to disperse the remaining pockets of protesters from the area. But they were only to allowed to leave in single file and only after giving their names and addresses and having their photographs taken.

"We're being treated like terrorists but all we're doing is showing that we're a bit pissed off with the way things are," said Ross Batman, 20, from Kent. "I am just here to make a stand because people don't seem to have a voice anymore but even when we're standing in the street they just section us off so we can't mingle with ordinary people."

fields.headline: Exorcism: abuse or cure?
fields.standfirst: While the use of exorcism in treating mental health problems may seem far-fetched, Anglican and Catholic priests are still performing the controversial ritual. David Batty reports
fields.trailText: David Batty examines the controversial use of exorcism by Anglican and Catholic priests to treat mental health problems.
fields.body:
In the first half of William Friedkin's classic horror film The Exorcist, 12-year-old Regan is transformed from a giggling girl to a guttural troll with abnormal strength, spouting obscene blasphemies.

Initially, the doctors examining her think she has a lesion on her temporal lobe but after further tests, they decide her problems are psychological. When a psychiatrist fails to cure her, they recommend an exorcist. If Regan believed in the paranormal, they suggest she might also respond to the exorcism rite.

The idea that the medical profession would consider this medieval religious practice as a treatment might seem far-fetched, but across the UK Anglican and Catholic clergy continue to perform the ritual, often with the sanction of psychiatrists.

The Church of England's Deliverance Ministry, which was set up in 1974 after an "unfortunate" exorcism in Yorkshire, has teams of clergy and psychiatrists in each diocese and investigates dozens of claims of haunting, poltergeists and demonic possession very year. No exorcism is sanctioned without the consent of the local bishop and a psychiatric assessment.

The Rev Lisle Ryder, head of the Deliverance Ministry in Worcester and a member of the Christian Deliverance Study Group, which trains parish clergy, regards deliverance as alternative form of therapy for people with strong religious beliefs.

"Many people in distress come to the church for help because they have a religious frame of reference and are either put off from visiting a doctor because of the stigma of mental illness or because they don't believe their problems have a scientific explanation," said Mr Ryder.

"Exorcism should only be used as a last resort," he warns. "I've only carried out five in the past eight years, but they have not followed the traditional rite. A simple blessing will usually suffice to comfort most people. Many clearly have a mental health problem.

"Our aim is to end or control their paranormal experience so they are more receptive to traditional treatment, although in many cases no follow-up is required."

Mr Ryder is contacted about "paranormal phenomena" about 25 times a year. Most of his work involves telephone advice to concerned clergy or saying prayers or offering parishioners "spiritual counselling", which encourages them to explore the emotions underlying their distress.

"I encourage them to describe the experience, whether they are frightened by an external force or something within them," he explains. "Then as sensitively as possible, try to find out whether they're on medication or are using illegal drugs, or have been dabbling in the occult."

"One case concerned a woman who had suffered years of domestic violence at the hands of her first husband. It had all the signs of poltergeist activity, cold spots and the toilet flushing by itself. This had happened during her first marriage but started again when she remarried. Talking to her, it seemed that anxiety about the new relationship was the root of the problem."

The priest's attitude to possession, poltergeists and haunting is similar to that of the hearing voices movement, which regards the voices heard by mental health service users as real experiences often triggered by traumatic events, such as bereavement, injury or abuse, rather than hallucinations.

Mike Smith, director of nursing at North Birmingham mental health trust, a leading advocate of voice hearing as a recovery model, has recently addressed and advised the Worcester Deliverance Ministry. He believes blessings and even exorcism can prove beneficial to patients if performed sensitively.

"Many people believe their voices are rooted in demonic possession and many have explored this safely with a minister," said Mr Smith, an atheist. "I know of one Scottish woman who was brought out of her distress through exorcism. Once she was able to put the experience in a religious framework she felt more in control and the voices stopped being so disruptive. After the spirits were cast out they went away and she's now functioning normally."

Mr Smith said the input of clergy could be valuable, as it could be hard for psychiatric nurses to differentiate between clients who were in a spiritual crisis and those suffering from a mental health problem. "In my experience, the Church is quite good at detecting when people are ill," he said.

"The context of the voices or spirits is crucial. If I were to say I was hearing the voice of God that would be different to someone from a very religious background, especially one which involves the belief in spirits, admitting the same thing. The problem may be down to stress caused by some conflict in their life, such as sexuality, with their religion rather than an illness."

However, despite such progressive approaches, concern about exorcism remains high among mental health charities, health professionals and among senior Church figures. There are particular fears about charismatic Anglican groups that take a fundamentalist approach to demonic possession.

"I saw a brother and sister who had been exorcised by a cousin from Scotland after their parents' funeral," said Mr Ryder. "He had heard them talking about transcendental meditation and believed this could have let evil spirits enter them. He exorcised them both but the girl had a particularly unpleasant reaction, retching and vomiting. They both felt they had been spiritually abused.

"I believe if you shout out the names of spirits and demons to be powerful you create a response in the 'host' like in the film The Exorcist."

Dr David McDonald, a psychiatrist who has advised the Church of England, said this "Bible-bashing approach" did not accept anything other than a spiritual cause to people's distress: "I have seen clients who were told they're possessed and an exorcism was performed but they felt no better. They believe they must be really evil if God can't help them, which can be terribly damaging."

In a survey last year by the Mental Health Foundation, entitled Spirituality and mental health: voices and realities, several respondents said they had been damaged by exorcism. The charity warned that the notion of demonic possession could be extremely damaging when linked to people with a label of mental illness and "risked conflating notions of evil and ill health."

Strategies for Living project coordinator at the MHF, Vicky Nicholls said: "One respondent from a Pentecostal background said a priest had placed their hands on them and said 'Let the demons be gone!' Most felt such practices had contributed to their mental health problems."

The Rev Stephen Parsons, author of Ungodly Fear: Fundamentalist Christianity and the abuse of power, said: "The charismatic movement wants to demonise mental illness so they can deal with it through exorcism. They say the Lord has given them a special insight that science and medicine cannot offer. But persuading vulnerable people that they are possessed gives you a great deal of power over them. It's a form of emotional abuse."

Mr Parsons said sexual abuse, homosexuality and unwanted pregnancy were often seen as routes for demonic possession. "Imagine telling someone who has been raped they're now possessed - that is terribly abusive."

However, Dr Chris Simpson, consultant psychiatrist at Friarage Hospital, Northallerton, who has treated many people after receiving deliverance, believes exorcism does not in itself cause a great deal of mental illness.

"The problem comes when a spiritual approach leads to a delay in receiving psychiatric help. If people bypass mental health services a lot of problems will be missed. So having the Church and the psychiatric profession work together when someone has a spiritual belief system can be beneficial."
