Mike Smith, director of nursing at North Birmingham mental health trust, a leading advocate of voice hearing as a recovery model, has recently addressed and advised the Worcester Deliverance Ministry. He believes blessings and even exorcism can prove beneficial to patients if performed sensitively. "Many people believe their voices are rooted in demonic possession and many have explored this safely with a minister," said Mr Smith, an atheist. "I know of one Scottish woman who was brought out of her distress through exorcism. Once she was able to put the experience in a religious framework she felt more in control and the voices stopped being so disruptive. After the spirits were cast out they went away and she's now functioning normally." Mr Smith said the input of clergy could be valuable, as it could be hard for psychiatric nurses to differentiate between clients who were in a spiritual crisis and those suffering from a mental health problem. "In my experience, the Church is quite good at detecting when people are ill," he said. "The context of the voices or spirits is crucial. If I were to say I was hearing the voice of God that would be different to someone from a very religious background, especially one which involves the belief in spirits, admitting the same thing. The problem may be down to stress caused by some conflict in their life, such as sexuality, with their religion rather than an illness." However, despite such progressive approaches, concern about exorcism remains high among mental health charities, health professionals and among senior Church figures. There are particular fears about charismatic Anglican groups that take a fundamentalist approach to demonic possession. "I saw a brother and sister who had been exorcised by a cousin from Scotland after their parents' funeral," said Mr Ryder. "He had heard them talking about transcendental meditation and believed this could have let evil spirits enter them. He exorcised them both but the girl had a particularly unpleasant reaction, retching and vomiting. They both felt they had been spiritually abused. "I believe if you shout out the names of spirits and demons to be powerful you create a response in the 'host' like in the film The Exorcist." Dr David McDonald, a psychiatrist who has advised the Church of England, said this "Bible-bashing approach" did not accept anything other than a spiritual cause to people's distress: "I have seen clients who were told they're possessed and an exorcism was performed but they felt no better. They believe they must be really evil if God can't help them, which can be terribly damaging." In a survey last year by the Mental Health Foundation, entitled Spirituality and mental health: voices and realities, several respondents said they had been damaged by exorcism. The charity warned that the notion of demonic possession could be extremely damaging when linked to people with a label of mental illness and "risked conflating notions of evil and ill health." Strategies for Living project coordinator at the MHF, Vicky Nicholls said: "One respondent from a Pentecostal background said a priest had placed their hands on them and said 'Let the demons be gone!' Most felt such practices had contributed to their mental health problems." The Rev Stephen Parsons, author of Ungodly Fear: Fundamentalist Christianity and the abuse of power, said: "The charismatic movement wants to demonise mental illness so they can deal with it through exorcism. They say the Lord has given them a special insight that science and medicine cannot offer. But persuading vulnerable people that they are possessed gives you a great deal of power over them. It's a form of emotional abuse." Mr Parsons said sexual abuse, homosexuality and unwanted pregnancy were often seen as routes for demonic possession. "Imagine telling someone who has been raped they're now possessed - that is terribly abusive." However, Dr Chris Simpson, consultant psychiatrist at Friarage Hospital, Northallerton, who has treated many people after receiving deliverance, believes exorcism does not in itself cause a great deal of mental illness. "The problem comes when a spiritual approach leads to a delay in receiving psychiatric help. If people bypass mental health services a lot of problems will be missed. So having the Church and the psychiatric profession work together when someone has a spiritual belief system can be beneficial."

fields.headline: War's mind field
fields.standfirst: Sarah Ebner on how the group Combat Stress helps the haunted soldiers whose wounds are hard to heal
fields.trailText: Sarah Ebner on how the group Combat Stress helps the haunted soldiers whose wounds are hard to heal.
fields.body:
It is almost 20 years since John shot the young Argentinian soldier but he can still see him, close up, in his mind's eye. "He was probably around my age. Afterwards I searched him and it turned out he wasn't armed. He didn't surrender, so I did my job. He could have had a pistol or a grenade. I didn't even consider whether he was armed or not. I just reacted to seeing him and I shot him."

John was 19 when he was sent to the Falklands. He had joined the Parachute Regiment two years earlier and had already had a tour of duty in Northern Ireland. But the Falklands came as a complete shock.

"I knew I was going to go to Northern Ireland, but I never thought I would ever go to war," he says. "It turned out to be very inhuman, very alien. War is not a glorious thing and anyone who makes out it is is a fool."

Now 38, John has spent the last 20 years trying to recover from his army experiences. Like soldiers in conflicts before, and after, the gruesome reality of killing people, seeing your friends - and even, as in John's case, your own brother - blown up or shot, was all too much for him. And for almost two decades, no one wanted to help.

Linda Winn, clinical director of Combat Stress, the ex-services mental welfare society, says John's experience is typical. "We help people aged from 19 to 95," she says. "As long as people are psychologically robust enough, we take them. People may think that shell shock or flashbacks are only suffered by veterans of the world wars. But that's not true. We have a lot of younger people coming through now, from the Gulf, the Balkans and Northern Ireland."

Combat Stress aims to help these men - and a few women - deal with their problems at its three residential centres in Surrey, Shropshire and Strathclyde. "The people who come here are suffering from psychological injuries resulting from their service experience," says Winn of the 2,000 or so people Combat Stress helps annually. "Quite often they're very angry and we try to give them a feeling of control. The sooner people can be referred, the more successful the treatment."

Last month, an extreme case of what can happen to someone who was not helped made its way into the news. George Daley, 80, an ex-Royal Artillery private from the second world war, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He had been woken from a deep sleep by fireworks and thought he had returned to the battlefields of North Africa. When his 85-year-old neighbour appeared, he was convinced she was the enemy breaking into his home and he stabbed her.

"Flashbacks can last for seconds or hours," says Winn. "And they can be triggered by so many things. They also have residual effects. Afterwards you feel disturbed and distraught.

"We have found that with ex-Far East prisoners of war, the flashbacks and nightmares are often so strong that they think people are talking to them in Japanese. Some attack their wives, thinking they are Japanese soldiers."

John, too, felt out of control. "When I returned from the Falklands, I wanted out of the army urgently," he says. "I never wanted to be put in that situation again and I left about a year afterwards." The memories, however, have remained.

"I've got no concept of time when it comes to the Falklands. It's all very blurred. I just know I left in April and came back in August. I get flashbacks and they're like a montage of events from Goose Green to Wireless Ridge, which were two weeks apart. I see them pretty much together. Goose Green was a bloody battle. It was very conventional. There was bayoneting and hand-to-hand combat. Trenches were being cleared."

John was in an alcoholic haze for years. He went from one job to another, but was often drunk, violent and extremely angry. He also began to abuse drugs. And he was not the only one of his former colleagues with problems.

"When we got back, there were no offers of help," he says. "The flashbacks were triggered by a variety of things, including news items and war films, but we got no psychological help. It was OK being with my mates, but I had real problems with other people. People thought they could pick your brains for a pint of lager. Then the first question was the most insensitive you can ask anyone who's just back from combat - if you killed anyone. That puts you in places you don't want to be. It can instantly set off a flashback."

John was violent and depressed. His behaviour even led to a three-month spell in prison for GBH. "I had no fear of anything. I wasn't scared of the police, of authority. Nothing. And of course I was suffering from awful nightmares and flashbacks.

"Times have changed too," he adds. "From world war two it seems like everybody was involved. After the war, your local bobby was also a veteran. He didn't arrest the drunken ex-soldier on the ground; he took him home and put him into bed. Nowadays there's no tolerance. I've got more in common with a pensioner who fought the Germans 60 years ago than I have with some of my own generation."

Eventually a friend told John to get help. "He was sure I had post traumatic stress disorder, but I said I was fine. He replied that nobody was safe walking down the street with me around."

John's doctor recommended a psychiatrist. That helped a little, but the treatment was stopped when the GP could no longer fund it. Finally, two years ago, John spoke to the war pensions agency, which recommended the residential courses run by Combat Stress (the agency funds 80% of the charity's costs).

"It's been pretty positive," John says. "You go on courses like anger and stress management and you feel they actually understand what you're going through. Gradually you become less angry and more at ease with yourself. You end up with a better understanding of your condition."

John is not "cured" in the sense that you can heal a physical ailment, but he has his problems more under control. "The flashbacks aren't as destructive now because I understand them better," he says. "I know what triggers to avoid - I don't go to the pub any more, for example - and, when they do happen, I know I'm not back in 1982. I realise it's 2001.

"I've talked to some of the old and bold from world war two and they still suffer but live with it. You've got to take what little positive there is. We've got an obligation to live a decent life for those who died - not just the British but also the Argentinians that some of us killed.

"It'd be too easy to go through life angry and cynical. My life didn't end when I was 19 and I don't want to be coming here in 30 years' time. There's a lot more to do out there."

 John's name has been changed.

webTitle: MagicButton becomes 212th dot bomb of the year

fields.headline: MagicButton becomes 212th dot bomb of the year
fields.trailText: MagicButton.net, a London based e-commerce technology provider, has become the 212th dot.com company to close its doors this year. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
MagicButton.net, a London based e-commerce technology provider, has become the 212th dot.com company to close its doors since the beginning of the year.

MagicButton, which was opened in 1999 and has offices in London and Germany, was forced into liquidation late last week.

The company's website was running as usual yesterday but, according to reports on netimperative.com, George Burdon, MagicButton's chief executive officer, said the firm had been forced into liquidation owing to "matters which we are unable to disclose".

No one at MagicButton was available to comment.

The news comes as webmergers.com, a San Francisco company, released a survey estimating at least 435 internet companies had folded since the beginning of last year. Nearly half of all the shutdowns from January 2000 have taken place in the last four months and the rate of companies failing accelerated last month, the company said.

At least 55 internet companies folded in April, making it the second "deadliest" month since January 200. In February there were 58 casualties, while in April last year "only one substantial dot.com folded", webmergers said.

The business-to-consumer sector was hardest hit, with 64% of closures coming from that area. That is slightly healthier than last year when 75% of dot.com failures were business-to-consumer companies.

E-commerce companies were most liable to failure in the past four months, accounting for 48% of the total, but the report also found internet access providers, online content sites and dot.com consultancies increasingly affected by the new-economy crash. Content sites made up 28% of casualties and access providers accounted for 10%.

The number and cost of mergers in the sector also fell: buyers spent almost $2.6bn to acquire 115 internet companies in April, compared with 143 acquisitions for $5bn in March.

webTitle: Italy is in the bag, crows Berlusconi

fields.headline: Italy is in the bag, crows Berlusconi
fields.standfirst: Foreign arrows bounce off election frontrunner
fields.trailText: A fresh assault on Silvio Berlusconi's integrity from a Spanish judge bounced off harmlessly yesterday as adoring supporters, writes Rory Carroll.
fields.body:
A fresh assault on Silvio Berlusconi's integrity from a Spanish judge bounced off harmlessly yesterday as adoring supporters roared approval at an election rally in Naples in defiance of international accusations that the centre-right opposition leader is a crook.

Mr Berlusconi regained the initiative and predicted triumph in the national election on May 13 as Italians apparently decided to ignore warnings from leading publications in London, Berlin, Paris and Madrid.

Political analysts said seven years of inconclusive trials involving corruption charges had made voters bored and cynical about allegations that the media tycoon has bribed judges, laundered money and cheated on tax.

It emerged yesterday that an investigating judge in Spain has formally asked Italy to lift Mr Berlusconi's parliamentary immunity to expedite an investigation into alleged tax fraud involving the Spanish television channel Tele 5, part-owned by Mr Berlusconi.

The request from Judge Baltasar Garzon was presented to the Italian foreign ministry last week, according to yesterday's edition of the Madrid newspaper El Mundo.

But more than 3,000 supporters who packed into the Santa Lucia theatre in Naples did not care and waved flags as the so-called Cavaliere strode on to the stage.

"The left has already understood that it will definitely lose," exulted Mr Berlusconi. Opinion polls at the weekend, the last that can be published under electoral laws, suggested he was correct.

His centre-right coalition was four percentage points ahead of the government and appeared to have northern Italy in its pocket despite its leader being roasted by the Economist, the International Herald Tribune, Le Monde, El Mundo and other prominent publications.

Pierluigi Battista, a political analyst with La Stampa, said a centre-right victory was almost assured. "They are 4-1 ahead with 15 minutes left to play."

The expressions of contempt in foreign publications "will definitely have some impact but it won't be decisive", said Claudio Lodici, a political scientist at the American University of Rome.

"Berlusconi is appealing to constituencies that are not very sensitive to opinions or objections in the European media." These included, he said, housewives, the elderly and the lower middle class.

The prime minister, Francesco Rutelli, 46, has run an energetic campaign but struggled to unite colleagues. To stand a chance the government must sweep the south. Mr Berlusconi says he would spend £6.5bn on its renaissance.

Since tumbling from power as prime minister in 1994, Mr Berlusconi, 64, has fought and won a public relations battle with investigating magistrates.

Three convictions - overturned on appeal - and four current cases are widely seen as evidence of a leftwing conspiracy. Even some leftwing commentators have wondered if the Cavaliere's European business rivals are planting some of the criticisms abroad.

Mr Berlusconi has been ramming home populist campaign themes: huge public work projects, lower taxes, less red tape, safer streets, 1.5m new jobs. Italy would accelerate from a laggard to a leader in Europe under a renewal inspired by Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, he has said.

Voters have not been told how he will rein in pensions and public spending to meet euro-zone rules.

fields.headline: Murdoch wins talks on Hughes
fields.trailText: General Motors and Hughes Electronics agreed to start takeover negotiations with Rupert Murdoch last night, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
General Motors, the car group, and Hughes Electronics, the largest US satellite broadcaster, agreed to start takeover negotiations with Rupert Murdoch last night in an announcement which brought fulfilment of the News Corp chief's global satellite ambitions much closer.

The decision reached by the GM board after a day-long meeting yesterday comes after eight months of tense negotiations between Mr Murdoch and the management of Hughes, which is controlled by GM.

Michael Smith, the chief executive of Hughes, had tried in vain to come up with a rival offer which matched that from News Corp, which wants to merge Hughes with Sky Global Networks, its own satellite operation.

GM returned to the discussion table after Mr Murdoch sweetened his original offer in a presentation to its executives last week. As part of the deal, News Corp shareholders would be left with 30% in the combined group rather than the 35% which it had originally asked for.

Shares in Hughes rose almost 4% to $22 yesterday, valuing the company at almost $20bn.

Mr Murdoch has said that the combined companies could be worth up to $50bn, although that was when both companies were trading at far higher multiples.

fields.headline: C4 defends digital investment
fields.standfirst: Channel 4 defends plans to invest more than £200m in digital TV and online services
fields.trailText: Channel 4 yesterday defended its plans to invest more than £200m in digital TV and online services, after the company's operating profit fell by more than a quarter.
fields.body:
Channel 4 yesterday defended its plans to invest more than £200m in digital TV and online services, after the company's operating profit fell by more than a quarter.

Michael Jackson, chief executive, said the broadcaster would continue to build investment in services such as E4 and FilmFour, even though it is hitting the bottom line. "If we weren't investing this money in new services, I think people would be asking questions."

Introducing Channel 4's an nual report and accounts for 2000, Mr Jackson said investment in these areas would rise to 10% of expenditure in 2001, from 4% last year. He pledged that it would not rise further.

Last week the former Channel 5 chief executive David Elstein described Channel 4 as a "runaway train" that wasted millions of pounds of taxpayers' money on excessive wages and perks. Mr Elstein, now a senior adviser at the management consultancy Arthur D Little, has often said the broadcaster should close the gap be tween its revenue and the main channel's programme budget. That gap rose by almost £50m to £293m last year.

The success of programmes such as Big Brother and Ali G helped push Channel 4's annual turnover to a record £716.4m, up 12% on 1999. The figures were boosted by increased revenue from advertising and sponsorship, coupled with strong ratings. Turnover on subsidiary interests such as FilmFour doubled to £8.8m.

Group operating profit fell to £33.8m, with £80m set aside for E4 and £60m for Film Four.

fields.headline: Plastic is fantastic for Perrier
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Nestle is launching Perrier in plastic bottles for the first time in an attempt to boost the brand, writes Julia Day.
27.03.2001: Nestle blasts 'inflated' TV prices
fields.body:
Perrier, the glass-bottled mineral water that was once the epitome of 80s yuppie cool, is being relaunched in plastic bottles.

Nestle is putting Perrier in plastic bottles for the first time in an attempt to turn around the fortunes of the troubled brand.

Perrier's image has never really recovered from a 1990 benzene contamination scare in the US, which was a PR disaster for the brand.

It had its first break-even year in 2000 after recording losses in every year since the disaster.

The plastic bottles are an attempt to make the brand attractive to people who eat and drink on the go. Glass bottles are not renowned for their portability.

The glass bottles have also limited the brand's appeal to the cafe and restaurant trade.

It is hoped the plastic bottle will appeal to young consumers who make impulse purchases in corner shops, fast food outlets and through vending machines.

A 50cl plastic bottle will be available in the UK in July.

The bottle retains the brand's famous green colour and is reminiscent of the original glass bottle's shape.

Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, based in Paris, is creating a £3.5m advertising campaign around the launch in July. Infoplan is masterminding a PR push.

The advertising will focus on the new bottle being "easily transportable" and "unbreakable".

webTitle: Tory peers angry over code for disclosure of interests

fields.headline: Tory peers angry over code for disclosure of interests
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Tory peers were angry last night after an all-party group recommended that all peers be required to disclose their relevant financial interests.
fields.body:
Tory peers were angry last night after an all-party group recommended that all peers be required to disclose their relevant financial interests.

The recommendations, which may include the acreage of landholdings and financial interests of friends, come from a group chaired by the attorney general Lord Williams.

The two Conservatives on the six strong group, Lord Elton and Lord Kingsland, protested that parts of the proposed code of conduct were "disproportionately intrusive, failing to strike an appropriate balance between what is legitimately made public, to reinforce public confidence, and what is legitimately private".

Critics claim the register will change the character of the upper house, where peers have been expected to act on their honour. But the Labour peer Lord Lipsey said: "What have the Tory peers got to hide ? The Tories' insistence that landholdings need not be declared gives the game away."

The present Lords register is voluntary and does not suggest that peers should reveal their fees as parliamentary lobbyists, a key proposal of the Williams group.

The proposals, including a code of conduct, follow recommendations of the Neill committee into standards of conduct in public life.

Peers will be required to register any parliamentary consultancy, including fee, employment as a parliamentary lobbyist, renumerated directorships, regular paid employment, shareholdings amounting to a controlling interest and provision of research assistance from an outside body.

Other disclosable interests may be shareholdings, landholdings and financial interests of a friend or relative.

The leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, said yesterday: "We feel if you have got a situation where local councillors and other members of public bodies are required to make a formal declaration of their interests, that it was something of an anomaly that the House of Lords code was voluntary."

Lord Williams suggested that on issues such as leasehold reform and the right to roam, there was a strong case for peers disclosing their landholdings. He said: "I would expect people to put acreage down. These things are not deep secrets".

Defending the suggestion that peers reveal the relevant financial interests of friends, Lord Williams said: "If you had a close friend who had a vast shareholding or a vast interest, most people would regard that as relevant when you spoke.

"If you had someone who owned an enormous chunk of an oilfield, and you had a close relationship with him, would it not be reasonable for the public to know about this? It is not a witchhunt. It is just dispelling clouds of potential suspicion."

He added that peers would be allowed to disclose the amount they were paid from employment irrelevant to their parliamentary work.

Lord Williams rejected suggestions that the sub-committee which would police the code would become "an informal Gestapo".

He pointed out that peers could exercise considerable influence and had access to ministers. Lady Jay stressed that the register would be enforced by peers themselves and no independent investigator would be appointed equivalent to the controversial parliamentary commissioner for standards in the Commons. She added that no peer would have breached the rules so long as they had acted on the advice of the register.

Peers do not receive a salary but can claim expenses and an attendance allowance.

Lady Jay said it would be good if the new code was introduced soon after the peers returned following the general election.

Lord Kingsland warned that "a habit of mutual denunciation is emerging, in which suspicion is cast on all outside interests and the dignity of the Commons is correspondingly undermined".

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • This year it would be a nice change if liberals and sneerers stopped moaning about heavy-handed May Day policing. It just isn't so, as Sean Dromgoole rings to point out. On Tuesday morning, the marketing consultant was in the middle of his weekly coach ride to London from Ilchester when a friend rang panicking that the new Mangiare restaurant he was opening in central London yesterday might get looted. Sean jokily suggested getting people in Mangiare T-shirts to hand out pizza to the protesters, because "if you're feeding them, they won't smash the shop up".
fields.body:
 This year it would be a nice change if liberals and sneerers stopped moaning about heavy-handed May Day policing. It just isn't so, as Sean Dromgoole rings to point out. On Tuesday morning, the marketing consultant was in the middle of his weekly coach ride to London from Ilchester when a friend rang panicking that the new Mangiare restaurant he was opening in central London yesterday might get looted. Sean jokily suggested getting people in Mangiare T-shirts to hand out pizza to the protesters, because "if you're feeding them, they won't smash the shop up".

Had he noticed the weaselly Scottish woman leaving the seat behind him to sneak off to the loo, mobile in hand, he might have been less startled when the coach was boarded on arrival in London by two PCs shouting "where's number 64? Where's number 64?" Sean was marched off the bus to find a third copper in plain clothes videoing him as he was lengthily questioned about alleged anarchist involvement until eventually being released. Well done the Met for a lesson in husbanding stretched resources and good old-fashioned common sense!

 The transcript of Stupidest MP frontrunner David Lock's attempts to bully the Midlands free sheet For You has arrived, and splendid it is. For now, though, while we try to persuade the junior minister to enter a residential anger management course under Diary supervision, we are holding it back. If he refuses, however, gems such as "I am a barrister and I'm going to show you the full force of the law" will feature tomorrow.

 The faux naif prattling of Lord Taylor (for God's sake, what kind of party did the man think he was joining?) makes us wonder if, as a one-time Tory candidate himself, he ever read the Tory Reform Group's Leadership for the Nation: Selecting Conservative Parliamentary Candidates. This relates that the weekend selection course all candidates must pass is "modelled on the British army's officer selection course as it was in 1978... itself lifted from the Nazi party which devised the original concept in the 1930's as a method of selecting its cadres". So Mr Townend and his mates were pretty much personally chosen by Hitler. Now let that be an end to it.

 Thanks to Sandy Ross, the MD of Scottish Television, for background on the picture of Robin Cook on a horse. Sandy was Cookie's agent when he stood for the safe Tory seat of Edinburgh North held by the then Earl of Dalkeith (later Duke of Buccleuch), and the stunt was devised to satirise the then Earl's preference for riding to hounds over addressing the problem of appalling tenements. "The woman (Miss Elizabeth Hop) was MP George Foulkes' girlfriend," Sandy writes, "and is now George's wife and the Labour provost of Ayr. The Earl of Dalkeith won handsomely. Robin became obsessed with horses. Robin went on to win Edinburgh central in 1974." And the rest is Turncoat history.

 At the DETR, security guards have refused environment minister Michael Meacher entry because he didn't have his pass. They should watch themselves with him next time. If Michael gets really cross, he'll buy the building and turn it into 128 luxury self-contained flats.

 Surveillance: Boris the Jackal Johnson, subject of yesterday's surveillance for heckling Mr Tony during the Trafalgar Square concert, at the pre-concert reception in South Africa House for anti-apartheid campaigners, loudly assuring all he met "I am a total impostor". Was this the beginning of a cunning campaign to usurp Polly Portillo as new pin-up boy of the Tory centre-left? If so, let us hope gatecrashing South Africa was an end to it, and that there is nothing in rumours that a tall blond man with a peroxide floor mop on his head, shouting "cripes gadzooks, strike me pink!", was nicked near Oxford Street yesterday while offering pizza to undercover cops.

fields.headline: Defying the blue rinse brigade
fields.trailText: I arrived at the Commons yesterday expecting to find the place surrounded by furious crowds. They were outnumbered by photographers, who in turn were outnumbered by the police.
fields.body:
I arrived at the Commons yesterday expecting to find the place surrounded by furious crowds. A demonstration was supposed to start at 11am. By 11.15 fully four protesters had turned up in Parliament Square, including a man with blue hair. They were outnumbered by photographers, who in turn were outnumbered by the police.

It seems symbolic of something or other that nobody thought that MPs were worth protesting at. Instead the demonstrators were gathered round stores. In the past we young people hated home secretaries and ministers of defence. This lot hate coffee shops.

One banner, several miles from the nearest politician, read: "Overthrow capitalism and replace it with something nicer." If you think that's vague and unhelpful, you should have been in the Commons yesterday. The message there seemed to be "Overthrow this government and replace it with something much the same."

That's almost exactly what Robin Cook said when his opposite number, Francis Maude, accused him of failing to support George Bush's missile defence scheme. "Is the foreign secretary trying to curry favour with CND types who are opposed to it?" he snarled.

The Tories still live in hope that soon some of Mr Blair's cabinet will reveal themselves to be red-fanged lefties, taking their orders from Moscow. It's rather sweet.

Mr Cook replied with his snort, which may derive from his interest in horse racing. "If that is the best you can do, then it really is time to clear the air by consulting the wider public in an election!" he harumphed.

He was in a highly contemptuous mood all round. For months now, poor Michael Fabricant has been trying to turn himself into a world statesman. He might even be shadow foreign secretary in June, if the Tories are reduced to six seats.

Mickey asked when Mr Cook would next meet the new US secretary of state, Colin Powell. "I regularly speak to him by phone," he said, with immense grandeur, "most recently, yesterday evening."

Mickey launched into a long disquisition on US-European relations, with lengthy quotes from somebody called Zeidelman. Cook decided to squash him. He had to confess that he had lost interest half-way through. And he wondered what right Mickey had to upstage the president of the United States?

Nonsense of course; Mickey was guilty of nothing more than ineffectual grandstanding. Most of us, however, were eagerly listening to the Cook voice. This week he has been accused of lowering it because he is hurt by the squeaky impression Rory Bremner does of him.

Indeed he sounded very gruff yesterday. But he usually does. His voice only goes up to the top of the register when he's excited or cross. Yesterday he said: "On the question ..." (high pitched voice), and suddenly rephrased it as "on the question of the Commonwealth ..." (deeper, rumbling noise). But I don't think his line, "we have been up and down this particular red herring many times" would make a lot of sense at any voice level.

I left the chamber to find a press release from Laurence Robertson, the Tory MP who backed John Townend's remarks on race and who was yesterday forced to recant.

I don't like Mr Robertson's views one bit, but I must say his grovelling confession reads like a Chinese show trial during the cultural revolution. "I undertake to cause no further embarrassment to the party, nor to give further offence to others, nor will I repeat my remarks under any circumstances."

In other words, "overthrow me and replace me with someone nicer!".

fields.headline: Working out of the spotlight
fields.standfirst: He may not get the media attention of Ken Livingstone, but the chief executive of the Greater London Authority, Anthony Mayer, could be the man to sort out the capital's housing crisis. Julian Blake reports
fields.trailText: He may not get the media attention of Ken Livingstone, but the chief executive of the Greater London Authority, Anthony Mayer, could be the man to sort out the capital's housing crisis. Julian Blake reports
fields.body:
A year ago, when London mayor Ken Livingstone first walked into the Greater London Authority's (GLA) home at Romney House, he had to push through a media scrum just to get to the door. The TV cameras and reporters have been trailing him ever since.

There must be times when the mayor of London sits back and wishes he had the seemingly magical ability of his chief executive, Anthony Mayer, to avoid the spotlight.

Mr Mayer, 54-year-old ex-banker and nine-year boss of the Housing Corporation, took up his job six months ago, with a brief to turn a fairly skeletal GLA organisation into a fully functional bureaucracy.

The low profile is not all that surprising, says Mr Mayer, given the mayor's huge personal profile and that of Bob Kiley, head of Transport for London. Mr Kiley is technically Mr Mayer's junior at the new authority, although you would never guess from their pay packets. Mr Mayer's £135,000 is relatively modest in comparison with the New Yorker's salary of up to £500,000.

"I know my place in this regime and I'm very happy with that," Mr Mayer says, humbly. "My profile is a function of the fact we have a very charismatic mayor who properly should be the voice of London."

At the corporation, Mr Mayer enjoyed a much higher public profile. He was in charge of an organisation responsible for delivering a revolution in English social housing by establishing a new system of mixed public-private funding for registered social landlords.

That saw more than £15bn of private money delivered for social housing provision - a successful public-private partnership if ever there was one. Unlike Mr Kiley, Mr Mayer faced not a single judicial review.

An ebullient character, Mr Mayer's presence injected a charisma largely absent from a housing sector that has long suffered from a penpushing image.

Not that Mr Mayer has lost any of his interest in housing. He has already managed to get himself into hot water by suggesting that the GLA - not currently a housing provider or funder - could take over some of the corporation's housing functions.

The sense of an impending turf war has been compounded by the work of Mr Livingstone's independent housing commission, set up to look at the homes crisis facing many Londoners, and by the authority's work on a new "spatial development" strategy. That strategy, essentially a planning tool with legal force, aims to set out the priorities and direction for the future development of London.

Mr Mayer is quite clear that he sees the GLA's scrutiny of housing as critical: "There are now profound housing access problems and, if we don't sort those out, you are going to have a serious problem with getting the workforce necessary to operate the London economy."

"That is a London-wide problem, not a borough problem," adds Mr Mayer. "The GLA as a strategic London-wide authority is very, very well-placed to take that new housing agenda forward. The fact that the GLA is not a strategic housing authority in terms of providing housing is actually neither here nor there."

But local authorities are taking on a more enabling role - helping others to provide housing rather than providing it themselves. Wouldn't it be logical for the GLA to take that function over from local government?

"London boroughs by definition can only be strategic about things within their boundaries," Mr Mayer agrees. "But there's also - and I think this is what the GLA is interested in, increasingly now - the need for a London-wide housing strategy."

Since April, the GLA, on the recommendation of Mr Livingstone's commission, has been overseeing a new London housing forum - a big tent bringing in representatives from, among others, the borough umbrella group, the Association of the London Government, the Housing Corporation and the London Housing Federation. The aims of the forum, which will meet regularly, are two-fold. One is to monitor all London housing trends, the other to start work towards translating that information into a strategy.

"We're taking the lead in information on the supply of the housing land and opportunity across London, and the data management department will be taking the lead in the London analysis of the 2001 census," says Mr Mayer. "So we can be a genuine knowledge organisation. The mayor is the person who speaks for London. In terms of making sure that London gets its fair share of housing investment, who better anywhere in Europe than the mayor?

"In terms of development of overall London housing strategy, well it can't be the boroughs. They do borough work. It can't really be the Housing Corporation in terms of mixing and melding the supply of housing and demand for housing because they in turn rely on borough strategies. We've got a good opportunity for it to be us."

"If you then want to move on and say the major allocation decisions for housing investment should be in these areas, I can see the GLA having a role if people want it to have a role. But at the moment, we're only 400 strong, and we haven't got a computer system that basically would enable us to receive monies from government and then make allocation decisions."

Mr Mayer is well aware of the ripples his comments have provoked, and of the suspicions about empire-building thrown up by the creation of the forum. So he adds in a caveat: "Where the GLA has to fit in is into the gaps. We've got to bring added value."

The GLA may indeed have no hidden agenda or designs on the work of the many other agencies controlling housing in the capital. But there is no denying the logic that London needs to take a more strategic view of its housing. If the GLA's role does expand, Mr Mayer is the right man to take it on.

In terms of making sure that London gets its fair share of housing investment, who better anywhere in Europe than the mayor? "In terms of development of overall London housing strategy, well it can't be the boroughs. They do borough work. It can't really be the Housing Corporation in terms of mixing and melding the supply of housing and demand for housing because they in turn rely on borough strategies. We've got a good opportunity for it to be us." "If you then want to move on and say the major allocation decisions for housing investment should be in these areas, I can see the GLA having a role if people want it to have a role. But at the moment, we're only 400 strong, and we haven't got a computer system that basically would enable us to receive monies from government and then make allocation decisions." Mr Mayer is well aware of the ripples his comments have provoked, and of the suspicions about empire-building thrown up by the creation of the forum. So he adds in a caveat: "Where the GLA has to fit in is into the gaps. We've got to bring added value." The GLA may indeed have no hidden agenda or designs on the work of the many other agencies controlling housing in the capital. But there is no denying the logic that London needs to take a more strategic view of its housing. If the GLA's role does expand, Mr Mayer is the right man to take it on.

webTitle: Back to front from the centre

fields.headline: Back to front from the centre
fields.standfirst: The government has made moves to allocate more powers to the public sector, but no other country is quite so centralised
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Will a second term Labour government be as centralist as the first? There were conflicting signals from the top last week.
fields.body:
Will a second term Labour government be as centralist as the first? There were conflicting signals from the top last week. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, signalled a radical devolution in the NHS. But the prime minister, in a speech billed as helping councils raise the quality of life, merely promised to let them keep the proceeds from fines for dropping litter or letting dogs foul pavements.

First the good news. Alan Milburn sounded like a true convert. He returned again and again to the need to shift money and decision-taking from the centre to the frontline if the 10-year health plan is to work.

This was the same Alan Milburn who, only a year ago, was promising personally to sack under-performing managers and send in hit squads to under-performing units, and who had so little faith in NHS staff that he took special powers to "direct" where the extra £600m allocated to health in the budget should be spent.

Now he speaks of staff feeling "disempowered or, worse, disillusioned", of creeping centralisation that had crowded out local innovation, of frontline staff needing to be "the architects of public service reform" if they are to be its ambassadors. Every hospital, health centre and GP surgery should get a copy of the speech and frame its many key devolution quotes.

The prime minister was more disappointing. He has never tried to hide his many criticisms of local councils. Indeed, he set them out in a pamphlet - the first on local councils by a serving prime minister - accusing them of inconsistent standards, poor decision making processes, low turn-outs. But last week was billed as something different.

Blair began on the same theme as Milburn: the need for local people and local government to be in the vanguard. But what he was talking about were clean streets and public spaces. He went on: "These issues may strike some as trivial but they are anything but trivial. They matter to people."

True. But the people are also concerned about central controls. Labour abolished capping and compulsory competitive tendering (CCT). Yet selective capping powers remain, as does the right to withdraw subsidies from excessive spenders. Business rates, nationalised in 1990, still go to the treasury. All that was on offer was a supplementary business rate on a voluntary basis.

No other country is quite so centralised. Local councils now raise only 20% of their spending. Adding in national services (police, health, benefits) shows why 96% of tax is centrally raised. Certainly high minimum standards, to avoid post-code variations, are needed. But let's leave room for some divergence.

fields.headline: Wiped out
fields.standfirst: Activist's anti-charity website blocked
fields.trailText: Activist's anti-charity website blocked.
fields.body:
A disability rights activist who ran a website criticising a leading charity has relinquished the domain name www.leonard-cheshire.com, after a ruling by the World Intellectual Property Organisation (Wipo).

After lengthy investigation of a complaint by charity Leonard Cheshire, a Wipo panel - appointed by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers - has come down in the charity's favour. The panel says the site is confusingly similar to the organisation's trademark; that the activist, Paul Darke, has no right or legitimate interest in the domain name; and that it has been registered and used by him in bad faith.

The site, which opens with the slogan "Say No to Leonard Cheshire", was described by Darke in his written response to the panel as "a work of political interventionist art" and an act of political freedom of expression. He argued that the site was "clearly anti-Leonard Cheshire", stating that he used the name "as a valid way to draw attention to criticisms of the organisation".

Darke, who has spina bifida and uses a wheelchair, is a conceptual artist who did a PhD on the stereotyping of disability on celluloid. In a recent work, Health, he shows three wheelchairs nailed to three crosses. He founded www.outside-centre.com, which shows work by disabled artists.

He registered the contested domain name last autumn, shortly before the end of a two-year contract as the charity's national advocacy officer. He also served on the charity's public affairs committee, from which he resigned. He subsequently offered to sell the name to the charity for £40,000 to fund a holocaust memorial to disabled people.

Darke advocates for disabled people who want to secure funding to live independently and not in institutions. He claims Leonard Cheshire institutionalises those with disabilities. He admitted to the panel that his site was intended to damage the charity, disrupt its interests and raise questions about funds it received from the national lottery. The site has had 51,000 "hits" since launching last October.

"The site is about the Leonard Cheshire Foundation, and all that it represents socially, politically and economically in the lives of disabled people," he said. "Thus, the domain name... As for damaging Leonard Cheshire Foundation, that is the aim of the site as an act of political art in a free society."

A spokeswoman for the charity says: "Leonard Cheshire respects Dr Darke's right to criticise the organisation and offered to pay the administration charge for him to move the site to another address. Sadly, he would not agree and we have challenged that registration by submitting a complaint to an arbitration centre. We were forced to take action as the site was becoming more misleading, inaccurate and increasingly unpleasant towards individuals."

The address leonard-cheshire.com will now house the site of the Friends of Leonard Cheshire in Washington, US, which works on behalf of disabled people throughout the Americas.

webTitle: Anti-social behaviour: Signs of the times

fields.headline: Signs of the times
fields.standfirst: It's intolerable when people who seem beyond the law terrorise a neighbourhood, but how can you stop them?  Helen Carter on the effects of anti-social behaviour orders
fields.trailText: It's intolerable when people who seem beyond the law terrorise a neighbourhood, but how can you stop them? Helen Carter on the effects of anti-social behaviour orders
fields.body:
Half a mile from Manchester's thriving city centre, where flats sell for hundreds of thousands of pounds, is the urban wasteland of the Beswick estate. It was here in late 1999 that Sean, Joseph and Michael McCann - when they were 16, 15 and 13 - became subjects of one of the government's first anti-social behaviour orders.

The McCanns' home has since been bulldozed, but other impoverished terrace houses and flats remain - some lived in, some burnt out. Security cameras monitor residents' every move and a walkway has been boarded up by the council in an effort to prevent crime. This area of east Manchester has been described by Brian Robson, director of Manchester University's urban policy studies centre, as "land of the forgotten".

Anti-social behaviour orders (Asbos) were introduced by the government in April 1999 as a flagship of home secretary Jack Straw's law and order programme. Local authorities and chief police officers, acting in consultation, may apply to a magistrates' court for what is in effect a banning order, protecting the community from a named individual alleged to cause harassment, alarm or distress to others.

The order, issued under the 1998 Crime and Disorder Act, involves civil proceedings, with a case needing to be proved only according to the rules of civil evidence; the burden of proof is less than demanded by criminal cases. Hearsay evidence is acceptable, as it is so difficult to persuade witnesses to appear. Yet a breach of an order is a criminal offence, the penalty for which may be anything up to a five-year jail sentence.

Gillian Crossley, the McCanns' solicitor, argues that Asbos should have been set wholly within the criminal justice context. Indeed, she is taking the case to appeal on this point. "I do not think it was a very well thought through piece of legislation," she says. "It is silent on standards of proof and I think it was naive to consider that these orders would be dealt with by duty solicitors in a five-minute hearing."

"By their very nature, they are not dealing with nice, compliant and friendly people with respect for authority. They are dealing with people with an inbred distrust of authority who are more likely to say no than yes".

The order against the McCanns has anyway proved counter-productive, Crossley claims. "To some people, they achieved enormous notoriety and gained hero status, and to the ordinary population they were seen as the scum of the earth," she says. "The family was marginalised and the order caused more trouble for them."

The family, one generation removed from travellers, has been divided by the order, she says. Forced to move away, the boys have been unable to maintain links with relatives who still live in Beswick.

Debate over the rights and wrongs of Asbos has been inflamed by an allegation by Straw that solicitors who challenge the orders are out to make money. He told a conference: "Very aggressive defence lawyers sometimes forget about their wider social responsibilities and their responsibilities to the court, and, in trying to protect their niche markets with the local criminal fraternity, act in a way which would have been unacceptable when I was practising [as a barrister] 25 years ago."

Crossley says she does not understand the basis for the minister's outburst. More important, she contends, is that Asbos have made no difference to the crime rate in Beswick. Superintendent Dave Thompson, of Grey Mare Lane police station in the heart of the estate, disagrees profoundly. He says that since the orders were introduced, crime has fallen by a third and burglaries by half.

Takings at the local supermarket increased £14,000 a week when the boys were banned, says Thompson. "At the time when we obtained the order, there was a feeling that anything went round here," he says. "A lot of people had lost confidence in the police and there was a perception that they [the McCanns] were untouchable. The three boys caused an enormous amount of problems for local people and committed a range of anti-social behaviour. And because residents were so scared of them, they were not willing to go to court."

In the McCanns' case, there was no mediation and no attempt to sort out their problems prior to use of the Asbo. Since then, however, there has been a subtle change and orders are now regarded locally as a last resort for dealing with similar cases. Thompson says: "We don't just want to beat them over the head with the orders; we're trying to explore the support systems that can be kicked in."

Frank Whiteley, of the Association of Chief Police Officers, reckons Asbos have been relatively successful, but concedes that there have been teething troubles. He says the association believes the orders are not a single answer to anti-social behaviour, but part of a bigger tool kit.

"We have never looked at Asbos on their own," Whiteley says. "But we have looked at the wider strategies and we have had some good successes." Orders can be used as part of an inter-agency approach involving mediation, injunctions and bail, but by themselves they are not a complete solution. "We are cautiously optimistic about their success so far."

The Home Office acknowledges that take-up of Asbos has varied across the country. More than 160 orders have been issued, including at least 50 against under-18s, but figures range from 18 in London and 15 in the West Midlands to just one each in Thames Valley, Leicestershire and south Wales. "There is some anecdotal evidence that the threat of an Asbo is often sufficient," says a spokeswoman. "We should not just judge it as a policy by numbers."

Ten years as an outcast

A 15-year-old Manchester youth last week received what is believed to be the longest anti-social behaviour order so far issued. Billy Kelly will be unable to enter the Fallowfield district, in the south of the city, for 10 years.

Manchester magistrates imposed the order after hearing that Kelly threatened staff of the city council's housing department when his family was being evicted. He was said to have told a police officer: "I'm going to come back and terrorise Fallowfield."

Kelly is currently finishing a six-month detention order for threatening to firebomb a neighbour. He is expected to be released next month and to live in Sale, Greater Manchester. Magistrates were told that he was involved in incidents dating from October 1998, including shoplifting, taking cars - one of which was involved in a police pursuit - and stealing a charity box. He is thought to have been involved in a gang, two other members of which were already subjects of Asbos.

Kelly, whose application to be allowed into the exclusion zone to visit his father was turned down, is also banned from entering part of the Rusholme district.

Basil Curley, Manchester council's executive member for housing, says: "We asked for a 10-year ban and we think it is fitting because there is no reason why this man should enter Fallowfield. It is also an indication to others who are contemplating creating havoc."

fields.bylineHtml: Helen Carter and John James

fields.headline: Doing a grown-up job
fields.standfirst: Study reveals the problems behind recruiting childminders
fields.trailText: Study reveals the problems behind recruiting childminders.
fields.body:
The government has recognised the crucial role of childminders by putting them at the heart of its national childcare strategy. But research published today indicates the scale of the challenge in their recruitment and retention.

Official statistics show that the number of registered childminders in England fell almost 30% from 106,000 in 1992 to 76,000 last year. The new study, Who Cares? - Childminding in the 1990s, points to low pay, poor status of the job, an increase in regulation, lack of support from local authorities, demographic change and the growing availability of more flexible working hours in alternative employment.

Researchers surveyed a sample of 1,050 childminders in eight English local authorities in January 1999. They also interviewed 10 new, 10 established and 10 former childminders from a city and a suburban English authority in 2000. Parents using the 20 active childminders were also interviewed.

The study, conducted by the Thomas Coram Research Unit at London University's Institute of Education and funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, concludes that childminders are the main providers of formal childcare - accounting for some 25% of all children receiving non-parental care. The majority are women with young children of their own and a partner in full-time employment.

A lack of any career progression and an expectation that the job will not be recognised in the wider labour market were found to be deterrents to working as a childminder. And the work can be uncertain. When care arrangements change, or end, childminders may have no idea when they will find new clients. As one interviewee said: "I wish the general public would recognise that childminding is a proper job."

Childminders were found to work an average 34 hours a week, with one in three doing more than 41. The average weekly income was £103. Half had vacancies for children and many reported difficulty filling places.

Despite all this, interviewees expressed a high level of job satisfaction. The ability to combine paid work with being at home was seen as the main advantage. More than half wanted to continue childminding.

The researchers warn that low levels of training and pay, and devaluation of the work, are making childminding unsustainable. "This government has realised the value of childminding, but in wider society childminding is seen as something women do for 'pin money'," says Ann Mooney, a researcher at the Thomas Coram research unit and co-author of the study. "This is not how the women interviewed saw it. Most said the money earned from childminding was essential to their household income and the majority said that they would have to look for other work if they weren't childminding."

Mooney acknowledges that new government initiatives have addressed some of the reasons for the decline in childminders. "Never theless," she says, "there are still underlying difficulties around status and working conditions. For childcare workers, it is a professional job."

Gill Haynes, chief executive of the National Childminding Association and a member of the research project's steering group, says the organisation alerted the government to the decline in the number of childminders more than two years ago. Introduction of start-up grants of £300-£600, and early years development and childcare partnerships which provide support and advice to childminders, have created a "dramatic" rise in the organisation's membership. "It has finally been recognised that childminders are self-employed and that we've got an army of female entrepeneurs out there," she says.

Haynes also welcomes new national standards which, from September, will replace all current local authority guidelines and will require newly registered childminders to attend a recognised introductory course within six months of starting work. The course will count as the first unit of a nationally accredited qualification. And, from the autumn, schools inspectorate Ofsted will extend its remit to childminders. "For the first time, standards will focus on how effectively childminders are providing care," Haynes says. "They will be treated as experts rather than gifted amateurs."

The association admits recruitment and retention are still problems. "Local authorities have been poor at recognising the value of what childminders do. Many are looking after children with special needs and still being paid £2.50 an hour. An authority should at least pay the minimum wage rather than exploit their goodwill and expertise."

 Who Cares? - Childminding in the 1990s is available at £13.95 plus £2 p&p from York Publishing Services, 64 Hallfield Road, York YO31 7ZQ (01904-430033). A summary is available at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation website.

Haynes also welcomes new national standards which, from September, will replace all current local authority guidelines and will require newly registered childminders to attend a recognised introductory course within six months of starting work. The course will count as the first unit of a nationally accredited qualification. And, from the autumn, schools inspectorate Ofsted will extend its remit to childminders. "For the first time, standards will focus on how effectively childminders are providing care," Haynes says. "They will be treated as experts rather than gifted amateurs." The association admits recruitment and retention are still problems. "Local authorities have been poor at recognising the value of what childminders do. Many are looking after children with special needs and still being paid £2.50 an hour. An authority should at least pay the minimum wage rather than exploit their goodwill and expertise."  Who Cares? - Childminding in the 1990s is available at £13.95 plus £2 p&p from York Publishing Services, 64 Hallfield Road, York YO31 7ZQ (01904-430033). A summary is available at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation website.

fields.headline: Steering ahead
fields.standfirst: Brian O'Hagan on the London governance project that is helping a group of small charities to plan their big picture
fields.trailText: Brian O'Hagan on the London governance project that is helping a group of small charities to plan their big picture.
fields.body:
The average charity is small, under-resourced and surviving on an income of about £1,000 a year. Organisations of this kind can be forgiven for concentrating on the day-to-day needs of their clients, rather than on a longer-term vision of what they are trying to achieve.

However, a project being piloted in London is working with 20 small voluntary groups with the aim of developing their capacity for organisational development and governance - the process by which trustees focus on overall ideals and vision.

Appropriately named the "governance project", this venture is the brainchild of a number of groups, including the City Parochial Foundation, the London Borough Grants Committee, the National Council of Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) and Voluntary Action Camden, which is overseeing the scheme.

The project is led by Kevin Nunan, formerly trustee development officer at the NCVO and a specialist in this field. He has a simple, yet effective, analogy for the key points of governance and its importance in organisational development. "The origins of the word governance comes from the Latin word to steer, a mariners' term for directing their ships at sea," he says. "It is also related to the word for helmsman, another seafaring term that is aptly suited to the role of the trustees in charting a course for their organisations."

Chosen from four London boroughs, the charities involved in the project are diverse in their needs and the fields they work in. One, Merton Community Transport, is hoping to improve the way its board of trustees works together; another, the Detainees Support and Help Unit, wants to strengthen the skills base of its trustees who currently rely on the founder, Comfort Afolabi, for direction and leadership.

"Our trustees are very active and supportive but a lot of the work falls on my shoulders," says Afolabi. "If we could undertake training for the management committee, then we would be better placed to serve our clients."

One of the groups involved in the project is struggling to remain independent of its local council, which not only exerts considerable influence on the management committee but is also the main source of funds. Developing skills in fundraising is therefore a key priority.

"We have to remain independent of the borough," says the charity's director, who wishes to remain anonymous. "They want us to merge with another group, but our members feel happier talking to us. They know us and feel that we understand them. Surely their needs are the most important consideration."

The criteria for participant organ isations is that they have been established for charitable or not-for-profit purposes; that they are small, but comprise at least four individuals; and that they agree to co-operate in follow-up evaluation. In return, each benefits from the support of its local council of voluntary service development worker; from the involvement of Nunan, who works with the groups to identify their needs and how best to progress; and from a £1,500 grant for training and development.

"The first thing we ask organisations to do is sit down with one another and discuss where they think they should be," Nunan says. "It doesn't necessarily matter how productive these discussions are. It is learning how to communicate with one another that will bring results. Then, once organisations have agreed where they want to go, or have identified what issues they need to address if a destination cannot be agreed on we can begin looking at the best ways to move forward."

Although groups participating on the project are first and foremost interested in furthering their work, there is a growing recognition that the right financial, administrative and management systems are necessary prerequisites for success. Funders in particular are more likely to support smaller groups when they see these key elements working effectively.

Dave Hobday, small groups worker at Merton voluntary service council, says: "One of the successes of the project so far is that the groups we are working with actually recognise the need for good governance. Thinking 'outside' of their organisations, and taking into account the needs of users, funders and other stakeholders is vital if they want to progress and develop their work."

The governance project will complete its pilot year next month, followed by a period of monitoring and evaluation. Funds permitting, the project may well expand its service to small charities and voluntary groups both in London and further afield.

"In the long run it would be good if funders and ourselves could refer groups to the governance project," Hobday says. "It may well prove an opportunity for funders in particular, who could refer groups they were unsure of to the project as a precondition for awarding a grant."

fields.headline: Haven and hell
fields.standfirst: Twenty-four years after  Peter White fostered a 10-year-old girl, they confront each other on radio to talk about how things went wrong - and might still be righted
fields.trailText: Twenty-four years after Peter White fostered a 10-year-old girl, they confront each other on radio to talk about how things went wrong - and might still be righted.
fields.body:
My wife and I fostered Fiona when she was 10, and when we already had three children of our own of five and under. With neither of us yet out of our 20s, maybe we didn't know what we were doing. And, thinking back, we were given little information on which to base the decision.

We knew Fiona had lived in a children's home for several years, that she had two natural brothers and that her mother had died when she was still a baby. What we didn't know until much later was that she had had 14 foster homes by the time she was three, and that attempts to establish a relationship between her remarried father and his three children had been messy and unsuccessful.

Knowing some of this might have prepared us better for the unnaturally good little girl who came to live with us, and the very angry teenager who left us abruptly five years later.

Why did we do it? I'm not sure, although I know the story we told ourselves and the social workers who interviewed us, and who were so keenly interested in "motivation". We had both been sent to boarding schools - I because I was blind and that's what they did to blind kids in the 50s; my wife, Jo, because her Catholic family was run by four devout maiden aunts who didn't believe that Jo's convert mum was capable of bringing them up properly. We were both angry about our childhoods and, equating children's home with boarding schools, thought vaguely that we could stop the same thing happening to somebody else. On such half-baked notions are crucial life decisions based.

Unusually, my blindness didn't seem to play much part in the decision about whether we would make suitable foster parents. I say unusually because at the time, and almost certainly still, there are as many stereotypical ideas in social services about the capacities of disabled people as anywhere else. I suspect that in my case the minor celebrity factor counteracted the disability factor: I was a local radio presenter.

For her first three months with us, Fiona was ridiculously good. Her explanation now is simple. "I was scared of being sent back," she says. "What most of us wanted in the home was a real family which cared about us." But, unknown to us, the little angel at home was raising merry hell at school and in the neighbourhood. When reports started filtering back of bullying, bad language and rebelliousness, we were genuinely disbelieving. "Not Fiona," we said. For a while, we convinced ourselves that because Fiona had suddenly fetched up in our locally well-known family, she was being picked on - by teachers as well as classmates and their parents - for the usual reason that she was different. I'm still sure this was an element in it, but we were soon to discover that Fiona was not playing by the rules of our nice, if a little unconventional, middle-class family and that she believed she was in a fight which she was damn well going to win.

But this is far from the whole picture. True, when the honeymoon period ended, Fiona vented her spleen on us too. But the Fiona I got to know over the next five years was also affectionate, generous, spontaneous, articulate and increasingly self-sufficient. She was fiercely protective of our other children - rather too fiercely sometimes - and once she settled she was prepared to have a go at anything, joining the local army training corps, the swimming club and getting her own part-time job at 13. But underlying all this - and although I think she grew genuinely fond of us - she was as angry with us as she was with everyone else.

Why? Well, I think I understand that a little better since we've been virtually forced to talk to each other about it in the making of a radio programme. What has emerged from Fiona's side is her sense of having a lack of space, almost of suffocation. As a family, we are intensely communicative. People are always being asked how they feel, what they want, what they think. Coming from a children's home, where the only choice was like it or lump it, Fiona was just not prepared for this. She says now that her worst nightmares were our family meetings, where the children were asked about their views on everything from the colour of their wallpaper to where they wanted to go on holiday. Throughout these, Fiona would sit mute and disconsolate, longing, I now know, for the anonymity of the children's home.

From our side, and in spite of some good times with Fiona, we were beginning to buckle under her pressure to leave us. She now admits that, towards the end, she was deliberately pushing us to reject her. Her version of this is that she didn't think she was worth loving and that, if she behaved badly enough, we would stop trying. Despite that good old staple of psycho-babble, low self-esteem, I think there's a good deal in that, although a simpler truth is that she just wanted us to get off her case.

It was bound to end in tears, and it did. Jo, taking the brunt of Fiona's angst, was reaching the end of her tether - one too many whining teachers, apoplectic parents, policemen at the door, and our increasing awareness that we now talked, ate and slept Fiona almost certainly to the detriment of our other children. In the end, I told social services we could not go on and they agreed that they would take her back into care - but they also said I must tell her that this was happening and when. I said that if I did, Fiona would run. They still insisted. After I told her - the hardest thing in my life I've had to do - Fiona ran. But she also phoned me at midnight to say that she was safe and staying with a friend. It was the first considerate thing she'd done in months - and a sign that there might still be a relationship to salvage.

Should we have done it in the first place? A heart-stopping moment in the making of this programme, two decades after the event, was when Fiona said to me for the first time: "I sometimes wonder whether it would have been better if you hadn't fostered me; if I had just stayed in the kids' home. Perhaps I would now have a better relationship with my natural brothers."

Fiona is entitled to that doubt, and by both agreeing to do the programme we had given each other licence to say what we thought. Not unduly given to self-doubt, I prefer to examine the facts. Three years after our break-up, and after very intermittent contact, we received a letter from Fiona, then living in Glasgow. She said she had a problem. I sent what I hoped was a helpful and encouraging letter back, and a bit of cash. Three days later, the doorbell rang. Fiona had used the money to buy a single train ticket home. We've been in contact ever since.

Fiona now has her own home, a good job and, in an interview conducted when I wasn't there, she says she loves us. Twenty-four years ago, when she first arrived, I would have settled for that. I hope she can.

Stability the key to good results

Two-thirds of children in local authority care are in foster homes. But almost one in five of all those in care has three or more placements in the course of a year.

Of youngsters in care continuously for more than four years, fewer than half have spent at least the past 24 months in the same foster home.

Ministers are trying to improve the stability of foster placements. They say that, on the whole, stability is associated with better outcomes. English councils have been set a target that no more than 16% of children in care should have three or more placements in a year.

In 1999-2000, the average was 17.8%. Almost a fifth of councils were judged to have performed unacceptably poorly.

The Department of Health says a placement is more likely to work if there is proper assessment of the child's needs and a good choice of foster carers. A 1990 survey found that 80% of women fosterers were aged 31-55, only one in eight had a child under five and just one in 20 was non-white.

 Peter White is the BBC's disability affairs correspondent. His programme, Leaving Home, is on BBC Radio 4 at 11am today.
