fields.headline: Can-do man at the wheel
fields.standfirst: Profile: Tom Dowling, the journalist a bullet couldn't hold back from success
fields.trailText: Profile: Tom Dowling, the journalist a bullet couldn't hold back from success.
fields.body:
The tabloid cliché of the trip of a lifetime turning into a nightmare came horribly true for journalist Tom Dowling. He was only 20 when, after three years' training on his local paper in Ellesmere Port, Merseyside, he set off with three friends in their blue Bedford van on a trip to the Himalayas.

Their goal was to get to Nepal, go on a trek to Everest base camp, then drive back. But things didn't go according to plan. Their engine blew up in Turkey, delaying them for a month. Then they all contracted dysentery. And by the time they reached Katmandu, the capital of Nepal, the monsoon season had started, leaving them with the time and energy for only one day's walking. But that was by no means the end of the trouble.

Exhausted but exhilarated, they set off on the return trip. In Iran, they were forced to stop overnight on the roadside between Teheran and Tabriz. Liverpool-born Dowling describes waking to a spectacular sunrise, but then realising that they were being bombarded with stones by two young robbers.

"I was sleeping in the luggage rack. As I tried to scramble down, I felt an enormous pain in my chest - as if a boulder had hit me."

In fact, Dowling had been shot in the spine by a 2.2 handgun. He taps the middle of his chest where, 27 years later, the bullet is still lodged. "There was no point in the doctors removing it," he says, "as the damage had been done."

Dowling was instantly paralysed from the chest down. The bullet had severed his spinal chord.

"The bullet was the size of my little fingernail, which apparently is the exact width of the spinal column," he smiles. "It was a clean wound, with only the tiniest trickle of blood. My friend [who fully recovered] was shot in the head and was covered in blood, which was much more scary."

He says he came to terms with his injury "very quickly", and feels lucky that he had completed his training as a journalist and could go back to work almost immediately. "I think my friends and family suffered more mental anguish, watching my every move and facial expression, as I had to learn to adapt to life in a wheelchair. I always say that I came off the lightest."

The following year, Dowling made a trip to Canada and the US, sneaking into American hospitals for Vietnam war veterans to use their toilet facilities because he knew they would be accessible. "I had some amazing conversations with veterans, who couldn't believe how I'd got shot, or how I'd come over from England in my wheelchair."

Two years after the shooting, he got a job with the Liverpool Daily Post & Echo. "I needed to advance my career in an accessible building. There were no such things as dropped kerbs or wheelchair ramps in the mid-1970s, but the Echo's offices were relatively OK."

Determined not to be defined as a disabled journalist, he worked as a features sub-editor. But gradually he saw the potential for a column for disabled people. "From a commercial point of view, I thought it would attract advertising, but there was also a need for the nitty-gritty practical information, where to get advice and products, a forum to help families like mine pick up the pieces. Charities had their own newsletters, but the number of people who subscribed to them was minimal. I felt that if we could create a regular section within the Echo, we could reach a lot more people, and also form good relationships and partnerships with organisations which could make opportunities for disabled people."

I Can Do That started as a monthly column in the Liverpool Echo in 1983, its title taken from the catchphrase of the time - the unemployed Yosser Hughes's mantra in the seminal television drama Boys from the Blackstuff. The main criterion was to keep the tone positive, says Dowling. "It's easy for people to walk away from someone in a wheelchair if they are moaning, so it has a deliberately light and newsy feel."

The column went weekly in 1988 and has grown from strength to strength, supported by succcessive Echo editors. But in addition I Can Do That was also launched four years ago as a 24-page, stand-alone, two-monthly magazine with a circulation of 25,000, distributed to newsagents, health centres, local authorities, libraries and disability groups across Merseyside and north Wales. Trinity Mirror, the Echo's owners and the biggest publisher of provincial newspapers, is looking at replicating its success in other regions.

"It's so successful, I can't get any work done because people keep phoning me up," Dowling jokes.

Earlier this year, I Can Do That racked up the latest in a long line of awards - the regional media prize in the Enabled awards run by disability charity Leonard Cheshire. "Some disabled people disagree with the magazine's existence, on the grounds that it excludes them from the mainstream," Dowling says, "but unfortunately there is nothing in the mainstream media that provides this service. I would love for there not to be a need, and maybe in 20 years that will be the case - but somehow I doubt it."

As he celebrates 25 years at the Echo this year, the success of I Can Do That is a fitting tribute to his positive energy. The memory of the 1974 attack is crystal clear but he is not haunted by it. He has good memories of the trip up until that awful day and a happy life now with his wife and three sons. He and his three travelling companions are still friends.

"People ask me what life is like in a wheelchair, but I find it hard to think of the negative aspects," Dowling says. "Of course there are obstacles, like not being able to play foot- ball with my sons, or not being able to reach things, but I can't expect the world to lower itself for me."

"I think my friends and family suffered more mental anguish, watching my every move and facial expression, as I had to learn to adapt to life in a wheelchair. I always say that I came off the lightest." The following year, Dowling made a trip to Canada and the US, sneaking into American hospitals for Vietnam war veterans to use their toilet facilities because he knew they would be accessible. "I had some amazing conversations with veterans, who couldn't believe how I'd got shot, or how I'd come over from England in my wheelchair." There were no such things as dropped kerbs or wheelchair ramps in the mid-1970s, but the Echo's offices were relatively OK." Determined not to be defined as a disabled journalist, he worked as a features sub-editor. But gradually he saw the potential for a column for disabled people. "From a commercial point of view, I thought it would attract advertising, but there was also a need for the nitty-gritty practical information, where to get advice and products, a forum to help families like mine pick up the pieces. Charities had their own newsletters, but the number of people who subscribed to them was minimal. I felt that if we could create a regular section within the Echo, we could reach a lot more people, and also form good relationships and partnerships with organisations which could make opportunities for disabled people." I Can Do That started as a monthly column in the Liverpool Echo in 1983, its title taken from the catchphrase of the time - the unemployed Yosser Hughes's mantra in the seminal television drama Boys from the Blackstuff. The main criterion was to keep the tone positive, says Dowling. "It's easy for people to walk away from someone in a wheelchair if they are moaning, so it has a deliberately light and newsy feel." The column went weekly in 1988 and has grown from strength to strength, supported by succcessive Echo editors. But in addition I Can Do That was also launched four years ago as a 24-page, stand-alone, two-monthly magazine with a circulation of 25,000, distributed to newsagents, health centres, local authorities, libraries and disability groups across Merseyside and north Wales. Trinity Mirror, the Echo's owners and the biggest publisher of provincial newspapers, is looking at replicating its success in other regions. "It's so successful, I can't get any work done because people keep phoning me up," Dowling jokes. Earlier this year, I Can Do That racked up the latest in a long line of awards - the regional media prize in the Enabled awards run by disability charity Leonard Cheshire. "Some disabled people disagree with the magazine's existence, on the grounds that it excludes them from the mainstream," Dowling says, "but unfortunately there is nothing in the mainstream media that provides this service. I would love for there not to be a need, and maybe in 20 years that will be the case - but somehow I doubt it." As he celebrates 25 years at the Echo this year, the success of I Can Do That is a fitting tribute to his positive energy. The memory of the 1974 attack is crystal clear but he is not haunted by it. He has good memories of the trip up until that awful day and a happy life now with his wife and three sons. He and his three travelling companions are still friends. "People ask me what life is like in a wheelchair, but I find it hard to think of the negative aspects," Dowling says. "Of course there are obstacles, like not being able to play foot- ball with my sons, or not being able to reach things, but I can't expect the world to lower itself for me."

webTitle: Are care home owners cashing in on closures?

fields.headline: Are care home owners cashing in on closures?
fields.standfirst: Lives are being put at risk by the closure of homes for elderly people. But for some owners, shutting down can mean cashing in
fields.trailText: Lives are being put at risk by the closure of homes for elderly people. But for some owners, shutting down can mean cashing in.
fields.body:
There's an old joke that goes: "What comes out of Cowes backwards? The Isle of Wight ferry." In a new twist, if the Isle of Wight County Press is to be believed, the ferry could soon be taking frail elderly people on a last trip to the mainland because of an acute shortage of care home beds on the island itself.

The story is not just journalistic licence. Charles Waddicor, the island council's social services director, confirms the bed shortage problem and accepts that using mainland care homes has been mooted. But he says shipping vulnerable old folk to the mainland could kill them - which is why he is against doing it. He says: "If you move frail, elderly people in this way, something like two-thirds will die within three months."

The severity of the care home problem on the Isle of Wight serves as a microcosm of wider problems across much of southern England - and beyond. There have long been gripes from home owners about the levels of payment for state-funded residents, but there is no doubt that homes are now closing. According to the latest survey by market analyst Laing & Buisson, 760 private and voluntary homes closed last year, with the loss of 16,200 places. A further 2,500 places were lost in local authority-run homes. Overall, the residential and nursing home sector suffered a net loss of 9,700 places.

But who is really to blame? Local authorities, which administer the state funding, are often painted as the bad guys. Community care money is provided through the revenue support grant, but the allocation comes from the Department of Health. It has announced inflation-busting rises for the past five years, fuelling expectations among home owners. But they have received below-inflation fee increases from councils.

The health department figures do stand up to scrutiny. Rises of 5.2%, 7.2%, 4.5%, 5.0% and 5.9% over the past five years of low inflation give credence to the claims of a 12% real terms increase in funding. But the Local Government Association (LGA), representing councils, has some figures of its own. Its recent survey of almost all the 150 social services authorities in England found they were due to overspend on social services by £205m. A staggering 85% of councils anticipated overspending. The figures suggested that while the money allocated by central government for personal social services under the standard spending assessment (SSA) had grown 11.2% since 1998, expenditure by councils had risen 14.2%.

The elderly do not take top priority. The LGA survey found that 64% of the expected overspend was on children's services - hardly surprising as children are a much higher profile area of spending and much more expensive if things go wrong. The harsh reality is that the penalties for injuring or mistreating an elderly person are cheap compared to the penalties for similar neglect of a child.

But the LGA did find that 21% of likely overspending was on the elderly. Mike O'Donnell, a member of the social services panel of the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy, says pressure on councils is growing in two ways. More elderly people need services and those already receiving them need more intensive support. The funding also covers those helped at home - the government's preferred option. A person receiving 10 hours' help at home might need just five extra hours - but that represents a 50% increase in the budget. "You might get a 6.5% increase in SSA, but most councils will need to implement a significant cuts package just to balance the budget," O'Donnell says. If they are lucky, they can afford a 2% rise for care home operators.

And councils fear things are about to get worse. The government gave them the gatekeeper role of deciding who needed community care in 1993. Before that, anyone who asked for it got it. Those people are still funded by the Department of Social Security (DSS), but at fees it fixes. In the south, these are significantly lower than council fees. From April next year, those people will transfer to council responsibility. The government has said it will give councils all the additional cash they need, but many are sceptical.

On the Isle of Wight, the difference between the fees is stark. For residential homes, the council's average contract price is £221.28 a week, compared to the DSS average of £161.02. For the council, that will mean finding the £60.26 difference for each of up to 186 residents each week - a potential annual cost of £582,835.

For nursing homes, the difference is even greater. The council's average contract price is £368.65, compared to the DSS average of £227.98, making a difference of £140.67. The 26 existing elderly patients currently on DSS books could cost an extra £190,186. On top of that, the island has 187 other residents under age 65 on preserved DSS rates. Even taking into consideration any additional funding for all these patients from their own resources, the Isle of Wight could easily be facing additional costs of more than £1m a year.

Local authorities claim they simply cannot afford to spend any more on care home fees without further government funding. However, the Registered Nursing Homes Association (RNHA) maintains some councils pay more to their own homes, or to their preferred voluntary sector operators, than they do to private sector homes in the same area.

Association chairman Frank Ursell says councils go out of their way to defend council or voluntary sector homes against competition from the private sector. Walsall council, he claims, recently put its homes out to tender but specifically excluded private sector bidders. The council chose not to comment on this to the Guardian. "When I was at school, they used to call this hypocrisy," Ursell says. Councils cannot pass all the blame on to central government, he argues. "It's poor husbandry of the money by local authorities, on top of poor allocation by the government."

But homes are not only facing this spending squeeze. New standards being phased in from next April will ramp up the costs of running care businesses.

The RNHA's chairman on the Isle of Wight is Kevin Dannett, owner of Springfield nursing home in Shanklin. One of the examples he gives is the new standard that doors used by wheelchair users must be 800mm wide. All his doors are 780mm wide. "Am I going to have to spend my limited resources to make my doors an inch wider?" he asks. If the 244 new standards are policed rigorously, many homes will face huge bills just to stay in business.

Ursell is frank about the situation. Between them, he and his wife have paid just £5,500 in income tax on profit from their home over the past four years - demonstrating how low the margins are. "It has not only taken away my profit," he says, "it has taken away my investment money."

Almost all homes will have to turn to banks for investment cash. But banks, understandably, are not keen to lend money when they cannot see in creased revenue resulting. For homes that have to convert to meet new single occupancy and room size standards, conversion may mean reducing the number of residents - hardly good grounds for lending money.

With high property prices in the south, banks point out that the value of the asset is often greater than the value of the business. "If you get an accountant in, or a banker, and you do the sums, then you should probably just sell up and realise the value of your asset," admits O'Donnell. And for those home owners approaching retirement age, selling for cash is undoubtedly a much more attractive proposition than soldiering on.

In the end, this appears to be the main reason homes are closing. The outcome will be fewer, larger home owners, but they will at least be in a better position to stand up to councils and demand more money - a fact not lost on Bupa, which, with 232 homes and 16,000 beds, is the private sector's largest player.

Only a quarter of Bupa patients are self-funding; the rest receive state support. "Local authorities are effectively a monopoly purchaser as against a fairly fragmented nursing home market," says Peter Ludford, Bupa's care home director. "As more homes close, it will start to put us on a more equal footing. Our elderly deserve a reasonable standard of care and support - but someone's got to pay."

fields.headline: Hidden assets
fields.standfirst: Victoria Silverman  explores evolving roles for Britain's relics of the bunker mentality that proliferated during the cold war
fields.trailText: Victoria Silverman explores evolving roles for Britain's relics of the bunker mentality that proliferated during the cold war.
fields.body:
It's not the post office, the pub, the church or the shop that villagers in Wawne, East Yorkshire, are fighting to save. It's their local bunker. The people of Wawne are so attached to the breeze-block relic of the second world war that they are applying to have it listed - and are battling with the county council, which wants to sell it off.

The single-storey block was used by the military during the war, but later became the area's civilian emergency planning centre. There are still maps, charts, chairs and desks in its dank, disused chambers. But by the early 1990s, files and plans to cope with catastrophes could be compactly stored on computers, so the disaster HQ was transferred to a quiet suite of offices 10 miles away in County Hall, Beverley.

Since the end of the cold war, the same thing has happened to bunkers all over Britain. They have become all sorts of things, from mushroom farms to interference-proof housing for internet servers. Several have put their secret wartime pasts on display as museums of military and civil defence - which is what the residents of Wawne hope to do.

"But in another cold war," says Derek Brown, of the Wawne Action Group, "we would want it used for its original purpose. Even though the bunker would only house officials, we need it to help the area recover from a nuclear attack."

The evolving roles of Britain's bunkers mirror the changing ways that governments, central and regional, have planned for disaster over the decades - from nuclear attacks to floods, droughts, oil spills and diseases such as foot and mouth. But it has been no seamless progress, with some critics arguing that the shadow of wartime procedures still hangs over the way authorities deal with civil emergencies, and that we need to get rid of all vestiges of military thinking.

Ministry of Defence reports confirm that nuclear war is no longer the preoccupation of military strategists. High on the nation's hazard list now are global warming, scarcity of fresh water and biogenetic food scares. However, the 100 members of the group of nuclear-free local authorities believe Britain has yet to adapt fully to this new security environment. "War planning still underwrites the whole emergency planning process," says spokesman Stewart Kemp. "A change in international relations and one circular from the Home Office could plunge us back into the 1980s."

At the height of the cold war, the government set about replicating key parts of its infrastructure in underground locations. Britain was divided into 10 regions, each the notional responsibility of a cabinet minister.

The network was underpinned by 19 bunkers, known as regional government headquarters. In each, about 150 key officials would have the task of restoring "civil governance", as official parlance put it, in their regions in the aftermath of an attack.

Each bunker had a secure phone system linked directly to police and fire services and to Whitehall. Spe cially constructed cabinets were installed to protect IT and secure systems from the electro-magnetic pulses of a nuclear blast.

All government ministries made arrangements to dovetail with this plan. Details of the extensive planning by all the big public service ministries were set out in once-secret war books. The Ministry of Agriculture, for instance, set up enormous food stores, the last of which was emptied in 1993.

Few of these structures survived the peace dividend and Treasury pruning of the 1990s. But two did: the major underground command centres which would become operational in event of an attack. One (codename Pindar) is under the Ministry of Defence building in Whitehall, and was completed in 1994 at a cost of £126m - at a time when it had been decided to sell off the regional bunkers. The other (codename Burlington) is at Corsham, Wiltshire. Both have facilities for a sealed-off subterranean community of several thousand officials.

In the early 1980s, contingency planning in case of a nuclear attack turned many local councils into temporary outposts for Nato exercises. Local officials rehearsed how everything from corpses and casualties to refugees and refuse would be handled in the event of disaster.

These annual operations, planned by Nato, still continue. Last year's was known as Intex 2000, an international warning and detection exercise between 16 nations. The scenarios included a number of imagined chemical, nuclear and satellite incidents. The latest exercise, Crisex, was staged in February.

There are also exercises arranged by the government, to rehearse reaction to domestic crises. By the late 1980s, it was clear from a string of such incidents - the King's Cross fire in 1987, the Lockerbie bombing in 1988 and the Hillsborough stadium disaster in 1989 - that there was a need for a far more co-ordinated approach to public safety.

As a result, local government civil and home defence units were instructed to concentrate on emergency planning, rather than the diminishing threat of nuclear annihilation. The Home Office, which had been responsible for orchestrating all local authority "war plans", as they were known (even after 1945), similarly switched focus.

To facilitate the transition, a series of regulations on disaster management was tacked on to the 1948 war planning regulations. Even today, councils still have no legal duty to plan for disasters. This can create a real tension between central government pressure to develop and test crisis plans and the reluctance of some council finance committees to fund them.

During the spending cuts of the early 1990s, councils resorted to funding disaster management from Home Office grants earmarked for war planning. These grants reached £110m in 1986-87, but by last year had shrunk to some £14m for England and Wales as a whole. After last autumn's flooding, deputy prime minister John Prescott - prompted by councils' complaints about resources - announced a review of emergency planning as a whole.

The Local Government Association is hoping the review will put disaster management on a proper footing, distinct from war planning and with adequate funds. As association spokesman Chris Drew says: "We have put up with command and control monoliths for too long. We're hoping to get proper legal and financial structures, tailored to the way society and government work today."

Deep-seated privilege

Under nuclear attack, people should "stay at home, using and improving the radiation protection of their own homes", said the Home Office's 1985 emergency planning guidance to local authorities. In Britain, unlike some other countries, bunkers were never intended for the hoi polloi.

In the still definitive War Plan UK, published in 1982, author Duncan Campbell described the building in the 1950s of an extensive network of bunkers.

He estimated that they provided at least 20,000 places for government ministers, officials and service chiefs. The privileged few, Campbell wrote, would be "the same grey rulers familiar from peacetime".

Peter Laurie, in the 1970 book Beneath the City Streets, was the first to reveal the locations of subterranean government "citadels" and tunnels. In central London, a web of secret tunnels is said to date back in part as far as the first world war.

In the second world war, a fortified government centre (codename Paddock) was constructed at Dollis Hill, north London, but prime minister Winston Churchill disliked it.

webTitle: Ethnic minority students targeted for civil service fast track

fields.headline: Ethnic minority students targeted for civil service fast track
fields.trailText: The Cabinet Office will today launch a recruitment drive to attract able undergraduates from ethnic minorities into the fast stream of the civil service - the elite group that can be expected to produce most of the next generation of senior officials.
fields.body:
The Cabinet Office will today launch a recruitment drive to attract able undergraduates from ethnic minorities into the fast stream of the civil service - the elite group that can be expected to produce most of the next generation of senior officials.

It has appointed an "outreach scout" to visit university campuses to sign up ethnic minority students for a summer programme to familiarise them with what it would be like to pursue a career in Whitehall.

Faisal Naru, a 24-year-old Oxford graduate, has been contracted to find about 60 potential recruits among students who might have the talent for this kind of work. They will get placements in Whitehall during the summer, coupled with residential training to hone their teamworking skills.

Naru, a maths graduate previously employed by Oxford University to boost its intake from inner-city comprehensives, says: "It's clear from talking to students and community groups that the perception persists that the civil service only offers rewarding careers for white, male, middle-class, middle-aged Sir Humphreys. That is not the case."

The Cabinet Office says the service welcomes applicants from all sections of society. Its existing 500,000 staff include 5.8% from ethnic minorities. This compares with 5.2% of all people in employment and 5.8% of the economically active population.

Among the top 3,500 jobs in the senior civil service, 2.1% are held by ethnic minorities staff. This has risen from 1.6% in 1998, with the government having set a target of 3.2% by 2005.

The programme to attract undergraduates and graduates from the ethnic minorities was piloted last year. Naru says it had two target groups: students who would not have considered a civil service career because they knew little about it; and those who saw it as "a closed domain of white Oxford males".

During the pilot, 70% of students said they would not have applied for the civil service before going on the course; afterwards, 90% said they would apply.

Akhil Patel was based in the prison service during the pilot and went on to apply for fast stream entry. "I had my doubts about the civil service beforehand," he says. "But I found it welcoming and supportive. People I trained with were open to ideas and I felt the work I was given was important and was making a real difference."

Shalini Chandru, another fast track applicant, was based in the Treasury last year. "On the programme, I had responsibility from the start and realised how important, worthwhile and diverse the work can be," she says. "Afterwards, I was motivated to apply and the training I received gave me more confidence to do so."

Naru, whose university visits start this week in Bradford and Leeds, says he was pleasantly surprised when he took on the civil service contract. "I was expecting it to be quite cliquey, but my experience has been different. I was supported during the month of fasting that I had as a Muslim. In some organisations that can be difficult. But flexible working hours in the civil service let me change around my days to keep up with my religious commitments as well as continuing with work I like doing."

Students attending the summer course will be encouraged to apply for the fast track entry in the September after they graduate. A further winter course will aim to boost applications for the January entry.

Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, says the proportion of ethnic minority recruits to the fast stream doubled over the past two years from 3% to 6%. "But we are not complacent about diversity in the civil service. Initiatives like this are crucial if the civil service is to reflect the society it serves."

fields.headline: War's mind field
fields.standfirst: Sarah Ebner on how the group Combat Stress helps the haunted soldiers whose wounds are hard to heal
fields.trailText: Sarah Ebner on how the group Combat Stress helps the haunted soldiers whose wounds are hard to heal.
fields.body:
It is almost 20 years since John shot the young Argentinian soldier but he can still see him, close up, in his mind's eye. "He was probably around my age. Afterwards I searched him and it turned out he wasn't armed. He didn't surrender, so I did my job. He could have had a pistol or a grenade. I didn't even consider whether he was armed or not. I just reacted to seeing him and I shot him."

John was 19 when he was sent to the Falklands. He had joined the Parachute Regiment two years earlier and had already had a tour of duty in Northern Ireland. But the Falklands came as a complete shock.

"I knew I was going to go to Northern Ireland, but I never thought I would ever go to war," he says. "It turned out to be very inhuman, very alien. War is not a glorious thing and anyone who makes out it is is a fool."

Now 38, John has spent the last 20 years trying to recover from his army experiences. Like soldiers in conflicts before, and after, the gruesome reality of killing people, seeing your friends - and even, as in John's case, your own brother - blown up or shot, was all too much for him. And for almost two decades, no one wanted to help.

Linda Winn, clinical director of Combat Stress, the ex-services mental welfare society, says John's experience is typical. "We help people aged from 19 to 95," she says. "As long as people are psychologically robust enough, we take them. People may think that shell shock or flashbacks are only suffered by veterans of the world wars. But that's not true. We have a lot of younger people coming through now, from the Gulf, the Balkans and Northern Ireland."

Combat Stress aims to help these men - and a few women - deal with their problems at its three residential centres in Surrey, Shropshire and Strathclyde. "The people who come here are suffering from psychological injuries resulting from their service experience," says Winn of the 2,000 or so people Combat Stress helps annually. "Quite often they're very angry and we try to give them a feeling of control. The sooner people can be referred, the more successful the treatment."

Last month, an extreme case of what can happen to someone who was not helped made its way into the news. George Daley, 80, an ex-Royal Artillery private from the second world war, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He had been woken from a deep sleep by fireworks and thought he had returned to the battlefields of North Africa. When his 85-year-old neighbour appeared, he was convinced she was the enemy breaking into his home and he stabbed her.

"Flashbacks can last for seconds or hours," says Winn. "And they can be triggered by so many things. They also have residual effects. Afterwards you feel disturbed and distraught.

"We have found that with ex-Far East prisoners of war, the flashbacks and nightmares are often so strong that they think people are talking to them in Japanese. Some attack their wives, thinking they are Japanese soldiers."

John, too, felt out of control. "When I returned from the Falklands, I wanted out of the army urgently," he says. "I never wanted to be put in that situation again and I left about a year afterwards." The memories, however, have remained.

"I've got no concept of time when it comes to the Falklands. It's all very blurred. I just know I left in April and came back in August. I get flashbacks and they're like a montage of events from Goose Green to Wireless Ridge, which were two weeks apart. I see them pretty much together. Goose Green was a bloody battle. It was very conventional. There was bayoneting and hand-to-hand combat. Trenches were being cleared."

John was in an alcoholic haze for years. He went from one job to another, but was often drunk, violent and extremely angry. He also began to abuse drugs. And he was not the only one of his former colleagues with problems.

"When we got back, there were no offers of help," he says. "The flashbacks were triggered by a variety of things, including news items and war films, but we got no psychological help. It was OK being with my mates, but I had real problems with other people. People thought they could pick your brains for a pint of lager. Then the first question was the most insensitive you can ask anyone who's just back from combat - if you killed anyone. That puts you in places you don't want to be. It can instantly set off a flashback."

John was violent and depressed. His behaviour even led to a three-month spell in prison for GBH. "I had no fear of anything. I wasn't scared of the police, of authority. Nothing. And of course I was suffering from awful nightmares and flashbacks.

"Times have changed too," he adds. "From world war two it seems like everybody was involved. After the war, your local bobby was also a veteran. He didn't arrest the drunken ex-soldier on the ground; he took him home and put him into bed. Nowadays there's no tolerance. I've got more in common with a pensioner who fought the Germans 60 years ago than I have with some of my own generation."

Eventually a friend told John to get help. "He was sure I had post traumatic stress disorder, but I said I was fine. He replied that nobody was safe walking down the street with me around."

John's doctor recommended a psychiatrist. That helped a little, but the treatment was stopped when the GP could no longer fund it. Finally, two years ago, John spoke to the war pensions agency, which recommended the residential courses run by Combat Stress (the agency funds 80% of the charity's costs).

"It's been pretty positive," John says. "You go on courses like anger and stress management and you feel they actually understand what you're going through. Gradually you become less angry and more at ease with yourself. You end up with a better understanding of your condition."

John is not "cured" in the sense that you can heal a physical ailment, but he has his problems more under control. "The flashbacks aren't as destructive now because I understand them better," he says. "I know what triggers to avoid - I don't go to the pub any more, for example - and, when they do happen, I know I'm not back in 1982. I realise it's 2001.

"I've talked to some of the old and bold from world war two and they still suffer but live with it. You've got to take what little positive there is. We've got an obligation to live a decent life for those who died - not just the British but also the Argentinians that some of us killed.

"It'd be too easy to go through life angry and cynical. My life didn't end when I was 19 and I don't want to be coming here in 30 years' time. There's a lot more to do out there."

 John's name has been changed. Combat Stress is on 01372-841 600.

fields.headline: Doing a grown-up job
fields.standfirst: Study reveals the problems behind recruiting childminders
fields.trailText: Study reveals the problems behind recruiting childminders.
fields.body:
The government has recognised the crucial role of childminders by putting them at the heart of its national childcare strategy. But research published today indicates the scale of the challenge in their recruitment and retention.

Official statistics show that the number of registered childminders in England fell almost 30% from 106,000 in 1992 to 76,000 last year. The new study, Who Cares? - Childminding in the 1990s, points to low pay, poor status of the job, an increase in regulation, lack of support from local authorities, demographic change and the growing availability of more flexible working hours in alternative employment.

Researchers surveyed a sample of 1,050 childminders in eight English local authorities in January 1999. They also interviewed 10 new, 10 established and 10 former childminders from a city and a suburban English authority in 2000. Parents using the 20 active childminders were also interviewed.

The study, conducted by the Thomas Coram Research Unit at London University's Institute of Education and funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, concludes that childminders are the main providers of formal childcare - accounting for some 25% of all children receiving non-parental care. The majority are women with young children of their own and a partner in full-time employment.

A lack of any career progression and an expectation that the job will not be recognised in the wider labour market were found to be deterrents to working as a childminder. And the work can be uncertain. When care arrangements change, or end, childminders may have no idea when they will find new clients. As one interviewee said: "I wish the general public would recognise that childminding is a proper job."

Childminders were found to work an average 34 hours a week, with one in three doing more than 41. The average weekly income was £103. Half had vacancies for children and many reported difficulty filling places.

Despite all this, interviewees expressed a high level of job satisfaction. The ability to combine paid work with being at home was seen as the main advantage. More than half wanted to continue childminding.

The researchers warn that low levels of training and pay, and devaluation of the work, are making childminding unsustainable. "This government has realised the value of childminding, but in wider society childminding is seen as something women do for 'pin money'," says Ann Mooney, a researcher at the Thomas Coram research unit and co-author of the study. "This is not how the women interviewed saw it. Most said the money earned from childminding was essential to their household income and the majority said that they would have to look for other work if they weren't childminding."

Mooney acknowledges that new government initiatives have addressed some of the reasons for the decline in childminders. "Never theless," she says, "there are still underlying difficulties around status and working conditions. For childcare workers, it is a professional job."

Gill Haynes, chief executive of the National Childminding Association and a member of the research project's steering group, says the organisation alerted the government to the decline in the number of childminders more than two years ago. Introduction of start-up grants of £300-£600, and early years development and childcare partnerships which provide support and advice to childminders, have created a "dramatic" rise in the organisation's membership. "It has finally been recognised that childminders are self-employed and that we've got an army of female entrepeneurs out there," she says.

Haynes also welcomes new national standards which, from September, will replace all current local authority guidelines and will require newly registered childminders to attend a recognised introductory course within six months of starting work. The course will count as the first unit of a nationally accredited qualification. And, from the autumn, schools inspectorate Ofsted will extend its remit to childminders. "For the first time, standards will focus on how effectively childminders are providing care," Haynes says. "They will be treated as experts rather than gifted amateurs."

The association admits recruitment and retention are still problems. "Local authorities have been poor at recognising the value of what childminders do. Many are looking after children with special needs and still being paid £2.50 an hour. An authority should at least pay the minimum wage rather than exploit their goodwill and expertise."

 Who Cares? - Childminding in the 1990s is available at £13.95 plus £2 p&p from York Publishing Services, 64 Hallfield Road, York YO31 7ZQ (01904-430033). A summary is available at www.jrf.org.uk.

fields.headline: Front... to back
fields.trailText: The Royal Navy is recruiting a squadron of barn owls to stop rodents nibbling exhibits in the Fleet Air Arm museum at Yeovilton, Somerset.
fields.body:
Wise move The Royal Navy is recruiting a squadron of barn owls to stop rodents nibbling exhibits in the Fleet Air Arm museum at Yeovilton, Somerset. Worcestershire Evening Mail, 12.4.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Drink problem A brewery football team in Warrington, Cheshire, has been evicted from its home ground because players aren't spending enough at the sports club bar. East Anglian Daily Times, 9.4.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Surplice to requirements An ageing choir has been disbanded by their church in Ilkeston, Derbyshire, because the vicar says the singers struggle to cope with new music and haven't attracted any young people to their ranks. Derby Evening Telegraph, 16.4.01 (Sarah Brookfield, Newton Solney)

Ee-aye,ee-aye, no The song Old MacDonald Had A Farm has been scrapped from the mayor's concert in Ledbury, Herefordshire, in case it upsets farmers hit by the foot and mouth crisis. Express and Star, 17.4.01 (David Smith, Stourbridge)

Lack of faith An almshouse cottage in Stockport, Cheshire, costing only £17 a week in rent, has stood empty for more than six months because the owners can't find a tenant who meets the criteria of being local, over 59 and Protestant. Metro News, 11.4.01 (Nasira Asghar, Stockport)

Rovers return clause Parishioners at a church in Blackburn, Lancashire, have taken the priest's signed team photograph of local rivals Burnley FC and say they won't return it unless he preaches a sermon in praise of Blackburn Rovers. Pendle Citizen, 5.4.01 (Sue Hogg, Colne)

On the old menu A 19th century brothel in York has been converted into a restaurant, decorated with photographs of the former establishment's working girls. Rotherham Star, 11.4.01 (Keith Billington, Rotherham)

Kit off A footballer in a local league match at Edenbridge, Kent, was so angry at being shown a red card that he stripped and walked naked off the pitch. Birmingham Evening Mail, 14.4.01 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

Down in the dumps A man from Kempston, Bedfordshire, spent hours rummaging through 14 tonnes of rubbish at a waste tip after accidentally throwing out a tiny jewellery box containing family heirlooms. Bedford Times and Citizen, 13.4.01 (B Chiswell, Bedford)

Big savings? Services are to be held in two Manchester supermarkets in a bid to stem the fall in congregations at local churches. Manchester Evening News, 14.4.01 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Beat pounders Policemen in north Wales are being encouraged to stop using station canteens and start eating at McDonald's restaurants to present a higher profile to the public. South Wales Echo, 13.4.01 (Ann Henderson, Edinburgh)

Highest authority A lay preacher stopped by police while driving in Skewen, south Wales, told police that he didn't require car insurance because he has divine protection. South Wales Evening Post, 17.4.01 (Bill Griffiths, Swansea)

fields.headline: Steering ahead
fields.standfirst: Brian O'Hagan on the London governance project that is helping a group of small charities to plan their big picture
fields.trailText: Brian O'Hagan on the London governance project that is helping a group of small charities to plan their big picture.
fields.body:
The average charity is small, under-resourced and surviving on an income of about £1,000 a year. Organisations of this kind can be forgiven for concentrating on the day-to-day needs of their clients, rather than on a longer-term vision of what they are trying to achieve.

However, a project being piloted in London is working with 20 small voluntary groups with the aim of developing their capacity for organisational development and governance - the process by which trustees focus on overall ideals and vision.

Appropriately named the "governance project", this venture is the brainchild of a number of groups, including the City Parochial Foundation, the London Borough Grants Committee, the National Council of Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) and Voluntary Action Camden, which is overseeing the scheme.

The project is led by Kevin Nunan, formerly trustee development officer at the NCVO and a specialist in this field. He has a simple, yet effective, analogy for the key points of governance and its importance in organisational development. "The origins of the word governance comes from the Latin word to steer, a mariners' term for directing their ships at sea," he says. "It is also related to the word for helmsman, another seafaring term that is aptly suited to the role of the trustees in charting a course for their organisations."

Chosen from four London boroughs, the charities involved in the project are diverse in their needs and the fields they work in. One, Merton Community Transport, is hoping to improve the way its board of trustees works together; another, the Detainees Support and Help Unit, wants to strengthen the skills base of its trustees who currently rely on the founder, Comfort Afolabi, for direction and leadership.

"Our trustees are very active and supportive but a lot of the work falls on my shoulders," says Afolabi. "If we could undertake training for the management committee, then we would be better placed to serve our clients."

One of the groups involved in the project is struggling to remain independent of its local council, which not only exerts considerable influence on the management committee but is also the main source of funds. Developing skills in fundraising is therefore a key priority.

"We have to remain independent of the borough," says the charity's director, who wishes to remain anonymous. "They want us to merge with another group, but our members feel happier talking to us. They know us and feel that we understand them. Surely their needs are the most important consideration."

The criteria for participant organ isations is that they have been established for charitable or not-for-profit purposes; that they are small, but comprise at least four individuals; and that they agree to co-operate in follow-up evaluation. In return, each benefits from the support of its local council of voluntary service development worker; from the involvement of Nunan, who works with the groups to identify their needs and how best to progress; and from a £1,500 grant for training and development.

"The first thing we ask organisations to do is sit down with one another and discuss where they think they should be," Nunan says. "It doesn't necessarily matter how productive these discussions are. It is learning how to communicate with one another that will bring results. Then, once organisations have agreed where they want to go, or have identified what issues they need to address if a destination cannot be agreed on we can begin looking at the best ways to move forward."

Although groups participating on the project are first and foremost interested in furthering their work, there is a growing recognition that the right financial, administrative and management systems are necessary prerequisites for success. Funders in particular are more likely to support smaller groups when they see these key elements working effectively.

Dave Hobday, small groups worker at Merton voluntary service council, says: "One of the successes of the project so far is that the groups we are working with actually recognise the need for good governance. Thinking 'outside' of their organisations, and taking into account the needs of users, funders and other stakeholders is vital if they want to progress and develop their work."

The governance project will complete its pilot year next month, followed by a period of monitoring and evaluation. Funds permitting, the project may well expand its service to small charities and voluntary groups both in London and further afield.

"In the long run it would be good if funders and ourselves could refer groups to the governance project," Hobday says. "It may well prove an opportunity for funders in particular, who could refer groups they were unsure of to the project as a precondition for awarding a grant."

 More information and advice on running your charity.

fields.headline: A fist for life
fields.standfirst: Tyll van de Voort, a garderner at Oaklands Park contemplates 'the Kafkaesque psyche of Maff'
fields.trailText: Tyll van de Voort, a garderner at Oaklands Park contemplates 'the Kafkaesque psyche of Maff'.
fields.body:
On April 18, the agriculture ministry sent the community farm at Oaklands a fax: "I should be grateful if your clients would co-operate in allowing us to organise the valuation and slaughter of Foot and Mouth Disease susceptible stock at Oaklands Park Community Farm. Yours sincerely, the Maff Disease Centre Manager."

The Kafkaesque psyche of Maff astonishes me. How can a huge bureaucratic machine, kept churning presumably by red-blooded human individuals, behave like a monolithic behemoth - seemingly without any internal discussion or dissent on an issue as controversial as the mass cull policy? In week nine of the epidemic, the machine has found its rhythm of robotic kill, burn and bury, leaving behind death and ashes, fields of silence and sorrow.

Finally the Maff machine had arived at Oaklands. Our village community of 116 people - effectively under house arrest for two weeks because of quarantine restrictions imposed on us for being next to an infected farm - gathered again to protect our healthy flock of ewes and lambs, a herd of 60 shorthorn cattle and the children's pet goats.

In the long hours of vigil on the barricades, erected along our drive to deter Maff's henchmen, I found time to reflect. What had moved me and my wife almost 20 years ago to give up careers that promised reputation, second homes and the joy of driving Saab convertibles into the sunset, to go to a crumbling island ruled by an Iron Lady and offering mainly grey skies, filthy weather and post-industrial decay - to join a community determined to turn the world as I knew it not on its head but on to its feet ?

Oaklands - near Newnham in Gloucestershire - promised only a life dedicated to the care of the environment and social renewal. As a Camphill community, it works with handicapped people; and its philosophy, based on Rudolph Steiner's work, is simple in the way life is simple: give and you shall be given. If everyone makes it his or her focus that the other one is "looked after", logically all will be cared for. If all grab for themselves, the weak and vulnerable will go empty.

So it was that our family started to live and work with the vulnerable. We live on, with and from a large farm: the waste goes for compost, we help with the harvest, support the farmer, celebrate the seasons and enjoy the animals and gardens. The surprise for me was that love, far from being a romantic idea, is a principle of order - the only logical principle of order for our time.

Love behaves like money in reverse: the more you spend, the more you get. It's the same with all creation - love is the reverse of entropy. So, the only appropriate attitude to nature is reverence and care. If they are there, abundance is inevitable. If they aren't, poverty, starvation and dejection ensue.

I hear the hyena laugh of materialists who look on the living world as dead matter ordered in sophisticated patterns and who regard self-regenerating and self-organising nature as a strip mine. The metaphor of the machine, with its image of combustion and exhaustion, is all-pervasive in our western thinking. It offers efficiency, expertise and exploitation and has a one-dimension simplicity. Its logic leads to the conclusion that man is the enemy of nature. But man is nature, so this means that man is enemy to himself and we behave accordingly.

Twenty years ago, I turned to biodynamic horticulture and now train people in the laws of life. I tell them that the patterns of life visible in plants pervade the universe. We think a lot about values and purpose in human existence. I use the words spirituality and love without embarrassment and without camouflaging them with irony.

A healthy social organism is impossible without a respectful, reverential attitude to nature. If we treat soil, plant and animals like commodities and waste, we will treat each other likewise. The laws of life are inherently different from the laws of industry. Land cannot be "owned", and consequently cannot be "inherited" as property. Nor can it be an object of speculation.

Finally, on the economic level, we have to realise that agriculture is intrinsically local, and thus needs trading arrangements other than those pushed by the WTO.

The solution of mass culling brought by the men in white coats is part of the problem. The problem is the industrial approach to agriculture - and to life and to people. The American psychologist Abraham Maslow put it well: "If the only tool you have is a hammer, you treat everyone like a nail."

However, back to the barricades! On Thursday morning Maff walked into the clenched fist of people power. By nine o clock, more than 200 people - friends, children, neighbours and distressed farmers - had turned up to celebrate and witness the power of community over bulldozers and stunguns.

But Maff never came. Several police officers did, one of them asking if we would allow Maff's men in. We declined. Would we be willing to talk to a Maff official? Yes. They went away and hours later the media, not Maff, told us that the ministry would reconsider our case. It became clear that Maff had backed off and our healthy animals could live.

What saved us - and other farmers in Anglesey and elsewhere - was a spark of resistance and the support of other farmers, members of the public and solicitors. They helped restore our belief that sanity can prevail - if we so want, if we speak up and if we listen.

 Tyll van de Voort is a gardener at Oaklands Park. Its website is www.camphill.org.uk.

fields.headline: Grey green
fields.standfirst: Jake Bowers and  Jason Torrance look back on 10 years of Earth First! - and ahead to uncertainty
fields.trailText: Jake Bowers and Jason Torrance look back on 10 years of Earth First! - and ahead to uncertainty.
fields.body:
Earth First! is dead, long live Earth First! Almost exactly 10 years ago, Earth First! UK, the enfant terrible of the British environmental movement, was born at the gates of Dungeness nuclear power station in Kent. There, on the sixth anniversary of the explosion at Chernobyl, 50 Sussex activists took the first steps to create a network based on informed rage rather than exhaustive research. Frustrated by the creeping corporatisation of the environmental movement, we were directly inspired by Earth First! in the US, the "no compromise" movement started 11 years earlier.

It was a boom time for many British groups who were enjoying an unprecedented growth in supporters and income. Even Margaret Thatcher had declared herself "green", but our line was to be unashamedly unreasonable. We knew EF US's original hardline "rednecks for wilderness" attitude wouldn't appeal here, so we set out to build a group that combined radical action and social justice to protect Britain's few remaining natural places.

The idea was to remind people that the Earth was not dying but being murdered, and that the murderers had names and addresses. If somebody was trying to rape and murder your mum, you wouldn't, we reasoned, write a letter to your MP about the issue - you'd physically intervene.

We were proud to be angry. We wanted no office or paid staff. We thought groups should do more than write reports, lobby government and treat their supporters as fundraising lackeys. We didn't want to create yet another organisation that would turn into a professional elite dependant on raising money for its existence. We wanted something wilder, less governable and modelled on nature itself.

When a network chooses to operate beyond the rule of law, it must have a moral framework to operate within if it is to avoid collapsing into chaos. So Earth First! UK tried to define its relationship to violence, property damage and the media. At the end of a gathering in Sussex, EF! adopted a strict non-violence code, decided that no form of property damage should be committed in its name and gave a series of interviews to the national press.

Within two years, 50 Earth First! groups and hundreds of nomadic activists were using Gandhi-style civil disobedience on a scale unseen since the early 80s peace movement. In 1992, an evangelical Earth First! roadshow culminated in more than 600 activists occupying Liverpool docks in protest at the importation of rainforest timber. But it was only when Earth First! answered a call from the Twyford Down Association that it really began to find its niche.

On December 10, 1992, Earth First! tasted its first blood when security guards physically and sexually assaulted activists at a camp it had established with a group of New Travellers known as the Dongas tribe. The 18 months of daily direct action that followed showed the gumption the green movement needed to drag itself out of its post Earth Summit hangover.

And so it went on. To Solsbury Hill outside Bath, the M11 campaign in Wanstead, Newbury and other road protests. Across the country, EF! activists focused on every form of destructive development they could find, from new supermarkets to new housing and quarrying developments.

In 1994, the Conservatives aimed to criminalise a whole array of activists and lifestyles with the criminal justice and public order bill. The broad coalition that was formed to defeat the bill lost the battle, but the alliances it created further invigorated Britain's direct action movement. By 1997, campaigns had helped defeat the largest road building programme Britain had seen. The success involved no multi-million pound budgets, green celebrities or impressive hardware - just a network of determined unpaid activists.

When Labour cancelled the roads programme, the network was left unbalanced, surprised and ultimately without its central campaign. Many activists, weary after years of what was often literally trench warfare, moved on. Others used the victory to focus on more progressive campaigns, from land rights occupations to trying to reclaim urban spaces from the car. So it was that Reclaim the Streets was born.

In the last few years, Earth First! activists have concentrated on GM crops and globalisation. But lately the lack of highly visible and destructive development projects has stemmed the flow into the movement of new activists with fresh anger and perspectives. A new wave of mass direct action has yet to be realised.

Earth First!, it seems, is hiber nating and has some hard thinking and work to do. Much was achieved, but while the mainstream environmental movement has come to accept Earth First!'s means, it has never accepted its agenda. It may have mobilised thousands, but it has failed to stop the further corporatisation of the wider movement.

Far from accepting that capitalism is intrinsically unsustainable, green pressure groups increasingly have used market-based strategies to campaign. Some even state they do not in principle oppose economic growth, let alone capitalism itself.

But revolutions are not so much put down as destroyed from the inside. Last year's Mayday protests weren't just criticised by the media, Earth First! activists themselves were depressed at its outcome.

At last year's gathering in Snowdonia, activists started to look at an issue they have long avoided - self-discipline. It's ironic that a movement that has thrived on its ability to be confrontational has often proved inept at confronting destructive personalities within its own ranks.

From the beginning, Earth First! has been plagued by people more interested in "me first", or "tea-by-the-campfire first" rather than putting the Earth first. Anti-road camps towards the end of their heyday often became cliquey and unwelcoming. While new activists were put off, many seasoned ones, tired and penniless after years of voluntary activism, went to work for mainstream pressure groups. This "brain drain" should have provided opportunities for new activists to take lead roles. But without establishing the infrastructure to pass on skills, a vacuum has been created.

So where now? If Earth First! is to survive in Britain it must learn to present radical green ideals without being sidetracked by loose cannons or media hysteria. But it must also go back to basics and rediscover what it used to do best - turn the threat of local development projects into political opportunities.

The government's £29bn road building programme will be a crucial test, if only because it threatens to wipe out Earth First!'s most visible political achievement, but also its own backyard, in the form of the proposed Hastings bypasses. The very place where Earth First! was started is now itself threatened.

If symbolism means anything, Hastings is the line drawn in the sand at the collapse of the last government's road programme. It must not be crossed. Earth Firsters, wake up, dust off the climbing harnesses, padlocks and laptops. This time, for some us at least, it's going to get personal.

 Jake Bowers is a Romani activist and freelance journalist. Jason Torrance is a network developer for Greenpeace UK. Contact: hastingsef@hotmail.com.

While new activists were put off, many seasoned ones, tired and penniless after years of voluntary activism, went to work for mainstream pressure groups. This "brain drain" should have provided opportunities for new activists to take lead roles. But without establishing the infrastructure to pass on skills, a vacuum has been created. So where now? If Earth First! is to survive in Britain it must learn to present radical green ideals without being sidetracked by loose cannons or media hysteria. But it must also go back to basics and rediscover what it used to do best - turn the threat of local development projects into political opportunities. The government's £29bn road building programme will be a crucial test, if only because it threatens to wipe out Earth First!'s most visible political achievement, but also its own backyard, in the form of the proposed Hastings bypasses. The very place where Earth First! was started is now itself threatened. If symbolism means anything, Hastings is the line drawn in the sand at the collapse of the last government's road programme. It must not be crossed. Earth Firsters, wake up, dust off the climbing harnesses, padlocks and laptops. This time, for some us at least, it's going to get personal.  Jake Bowers is a Romani activist and freelance journalist. Jason Torrance is a network developer for Greenpeace UK. fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Means-testing's failure | GM and rhetorical roots
fields.body:
Means-testing's failure

Malcolm Dean (April 25) draws the wrong conclusions regarding the increasing use of means-tested benefits. The ingrained hostility towards means-testing from pensioners, to which he refers, is not merely because the idea needs to be repackaged or better advertised.

Successive governments have already tried this, by renaming means-tested benefits from poor relief, through income support to the new minimum income guarantee (Mig) - and all have singularly failed to improve take-up of such benefits.

Means-testing actually hinders any attempt seriously to tackle poverty. It is more bureaucratic and costly to administer than the universal state pension; it acts as a disincentive to saving for retirement; it demeans those who are forced to jump through hoops in order to receive extra money; and it fails in its biggest claim - to get money to those who need it most.

Currently, more than 500,000 pensioners who are eligible for the Mig do not claim it. Not because they don't know about it, but because the system is complex and cumbersome. These are the very poorest pensioners - those means-testing ignores.

It is foolish to accept that means-testing eliminates poverty among older people. The only way to do this is through the payment of a decent universal state pension, free from means-testing and linked to average earnings. That's the message we want to get across.
Joe Harris
General secretary
National Pensioners Convention

While admitting that some people milk the taxpayer, I must object that, at the age of 88, I have to fill in forms which are insulting and cynical in content.

They want to know what I earn, what money I have in the house and seemingly what I had for lunch. Please Tony, or Willie, or whoever rules in the next Commons, just give us old folks a future.
Albert Easdale
Thornton
Lancs

GM and rhetorical roots

Polarisation of discussion about agriculture (Eco soundings, April 25) serves the agendas of campaigners, but does little to address how we secure global acces to good quality, safe food.

The 50% increase in food production needed by 2050 cannot come from increases in cultivated land, and higher yields will need to be generated from reduced inputs and with reduced environmental impact. Moreover, global climate change will exacerbate problems in many populous regions where water will be an increasingly scarce resource.

The Global Agriculture 2020 meeting examined these pressing challenges from many perspectives - farmers, consumers, developing country agronomists and economists, academic and industrial researchers - in an attempt to understand what science can contribute. Anti-GM campaigners were present but had relatively little to say, presumably because the conference was not on the single issue of GM but was fostering balanced scientific discussion of a multifaceted problem.

While the drive to sustainable food security must include political, social and economic solutions, a "precautionary principle" urges accelerated scientific research and the development of strategies for the effective application of technologies tailored to local needs. Resolution of the huge problems facing agriculture and food production will require flexible, pragmatic new partnerships between private and public research, governments, charities, NGOs and agricultural communities - not polarising rhetoric.
Professor Chris Lamb
Director
John Innes Centre
Norwich

fields.headline: A 'soft' touch on loans
fields.standfirst: Charities get go-ahead for low-interest investments
fields.trailText: Charities get go-ahead for low-interest investments.
fields.body:
Charities will today be given the green light to use their income or endowment funds to provide "soft", low-interest finance for projects that fit their charitable purposes.

The move by the charity commission follows a report last autumn by the social investment taskforce, which called for clarification of the position on so-called "programme-related investments". According to the commission, charities have always been free to use their resources in such a way.

"People think of it as investment in a purely financial sense, as something through which they have got to generate the best return," says Richard Corden, the commission's head of charity standards. "But it's not something to which the normal strict rules on financial investment apply."

The burgeoning social entrepreneur movement is leading growing numbers of charities to consider if and how they may extend financial support to projects in their fields. Many are thought to have concluded, wrongly, that they must not extend loans at interest rates below those available in the market.

John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, will today set the record straight in an address to the annual conference of the Charity Finance Directors Group, which is supported by the Guardian. He will announce new guidance on programme related investments and say there is "almost certainly scope" for more charities to make them - provided their trustees wish to do so.

The guidance says charities may offer finance from either their income and reserves or any endowment. In some cases, a loan on non-commercial terms may be a better way of achieving a charity's objectives than would be a grant. "Any charity that can give grants can undertake this type of programme-related investment unless it is specifically prohibited in the charity's governing document."

As examples, the guidance says a charity may wish to lend £1,000 to a project at 2%, repayable over 10 years, which would yield an additional income of just over £110 a year for the period of the loan; or it may wish to provide £100,000 from endowment at 1%, repayable over 20 years.

In the latter case, the charity's trustees may be looking for a 4% return on their investment portfolio. But a return of £3,000 less in the first year - falling subsequently as the loan is repaid - would be acceptable if the project offered real help to the charity's beneficiaries.

Corden says: "Many charities, their trustees in particular, have had it drummed into them that, when you are investing charity money, you have got to get the best possible return. That's where the confusion has arisen."

 The guidance, Charities and Programme Related Investment, will be available on www.charity-commission.gov.uk.

webTitle: Malcolm  Dean: Back to front from the centre

fields.headline: Back to front from the centre
fields.standfirst: Malcolm  Dean
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: 'Will a second-term Labour government be as centralist as the first? There were conflicting signals from the top last week.'
fields.body:
Will a second-term Labour government be as centralist as the first? There were conflicting signals from the top last week. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, signalled a radical devolution in the NHS. But the prime minister, in a speech billed as helping councils raise the quality of life, merely promised to let them keep the proceeds from fines for dropping litter or letting dogs foul pavements.

First the good news. Alan Milburn sounded like a true convert. He returned again and again to the need to shift money and decision-taking from the centre to the frontline if the 10-year health plan is to work.

This was the same Alan Milburn who, only a year ago, was promising personally to sack under-performing managers and send in hit squads to under-performing units, and who had so little faith in NHS staff that he took special powers to "direct" where the extra £600m allocated to health in the budget should be spent.

Now he speaks of staff feeling "disempowered or, worse, disillusioned", of creeping centralisation that had crowded out local innovation, of frontline staff needing to be "the architects of public service reform" if they are to be its ambassadors. Every hospital, health centre and GP surgery should get a copy of the speech and frame its many key devolution quotes.

The prime minister was more disappointing. He has never tried to hide his many criticisms of local councils. Indeed, he set them out in a pamphlet - the first on local councils by a serving prime minister - accusing them of inconsistent standards, poor decision-making processes, low turn-outs. But last week was billed as something different.

Blair began on the same theme as Milburn: the need for local people and local government to be in the vanguard. But what he was talking about were clean streets and public spaces. He went on: "These issues may strike some as trivial but they are anything but trivial. They matter to people."

True. But the people are also concerned about central controls. Labour abolished capping and compulsory competitive tendering (CCT). Yet selective capping powers remain, as does the right to withdraw subsidies from excessive spenders. Business rates, nationalised in 1990, still go to the treasury. All that was on offer was a supplementary business rate on a voluntary basis.

No other country is quite so centralised. Local councils now raise only 20% of their spending. Adding in national services (police, health, benefits) shows why 96% of tax is centrally raised. Certainly high minimum standards, to avoid post-code variations, are needed. But let's leave room for some divergence.

webTitle: Homes for the elderly: All round the houses

fields.headline: All round the houses
fields.standfirst: Stephen Bates on the moving experiences of his father
fields.trailText: Stephen Bates on the moving experiences of his father.
fields.body:
In the first 66 years after he moved to Newbury in Berkshire as a young man, my father had just three addresses. In the past four years, since moving into a nursing home in his mid-80s, he has had three more.

It isn't that Dad is awkward or difficult to please; he has always been very phlegmatic in life, accepting what has been thrown at him. It is just that, one after the other, the care homes have closed under him.

Dad first moved into a home in late 1996 at the age of 84, after his diabetes finally caught up with him and he had to have a leg amputated. Prior to that, he had always been very fit and active, looking after an enormous garden for many years in his retirement. But it was clear that his active days were now in the past and that my stepmother, five years older than he was, could not cope with looking after him.

The first home, in a large 1920s detached house built for the Berkshire bourgeoisie and their servants, was very pleasant and well adapted. But after Dad had been there less than two years, the owner decided to close, allegedly tired of regulation by the local social services. The house was sold for demolition and redevelopment, for getting on for £1m.

Fortunately, we managed to move Dad into a similar development just round the corner - again, a large 1920s house, all polished brass doorknobs, grandfather clock in the hall loudly ticking away the minutes. Dad had a sunny room overlooking a large garden. For two years, he was very happy there.

Then, this spring, the owners decided they too would sell up, after 30 years in the business. You couldn't blame them exactly - they were in their 70s themselves and had had enough. Their property, too, will be sold for redevelopment and, since it is on a large site in a prosperous part of a town with a booming hi-tech economy, it presumably will fetch another seven-figure sum.

Each time, the burden of regulation has been cited as a reason for closing down. The obligation to fit en suite toilets in every room is seen as a terrible blight, though this regulation will not come in for several years. The corollary that such luxuries would make life a bit easier and more pleasant and private for residents is never, of course, mentioned. It is always the cost and inconvenience to the owners. It is said that the old folk don't want all that fuss and bother. They are people, after all who lived through the Blitz. They can take it!

So the little community in the home is now scattering to homes as far apart as Nottinghamshire and Dorset. One elderly lady has lived in the house ever since it opened for business.

Each time Dad has had to move, the family has again started a trawl of local care homes to find a place for him to live. The pool is shrinking and getting more expensive each time, and now we eye the owners to see whether they are likely to stay the course almost as much as whether they will look after Dad properly.

This time we have found him a very pleasant room (the cost makes him wince; it's almost as much in a month as his annual salary when he retired in 1977) in a house on the other side of town. He can look out of his window under the eaves across fields to the local castle ruins.

Earlier this month, though, he was 89 and the moves are getting more strenuous. Each time, a little bit more of his past is eradicated, a few more possessions discarded, friends and neighbours shed. After we moved him on a Friday a few weeks ago, on the Saturday evening he was rushed to hospital with a suspected stroke. It probably wasn't - though no one seems very sure what did happen, except that he had been stressed by the move. A week of confusion and discomfort followed in the Royal Berkshire hospital in Reading, 20 miles away.

Dad remains phlegmatic and resigned, but we wonder how many more times now he would be able to cope with the stress of moving.
