fields.headline: Wiped out
fields.standfirst: Activist's anti-charity website blocked
fields.trailText: Activist's anti-charity website blocked.
fields.body:
A disability rights activist who ran a website criticising a leading charity has relinquished the domain name www.leonard-cheshire.com, after a ruling by the World Intellectual Property Organisation (Wipo).

After lengthy investigation of a complaint by charity Leonard Cheshire, a Wipo panel - appointed by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers - has come down in the charity's favour. The panel says the site is confusingly similar to the organisation's trademark; that the activist, Paul Darke, has no right or legitimate interest in the domain name; and that it has been registered and used by him in bad faith.

The site, which opens with the slogan "Say No to Leonard Cheshire", was described by Darke in his written response to the panel as "a work of political interventionist art" and an act of political freedom of expression. He argued that the site was "clearly anti-Leonard Cheshire", stating that he used the name "as a valid way to draw attention to criticisms of the organisation".

Darke, who has spina bifida and uses a wheelchair, is a conceptual artist who did a PhD on the stereotyping of disability on celluloid. In a recent work, Health, he shows three wheelchairs nailed to three crosses. He founded the website www.outside-centre.com, which shows work by disabled artists.

He registered the contested domain name last autumn, shortly before the end of a two-year contract as the charity's national advocacy officer. He also served on the charity's public affairs committee, from which he resigned. He subsequently offered to sell the name to the charity for £40,000 to fund a holocaust memorial to disabled people.

Darke advocates for disabled people who want to secure funding to live independently and not in institutions. He claims Leonard Cheshire institutionalises those with disabilities. He admitted to the panel that his site was intended to damage the charity, disrupt its interests and raise questions about funds it received from the national lottery. The site has had 51,000 "hits" since launching last October.

"The site is about the Leonard Cheshire Foundation, and all that it represents socially, politically and economically in the lives of disabled people," he said. "Thus, the domain name... As for damaging Leonard Cheshire Foundation, that is the aim of the site as an act of political art in a free society."

A spokeswoman for the charity says: "Leonard Cheshire respects Dr Darke's right to criticise the organisation and offered to pay the administration charge for him to move the site to another address. Sadly, he would not agree and we have challenged that registration by submitting a complaint to an arbitration centre. We were forced to take action as the site was becoming more misleading, inaccurate and increasingly unpleasant towards individuals."

The address leonard-cheshire.com will now house the site of the Friends of Leonard Cheshire in Washington, US, which works on behalf of disabled people throughout the Americas.

webTitle: Homes for the elderly: Going concerns

fields.headline: Going concerns
fields.standfirst: Lives are being put at risk by the closure of homes for elderly people. But for some owners, shutting down can mean cashing in
fields.trailText: Lives are being put at risk by the closure of homes for elderly people. But for some owners, shutting down can mean cashing in.
fields.body:
There's an old joke that goes: "What comes out of Cowes backwards? The Isle of Wight ferry." In a new twist, if the Isle of Wight County Press is to be believed, the ferry could soon be taking frail elderly people on a last trip to the mainland because of an acute shortage of care home beds on the island itself.

The story is not just journalistic licence. Charles Waddicor, the island council's social services director, confirms the bed shortage problem and accepts that using mainland care homes has been mooted. But he says shipping vulnerable old folk to the mainland could kill them - which is why he is against doing it. He says: "If you move frail, elderly people in this way, something like two-thirds will die within three months."

The severity of the care home problem on the Isle of Wight serves as a microcosm of wider problems across much of southern England - and beyond. There have long been gripes from home owners about the levels of payment for state-funded residents, but there is no doubt that homes are now closing. According to the latest survey by market analyst Laing & Buisson, 760 private and voluntary homes closed last year, with the loss of 16,200 places. A further 2,500 places were lost in local authority-run homes. Overall, the residential and nursing home sector suffered a net loss of 9,700 places.

But who is really to blame? Local authorities, which administer the state funding, are often painted as the bad guys. Community care money is provided through the revenue support grant, but the allocation comes from the Department of Health. It has announced inflation-busting rises for the past five years, fuelling expectations among home owners. But they have received below-inflation fee increases from councils.

The health department figures do stand up to scrutiny. Rises of 5.2%, 7.2%, 4.5%, 5.0% and 5.9% over the past five years of low inflation give credence to the claims of a 12% real terms increase in funding. But the Local Government Association (LGA), representing councils, has some figures of its own. Its recent survey of almost all the 150 social services authorities in England found they were due to overspend on social services by £205m. A staggering 85% of councils anticipated overspending. The figures suggested that while the money allocated by central government for personal social services under the standard spending assessment (SSA) had grown 11.2% since 1998, expenditure by councils had risen 14.2%.

The elderly do not take top priority. The LGA survey found that 64% of the expected overspend was on children's services - hardly surprising as children are a much higher profile area of spending and much more expensive if things go wrong. The harsh reality is that the penalties for injuring or mistreating an elderly person are cheap compared to the penalties for similar neglect of a child.

But the LGA did find that 21% of likely overspending was on the elderly. Mike O'Donnell, a member of the social services panel of the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy, says pressure on coun cils is growing in two ways. More elderly people need services and those already receiving them need more intensive support. The funding also covers those helped at home - the government's preferred option. A person receiving 10 hours' help at home might need just five extra hours - but that represents a 50% increase in the budget. "You might get a 6.5% increase in SSA, but most councils will need to implement a significant cuts package just to balance the budget," O'Donnell says. If they are lucky, they can afford a 2% rise for care home operators.

And councils fear things are about to get worse. The government gave them the gatekeeper role of deciding who needed community care in 1993. Before that, anyone who asked for it got it. Those people are still funded by the Department of Social Security (DSS), but at fees it fixes. In the south, these are significantly lower than council fees. From April next year, those people will transfer to council responsibility. The government has said it will give councils all the additional cash they need, but many are sceptical.

On the Isle of Wight, the difference between the fees is stark. For residential homes, the council's average contract price is £221.28 a week, compared to the DSS average of £161.02. For the council, that will mean finding the £60.26 difference for each of up to 186 residents each week - a potential annual cost of £582,835.

For nursing homes, the difference is even greater. The council's average contract price is £368.65, compared to the DSS average of £227.98, making a difference of £140.67. The 26 existing elderly patients currently on DSS books could cost an extra £190,186. On top of that, the island has 187 other residents under age 65 on preserved DSS rates. Even taking into consideration any additional funding for all these patients from their own resources, the Isle of Wight could easily be facing additional costs of more than £1m a year.

Local authorities claim they simply cannot afford to spend any more on care home fees without further government funding. However, the Registered Nursing Homes Association (RNHA) maintains some councils pay more to their own homes, or to their preferred voluntary sector operators, than they do to private sector homes in the same area.

Association chairman Frank Ursell says councils go out of their way to defend council or voluntary sector homes against competition from the private sector. Walsall council, he claims, recently put its homes out to tender but specifically excluded private sector bidders. The council chose not to comment on this to the Guardian. "When I was at school, they used to call this hypocrisy," Ursell says. Councils cannot pass all the blame on to central government, he argues. "It's poor husbandry of the money by local authorities, on top of poor allocation by the government."

But homes are not only facing this spending squeeze. New standards being phased in from next April will ramp up the costs of running care businesses.

The RNHA's chairman on the Isle of Wight is Kevin Dannett, owner of Springfield nursing home in Shanklin. One of the examples he gives is the new standard that doors used by wheelchair users must be 800mm wide. All his doors are 780mm wide. "Am I going to have to spend my limited resources to make my doors an inch wider?" he asks. If the 244 new standards are policed rigorously, many homes will face huge bills just to stay in business.

Ursell is frank about the situation. Between them, he and his wife have paid just £5,500 in income tax on profit from their home over the past four years - demonstrating how low the margins are. "It has not only taken away my profit," he says, "it has taken away my investment money."

Almost all homes will have to turn to banks for investment cash. But banks, understandably, are not keen to lend money when they cannot see in creased revenue resulting. For homes which have to convert to meet new single occupancy and room size standards, conversion may mean reducing the number of residents - hardly good grounds for lending money.

With high property prices in the south, banks point out that the value of the asset is often greater than the value of the business. "If you get an accountant in, or a banker, and you do the sums, then you should probably just sell up and realise the value of your asset," admits O'Donnell. And for those home owners approaching retirement age, selling for cash is undoubtedly a much more attractive proposition than soldiering on.

In the end, this appears to be the main reason homes are closing. The outcome will be fewer, larger home owners, but they will at least be in a better position to stand up to councils and demand more money - a fact not lost on Bupa, which, with 232 homes and 16,000 beds, is the private sector's largest player.

Only a quarter of Bupa patients are self-funding; the rest receive state support. "Local authorities are effectively a monopoly purchaser as against a fairly fragmented nursing home market," says Peter Ludford, Bupa's care home director. "As more homes close, it will start to put us on a more equal footing. Our elderly deserve a reasonable standard of care and support - but someone's got to pay."

webTitle: Italian Radical starves for party publicity

fields.headline: Italian Radical starves for party publicity
fields.trailText: Leaders of a maverick Italian party have compelled the media to cover their election campaign by going on a hunger strike in protest at being ignored.
fields.body:
Leaders of a maverick Italian party have compelled the media to cover their election campaign by going on a hunger strike in protest at being ignored.

The former European Commissioner Emma Bonino, a senior figure in the Radical party, has scored a propaganda triumph by losing 4kg since Saturday, triggering doctors' concern and accusations of blackmail from the media.

Newspapers splashed images of her sunken cheeks across front pages yesterday but complained she was subjecting them to "psychological violence" and blackmail.

President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, Italy's head of state, pleaded with the media to further boost its coverage of the Radical party to wean Ms Bonino, 53, off the strike.

The health minister, Umberto Veronesi, himself a medical doctor, emerged from a meeting with Ms Bonino to say he was very concerned about her dehydration and softening muscles. "She is in danger."

The Radicals, a tiny, liberal party, say they had no choice but to strike because the country's two main parties had the media stitched up.

In a bitter, closely fought election the government has relied on three state-owned Rai channels, while the main centre-right opposition, led by Silvio Berlusconi, relied on three Mediaset channels, which his family owns.

Italy's general election is on May 13 and parties are scrambling to sway undecided voters.

fields.body:
 Germany Police in Berlin fought a pitched battle with protesters despite the deployment of 9,000 officers on the streets of the capital. Several cars were overturned and two were set ablaze. Molotov cocktails, stones and bottles were thrown at police.

 France Tens of thousands of people marched through town centres around the country in protest at a string of recent mass redundancies by multinational companies.

 Australia Anti-globalisation protesters tried to blockade the stock exchanges in state capitals. Dozens were arrested after violence in Sydney and Brisbane as demonstrators targeted companies such as Nike, McDonald's and Shell.

 Italy Rallies passed off peacefully in advance of a May 13 general election despite threats by leftwingers to ambush Silvio Berlusconi in Naples.

 Norway Protesters threw a cream pie in the face of foreign minister Thorbjoern Jagland during a rally in Oslo.

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Freedom frenzy grips the cows as they get a whiff of new grass after seven months in the barn


Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Freedom frenzy grips the cows as they get a whiff of new grass after seven months in the barn.
fields.body:
I escaped from the farm on Friday evening for a few hours. I received a spur-of-the-moment invitation to join a murder mystery evening at the golf club in Hexham. It was a real hoot and a welcome change to get off the farm and leave everything behind. But was it sheer coincidence that the character I played was named Beryl Sheep?

There is still, after 10 exhausting weeks, no escape from the subject of foot and mouth. Even school homework, a list of spellings, brought us back to the topic. One of the words was assonance, and two of the words the dictionary lists to illustrate the definition of sound resemblance were "killed" and "culled". Culled used to be a farming term, yet is now in daily usage.

Yesterday we rejoiced at a rare and absolutely brilliant morning, with the clearest of blue skies and wall-to-wall sunshine. It cheered us immensely but maddened the cattle: they bellowed all day, informing us that they wanted to be let out to the pastures. Some of the older cows banged on the huge metal doors in an effort to escape, but the doors held fast.

Turning out the cattle will not be simple this year. Peter and I have almost fallen out over how best to deal with the mechanics of turnout - the logistics resulting from the strict foot and mouth restrictions are proving almost too much.

First we need to reapply for a second occupational licence, which allows us to move animals around our single holding on a day-to-day basis. Our first one limited us to within 500m of the steading (farm buildings), which has meant a lot of crossing fields and other difficulties. The new occupational licences allow a longer distance to be covered within the same holding, which will help enormously.

But nothing will save us from the pandemonium that ensues as soon as we open the cattle-shed doors. It is not just a rodeo, but more like Buffalo Bill's grand extravaganza, as the smell of fresh grass and the chance of freedom after almost seven months inside sends the beasts into a highly vocal, pounding frenzy. Normal practice is to block the road in the yard and down beside the field. The animals hurtle down the road, mooing loudly, to the field where they will stay for the next few weeks. This year we may have to put them in one field, across from the shed, let them calm down and try to move them again from field to field. This method could take days and days, and by the time the last ones are let out they will be even more frantic, having watched and heard their mates go out shed by shed.

It is also a riskier operation as the chance of broken fences, walls and even legs increases every time we try to move them on. Unfortunately, our Limousin cross cattle have always been particularly hot-headed and despite their daily feeding and bedding throughout the long winter, they never seem to quieten. The slightest change in routine can set them off into a bucking and bolting session over which we are powerless - the foot and mouth regulations mean absolutely nothing to a beefy half-tonne bullock in full flight.

We have posted our census form and the next hefty task in the paperwork department will be the annual IACS (integrated administrative control system) form listing all our land and forage hectares. The forage area refers to all the fields that can be grazed. We normally take this form to Carlisle to be checked, but this year it will have to be sent by recorded delivery. The deadline is May 15.

Another of our neighbours has had an unwelcome scare. A phone call from the control room at Kenton Bar informed them of an inspection by a Maff vet. This was triggered by a coal lorry which came to them after previously calling at a farm confirmed later as infected premises. After a check, all was pronounced well.

Peter is unloading the fertiliser from a lorry. We only use a small amount to encourage grass growth in the best fields and ensure we have sufficient hay and silage to last the winter.

A final thought: a local vet thinks Phoenix the calf could not have lain outside for five days with her dead mother as she was in far too good a condition. He wonders if Phoenix was a set-up, or if she was simply hidden? She is very tame and takes her bottles of milk so sweetly. Most of us who have dealings with cattle know that few calves are so immediately amenable.

 The next On the Farm will be on Friday. The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland.

webTitle: Oliver Burkeman meets the lottery losers

fields.headline: It could've been you
fields.standfirst:
When a big lottery prize goes unclaimed, dozens of people always call in to say they've lost the winning ticket. But Martyn and Kay Tott stood out in one major way - Camelot believed them. So how come it didn't pay up? Oliver Burkeman meets the couple who lost out on £3 million

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: When a big lottery prize goes unclaimed, dozens of people always call in to say they've lost the winning ticket. But Martyn and Kay Tott stood out in one major way - Camelot believed them. So how come it didn't pay up? Oliver Burkeman meets the couple who lost out on £3 million.
fields.body:
On the Monday night in March when Camelot announced that somebody in Watford, or maybe St Albans, had failed to claim a jackpot worth £3,011,065, 115 people rang the national lottery operator to say the prize was theirs. Mostly, they were the chancers the company's security department has come to expect whenever the 180-day deadline for unclaimed money draws close: the man who would still have the winning ticket if only his dog hadn't eaten it; the fraudsters who seem to think they can get their hands on the cash by just signing on a dotted line, no questions asked.

But amid the usual flurry of calls, Martyn Tott's stood out. The 33-year-old purchasing manager had a particularly convincing tale, pinpointing the time the ticket was bought, the place - a small newsagents' in St Albans High Street - and enough circumstantial detail to persuade Martin Challis, Camelot's head of security, to drive the next day to the cramped first-floor Watford flat Tott shared with his 24-year-old wife Kay, a receptionist. There was only one problem; like all the others who called to claim the jackpot that night, Tott couldn't actually produce a ticket.

Had they known what was to follow - an agonising seven-week switchback of positive and negative signals from Camelot; of paranoia and secret telephone recordings; of depression alternating with barely stifled ecstasy; all in a desperate attempt to prove they were entitled to the money - the Totts might not have bothered to make the call. But they did, and 12 days ago they finally discovered that they had failed: Camelot knew they had bought the ticket, they were told - but they wouldn't be getting their money. Rules, after all, are rules.

"That Monday in March," Martyn recalls, "we got in from work and Kay wanted to watch a video, but I caught the newsreader on Newsroom South East say there was an item on an unclaimed jackpot in our area later in the programme." He called up Teletext, found the relevant page, and there on the screen were the winning numbers for the September 16 draw - their numbers: 6 and 7, their birthdays; 11 for the day they got engaged; 23 and 32 for their ages when they met; and 44, Martyn's grandmother's door number. "Kay just screamed, jumped up and screamed, 'It's our numbers, it's our numbers.' But I immediately thought: we'll have thrown that ticket away. I just felt numb."

Almost two months later, we are sitting in the impossibly plush bar of the impossibly lovely Lainston House Hotel, a luxurious country house retreat outside Winchester. Kay is present, but pleads exhaustion, so Martyn is doing most of the talking. Despite his protestation, he doesn't look at all tired, and is clearly excited by recounting his story. For a brief moment, the two had teetered on the brink of being Britain's Sorest Losers, but thanks to the intervention of Max Clifford PR and the Mirror (no money changed hands) they have been anointed Britain's Unluckiest Couple.

This explains the expressions of celebrity support - everybody from Ulrika Jonsson to Great Train Robber Bruce Reynolds has spoken up in their support; Richard Branson has renewed his ongoing hostilities with Camelot by offering them a free holiday on his private island - and also why they are being put up at Lainston by the Mirror. "This is the sort of thing we might have been doing if ..." Martyn trails off. "But even just to come here for a few days is lovely."

But seven weeks ago, as the possibility of exchanging their £34,000 annual joint income for a life of never having to think about annual joint incomes again flashed before them, things were rather more fraught. Despite Martyn's growing certainty that they had thrown the ticket away, the couple embarked on a microscopic hunt. "We turned the flat upside down, took drawers out, went through personal papers, everything," he says. "You know how sometimes you've got a cup where you put loads of pencils in? Things like that." While Kay went through their wardrobes, checking the linings of clothes, he clambered up to the loft to scrabble underneath the boards he had recently put down. And, for a moment, it looked as if the search was over.

"I found a bag in the corner of the loft, a carrier bag," he says. "I thought there might be an old ticket in it, I suppose, so I took all the stuff out. And there was. There was a ticket at the bottom. I just sat there looking at the back of it for ages. It was like my heart stopped. But then I turned it over and it was from way, way back." It was the first of many emotional precipices over which the couple were to dangle in the folllowing weeks.

Next day, he was combing through the garage and the shed - "for three million pounds, what wouldn't you do?" - when Challis arrived on their doorstep. "I told him, 'I'm pleased to see you, I think,' like a joke, but he just stared at me," Martyn recalls. "He said there was a rule that you can't claim for a lost ticket after 30 days. But then again, he said, 'If you hadn't given the details you gave, I wouldn't be here now.'"

It was the glimmer of hope they were yearning for. Challis swore them to secrecy. "If there's no payment, he told us, you and Kay must never tell anyone. You'll never forget it, but you'll learn to live with it." Within a week, Martyn says, Camelot had carried out checks on ticket sales, confirming the couple's story that they bought 10 tickets in blocks every five weeks at Londis in St Albans - one ticket for each bi-weekly draw. "They said they were 101% certain," Martyn says. But for a second week, nothing happened.

Paranoia set in. The purchasing manager in Martyn took over and he started to treat the jackpot like an unpaid invoice, logging in detail his every fruitless call to Camelot. He borrowed telephone recording equipment from a friend under the guise of needing evidence for a mail-order dispute. "I was thinking, 'Hang on - what proof have I got that any of this even took place? If this is just Camelot versus a disgruntled punter who says they lost their ticket, what chance have we got?'"

Then, finally, Challis called with a new request. Camelot needed proof that the couple were who they said they were: pay slips, utility bills, mortgage details, bank statements, wedding and birth certificates. "I thought, well, this is intimidating - but why do all this if it wasn't pretty much sorted out? I thought Camelot had just told him, 'Go back and just be certain they're not fraudsters.'" They were thrilled, convinced they were on the verge of winning.

That weekend, they broke their self-imposed rules and allowed themselves to fantasise. In a dreamlike, near-hysterical state, they started to plan what to do with their millions. Of course, there would be lump sums for the family, and treatment for Martyn's father's arthritis, but there would also be luxuries. "We're not the sort of people that would get a mansion and a Ferrari," Martyn says, "but something with four or five bedrooms in a nice area, your average £30,000 car, one of those new Audi TT Quatros?" Giggling, they drove around Theydon Bois - "where Rod Stewart lives" - fantasising about houses costing £500,000.

But then, agonisingly, nothing did happen: Camelot fell effectively silent for four weeks. Kay couldn't sleep; Martyn drank more than he usually did - nothing calamitous, just the indistinct chaos of a life on hold. They started to argue. "We were starting to fray a bit," says Martyn. "We were bickering all the time. One person would ask the other what they thought was going to happen next, but of course neither of us could answer that." Their parents, still in the dark, began to worry. "They thought there was something wrong with out marriage, there was this atmosphere between us. It was all we could talk about between ourselves but we were desperate to tell someone." In the end they told their parents, swearing them to secrecy on Camelot's instructions. They kept on showing up at work as if nothing was out of the ordinary, and waited.

It was a call from Challis, two Thursdays ago, that ended the waiting. Kay had a towel around her head, preparing to go out; Martyn was running a bath. But Challis was calling them from his car outside their house and wanted to come in, so Martyn set up his recording equipment in the kitchen in a hurry. "He said he had bad news: rules is rules, and no exception can be made in this case," says Martyn. Camelot, Challis explained, had spent the last weeks "legally testing" the 30-day rule in consultation with the creators of the rules, the national lottery commission, and had concluded that their hands were tied. "We were just stunned. We just sat there. Were they testing the rules, or testing our resilience not to crack up? Weaker people would have split up or, I don't want to say it, but someone could have done themselves in over this."

Kay's anger returned quicker than Martyn's. "Challis had a woman with him like a social worker, and all she kept saying was 'I understand, I understand.' This woman who I'd never seen before in my life was saying 'I understand' - I was just boiling up, I felt sick. I was shaking. I just told Martyn, 'Get them out of my house.'" Martyn did not remain stunned for long. By the Monday morning, he was in Max Clifford's office in London.

To the Totts, their experiences with Camelot and their subsequent public statements amount to nothing less than a fight for justice against the lottery's Kafkaesque bureaucracy. They reserve their strongest words for Challis, and for the "30-day rule" on lost tickets, which was not widely publicised when it was introduced in December 1997 to replace a rather more straightforward "no ticket, no prize" policy. "We wanted the truth to get out, to say this is how Camelot behaved to us, and this is how they could behave to you," says Martyn. "We want justice to be done."

If it is difficult to take such grand claims at face value, it is equally hard not to feel sympathy. The Totts have been caught in the contradiction that makes the lottery function - the insistence that it's all just a bit of fun, a moment's relief from the daily grind, overlain with the unspoken riposte: yes, but it could change everything forever.

It was the former thought that explained why they didn't check their ticket that week in September - "after seven years, you just think well, I buy a ticket, but I'm never going to win a blooming thing" - but it was the latter that got them hoping. "It's not only about the money," says Kay. "We were happy before, and we'll be happy again. But if they'd have told us that first night there'd be no money because we had no ticket, we'd have been gutted, but at least we could have got on with our lives."

fields.headline: Why I was there
fields.standfirst:
Opinions from people who were there

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: Shaggy, 18, a factory worker from Peterborough
fields.body:
Shaggy, 18, a factory worker from Peterborough

I'm here to express my opposition to third world poverty and to protest about environmental issues. I'm also giving out peaceful protest leaflets and T-shirts in the hope that we can raise awareness but keep the day as trouble-free as possible. Of course there are factions that want violence, but I've been very distressed to see the way that the police and the media have concentrated on that. Every time there's violence, that just clouds things.

Niki Adams, 37, from London, campaigner for Wages for Housework

We want payment for all the caring work that women and children do across the globe, as well as equality of pay for all. We need to transfer the millions currently allotted to defence into the essentials of life: decent pay, paid maternity leave, and the abolition of third world debt. Women pay the highest price for globalisation and third world poverty. They do two-thirds of the world's work, much of which is low-waged or unpaid. Multinational companies need to reform their pay structures. Why is a sweatshop worker in India not given the same rate of pay as a worker doing a similar job in the west?

Ronny, 27, from London, caterer

I've made veggie burgers to hand out to the Critical Mass cyclists after they've finished their action. I'm involved in campaigning on animal rights, and I've set up outside McDonald's because that company represents, for me, the very worst side of global capitalism. Think of the number of people who are touched by a big corporation like this, from the parents who have to fork out for their kids to eat there, because of their targeted advertising towards children. All for food that doesn't fill people up and is bad for them.

June Williams, 50s, from London, retired

I came here to show solidarity, and in defiance of the mayor of London, who wants us to stop feeding the pigeons in Trafalgar Square. I suspect that Westminster city council is desperate to get rid of this square, get rid of the pigeons and replace it with something altogether more corporate. It's a free space for poor families to come to, and there aren't many other areas like that in London. It's not enough to stay at home and grumble. You realise that that's not going to change anything.

Tym Ellis, 21, from Twickenham, south-west London, works in a toy shop

I came to the May Day action last year, and I really liked the atmosphere. Everyone was relaxed and it was really chilled out. Similarly, I've really enjoyed this morning. I'm here to make my voice heard about globalisation - all the cliches I suppose - third world debt, anti-capitalism, the environment - but it's important for me to be here. It's good to feel part of something, part of protests and concerns that are happening all over the world.

Joel Hirsch, 52, post office worker from London

I've just popped out from work in my lunch break. The politicians are all the same, turning a blind eye to the multinationals and what they're doing to the world. But people are beginning to realise how those companies are having an impact on their lives. I thought that I'd have a lot of arguments with people at the office when I told them that I was coming here, but actually most of them thought it was worthwhile.

Siobhain O'Conner, 18, A-level student from Tooting, south London

I came here to be educated. I don't know much about politics yet, but it seems to me it's all about freedom and choice. I've just been to a demonstration about student debt, demanding grants not fees. Too many people I know are saying they won't go to university because they don't want to get into debt.There are lots of ordinary people here - it's not all hippies and anarchists. It's really important for people to assert themselves.

Leah Barnett, 30s, from London, solicitor

I'm not a member of any particular party or group, and I'm not here for any particular event. I suppose I'm against the whole corporatisation of the world. Look at the shops around here: pretty much every one of them is charging too much, using sweatshops and exploiting its workers. It's actually great to see them boarded up today. The threat of rubber bullets did put me off. But it's more important as a citizen of this country to stand up for people's rights.

Nessa Heroabadi, 20, student from Middlesex

Everyone turns a blind eye to what's going on in the world, yet when people get together to protest about it they all make a big deal about the possibility of violence. There are 800m people starving in the world, but we spend millions on defence and wars. It doesn't make sense. What's most upsetting is feeling like nothing's ever going to change.

Katie Fiander, 16, schoolgirl from Middlesex

I don't want to be violent, but we all have the right to voice our opinion. It upsets me to see people getting violent. What's the point in smashing a window? It's not going to solve anything. The police aren't helping though. It all feels quite aggressive here. All the grown-ups and the police were telling us not to go, but I wanted to see what it was like. I wanted to meet interesting people, and find out what's really going on. It's my future.

Helen Kelly, 35, playwright, from Birmingham

It's my first time at a demonstration of this size. I'm particularly concerned about pollution. I don't drive, and I used to cycle, but I don't any more because it's so dangerous with all the traffic. I also think that raising people's awareness of issues like sweatshops and child labour is important. Something like this focuses these questions in people's minds.

Lola, 24, singer, from London

People are unhappy, seeing what big business has done to the planet. And there's this weird sort of mental exhaustion, as people strive after this dream that they're fed by big business: buy this, buy that. It scares me because you feel that everything's controlled by this massive, faceless organisation, and that every government and politician is intertwined in it.

Think of the number of people who are touched by a big corporation like this, from the parents who have to fork out for their kids to eat there, because of their targeted advertising towards children. All for food that doesn't fill people up and is bad for them. Everyone was relaxed and it was really chilled out. Similarly, I've really enjoyed this morning. I'm here to make my voice heard about globalisation - all the cliches I suppose - third world debt, anti-capitalism, the environment - but it's important for me to be here. It's good to feel part of something, part of protests and concerns that are happening all over the world. The politicians are all the same, turning a blind eye to the multinationals and what they're doing to the world. But people are beginning to realise how those companies are having an impact on their lives. I thought that I'd have a lot of arguments with people at the office when I told them that I was coming here, but actually most of them thought it was worthwhile. Siobhain O'Conner, 18, A-level student from Tooting, south London I came here to be educated. I don't know much about politics yet, but it seems to me it's all about freedom and choice. I've just been to a demonstration about student debt, demanding grants not fees. Too many people I know are saying they won't go to university because they don't want to get into debt.There are lots of ordinary people here - it's not all hippies and anarchists. All the grown-ups and the police were telling us not to go, but I wanted to see what it was like. I wanted to meet interesting people, and find out what's really going on. It's my future. I don't drive, and I used to cycle, but I don't any more because it's so dangerous with all the traffic. I also think that raising people's awareness of issues like sweatshops and child labour is important. Something like this focuses these questions in people's minds. Lola, 24, singer, from London People are unhappy, seeing what big business has done to the planet. And there's this weird sort of mental exhaustion, as people strive after this dream that they're fed by big business: buy this, buy that. It scares me because you feel that everything's controlled by this massive, faceless organisation, and that every government and politician is intertwined in it. webTitle: Britain a nation of business hopefuls

fields.headline: Britain a nation of business hopefuls
fields.trailText: Britain is a nation of frustrated entrepreneurs, with nearly half the population dreaming of setting up in business, research shows today.
fields.body:
Britain is a nation of frustrated entrepreneurs, with nearly half the population dreaming of setting up in business, research shows today.

The US, Poland and Portugal lead international league tables of entrepreneurial spirit, with three quarters of their populations reporting that they would like to be self-employed. Norway is the least entrepreneurial.

There is a big gap between the number of people who tell researchers they want to become self-employed and the numbers who actually do. While more Americans dream about self-employment, the British are more likely to take action. Nearly 16% of the workforce are self-employed compared to 14% in the US.

Professor Andrew Oswald from Warwick University who conducted the research with an American colleague said lack of access to capital is one of the factors holding people back from realising their dreams. Most small businesses are begun with savings or family money.

"An inheritance as small as £5,000 can make a marked difference to the chances of people setting up in business," said Prof Oswald. Lottery winners are also more likely to become self-employed.

Prof Oswald said Labour's baby bonds could potentially fund a generation to set up businesses. "It's an excellent idea in my opinion."

webTitle: Treasury committee fails to bank anything

fields.headline: Treasury committee fails to bank anything
fields.standfirst: Notebook Dozy MPs fail the Barker test
fields.trailText: The Weakest Link came to mind yesterday at Kate Barker's confirmation hearing in front of the Treasury select committee. These occasions would be much more entertaining if the witness were allowed to disqualify the doziest MP.
fields.body:
The Weakest Link came to mind yesterday at Kate Barker's confirmation hearing in front of the Treasury select committee. These occasions would be much more entertaining if the witness were allowed to disqualify the doziest MP.

As always the committee provided plenty of candidates, but yesterday's winner was David Kidney for asking why the Bank can't control the exchange rate as well as inflation. The committee has heard numerous Bank representatives explain that monetary policy can target inflation or the exchange rate but not both at the same time. But, no matter, Mr Kidney plaintively asked yet again whether the Bank could do something about the level of sterling.

In an alternative universe, the trapdoor would have opened under his seat. "Mr Kidney, your question demonstrates you haven't read Robert Mundell's seminal work on the effects of monetary policy in an open economy. You are the weakest link. Goodbye."

The committee's questions on these occasions have become more sophisticated since the first hearings when Brian Sedgemore subjected DeAnne Julius to a protracted grilling over her links to the CIA. But the lack of expertise on the committee makes it hard for MPs to ask the right questions which would expose the professional competence or otherwise of the chancellor's appointees.

No-Faith zone

"And, er . . . shuffle papers, glance to camera right . . . focus! focus! We can now exclusively reveal to viewers that you are unlikely to be tuning into Money Channel for much longer. This is due to a technical disparity between the fantastical financial projections upon which this broadcasting company was sold to the public two years ago and the real world. Shares in Money Channel have now been suspended at 13p, having fallen 97% from their high. Adam Faith, our founder, now explains why the share price graphic looks like his own dicky heartbeat . . ."

The actual story is this. Faith, having pumped up his pretensions to offering serious investment advice through the pages of the Mail on Sunday, teamed up with private client stockbroker Paul Killik and steamed off into the brave new world of digital TV. Alongside his wife Jacqueline and his daughter Katya, Faith wagered 20 grand on the concept of a station devoted to financial news. Killik bunged in just under £14k and even before any deal had been reached to broadcast the channel through any of the digital platforms (and before a broadcasting licence had been obtained through the independent television commission), the fledgling business was floated.

Grand Thornton and Sutherlands acted as advisers, getting investors to pay 22p a share - capitalising the Money Channel at £9m and the combined stakes of Messrs Faith and Killik at a close to £2m.

This initial capitalisation of hope was just the start. It did get a licence, it did get a broadcasting platform and a few people actually watched the show. On the assumption that a good portion of the population would throw in their day jobs and instead tune in to get tips on making a killing on the stock market, the company's value soared to £300m during the tech boom.

What the Money Channel failed to get was advertising. Revenue should have been heading towards £1m a month; instead the company was burning close to that much.

Rumour has it that someone like Ladbrokes will pick up the assets and use the channel's infrastructure for something more proven, like betting. Still, even at yesterday's suspension price, Faith's investment is still valued at £700,000. He might even get his money back. The mugs who bought his story will not.

Vodafone vitality

It is nothing short of gob-smacking: as revealed in these pages today, Vodafone is raising £3bn in new money to fund the next stage of expansion into Spain and Japan. An institutional placing of this size is probably a record in its own right and a shudder will run through the City this morning as investment banks (led by UBS, we suspect) seek buyers for well over one billion new shares.

But the shock here is not about the size of the issue. It is about the timing.

Every financial pundit in town has spent the past fortnight jaw-jawing on whether British Telecom has done enough to get the market's support for a £5bn rescue rights issue - and then up pops Vodafone, saying it plans to raise almost as much before lunchtime today. There could be no clearer demonstration of this mobile company's supremacy in its sector; and no more embarrassing reminder to the board of BT and its myriad advisers over how completely they have failed their shareholders and their customers.

webTitle: Cheney promises big US nuclear power expansion

fields.headline: Cheney promises big US nuclear power expansion
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration is ready to increase America's energy supply by drilling for oil in some of the country's most protected natural wildernesses and expanding the nuclear power industry for the first time in 22 years.
fields.body:
The Bush administration is ready to increase America's energy supply by drilling for oil in some of the country's most protected natural wildernesses and expanding the nuclear power industry for the first time in 22 years.

The vice-president, Dick Cheney, who heads a taskforce set up by President George Bush to look into the US energy crisis, dismissed on Monday night the idea of "conserving or rationing" as 1970s-era solutions to the US's energy shortages.

In a speech in Toronto, Mr Cheney said that "conservation may be a sign of personal virtue, but it is not a sufficient basis for a sound, comprehensive energy policy".

His taskforce's report, asked to find solutions to the energy crisis which has caused power blackouts in California and a rise in petrol prices across America, is expected to be published later this month.

Ignoring international outrage at Washington's decision to pull out of the Kyoto protocol on climate change, Mr Cheney said he would call for oil and natural gas drilling in protected areas in Alaska and the Rocky Mountains, the revival of the US coal industry and the first nuclear power plant-building programme in North America since the Three Mile Island reactor disaster in 1979.

He rejected energy conservation and renewable energy sources as major alternatives, promoting nuclear power as good for the environment since it emitted few greenhouse gases, ignoring the problems of nuclear waste disposal.

This new tact will be greeted with delight by British Nuclear Fuels, the largest designer of nuclear stations in the world.

"America's reliance on energy, and fossil fuels in particular, has lately taken on an urgency not felt since the late 1970s," Mr Cheney said. "Without a clear, coherent energy strategy, all Americans could one day go through what Californians are experiencing now, or worse."

Oil, coal and natural gas would remain the US's primary energy resources for "years down the road", he said.

Drilling for oil was needed in the Arctic National Wildlife Reserve (ANWR) in Alaska, Mr Cheney said. The US needed to build between 1,300 and 1,900 new power plants during the next 20 years just to satisfy existing levels of demand.

These and other projects would be a windfall for energy construction companies such as the Halliburton Corporation, from which he received an income of $36.1m (£25m) in 2000, according to tax returns he filed last month.

A report later this week by the American Council for the Energy Efficient Economy is expected to say that compulsory fuel efficiency measures for cars would save almost three times as much energy a day as could be obtained from drilling for oil in Alaska.

webTitle: Room for growth, Barker tells MPs

fields.headline: Room for growth, Barker tells MPs
fields.trailText: Kate Barker, the newest addition to the Bank of England's rate-setting committee, confirmed her reputation as a dove yesterday, telling MPs that there was more room for the economy to grow without reigniting inflation.
fields.body:
Kate Barker, the newest addition to the Bank of England's rate-setting committee, confirmed her reputation as a dove yesterday, telling MPs that there was more room for the economy to grow without reigniting inflation.

Ms Barker replaces DeAnne Julius, the Bank's leading inflation dove, in June as one of the four outside members of the monetary policy committee chosen by the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Her appointment attracted criticism because of her present position as chief economist to the Confederation of British Industry.

Ms Barker made it clear, however, that she will be an independent voice on the committee. "Once I am on the MPC I will not be in any sense a representative of business," she told backbench MPs on the Treasury select committee.

Asked whether she would vote for higher rates, if the economy needed them, even though it would be painful for manufacturing, Ms Barker said: "I would have no hesitation in deciding in the interests of the whole economy."

Ms Barker indicated she was sympathetic to arguments of the MPC's doves that changes in the economy had reduced the dangers of price pressures building up, although she cautioned there was a lack of concrete evidence.

"Doves, I suppose, are people who believe that because of changes in technology and the labour market, growth can go on for longer without inflationary pressure," she said. "In that sense I incline towards the dovish camp."

Ms Barker's views place her "in the middle camp within the MPC", said Danny Gabay, economist at JP Morgan.

webTitle: Thus says things can only get better

fields.headline: Thus says things can only get better
fields.trailText: Telecoms group Thus yesterday promised shareholders that it had finally turned the corner and was on track to get into the black this year.
fields.body:
Telecoms group Thus yesterday promised shareholders that it had finally turned the corner and was on track to get into the black this year.

The pledge of an underlying profit, built on the back of rising revenues, lower capital spending and greater efficiency, saw the shares climb 10% higher as investors took the view the worst could be over.

Bill Allan, the chief executive, said: "All the numbers are going in the right direction. If we keep on going the right way we have nothing to fear."

Thus spent heavily on building a national network, sought to focus on the business market and now believes it is seeing the benefits of this strategy.

It has picked up clients including BSkyB, GE Capital, Scottish Provident, Intelligent Finance, Royal Bank of Scotland and London Electricity, many in its fast growing data and telecoms sector.

Revenues for the year to the end of March rose by 8% to £233.8m with the second half showing a much faster rate of growth - up 25% to £129.9m.

The focus on the corporate and small- and medium-sized enterprise market meant a switch in sales of the internet business from traditional dial-up services to more business orientated services such as access, commercial web hosting, e-commerce and streaming media.

However the continued cost of spending on building up the network - £158.9m - meant the company was left with a loss before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of £21.4m - though all but £4.1m of that total was clocked up in the first half.

This year Thus is expecting revenues to continue growing strongly - by more than 20%, excluding the interactive services division which is up for sale - while capital spending is expected to fall to around £110m and in the long term should settle down at between 10% to 15% of revenues.

As a result - and provided the economy is not suddenly blown off course - the group is expecting that earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation is expected to be "positive over the year as a whole."

Nigel Hawkins, telecoms analyst at Williams de Broe, said: "Revenues are on target and I think the market thinks the worst really is over now. Thus has got past the peak in terms of spending and things can only get better."

Competition remains tough. Mr Allan says that the company has walked away from a number of pitches for corporate business because "we did not see how we could make any money".

In one case the successful bidder had to buy capacity from Thus and "we did not give it away for nothing".

The completion of the network building programme will not mean heavy job losses as Thus contracted out much of the work. "You won't see much change (in employment numbers) this year, either up or down," Mr Allan said.

He said that the group had received a number of approaches for the interactive services business and hoped to complete a sale by the end of June.

Yesterday's news saw Thus's shares climb 6.5p to 60p - a far cry from the peak of almost £8.50 in the spring of last year.

"I think what we have shown today and what I hope the market will see is the underlying strength of the business," said Mr Allan.

webTitle: Factories shed labour as output sinks

fields.headline: Factories shed labour as output sinks
fields.standfirst: Britain's factories embarked on widespread job cuts last month
fields.trailText: Britain's factories embarked on widespread job cuts last month as the drop in business triggered by the foot and mouth epidemic and the slowdown in the United States resulted in the weakest performance by manufacturing in more than two years.
fields.body:
Britain's factories embarked on widespread job cuts last month as the drop in business triggered by the foot and mouth epidemic and the slowdown in the United States resulted in the weakest performance by manufacturing in more than two years.

The Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said employment in industry fell sharply in April, with firms reporting an increased use of in voluntary redundancies in order to cut costs and boost profitability.

City analysts said the CIPS purchasing managers' index showed that the 3,000 job losses at mobile phone company Motorola were evidence of a more general malaise.

With output falling and order books weakening, manufacturing was slipping into recession, they said, and predicted that bad news from the CIPS tomorrow about the hitherto robust service sector would lead to a further cut in interest rates by the Bank of England's monetary policy committee next week.

George Buckley, UK economist at Deutsche Bank, said: "This survey should probably come with an 18 certificate. The report clearly shows a sector sliding into recession."

The CIPS reported across-the-board weakness in April, with firms responding to lower demand by running down stocks and, for the 18th month in succession, reducing pay rolls. The PMI fell from 49.8 in March to 47.8 last month, with any reading below 50 an indication of recession.

 Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George defended the European Central Bank's decision not to cut interest rates, after criticism from the US that Europe should be doing more to stimulate global recovery.

He told the a House of Lords committee that the ECB was "at least as aware as we are of the potential impact of the slowdown in the US".

City analysts said the CIPS purchasing managers' index showed that the 3,000 job losses at mobile phone company Motorola were evidence of a more general malaise. With output falling and order books weakening, manufacturing was slipping into recession, they said, and predicted that bad news from the CIPS tomorrow about the hitherto robust service sector would lead to a further cut in interest rates by the Bank of England's monetary policy committee next week. George Buckley, UK economist at Deutsche Bank, said: "This survey should probably come with an 18 certificate. The report clearly shows a sector sliding into recession." The CIPS reported across-the-board weakness in April, with firms responding to lower demand by running down stocks and, for the 18th month in succession, reducing pay rolls. The PMI fell from 49.8 in March to 47.8 last month, with any reading below 50 an indication of recession.  Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George defended the European Central Bank's decision not to cut interest rates, after criticism from the US that Europe should be doing more to stimulate global recovery. He told the a House of Lords committee that the ECB was "at least as aware as we are of the potential impact of the slowdown in the US".

webTitle: EMI insists it can survive as a solo act

fields.headline: EMI insists it can survive as a solo act
fields.trailText: EMI, the music company behind Robbie Williams and the Spice Girls, yesterday sought to assure investors of its prospects as an independent company after aborting its second planned merger in eight months.
fields.body:
EMI, the music company behind Robbie Williams and the Spice Girls, yesterday sought to assure investors of its prospects as an independent company after aborting its second planned merger in eight months.

The company said discussions with BMG, the music arm of German media group Bertelsmann, had ended due to fears the deal would not get past regulators without significant sacrifices being made.

"The conclusion we came to was that it quite simply wasn't possible," said EMI group chairman Eric Nicoli. "It's frustrating because this was a great opportunity. But we were always realistic going into this deal and there's a limit to how long it's worth pursuing before you want to remove the uncertainty hanging over the business."

It would be "extremely difficult if not impossible" for a merger of any of the big five music groups to get past Brussels and Washington in the current market. EMI announced the £10bn BMG merger plan five months ago, soon after abandoning an agreement with Warner Music of the US because of competition issues.

EMI rushed out figures before its full-year results, due in three weeks' time, to demonstrate its future as a standalone business. They show a 12% increase in sales to £2.7bn in a generally flat market, while pretax profits were an estimated 6% higher at £260m. Mr Nicoli said they were evidence that EMI had not been too distracted by the merger. EMI shares inched 1p higher to 445p.

"Although we came straight out of Warner and into BMG we are not obsessed with doing a deal for a deal's sake. Both of those had blindingly obvious rationales," he said.

The collapse of a second agreement is a blow to Mr Nicoli, who took the helm at EMI in 1999, but he was not held entirely to blame.

"There's not much more he could have done," said one media analyst. "He led the business toward two potentially good deals which failed because of the regulators, not because of anything he did.

"We believe EMI is still viable as a standalone company. The fundamentals are good, the market share is improving in the US and there are cost savings still to be gleaned despite the merger falling apart. EMI still has to be subject to bid speculation, although it would have to be from a company outside the music industry."

Thomas Middelhoff, chairman of Bertelsmann, also appeared upbeat. "Our companies will now continue along their respective paths.

"The music industry has really gotten going. It is finally building digital services that are user-friendly, convenient, fast and mobile. In these stormy times, there exists a particularly high demand for the core competence of music companies like BMG."

fields.headline: No1,871
fields.standfirst: Leeds
fields.trailText: Leeds.
fields.body:
You sure that's Leeds? Ferry, cross the Mersey ...

Isn't that the Liver building? Cos this land's the place I love ...

Get me the reader's editor! Leeds - home of the Beatles, Roger McGough, Robbie Fowler...

The LIVER building. There could be a clue in the name. Ah, I get it, you're trying to tell me something.

Ahem, yes ... I think maybe you've got a bit muddled. That's not Leeds, it's Liverpool. Well, y'know, confusing Leeds and Liverpool is very hip at the moment. It's very now. It's what all the celebrities are doing.

Really? Well OK. Just one. Who?

Nelson Mandela, who was visiting Leeds on Monday, in order to be made a freeman of the city. What? I wouldn't make him a free man of the city! Who knows where he'd roam off to? He'd be in Huddersfield in no time, calling it Halifax. You want to keep him where you can keep an eye on him

What did he say exactly? He declared, in front of the 5,000 people who had thronged to the Millennium Square: "I have already thanked the people of Liverpool for the honour of being a citizen of this great city."

Oops. Exactly.

Well, they're almost the same... Virtually interchangeable.

They're sort of the conjoined twins of cities. Yes, yes, ignoring the 90 miles or so (or indeed the Leeds-Liverpool canal) between them. It's easy to see how a former president of South America might get confused.

South Africa. Yeah, yeah, whatever.

Let's just hope Venice don't make the same mistake tonight, eh? Venice, Leeds, big footy showdown? Oh right. You mean Valencia.

Sure, sure. Sorry about that. I always get canals and oranges confused, yunno? Yeah, I know. That happens when you're 82.

I'm 82? Yup.

Where am I? You're in Pass notes, in the Guardian.

What! Am I? I could've sworn this was the Times.

webTitle: Veterans invade Zimbabwe's May Day rally

fields.headline: Veterans invade Zimbabwe's May Day rally
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's war veterans took over Zimbabwe's May Day rally yesterday and gave notice of further factory invasions.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's war veterans took over Zimbabwe's May Day rally yesterday and gave notice of further factory invasions.

The rally, organised by the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions, began with union leaders criticising the Mugabe regime and receiving enthusiastic cheers from more than 6,000 workers.

Then a few hundred veterans took over the stage and vowed to renew their attacks on scores of leading businesses.

Several hundred more joined the trade unionists in the stands at the Harare football stadium. The two groups were kept apart by the police.

The leader of the factory invasions, Joseph Chinotimba, arrived in a government vehicle driven by a police officer and was protected from the crowd by riot police.

He told the rally: "The ZCTU is a political party and has failed to represent you. Whatever you want as workers, whether MDC or Zanu-PF, come to comrade Chino for help."

The labour movement is the bedrock of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), and for years urban workers have been Mr Mugabe's most vociferous critics. His Zanu-PF party did not win a single urban seat in the parliamentary elections last June.

The ZCTU president, Lovemore Matombo, told the rally: "The unions remain the true representatives of the workers, no matter what others do.

"If the war veterans want confrontation, they will get it. If it is war that they want, then we will fight for our rights. They can kill us, but for how long can they do that?"

He cut short the programme, saying: "We will not be intimidated by anyone ... Go back to your homes, refrain from violence and provocation."

Mr Mugabe, 77, recently announced that he will stand for the presidency again next year, and he is trying to wrest back the workers' support by sending his war veterans into factories and businesses.

On the pretext of settling old labour disputes, they have beaten and humiliated managers, both black and white, and extorted millions of dollars, hoping to undercut the unions.

The targets they named yesterday included the electronics company Philips and the state railways, the state post and telecom corporation, and the national bus line.

webTitle: Israel: Settler dies in copy of father's death

fields.headline: Settler dies in copy of father's death
fields.standfirst:
British woman's family is undeterred by second killing

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Jewish settler whose wife is from Britain was shot dead in a Palestinian ambush yesterday, only three months after his father died in a similar shooting.
fields.body:
A Jewish settler whose wife is from Britain was shot dead in a Palestinian ambush yesterday, only three months after his father died in a similar shooting.

Assaf Hershkovitz was wearing the bullet-proof vest his mother gave him after his father's death, in the hope that it would protect him.

Hershkovitz, 30, whose widow Hela is British, died almost instantly when men hiding on a hillside fired at his pick-up truck near his home in the West Bank town of Ofra. Two bullets hit him in the neck.

He had left earlier than usual to fill up with petrol before going to his job with a fence-building company.

He leaves a son, Re'i, five, and a daugher, Shvut, four.

The Islamic fundamentalist group Hamas claimed responsibility, saying he was shot in retaliation for the explosion in Ramallah late on Monday night which killed three Palestinians, two of them children, and levelled a two-storey house.

The Israelis said the third person killed, Hassan al Kadi, was involved in the murder of an Israeli teenager enticed to the West Bank to meet a Palestinian woman he had corresponded with on the internet.

In other incidents a Palestinian policeman was killed in a shoot-out with Israeli troops in the Gaza Strip, and another Palestinian was shot as a suspected collaborator at Qalquilya in the West Bank.

Ariel Sharon was seen as the champion of the settlers when he was elected prime minister in February, but settler organisations are becoming disillusioned with his failure to either protect them or inflict harsher punishment on the Palestinians.

Women in Green, a nationalist group set up in opposition to the Oslo peace agreement eight years ago, will hold its first demonstration against him outside the knesset today.

Its co-chairwoman, Nadia Matar, said : "We grieve over the death [of Hershkovitz] but it strengthens us. Ariel Sharon has no mandate for talks, only to crush the enemy and to send Arafat back to Tunis or wherever it may be."

The presence of almost 200,000 Jewish settlers in more than 150 towns and villages in the mainly Palestinan West Bank and Gaza Strip is one of the main obstacles to peace.

Hershkovitz's sister Yasmin said that in spite of the two deaths in the family since it moved moved to Ofra 14 years ago, they were determined to stay. "If we leave and go someplace else, then they will shoot us there."

A neighbour, Ruchi Avital, who was born in London and arrived in Ofra a year before the Hershkovitz family, said that, far from persuading settlers to leave, the uprising had seen the arrival of 10 families in Ofra.

webTitle: South Africa unions threaten split with ANC

fields.headline: South Africa unions threaten split with ANC
fields.trailText: South Africa's powerful trade union confederation, Cosatu, has warned that its longstanding alliance with the ruling African National Congress is in danger of "dying a natural death" because of growing differences with Thabo Mbeki's government.
fields.body:
South Africa's powerful trade union confederation, Cosatu, has warned that its longstanding alliance with the ruling African National Congress is in danger of "dying a natural death" because of growing differences with Thabo Mbeki's government.

It is the first time that the union leadership has publicly questioned the tripartite alliance, formed during the anti-apartheid era along with the Communist party. But if the unions were to break away and take a more independent stand - if not become a de facto opposition - it would be a major blow to the credibility of Mr Mbeki's rule.

The government's investigation of three leading anti-apartheid politicians for allegedly plotting to oust Mr Mbeki have highlighted the differences. They also reveal why the president is vulnerable to charges that the episode is an attempt to stifle a challenge to his rule rather than simply a ludicrous error.

Cosatu has been highly critical of the safety and security minister, Steve Tshwete, for naming the suspects - the former ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa and two former provincial premiers, Mathews Phosa and Tokyo Sexwale - on the flimsiest of evidence and called on him to apologise.

While the government has played down the crisis, Cosatu's general secretary, Zwelinzima Vavi, highlighted fears that the accusations are aimed at forestalling a challenge to Mr Mbeki over his contentious economic and social priorities.

Mr Vavi said: "If we do not urgently address the problems in the alliance, it will die a natural death as people lose faith in the alliance as a vehicle for change."

Mr Vavi has been critical of Mr Mbeki's rule in the past. While cabinet ministers remained silent over the president's controversial views on Aids, even though some strongly disagreed, Mr Vavi backed the conventional medical view. The Cosatu leader has also criticised the government's purchase of weapons worth £4bn, and its approach to events in Zimbabwe.

But the individual differences reflect a deeper philosophical division over how the country should be run.

Part of Mr Mbeki's problem is that what are regarded abroad as his achievements are not always seen in the same way at home. Like New Labour, the ANC has undergone a radical image change. Little more than a decade ago it was widely viewed as too entrenched in socialist rhetoric to manage a modern economy.

But while Mr Mbeki has shown a safe pair of economic hands, influential forces within the ANC and its allies are sceptical of the benefits to ordinary South Africans.

The Communist party is too reliant on the ANC to be an effective critic, although it subtly distanced itself from Mr Mbeki yesterday, saying that South Africa should not get hung up on individual leaders. But Cosatu has found it increasingly hard to ignore policies that its leadership fundamentally disagrees with.

The unions concede that there have been important gains for the poor, particularly in housing, clean water and free electricity. But rising unemployment, a wealth gap that has barely narrowed since apartheid, and employment policies seen as satisfying business leaders more than the bulk of South Africans have unsettled the unions.

Cosatu has called a general strike over job losses brought on by privatisation. Officially, one in three workers are out of work but that statistic only counts those who had jobs in the first place.

Dissent is not limited to the unions. Trudy Thomas, a former ANC health minister for the Eastern Cape, said she was uncomfortable about monetary policies which she said were deepening the "abhorrent inequities of apartheid", and resigned from the party.

The ANC described her resignation as a "great shock", and the ANC's chief whip in the region conceded that many others in the party felt similar frustration.

Dissenters also wonder if, while Mr Mbeki has worked hard to build international trust in the ANC's handling of the economy, he has undermined it with "unstable" views on Aids and alleged plots.

webTitle: Man held by Swazi police for 34 murders

fields.headline: Man held by Swazi police for 34 murders
fields.trailText: An alleged serial killer has been charged with the murder of 34 women and children found in shallow graves in Swaziland.
fields.body:
An alleged serial killer has been charged with the murder of 34 women and children found in shallow graves in Swaziland.

David Thabo Simelane, 45, is accused of carrying out the murders over a period of about two years but it was only a month ago that the Swazi authorities said they had a suspected serial killer on their hands after the discovery of a mass grave in a commercial forest 30 miles from the capital.

The bodies of four babies were among the dead. Police say many of the women had their hands tied, were naked and appeared to have been sexually assaulted. About half of the women had been decapitated. Only two of the bodies have been identified.

The Swazi authorities called in six South African police forensic experts after a herd boy looking for a lost cow discovered the first bodies in the Usuthu Pulp Forest, a popular spot for lovers, in the central Malkerns area. A week later, the police uncovered another grave nearby.

A Royal Swazi Police inspector, Ross Maseko, said he believed Mr Simelane was working alone. "We cannot say that the man confessed to the killing, but he is being very cooperative with the police in their investigations. From the responses, we are positive that he is responsible for the killings," he said.

The interlude between the announcement that a serial killer was on the loose and the capture of the alleged murderer led to fevered speculation as to what motivated the crimes.

King Mswati III's mother, who rules alongside her son, suspected demonic activity and urged her subjects to pray for salvation. "The demons have spread everywhere and they can only be subdued by prayer," she said.

webTitle: Philippines senators held after mob riots

fields.headline: Philippines senators held after mob riots
fields.trailText: The president of the Philippines began arresting her political opponents yesterday after rampaging supporters of her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, tried to storm the presidential palace.
fields.body:
The president of the Philippines began arresting her political opponents yesterday after rampaging supporters of her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, tried to storm the presidential palace.

The demonstrations, involving at their peak up to 40,000 protesters, "were funded by people with a political agenda," Gloria Arroyo said on television after sending troops and riot police on to the streets of Manila and declaring a state of rebellion.

The protesters' goal was "to bring down the legitimate government", said the president, looking haggard as she spoke on television after two nights without sleep.

Anyone plotting to overthrow the government, she added, would be "beaten to a pulp".

When a state of rebellion is decreed suspects can be arrested without a warrant. Eleven opposition figures are reported to be on President Arroyo's list as suspected organisers of the protests.

At least two policemen and two rioters were killed, more than 140 people were injured, and 100 protesters were in detention as the worst violence in the city for 15 years continued into yesterday morning after erupting late on Monday.

After failing to force their way into the palace on Monday, the mob of Estrada supporters - mostly young men armed with a motley assortment of weapons - started attacking shops, vehicles and construction equipment. Calm eventually returned last night.

There is no word on how long the state of rebellion will last.

The first opposition leader detained was Senator Ponce Enrile, the former defence secretary. Several other senators were on the list, along with Panfilo Lacson, the police chief under the disgraced former president, Joseph Estrada. Mr Lacson is running for the senate in elections due on May 14.

The rioting broke out just days after Mr Estrada was put in detention charged with plundering the economy.

As the disturbances spread, the one-time hero of the poor was taken from a military hospital where he was having tests to a top-security centre 30 miles from Manila. From there he issued a statement urging calm and criticising Ms Arroyo.

"Exercise restraint in the face of the grave crisis facing our nation today," he said. "We must not give this regime any reason to further trample on our rights of assembly by using excessive force. We must not also give this regime an excuse to declare martial law to ensure its continued stay in power and to further inflict harm on its own people."

He reiterated his long-trumpeted view that he did not resign when he surrendered the presidency in January to Ms Arroyo after massive street protests and the defection of the security forces and much of his cabinet.

Analysts expect Ms Arroyo to survive this first major threat to her fledgling administration, even if the violence continues, because the security forces and most of the legislature are fully behind her.

Referring to Mr Estrada, the head of the Roman Catholic church in the Philippines, Cardinal Jaime Sin, said at a mass yesterday: "Those who abused and manipulated the poor will be accountable to God."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Macedonians riot after burial | Danish police in Cannonball Run | Problem falls on minister's lap
fields.body:
Macedonians riot after burial

Hundreds of Macedonian Slavs torched ethnic Albanian businesses in the country's second-largest city of Bitola early yesterday, just hours after the funeral of four policemen killed by ethnic Albanian guerrillas at the weekend. Eight men died in the weekend attack. Crowds of mostly young men set on fire and destroyed cafes and shops owned by minority ethnic Albanians or Muslim Macedonians.
Reuters
Skopje

Danish police in Cannonball Run

Danish police are out in force to catch speeding drivers on the 13th stage of the annual Gumball 3000 rally. A hundred luxury cars, driven mainly by pop stars and tycoons, aim to race across Europe in the fastest time and with the least speeding fines. The rally is based on film The Cannonball Run.
AFP
Copenhagen

Problem falls on minister's lap

Romania's deputy culture minister must draft a new anti-pornography law as punishment for appearing with a lap dancer at the launch of a sex magazine. The prime minister, Adrian Nastase, said Ion Antonescu had breached the "principles of decency" after a newspaper printed a picture of him leering at a woman in a G-string gyrating on his lap.
Kate Conolly

Late for church driver, 71, fined

A 71 year-old woman has been fined for speeding at 108mph on a South African motorway known locally as "the road of death" to get to church on time. Anna Kemp was fined £85.
Chris McGreal
Johannesburg

Dubai to build new islands

Dubai is to build the largest artificial islands in the world, both of them shaped like palm trees. The Palm Islands project will feature 40 hotels, thousands of homes, and add 75 miles of sandy beaches to the Gulf emirate.
AP
Dubai
