fields.headline: US returns to nuclear energy
fields.standfirst:
String of power stations could enrich British Nuclear Fuels

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Vice-President Dick Cheney threw away 20 years of environmental caution yesterday when he announced that the US would build a new generation of nuclear power plants in the government's effort to overcome a national energy shortage.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington,  Paul Brown and Mark Milner
fields.body:
Vice-President Dick Cheney threw away 20 years of environmental caution yesterday when he announced that the US would build a new generation of nuclear power plants in the government's effort to overcome a national energy shortage.

The US rejected nuclear power after the major accident at Three Mile Island in 1979. It has not built a single new nuclear plant since then, although the industry still produces a fifth of its electricity.

Apart from the fear of an accident, reinforced by Chernobyl in 1986, the industry has been dogged by the problem of dealing with spent nuclear fuel and nuclear waste.

Attempts to create a long-term depository for thousands of spent fuel rods and the accumulated waste of 50 years have failed, in both the US and Britain.

In Russian and Ukraine, which have toyed with the idea of taking the west's nuclear rubbish, the problem is even more acute, and there are doubts about the safety of their reactors and storage sites.

Mr Cheney has shrugged aside these difficulties, and given the government-owned British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL), which two years ago bought the biggest US nuclear reactor designer, Westinghouse Electric, a huge boost.

Westinghouse has designed half the world's nuclear stations and 60% of those in the US. Eighteen months ago, after 14 years of work, its newest design, the AP600, was licensed by the US department of energy, but none has been built.

At 600MW, it is much smaller than previous Westinghouse station: half the size of Britain's newest nuclear station, Sizewell B in Suffolk, also a Westinghouse design.

The idea would be to build a series of them across the US. Mr Cheney said between 1,300 and 1,900 new generating plants would be needed. If Westinghouse built only a few of them it would make BNFL a very rich company.

The US has not revealed the scale of its proposed reinvestment in nuclear power, but Mr Cheney has not concealed in recent weeks that he is determined to give it a prominent role in the report of his energy policy taskforce, which he is due to hand to George Bush later this month.

"If we are serious about environmental protection, then we must seriously question the wisdom of backing away from what is, as a matter of record, a safe, clean and very plentiful energy source," he said in a speech in Toronto.

His report is expected to call on the US to build at least 5 new power plants a year for the foreseeable future to create enough energy to avert the power cuts which have plagued California this year and are expected in parts of north-eastern US, including New York City, this summer.

Neither Mr Bush nor Mr Cheney made any prominent mention of their readiness to embrace nuclear power in last year's election campaign. The Republican party policy platform for the elections did not mention the nuclear option in its nine-point energy plan.

But the nuclear industry has an open line to Mr Cheney through his long-standing friend Tom Loeffler, a former Republican congressman and Washington lobbyist whose clients include the Nuclear Energy Institute, the industry pressure group. Mr Loeffler's former aide Nancy Dorn is now in charge of congressional liaison for Mr Cheney.

Power generators have begun talking to the energy department and the nuclear regulatory commission about speeding up the licensing process adopted after Three Mile Island.

The nuclear industry has no shortage of supporters in Congress. Ten senators, led by the Republican Pete Domenici of New Mexico, are sponsoring a bill to require the US to build new nuclear plants. The senior Republican in the lower house, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, said this week that he "absolutely and firmly" supported new nuclear plants.

The US has 103 nuclear power plants, which produce 571.2bn kilowatt-hours a year, about 20% of the total.

The incident at Three Mile Island, near Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, in which a reactor overheated and its core partially melted, was the worst nuclear accident in US history. No one was killed and the radiation was contained, but it dealt a devastating blow to the industry's credibility.

Recent opinion polls suggest that about two-thirds of Americans favour new nuclear plants, compared with under half two years ago.

In recent months there have been leaks that BNFL wants to build new nuclear stations to replace its ageing Magnox reactors, which are due to close over the next seven years. It is expected to propose in its five-year corporate plan, due soon, that they are replaced with AP 600s.

It is being encouraged by Department of the Trade and Industry officials, who have long been known to favour the expansion of nuclear power, despite the current government policy of letting the industry fade away as the plants reach the end of their design life.

British Energy, the privatised company which operates Sizewell B and the seven British-designed advanced gas-cooled reactors built in the 70s and 80s, is also engaged in the US through a joint venture, but is not thought to be considering new stations.

France relies heavily on nuclear power but the government has decided to diversify. Germany is committed to a phasing out its plants, and no new stations are planned in western Europe. There are about 70 reactors in Russia and eastern Europe, only a handful built to western standards.

webTitle: Croat town now a criminal haven

fields.headline: Croat town now a criminal haven
fields.standfirst:
SAS investigator asks why gangsters and ethnic warriors live freely in Stolac, Bosnia

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: A senior British army officer has called on the international community to bring Croat war criminals to justice in Bosnia.
fields.body:
A senior British army officer has called on the international community to bring Croat war criminals to justice in Bosnia.

Lieutenant-Colonel Hector Gullan of the Parachute Regiment and the SAS led an undercover investigation into the violent intimidation of refugees trying to return to Stolac, in south-eastern Bosnia, in 1998 and 1999.

His report, delivered to the international authorities in Bosnia, called for the immediate arrest of 22 people suspected of violence, extortion and intimidation since the war, and for crimes against humanity during the expulsion of Bosnian Muslims from the area during the war in the republic in 1993.

But the men his report accused are still free, and in many cases, still hold power.

He made his statement yesterday, after receiving an OBE from the Queen for his services in Bosnia.

"Until those that perpetrated these appalling crimes, and who continue to rule the Stolac municipality by fear, are brought to account in the courts - either in Sarajevo or at the Hague [war crimes tribunal] - and made to stand responsible for what they did, this medal will never shine as it should," he said.

Before the war Stolac was a town of 8,000 Muslims, 6,000 Croats, and 4,000 Serbs. Dark red poppies stand out against the bare mountainsides and the scrub vegetation growing in valleys where the stones seem to outnumber patches of soil. The town itself, 40 minutes' drive south of Mostar, was a jewel in this wilderness - proposed for inclusion in Unesco's list of world heritage sites.

Mosques, Catholic and Orthodox churches stood close by. But during the war, and even afterwards, every sacred and secular building belonging to Muslims was blown up, including three medieval mosques and 2,000 homes. The aim was to prevent non-Croats ever returning.

The town is still in ruins, and the ostensible nationalism has become a cover for hanging on to what was looted in the war, and present-day earnings from running guns to Kosovo, cigarettes to Italy, and stolen cars through the Balkans.

Non-stolen goods can also be profitable. As no one dares to come from the capital here to collect taxes, even the sale of everyday consumer goods can line the pocket.

Stark concrete crosses dot the valleys - with little pretence to religious significance. They are intended to mark territory, and keep out Muslims.

Men with dark glasses watch for intruders outside bars and petrol stations. Within minutes, the whole network of war criminals and their protectors can be tipped off.

Beside the road are stocks of building material in strategic places. If Bosnian police make another attempt to seize local criminals - they have failed twice so far - roads can be blocked in moments, and the police ambushed.

While a few war-crimes suspects are in hiding, many of those accused of being torturers at the Dretelj, Heliodrome and Gabela concentration camps are still at large.

Returnees - 2,000 Muslims and several hundred Serbs so far - sometimes see in the street those who abused and expelled them, and now treat them as second-class citizens.

Farida (not her real name) will return soon from Mostar, despite her fear of doing so.

She and her family were among those driven out in 1993. She carried her mother on her back for several miles in the terrible heat of July, with Croat snipers shooting over the heads of those fleeing, to spur them on.

On this death march from Buna to Blagaj, Farida had to choose between saving her mother, or her two young children. To her torment, she abandoned her invalid mother to die in no-man's land.

Fuad (his name has also been changed) describes Dretelj concentration camp that same month. Crammed into a metal-roofed hangar in one of the hottest areas of Europe, some prisoners died in the oven, others went mad. The guards sprayed bullets through the door, for fun.

"The victims are exaggerating," says the current mayor of Stolac, Zdravko Guzman. "It's time to forget about the past, and turn instead to the future.'

A member of the nationalist Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) which wants to break from Bosnia, he laughs when I ask if it would help reconciliation if Croats apologised for destroying the Muslims' homes and mosques: "Why should we apologise? Perhaps someone should apologise to us."

"The people we would like to see arrested" said Harry Leefe, head of the UN refugee agency in Mostar, "are the serious criminals, the ones who organised the concentration camps, the torture, the rape camps; the ones who forced women and children to walk through minefields".

 A bomb yesterday in Vitez - a central Bosnian town dominated by the hardline HDZ - destroyed the office of the Social Democratic Party, which leads Bosnia's multi-ethnic government.

webTitle: Leader: Berlusconi and the Italian election

fields.headline: Unclean hands
fields.standfirst: But Italians may resent foreign criticism
fields.trailText: Anti-Berlusconi views expressed by Le Monde were front-page news in Italy yesterday and a lot of attention has been paid to opinion in Germany, the United States and the UK.
fields.body:
A leader in Corriere della Sera questioning William Hague's fitness for the prime minister's job would cause no loss of sleep at Smith Square - they have enough domestic anxiety to cause permanent insomnia. Yet the converse holds good. Anti-Berlusconi views expressed by Le Monde were front-page news in Italy yesterday and a lot of attention has been paid to opinion in Germany, the United States and the UK. The Berlusconi camp has so far calculated that attacks on their man from abroad are counterproductive. Italian pride will be wounded and even if Il Cavaliere does not get a sympathy vote, the left would find it hard to rouse their supporters to turn out at the behest of foreigners. Even in La Repubblica, on the centre-left, there is a slight sense of resentment that Spanish papers say they have found evidence of wrongdoing by Berlusconi companies, which may lead to an investigation by Baltazar Garzon (the magistrate who sought Augusto Pinochet's extradition from the UK). Repubblica has already published exhaustive studies of the octopoid media empire headed by Mr Berlusconi, to deafening silence at home.

It will not be foreign opinion that prevents Forza Italia winning the general election on May 13, just as two years ago Austrian voters were not deflected from giving Jörg Haider's Freedom party its chance. Foreign opinion is none the less right. A Berlusconi victory would weaken Italy's already feeble contribution to European and G7 debate and action. fields.headline: Taking to the streets
fields.standfirst:
Protesters gained little except air time

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: The siege of Sydney Street it was not. But what was billed as the battle of Oxford Street will doubtless secure its own small place in history. It was mainly a peaceful demonstration punctuated by outbreaks of hostility.
fields.body:
The siege of Sydney Street it was not. But what was billed as the battle of Oxford Street will doubtless secure its own small place in history. It was mainly a peaceful demonstration punctuated by outbreaks of hostility. But it was always permeated by a strong repugnance to power most immediately aimed at the police - because they were there in large numbers - but ultimately at the spectre of international capitalism which Oxford Street had been chosen to symbolise. It was all the more perverse that at one point yesterday evening a good deal of physical aggression was aimed at the nearby John Lewis store. A company which is owned and run by its workers might be thought an unworthy target for attack by protesters against predatory global giants.

The issues behind the protest - ranging from opposition to capitalism in any form through anti-car culture to outrage at the number of children who die in the world every day - were somewhat masked by the unrelenting attention of the cameras. But that did not matter to the marchers because they certainly attracted much more publicity to themselves than if they had taken peacefully to the streets in unannounced groups.

On the whole, the police conducted the operation diplomatically. They knew they had to be there in force after the outraged reaction of politicians a year earlier. They also knew that they too were on trial before the cameras of the world chronicling their every move and reaction as if they were part of a spectator sport. The fact that it ended without excessive violence does not alter the fact the protesters should have exercised their democratic right to coordinated public protest by informing the police in advance and pledging themselves against unlawful activity. There would have been fewer television cameras around, but it would be a salutary reminder to the protesters that the right to protest peacefully is one of the core principles to defend in a democratic society.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The aircraft photographed at Speke airport, page 20, April 30, is not a Dragon Rapide but its four-engined big brother, the De Havilland DH86.
fields.body:
The aircraft photographed at Speke airport, page 20, April 30, is not a Dragon Rapide but its four-engined big brother, the De Havilland DH86.

Sir Richard Body MP is not president of the Wodehouse Society, as we said in a column, Old-fashioned racism and a Britain that never was, page 20, April 20. That honour goes to the actor Richard Briers. Sir Richard bred Berkshire pigs, a breed of which the Empress of Blandings was both example and ornament, and not, as we said, Gloucester Old Spots.

We referred to the saxophonist-playing MP Kelvin Hopkins in a caption story, page 11, yesterday, when we should have said either that he plays the saxophone or that he is a saxophonist. The headline, Sax appeal, over the photograph implied it was of a saxophone, when it in fact showed a clarinet.

Peter Finch gave a winning performance as Oscar in The Trials of Oscar Wilde, rather than an Oscar-winning performance, as we said in an obituary of the director Ken Hughes, page 20, yesterday.

Anni Rainbow was not charged in Harrogate magistrates' court with disorderly conduct, as we said in a report, Veteran nuclear arms protesters win court battle against US base, page 4, Guardian North, April 28. She was charged only with obstructing the highway and was acquitted.

webTitle: Germany: Thousands flee roller coaster fire

fields.headline: Thousands flee roller coaster fire
fields.trailText: The May Day holiday turned into a nightmare at one of Europe's biggest amusement parks when fire swept through a wooden roller coaster at Phantasialand in Brühl, near Cologne, in western Germany.
fields.body:
The May Day holiday turned into a nightmare at one of Europe's biggest amusement parks when fire swept through a wooden roller coaster at Phantasialand in Brühl, near Cologne, in western Germany.

Fifty-four people were injured as the fire spread, and thousands fled in panic. More than 150 passengers had to scramble down 60-foot (18-metre) ladders to escape the flames. Firefighters with 100 appliances from around the region were brought in to put out the fire.

Earlier reports of deaths were dismissed by Cologne's police chief, Winrich Granitzka, who said that a helicopter which flew repeatedly over the site - one of Germany's most popular recreation sites - saw no bodies. But officials said they could not be certain until the site had been cleared.

"We were on the train when a man behind us shouted 'fire!'" a boy told Info Radio of Berlin, "and I turned and there was suddenly a ball of fire behind us, and grabbed my friend and told him we had to jump off."

There were 150 passengers on the roller coaster when the blaze began, and they used an 18-metre emergency ladder to climb out. Eighty rescue workers were on the scene within minutes to help.

Witnesses said burning sections of the wooden tracks flew hundreds of feet through the air, setting light to other buildings in the park.

Some visitors frantically pulled down a fence to flee. Pictures on German television showed 10 burned-out carriages at the top of the track.

"We just barely avoided a catastrophe," Mr Granitzka said. The authorities excluded arson, saying the fire was caused by a technical fault, probably a short circuit.

The park's founder, Gottlieb Loeffelhardt, said he thought it likely that a cable fire in one of the cars activated the emergency brakes, causing sparks.

NTV television showed the singer Michael Jackson visiting Phantasialand in 1996, saying he owned a carousel there. The site has been closed until further notice.

fields.headline: German gspel according 2 txt msg
fields.trailText: The world's first mobile phone religious service will ring out across Germany this week, the brainchild of a evangelical minister who is hoping to lure young people back to the church.
fields.body:
The world's first mobile phone religious service will ring out across Germany this week, the brainchild of a evangelical minister who is hoping to lure young people back to the church.

The 45-minute service at the Hanover Evangelical Youth church will be relayed by text message (or SMS) tomorrow afternoon to those who pre-register on a website.

The Reverend Stefan Heinze said he wants to combine technology with tradition to attract those who have not been to church since their confirmation.

"Mobile phones are a hugely popular form of communication among young people, and we wanted to bridge the gap between youth culture and the church," Mr Heinze said.

More than 1,100 people across Europe have registered to take part in the service so far, using the code name "spirit". They have been encouraged to send prayers and thoughts by text message which will be read out during the service. Those without mobile phones can follow the service on the internet.

At 5pm tomorrow an internet company contracted by the church will begin transmitting the service in short, snappy phrases. One example roughly translates as: "God says fear not cos I'v saved u."

"We're making it as succinct as possible," insisted Mr Heinze. "The Our Father requires 325 characters, but seeing as a text message can only carry up to 160, we've had to paraphrase it."

Seven-minute pauses between messages allow time for reflection.

"Of course, this can't replace a traditional service, and you can't explain the world in bites of 160 characters," said Fabian Kirschner, a Hanover A-level student who has signed up. "But a sermon doesn't have to last 20 minutes when a single succinct phrase might do the trick."

The website encourages people to participate wherever they are. "In the park, at home, wherever you can reflect and be at peace," it says.

"We want to reach you; we want to put our message clearly, wherever you are you can send us something ... we are connected, you are receiving - you will be blessed."

The Hanover church has even said it will dip into its electronic collection box to ensure that one phone user who told the website's message board that he had run out of credit still receives the holy word.

fields.headline: Dutch drugs pick up speed
fields.trailText: Dutch officials unveiled radical new plans yesterday to open up drive-through coffee shops selling hashish and marijuana to German drugs tourists.
fields.body:
Dutch officials unveiled radical new plans yesterday to open up drive-through coffee shops selling hashish and marijuana to German drugs tourists.

Weary of being hassled by drug dealers and coffee shop touts in the centre of town, officials in Venlo, near the border, have drafted plans to set up two drive-through drugs shops on Venlo's outskirts as early as next year.

It has been legal since 1976 to buy and use cannabis, hashish and marijuana in any one of the Netherlands' 1,500 coffee shops but none of them have window hatches dispensing soft drugs to hemp fans in a hurry. If Venlo's town council agrees to the plan, such shops could soon become part of everyday Dutch life.

Venlo has five coffee shops which sell soft drugs to the thousands of Germans who pour across the border every week in search of a product they cannot purchase legally at home, but the shops are unable to meet the increasing demand.

Officials believe opening drive-through coffee shops would force drug dealers and touts to peddle their trade away from the centre of town.

"It's not the drug tourists themselves causing the problems, it's the drugs scene around them," said the town spokeswoman, Tamira Hankman. "They attract dealers and create an environment that makes ordinary people feel unsafe."

Some of the dealers are known to sell hard drugs too and locals blame an increase in street crime on the trade.

"On my way home they [the dealers] whisper to me 'coffee shop, coffee shop' and for someone who isn't interested in that kind of thing it can be annoying," one official said.

"This plan is meant to give the people of Venlo more security and freedom and is designed to prevent foreign drugs tourists coming into the centre of town where there are other shops."

webTitle: Former royal aide tells jury of rape attack

fields.headline: Former royal aide tells jury of rape attack
fields.standfirst: Murder accused who worked for Duchess of York says her lover used prostitutes
fields.trailText: A former aide to the Duchess of York told a court yesterday how she was raped by her lover less than 24 hours before he was found stabbed to death at their home.
fields.body:
A former aide to the Duchess of York told a court yesterday how she was raped by her lover less than 24 hours before he was found stabbed to death at their home.

Jane Andrews, who denies murder, described how her partner Tommy Cressman put a pillow over her head, tied her to the bed, and then forced her to have anal sex on the morning of September 16 2000 - the day she is alleged to have stabbed him.

Asked why she had not mentioned this to police at the time of her arrest, Andrews, who was sexually abused as a child, said: "I was so ashamed, I was so embarrassed. I just couldn't talk about it."

The revelation of the alleged rape emerged after the Old Bailey jury of 10 women and two men heard extensive details of the sexual proclivities of Mr Cressman, a wealthy businessman with whom Andrews had been living in his £400,000 Fulham mews house since November 1998.

Andrews, 34, who had worked for the duchess for nine years until 1997, told how her lover, a former stockbroker who owned a company with the former motor racing star Sir Stirling Moss, liked her to dress in "kinky clothing", to tie her up, and to have anal sex.

She also claimed Mr Cressman, 39, used prostitutes he contacted through fetish magazines, two of which, Desire and Stiletto Heel police found in his study and in a cabinet by the side of his bed.

"He was contacting prostitutes and I found a lot of lists and they suggested what he would probably do and costs," she said. "And I found out he used to come back in the afternoon from the office and call prostitutes and masturbate."

While claiming that Mr Cressman was "wonderful" to her "95% of the time", Andrews admitted they rowed throughout their relationship because of her jealousy, his contact with prostitutes, and her pressuring him about the future of their relationship. The prosecution has claimed the Duchess of York's former dresser, whom friends have said made Tom Cressman "her life", stabbed him with a kitchen knife on the night of September 16 after she realised he would never marry her.

Rows also erupted after she found emails of a "strong sexual nature" from Mr Cressman to a woman named Deborah in Las Vegas. In one, which she found in February 2000, her lover described a sexual fantasy in which a woman, dressed in a maid's outfit, black high heels and stockings, ordered him to tie her to a four-poster with the words: "Finish tying me up and rape me."

Describing herself as "very angry and very upset" by the emails, which Mr Cressman allegedly dismissed as "just a bit of fun" and promised to stop. Andrews also claimed he was violent to her on two occasions before their alleged fight which ended with his death. On the first - in September 1999 - he struck her across the face, bruising her, while on the second, in November that year, he allegedly pushed her down the stairs during an argument after which she required hospital treatment.

In tapes of police interviews, played yesterday in court, Andrews, whom the court heard had suffered from bouts of depression, described how her lover was killed during a fight which, she claimed, followed his desire to have sex.

As she tried to sleep, he allegedly curled up to her and said: "Come on, I want to have sex. You know you like it."

Andrews told the police: "I told him: "Don't be so horrible." I tried to push him away and he grabbed me.

His approach came after the alleged assault that morning, during which, Andrews said, she was forced to have anal sex. Following his second approach, she ran to the kitchen to fetch a knife which she placed by the side of her bed.

When he began to hit her, she got out of bed and hit him with his cricket bat, but claimed she had no intention of stabbing him as he came towards her during the fight. "I didn't go out of my way to hurt him, I was just protecting myself," she said in police interviews. "I was holding the knife and he came towards me. I don't know: it just went into him. It must have done."

Andrews also claimed that, when she fled from the house to drive to the west country - where she was found four days later - she believed he was unharmed.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Slimline home goes on sale
fields.trailText: For sale: des res on picturesque Scottish island. Suit skinny type.
fields.body:
For sale: des res on picturesque Scottish island. Suit skinny type.

The house with the world's narrowest front went on the market yesterday with barely enough space to hang the estate agent's sign.

The property on the island of Great Cumbrae off the Ayrshire coast measures just 3ft 11in at its narrowest point. Downstairs there is just enough room for the front door and upstairs there is a single window.

The house, shaped like a slice of cheese, is known locally as The Wedge.

The owners, George and June Allison, bought it almost 20 years ago before its record-holding potential was realised.

Mrs Allison, 57, said they were selling because her husband George, 65, was retiring and they wanted to enjoy more leisure without having to look after the house, which they have been renting out.

"It goes from the smallest point and opens out," she said. "Downstairs there is a small porch and you walk through into a kind of studio-lounge-cum-kitchen. Then you go upstairs and there is a bathroom or shower-room, and then there's a bedroom. I think the bedroom is about 17ft long."

The house, which is being sold for £27,000, was about 22ft long and 11ft wide at its widest point, she said, adding: "It's lovely, it's unique, it's something you have to see."

Mrs Allison, who has lived on the island with her joiner husband for about 30 years, said they had had no idea of the property's record-holding potential when they bought it.

The issue came to light when a story appeared in the Glasgow Herald on the narrowest house, which was supposedly in the south of England.

An architect friend suggested they should measure The Wedge as he thought it might be narrower.

The front of the house proved to be only 47ins - narrower than the house mentioned in the article - so Mrs Allison said they contacted the newspaper and soon had a listing in the Guinness Book of Records.

A spokeswoman for the Guinness Book of Records confirmed The Wedge was listed as having the narrowest house frontage in the world.

Downstairs there is just enough room for the front door and upstairs there is a single window. The house, shaped like a slice of cheese, is known locally as The Wedge. The owners, George and June Allison, bought it almost 20 years ago before its record-holding potential was realised. Mrs Allison, 57, said they were selling because her husband George, 65, was retiring and they wanted to enjoy more leisure without having to look after the house, which they have been renting out. "It goes from the smallest point and opens out," she said. "Downstairs there is a small porch and you walk through into a kind of studio-lounge-cum-kitchen. Then you go upstairs and there is a bathroom or shower-room, and then there's a bedroom. I think the bedroom is about 17ft long." The house, which is being sold for £27,000, was about 22ft long and 11ft wide at its widest point, she said, adding: "It's lovely, it's unique, it's something you have to see." Mrs Allison, who has lived on the island with her joiner husband for about 30 years, said they had had no idea of the property's record-holding potential when they bought it. The issue came to light when a story appeared in the Glasgow Herald on the narrowest house, which was supposedly in the south of England. An architect friend suggested they should measure The Wedge as he thought it might be narrower. The front of the house proved to be only 47ins - narrower than the house mentioned in the article - so Mrs Allison said they contacted the newspaper and soon had a listing in the Guinness Book of Records. A spokeswoman for the Guinness Book of Records confirmed The Wedge was listed as having the narrowest house frontage in the world.

webTitle: Naples: Outcry as sunbathers ignore body

fields.headline: Outcry as sunbathers ignore body
fields.trailText: Holidaymakers on a beach near Naples have appalled Italy by sunbathing, fishing and playing football just metres from the corpse of a drowned pensioner.
fields.body:
Holidaymakers on a beach near Naples have appalled Italy by sunbathing, fishing and playing football just metres from the corpse of a drowned pensioner.

The fully dressed body washed ashore in front of hundreds of onlookers who chose to ignore it rather than interrupt their sunny bank holiday Monday.

A sheet was thrown over the 69-year-old local man, named only as Ciro, as families resumed paddling and picnicking, sometimes pointing and laughing at the waves lapping at his shoes. In a dark suit and blue shirt, the corpse had no identity documents and it took police several hours to trace his widow to the nearby Bagnoli quarter of Naples.

No marks were found on the body, and police said suicide or an accident was the most likely explanation, although foul play was not ruled out. Police removed the body after two hours.

The Catholic church and social commentators said that there was no excuse for the Neapolitans' lack of reaction.

"Not even death can make us reflect. But what society is this? What sort of society are we building?" said the archbishop of the city, Cardinal Michele Giordano.

"To fish or swim a few metres from a body without life is like an alarm bell ringing in our conscience. The true enemy of our time is indifference, of closing our eyes to each other, even those who suffer and ask help."

National newspapers yesterday published photographs of the bathers and articles condemning them.

Similar incidents happened in Trieste in 1997 and Genoa in 1999, but southern Italians had a reputation for humanity and compassion.

"Times are changing. Once Neapolitans would have wept tears for the dead; would have waited in prayer for the ambulance. But these Neapolitans no longer exist," said the Corriere della Sera newspaper. "Today Naples is a city without identity that desperately gropes for new values."

fields.headline: Flower power
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge.
fields.body:
It's damson time. Trees which have scratched against bitter winds through months of incessant rain have suddenly flounced into white starry blossom. The damson trees are alive with small birds, yelling with song. I'd almost forgotten how busy spring is.

Leaves are leaping from those flinty little buds, gloomy stems and huddled roots which weathered the grim winter. With a blue sky and warm sun, it's like this manic-depressive landscape is bouncing up to a new high. Although the foot and mouth nightmare rumbles on, there is another feeling gaining ground. The reduction in outbreaks probably has more to do with a change in the weather than all the insane slaughtering. Many foot paths will be open soon, but the wonderful grove of wild cherries, shining in the morning sun in the corner of a wood is still, tantalisingly, out of reach.

Down at the ford, the stream races over the road again. Brown as beer, its wild, deep song is framed by a stillness of alders and leafing hazel. The footpaths may still be closed, but the weather which clogged the sky-roads from the south has shifted and the magic Africans are back. Swallows zip low over trees and skim across fields. House martins rummage about in last year's nests, chucking out old bits of feather and all the bad feng shui which accumulated there. Coming up the Edge from the ford I heard the two crazy notes which prove that spring has truly sprung. The voice of the cuckoo, clear and bright, rang from a spinney. Then the bird itself flew out, followed by another. Two cuckoos, one calling, one silent, flew over the fields, and a huge grin spread right across the landscape.

fields.headline: Fall in number of childminders
fields.trailText: An "unsustainable" decline in the number of childminders could threaten the government's drive to make good quality childcare available in every neighbourhood, according to a report today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
An "unsustainable" decline in the number of childminders could threaten the government's drive to make good quality childcare available in every neighbourhood, according to a report today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

The report found that the number of registered childminders fell from 106,000 in 1992 to 76,000 in 2000 - a drop of more than a quarter.

The government is preparing to introduce national standards for childminders, backed up by inspections from Ofsted. But the study, by researchers from London University's institute of education, said the system could not rely on an outdated notion that childminding was a service provided by women working for pin money.

Peter Moss, co-author of the study, said: "Childminding largely depends on women being prepared to work at home for low wages. The declining number of childminders suggests that the present situation is unsustainable."

The researchers found that the most common form of childcare for young children whose parents work was pro vided by relatives and friends. This was especially true if the parents were working part time or in non-professional jobs.

But it concluded that childminders were the main providers of formal childcare. They accounted for nearly a quarter of the children receiving non-parental care.

The survey of more than 1,000 childminders, in eight English local authorities, found childminders were working an average of 34 hours a week for a gross income of £103.

webTitle: Jon Snow on NTL, Mandela and transport

fields.headline: Dodgy connection
fields.trailText: They have a snooker table, a gym, even an Indian masseuse, but the workers at NTL's call centres are not happy. Complaints from NTL staff feature strongly on the TUC's call centre hotline.
fields.body:
They have a snooker table, a gym, even an Indian masseuse, but the workers at NTL's call centres are not happy. Complaints from NTL staff feature strongly on the TUC's call centre hotline. This inventory sports many high-street names and makes grim reading.

Last December, before discovering NTL's presence on the list, I was foolish enough to attempt to transfer my phone service from BT to NTL. The conversion cost £88.13 and NTL has charged £4.99 a month for its non-service in the five months since. In March, a red reminder from BT revealed that not one call had been processed by NTL. The pressured but kindly operative at NTL's Swansea call centre said it would pay the bill and then bill me, less the excess that BT's charges represented over NTL's.

Last week, my telephones were cut off. NTL had not paid the bill. Despite 10 separate attempts to make my NTL service work, it never managed to connect or process a single call.

On one occasion in February, it announced deliciously that owing to a "telephony failure" it could not take any calls to its call centre. The recorded instructions for trying to kick-start your service involved dialling a series of figures, waiting an hour, watching to see if a green light went out for up to 20 minutes, and then embarking on the whole process all over again.

For any hack, the moment of having a phone service terminated altogether is a moment of blind panic. You suddenly want your phone service at any cost, and doesn't BT know it. The 30-second read-out of a credit card to the BT operator restores normal service instantly. Suddenly I realise that I have become a BT statistic: "Thousands are coming back," it says on the side of the firm's vans. But it seems I never went away. Was that because BT makes it so hard to escape, or because NTL was plain incompetent about securing the business?

By the way, the difference between the BT quarterly bill, and what it would have cost with NTL was £4.90 on a £490 bill - 1%. In all, the NTL experience has cost me £113.08, and a concern for the lives of the operators at the company's call centres.

No wonder BT enjoys such high charges - and there were we thinking that the real privatisation disaster was the railways.

Nelson's party in the Square

To enter Trafalgar Square last Sunday night was to enter a new world. The unprecedented sight of a vast "shed" extending more than half way up Nelson's column signalled the unprecedented take-over of this sacred imperial and protest preserve. Lights, sound systems and the Corrs filled the square, if not with revolution, then certainly with a hint that Britain may indeed be changing.

It was perhaps fitting that "Celebrate South Africa" got the first taste of "people's freedom" in the square. Mayor Ken's first experiment in using it as a rock venue, proved to be an over-conservative affair. The police had the place expertly contained and were probably over cautious about the numbers allowed in - maybe 30,000. There was just a bit too much space around the edges - next time 40- or 50,000 might give it still more atmosphere.

At least as improbable as glimpsing Mandela on stage was finding the suspected former IRA commander from Derry, now Stormont's minister of education, leaning on a railing savouring the night air and the music. Twenty years ago, if someone had predicted that Nelson Mandela and Martin McGuinness would one day be found sampling a rock concert outside South Africa House, without even a whiff of a diplomatic incident, you'd have sent for a doctor.

Incidentally, the complete closure of numerous streets around Trafalgar Square caused effectively no congestion. Isn't it time the British followed the Italians and cleared traffic from all the country's key city centres every Sunday?

Trouble on the 06.35 to Nottingham

Can I recommend attempting to take a bicycle on the 06.35 Midland mainline to Nottingham? The ticket office won't let you buy a cycle ticket to do so, nor will it take a bike reservation over the phone. But bikes are not actually banned from this state-of-the-art Turbo beauty which is the very latest rolling stock to enter the service. It's that just as you settle down to the free copy of an unmentionable national newspaper, the revenue protection officer (that's what the ticket collector is now, according to his name badge), harangues you for blocking a doorway with the bike.

"You should be on the express," he says.

"But I have to be there before nine and the express doesn't get there until 9.11."

"There's a bike van on that," he says. "You are going to have to move that."

Eventually a £3 ticket is bought and the bike ends up outside the flash "superloo". The train is spot on time, the service excellent. But how did John Prescott's integrated transport policy allow new rolling stock to enter service to and from Britain's cycle manufacturing capital with no provision for bicycles? (On the return journey, I caught the express. Exceedingly expensive, but it had a bike van and once again was spot on time.)

But in Nottingham, home of the Raleigh, worse was to follow; for it boasts a network of bike-hostile race tracks around the station. One leads to a dead end then casts the unsuspecting cyclist into a mayhem of densely packed, speeding cars and trucks on the inner ring roads.

London's roads sport many more green-painted cycle lanes than Nottingham. But these are potential killers, lulling the cyclist into a belief that cars won't enter. In reality, they not only enter them, they speed, turn left, park and open their doors in them. Camden council is building the only safe option between St Pancras and Paddington - cycle lanes separated from the main drag by substantial kerbs. The council has destroyed nearly a mile of illegal street parking - the new cycle lanes rendering the rest of the street too narrow to park in.

Perhaps Prescott's policy is at work in stealthier and more devious ways than we had guessed. Then again, perhaps not.

 Francis Wheen is away.

webTitle: Duncan Campbell meets American icon Patty Hearst

fields.headline: 'It has turned into my trial'
fields.standfirst: In 1974, Californian heiress Patty Hearst was kidnapped by terrorists. When she helped the group carry out a bank robbery, she became one of the most famous faces on the planet. Now she's back in court - giving evidence against a fellow member. But with a family and a film career she would rather forget her past, finds  Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: In 1974, Californian heiress Patty Hearst was kidnapped by terrorists. When she helped the group carry out a bank robbery, she became one of the most famous faces on the planet. Now she's back in court - giving evidence against a fellow member. But with a family and a film career she would rather forget her past, finds Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
Patricia Hearst is on stage in west Hollywood, demonstrating how she helped to rob the Hibernia bank in San Francisco 27 years ago. The audience is spellbound, recalling the moment when the young heiress, who had been kidnapped by an urban guerrilla group calling itself the Symbionese Liberation Army, was captured on film taking part in a daylight robbery that sent shock waves across the US.

This is not the real Patricia Hearst, however, but one of Los Angeles's brightest young comedians and actors, Mona Mansour, starring in her one-woman show, Me and the SLA. It is a tour de force in which Mansour takes on the persona of herself as a seven-year-old girl who witnesses the Hibernia robbery, then runs off and joins the SLA, sharing a closet with Patty Hearst and living on the run. During the performance, Mansour reads out a letter from the Hearst family lawyers, warning her not to stage the show or to face a lawsuit. It transpires that she has been fascinated by the case ever since it happened and she was a seven-year-old who fantasised about helping poor Patty and having her as a friend.

The real Patricia Hearst will shortly be performing in LA, not on stage but as prosecution witness in the trial of Sarah Jane Olson. A former associate of the SLA, she was arrested in 1999 in St Paul, Minnesota, after more than two decades of living on the run as a respectable doctor's wife and - as the press likes to portray her - a "soccer mom".

The real Hearst will certainly be asked in detail about that strange period in her life so carefully conjured up on stage in Me and the SLA. After the show, Mansour says that she had contacted the Hearst family lawyers to let them know she was planning to do the show and they had been very relaxed about it. Perhaps, after more than a quarter of a century, Patricia Hearst has reconciled herself to people's fantasies about her.

There will be fewer laughs when the case of Olson, who changed her name from Kathleen Soliah, finally gets under way after many delays. Olson had managed to disappear into quiet suburban anonymity, bringing up her three daughters with her wealthy surgeon husband, acting in the local dramatic society and doing good works through her local church. Had the FBI not supplied her photograph for a special edition of the television programme America's Most Wanted, to coincide with the 25th anniversary of the Hearst kidnapping, she would still be going quietly about her life. She is out on $1m bail now, has written a cookbook to raise funds for her defence and has had to tell her daughters about her outlaw past. A student radical, she had joined the SLA after her friend, Angela Atwood, had been one of the six SLA members who died in a blazing house following a gunfight with the LA police.

In her court appearances so far, Olson has come across as a thoughtful, intelligent woman, far removed from the craziness that was the SLA. Her lawyers are clearly counting on this to win over the jury in what promises to be a long trial; the initial legal arguments, even before a jury can be sworn in, are estimated to last at least three weeks.

The expected highlight of the case, however, will undoubtedly be the evidence of Hearst, forced by subpoena to relive that time of her life when she was taken at gunpoint from her home in Berkeley in 1974 and forced to join up with a group that lived out mad fantasies of revolution. She was held in a closet for more than 50 days, given gun training and the "revolutionary" name Tania, and learned the SLA's memorable slogan: "Death to the fascist insect that preys upon the life of the people."

Hearst was present for the Hibernia robbery, carried out to garner funds and publicity for the SLA, but was not with the core of the group when they died in the LA blaze. She was arrested in San Francisco in 1975, jailed for seven years and freed 23 months later, after Jimmy Carter, then US president, commuted her sentence on the grounds that she had been forced into the SLA. President Clinton finally pardoned her on his final day in office, an act that passed almost unnoticed amid the fuss generated by his other acts of clemency.

What has happened to Hearst in the time between being hoisted off campus as a privileged young student to her status now as an independent movie diva and gay icon is, in its way, every bit as revolutionary as what the SLA was preaching. The Patricia Hearst who is now familiar to fans of the radical film-maker John Waters is very different from the Patty Hearst who so terrified the parents of America in 1974. The new one is blonde and smiling, the latter was dark-haired, beret-wearing and, understandably, grim-faced.

Hearst appears in Waters's film Cecil B Demented, just released on video, playing a role that must be as close to postmodern edge as you can get without falling over the other side. The story is of the kidnap of pampered actress Holly Whitlock (played by Melanie Griffith) by a group of independent guerrilla film-makers whose slogan is "bad movies must be avenged". Holly resists the kidnappers at first but then becomes part of the gang, shooting it out with the best of them. Hearst plays the tearful mother of one of the kidnappers, the mild-mannered young Fidget, and appears on television with her very straight husband, trying to talk reason to her wayward boy. In the course of all the mayhem, a policeman is shot. Hearst's part mirrors that played by her own mother, who also made tearful appearances on television during her daughter's time with the SLA.

Hearst met Waters at the Cannes film festival, which she attended for the screening of Paul Schrader's 1988 film Patty Hearst, with Natasha Richardson as Hearst. She enjoys her new career, though she has said there are easier ways to get into films than being kidnapped - waiting tables, for instance. She has appeared in Cry-Baby, Serial Mom and Pecker, and in sitcoms such as Boston Common; her next project is a film about sex addicts, set in Baltimore, and her reappearance on the criminal justice scene coincides with her debut as a television presenter.

Her first project, screened on the Travel Channel in March and entitled The Secrets of San Simeon, was a guide to her family's stately home, Hearst Castle on the California coast. Secrecy seems to be a theme of her work. Her autobiography, Every Secret Thing, published after her release in 1982, took its title from Ecclesiastes 12:14: "For God shall bring every work into judgment with every secret thing whether it be good or whether it be evil."

Olson, now 54, is charged with conspiring to murder, in connection with a plot to plant nailbombs under police cars in LA. No one died in that attempt but a woman was murdered during a bank robbery in Sacramento in which Olson is alleged to have taken part. In Every Secret Thing, Hearst puts Olson at the scene, but does not make her responsible for the shooting of Myrna Lee Opshal, the woman who died.

Olson has not been charged with that murder, though the son of the dead woman, Jon Opshal, has urged that she should be prosecuted and the new Los Angeles district attorney wants to see the case re-examined. Olson contests the Hearst version. She told a gathering to raise funds for her defence in San Francisco: "Her version has been enshrined as the undisputed truth - until my trial."

Hearst, meanwhile, does not see it as Olson's trial. In her only interview about the case, last year with Talk, which is part-owned by the Hearst family, she said: "It has turned into my trial. And I am not going to play dead any more. I keep trying to forget these people and they keep dragging me back into it."

Of Olson, she said: "She had been leading such a quiet life. I heard about her reading to the blind and all. I thought, well, she's probably a lot nicer than I am. Who knows? But I have had to live my entire life in the public eye because of her actions and ... the rest of the SLA. And I just didn't feel sorry for her. She was just getting a good dollop of it. It's no fun, is it? But now I wish they'd never found her."

When she appeared in Pasadena to promote her family history documentary last month, she told the press she was more than happy in her new role: "It would be shocking if I weren't happy. And even if I weren't, who could possibly sympathise? I have a nice husband, two great kids and a nice house. I can't imagine who I'd complain to." She married her bodyguard, Bernard Shaw; they live in Fairfield County, Connecticut. Shaw is security director of the Hearst Corporation.

Of the Schrader version of her life, Hearst said: "It was well done, well acted, it pretty much stuck to the book and absolutely no one saw it. I was kind of glad it didn't do well. It meant no one else was tempted to do their version because who needs it?"

The trial will also be a strange time for the other surviving former members of the SLA. They, too, have gone in different directions since 1974. The audience is spellbound, recalling the moment when the young heiress, who had been kidnapped by an urban guerrilla group calling itself the Symbionese Liberation Army, was captured on film taking part in a daylight robbery that sent shock waves across the US. This is not the real Patricia Hearst, however, but one of Los Angeles's brightest young comedians and actors, Mona Mansour, starring in her one-woman show, Me and the SLA. It is a tour de force in which Mansour takes on the persona of herself as a seven-year-old girl who witnesses the Hibernia robbery, then runs off and joins the SLA, sharing a closet with Patty Hearst and living on the run. During the performance, Mansour reads out a letter from the Hearst family lawyers, warning her not to stage the show or to face a lawsuit. It transpires that she has been fascinated by the case ever since it happened and she was a seven-year-old who fantasised about helping poor Patty and having her as a friend. The real Patricia Hearst will shortly be performing in LA, not on stage but as prosecution witness in the trial of Sarah Jane Olson. A former associate of the SLA, she was arrested in 1999 in St Paul, Minnesota, after more than two decades of living on the run as a respectable doctor's wife and - as the press likes to portray her - a "soccer mom". The real Hearst will certainly be asked in detail about that strange period in her life so carefully conjured up on stage in Me and the SLA. After the show, Mansour says that she had contacted the Hearst family lawyers to let them know she was planning to do the show and they had been very relaxed about it. Perhaps, after more than a quarter of a century, Patricia Hearst has reconciled herself to people's fantasies about her. There will be fewer laughs when the case of Olson, who changed her name from Kathleen Soliah, finally gets under way after many delays. Olson had managed to disappear into quiet suburban anonymity, bringing up her three daughters with her wealthy surgeon husband, acting in the local dramatic society and doing good works through her local church. Had the FBI not supplied her photograph for a special edition of the television programme America's Most Wanted, to coincide with the 25th anniversary of the Hearst kidnapping, she would still be going quietly about her life. She is out on $1m bail now, has written a cookbook to raise funds for her defence and has had to tell her daughters about her outlaw past. A student radical, she had joined the SLA after her friend, Angela Atwood, had been one of the six SLA members who died in a blazing house following a gunfight with the LA police. In her court appearances so far, Olson has come across as a thoughtful, intelligent woman, far removed from the craziness that was the SLA. Her lawyers are clearly counting on this to win over the jury in what promises to be a long trial; the initial legal arguments, even before a jury can be sworn in, are estimated to last at least three weeks. The expected highlight of the case, however, will undoubtedly be the evidence of Hearst, forced by subpoena to relive that time of her life when she was taken at gunpoint from her home in Berkeley in 1974 and forced to join up with a group that lived out mad fantasies of revolution. She was held in a closet for more than 50 days, given gun training and the "revolutionary" name Tania, and learned the SLA's memorable slogan: "Death to the fascist insect that preys upon the life of the people." What has happened to Hearst in the time between being hoisted off campus as a privileged young student to her status now as an independent movie diva and gay icon is, in its way, every bit as revolutionary as what the SLA was preaching. The Patricia Hearst who is now familiar to fans of the radical film-maker John Waters is very different from the Patty Hearst who so terrified the parents of America in 1974. The new one is blonde and smiling, the latter was dark-haired, beret-wearing and, understandably, grim-faced. Hearst appears in Waters's film Cecil B Demented, just released on video, playing a role that must be as close to postmodern edge as you can get without falling over the other side. Holly resists the kidnappers at first but then becomes part of the gang, shooting it out with the best of them. She enjoys her new career, though she has said there are easier ways to get into films than being kidnapped - waiting tables, for instance. Secrecy seems to be a theme of her work. Her autobiography, Every Secret Thing, published after her release in 1982, took its title from Ecclesiastes 12:14: "For God shall bring every work into judgment with every secret thing whether it be good or whether it be evil." webTitle: Paul Macinnes on celebrity marriage vows

fields.headline: Nifty ways to wed your lover
fields.standfirst: Rod Stewart says marriage vows are 'impossible' and need to be completely rewritten. So what kind of wedding pledges should we be making?  Paul Macinnes turns to the stars for inspiration
fields.trailText: Rod Stewart says marriage vows are 'impossible' and need to be completely rewritten. So what kind of wedding pledges should we be making? Paul Macinnes turns to the stars for inspiration.
fields.body:
The David Beckham

The Prince and Princess of Britain, Dave and Posh are a beacon, or maybe a standard lamp, to the rest of the country. These vows were originally dressed in regal purple:

"Me, him wot plays for United, do solum, sol, solumena, solemonlly take our Vicky to be my wife for ever and ever. And ever and ever and ever. To have nice clothes, if Vicky wants me to, and to hold hands outside the Ivy. I promise to love and to cherish and to kiss and to hug, to wear Vicky's knickers and to hide behind her on telly when some comedian's taking the mick. In the name of our Lord Alex Ferguson, appearances in OK! without end, amen."

The Prince Charles

A revolutionary development in sacred oaths, the Prince Charles is the first vow to cater for three people in a marriage. Still popular today amongst minor soap stars and residents of Juab, Utah:

"One does solemnly swear to take this fine-looking young lady as a sop to the press and mama. To hold when in public, to turn my cold cheek against her when in private, and to generally carry on with my old flame with no compunction whatsoever, until I catch her indoors knocking about with an officer in the Life Guards. After that one swears to forsake all others, and be true as long as I shall live, to my favourite royal reporters. Is that OK with you, Mills?"

Catherine Zeta-Jones

When our Cath wed Hollywood legend Michael Douglas last year, it made news the world over. Now Hollywood's top couple, they turn heads wherever they go, usually towards the floor. Here are their vows:

"I, the most beautiful woman in the whole of Swansea, do take him, the son of Kirk with the libido problem, to be my lawfully wedded husband. To have and to ... actually, before we go any further here I want to get a few things straight. Any 'having' or 'holding' is strictly defined according to the terms clearly laid down in the pre-marital agreement. Ditto 'loving' and 'cherishing'. And if he thinks that that 'richer or poorer' stuff doesn't come with a few provisos attached then, buster, you've got another think coming. Do we kiss now?"

The Chris Evans

Some people have trouble with expressing commitment. Others with commitment itself. But with these new vows you can say whatever you like and mean something completely different!

"I, [insert name of publicity-ravenous washed up personality here], take [insert name of similarly fading babe young enough to be groom's daughter] to be my lawfully wedded wife. But not quite yet, in a couple of weeks' time. It's definitely going to happen though, take my word for it. Gazza, Danny Baker, they'll all be there. Till death do us part. Or we change PR firms, whichever comes first. What's that, lads, want another shot? No problem. Smashing."

The Anna Nicole-Smith

It was a marriage made in heaven. The Texan Playboy model and the 89-year-old tycoon, tied by bonds of love. For them marriage was something sacred, something pure, and something that could be redeemed for fur coats at regular intervals:

"Ah, a sweet homespun young girl with no interest in money, lovely money, do hereby take this ailing man for my mortal wedded husband. Sorry, ah meant lawful. Ah do solemnly swear to love this man for richer, for poorer (me richer, him poorer), to have and to hold, to buy and return, to drink and fall over, till death do us part. Which, by mah watch, should be in about half an hour."

The Michael Jackson

Tired of being alone, misunderstood, black? This could be the nuptial vow for you. Pioneered in California in 1996, this is now the second most popular promise in America (source Oaths Monthly), and provides colour to any marriage ceremony:

"I, [insert name of crumbling-faced pop recluse here], do solemnly take this nurse/chimp to be the lawful bearer of my precious seed. To have and to hold (albeit with surgical gloves and at strictly appointed times) to love and cherish and all that other stuff that I never had because my dad was a tyrant and my childhood was stolen by the TV cameras. I do solemnly pledge, for richer for poorer, for better or worse, to keep on churning out ego trips masquerading as albums until informed otherwise. Amen."

webTitle: Anti-social behaviour: Signs of the times

fields.headline: Signs of the times
fields.standfirst: It's intolerable when people who seem beyond the law terrorise a neighbourhood, but how can you stop them?  Helen Carter on the effects of anti-social behaviour orders
fields.trailText: It's intolerable when people who seem beyond the law terrorise a neighbourhood, but how can you stop them? Helen Carter on the effects of anti-social behaviour orders
fields.body:
Half a mile from Manchester's thriving city centre, where flats sell for hundreds of thousands of pounds, is the urban wasteland of the Beswick estate. It was here in late 1999 that Sean, Joseph and Michael McCann - when they were 16, 15 and 13 - became subjects of one of the government's first anti-social behaviour orders.

The McCanns' home has since been bulldozed, but other impoverished terrace houses and flats remain - some lived in, some burnt out. Security cameras monitor residents' every move and a walkway has been boarded up by the council in an effort to prevent crime. This area of east Manchester has been described by Brian Robson, director of Manchester University's urban policy studies centre, as "land of the forgotten".

Anti-social behaviour orders (Asbos) were introduced by the government in April 1999 as a flagship of home secretary Jack Straw's law and order programme. Local authorities and chief police officers, acting in consultation, may apply to a magistrates' court for what is in effect a banning order, protecting the community from a named individual alleged to cause harassment, alarm or distress to others.

The order, issued under the 1998 Crime and Disorder Act, involves civil proceedings, with a case needing to be proved only according to the rules of civil evidence; the burden of proof is less than demanded by criminal cases. Hearsay evidence is acceptable, as it is so difficult to persuade witnesses to appear. Yet a breach of an order is a criminal offence, the penalty for which may be anything up to a five-year jail sentence.

Gillian Crossley, the McCanns' solicitor, argues that Asbos should have been set wholly within the criminal justice context. Indeed, she is taking the case to appeal on this point. "I do not think it was a very well thought through piece of legislation," she says. "It is silent on standards of proof and I think it was naive to consider that these orders would be dealt with by duty solicitors in a five-minute hearing."

"By their very nature, they are not dealing with nice, compliant and friendly people with respect for authority. They are dealing with people with an inbred distrust of authority who are more likely to say no than yes".

The order against the McCanns has anyway proved counter-productive, Crossley claims. "To some people, they achieved enormous notoriety and gained hero status, and to the ordinary population they were seen as the scum of the earth," she says. "The family was marginalised and the order caused more trouble for them."

The family, one generation removed from travellers, has been divided by the order, she says. Forced to move away, the boys have been unable to maintain links with relatives who still live in Beswick.

Debate over the rights and wrongs of Asbos has been inflamed by an allegation by Straw that solicitors who challenge the orders are out to make money. He told a conference: "Very aggressive defence lawyers sometimes forget about their wider social responsibilities and their responsibilities to the court, and, in trying to protect their niche markets with the local criminal fraternity, act in a way which would have been unacceptable when I was practising [as a barrister] 25 years ago."

Crossley says she does not understand the basis for the minister's outburst. More important, she contends, is that Asbos have made no difference to the crime rate in Beswick. Superintendent Dave Thompson, of Grey Mare Lane police station in the heart of the estate, disagrees profoundly. He says that since the orders were introduced, crime has fallen by a third and burglaries by half.

Takings at the local supermarket increased £14,000 a week when the boys were banned, says Thompson. "At the time when we obtained the order, there was a feeling that anything went round here," he says. "A lot of people had lost confidence in the police and there was a perception that they [the McCanns] were untouchable. The three boys caused an enormous amount of problems for local people and committed a range of anti-social behaviour. And because residents were so scared of them, they were not willing to go to court."

In the McCanns' case, there was no mediation and no attempt to sort out their problems prior to use of the Asbo. Since then, however, there has been a subtle change and orders are now regarded locally as a last resort for dealing with similar cases. Thompson says: "We don't just want to beat them over the head with the orders; we're trying to explore the support systems that can be kicked in."

Frank Whiteley, of the Association of Chief Police Officers, reckons Asbos have been relatively successful, but concedes that there have been teething troubles. He says the association believes the orders are not a single answer to anti-social behaviour, but part of a bigger tool kit.

"We have never looked at Asbos on their own," Whiteley says. "But we have looked at the wider strategies and we have had some good successes." Orders can be used as part of an inter-agency approach involving mediation, injunctions and bail, but by themselves they are not a complete solution. "We are cautiously optimistic about their success so far."

The Home Office acknowledges that take-up of Asbos has varied across the country. More than 160 orders have been issued, including at least 50 against under-18s, but figures range from 18 in London and 15 in the West Midlands to just one each in Thames Valley, Leicestershire and south Wales. "There is some anecdotal evidence that the threat of an Asbo is often sufficient," says a spokeswoman. "We should not just judge it as a policy by numbers."

Ten years as an outcast

A 15-year-old Manchester youth last week received what is believed to be the longest anti-social behaviour order so far issued. Billy Kelly will be unable to enter the Fallowfield district, in the south of the city, for 10 years.

Manchester magistrates imposed the order after hearing that Kelly threatened staff of the city council's housing department when his family was being evicted. He was said to have told a police officer: "I'm going to come back and terrorise Fallowfield."

Kelly is currently finishing a six-month detention order for threatening to firebomb a neighbour. He is expected to be released next month and to live in Sale, Greater Manchester. Magistrates were told that he was involved in incidents dating from October 1998, including shoplifting, taking cars - one of which was involved in a police pursuit - and stealing a charity box. He is thought to have been involved in a gang, two other members of which were already subjects of Asbos.

Kelly, whose application to be allowed into the exclusion zone to visit his father was turned down, is also banned from entering part of the Rusholme district.

Basil Curley, Manchester council's executive member for housing, says: "We asked for a 10-year ban and we think it is fitting because there is no reason why this man should enter Fallowfield. It is also an indication to others who are contemplating creating havoc."

Magistrates were told that he was involved in incidents dating from October 1998, including shoplifting, taking cars - one of which was involved in a police pursuit - and stealing a charity box. He is thought to have been involved in a gang, two other members of which were already subjects of Asbos. Kelly, whose application to be allowed into the exclusion zone to visit his father was turned down, is also banned from entering part of the Rusholme district. Basil Curley, Manchester council's executive member for housing, says: "We asked for a 10-year ban and we think it is fitting because there is no reason why this man should enter Fallowfield. It is also an indication to others who are contemplating creating havoc."

webTitle: Call for joint adoption rights for unmarried couples

fields.headline: Call for joint adoption rights for unmarried couples
fields.trailText: Unmarried straight or gay couples should be allowed to adopt jointly, instead of only one partner being designated the legal parent, a leading charity has told MPs.
fields.body:
Unmarried straight or gay couples should be allowed to adopt jointly, instead of only one partner being designated the legal parent, a leading charity has told MPs.

Children should have two legal parents when adopted by people in long-term relationships, said the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF) yesterday in evidence to the select committee on the adoption and children bill.

As it stands, the bill will not change the current law, which only permits both partners to adopt if they are married.

Politicians are likely to be wary about the move because of fears of a moralistic "family values" backlash and headlines about gay adoptions.

"We believe it is inappropriate to use adoption as a means of promoting the importance of marriage, if this has the effect of denying children, who are already disadvantaged, the opportunity of the joint legal and lifetime commitment of two parents," said BAAF chief executive Felicity Collier.

"It is estimated that 40% of children are born outside of marriage and that a similar proportion of adults live in committed relationships. If we restrict joint adoption to married couples, we can only reduce the opportunity for children to find adoptive parents."

She said that social workers would take into account the stability and longevity of any relationship when assessing prospective adopters.

But Conservative select committee member Caroline Spelman said married couples were more likely to offer a permanent two-parent home: "The evidence shows that, if we are worried about permanency, married couples tend to stay together longer."

Mrs Spelman said there was a contradiction between putting the welfare of the child first and allowing unmarried couples to become joint legal parents.

The bill brings adoption law into line with the Children Act 1989 by making the welfare of the child paramount.

Labour MP David Hinchcliffe, committee chairman, told SocietyGuardian.co.uk that: "From a personal point of view, I can see the concern over where you have a child placed with unmarried foster carers and it may be deemed in their best interests to be adopted by both."

But he added: "I am not advocating lesbian and gay adoption - nor unmarried adoption, for that matter."

BAAF also called for amendments to introduce a national system of financial support for adoptive parents and a register of private, informal fostering by friends and relatives.

The government has promised that all adoptive parents will have a right to be assessed for post-adoption services from local authorities. However, it has stopped short of offering an adoption allowance with national criteria for eligibility.
